3 stars isn't super fair.. I'd say 3.5 stars would be the rating I give them.
author: Wanster L.

description: Excellent food and service. Fast, friendly and attentive. The best entree we ordered were the short ribs but everything was delicious, including dessert.
author: Mike J.

description: Had a client lunch here and it did not disappoint. We ordered the papaya salad, pad kee mao, prawns with brown rice, chicken dish with white rice and the soft rolls. I also had the mango cosmo. The papaya salad was spicy and had a kick to it. My favorite dish was the pad kee mao. The beef was tender and I love the fat noodles. It was very flavorful. For dessert we had the Thai coffee granita with Kalhua and whipped cream. It was an unexpected surprise! It was like a coffee slushee, I know it doesn't sound appetizing but I loved it! It was the perfect end to the meal, considering it was a hot day. The servers were attentive and friendly. It's a cute little restaurant. I would definitely go back.
author: Bj S.

description:
Very nice ambiance once you walk into the restaurant and certainly dim lighted which gives that romantic feel to it. 

The servers were very attentive and really catered to the customer's needs, which adds to the overall experience. The restaurant fills up as the night goes on, so be sure to make a reservation. 

We ordered a variety of foods, which included a few appetizers and several entrees:

Appetizers:
1.Puff pastry of curried diced duck and sweet potato (curry puff) - crispy curry puffs with a nice, cold cucumber salad on the side that adds a bit of tang to compliment the saltiness of the curry puff

2. Papaya Salad - SOOO delicious!! My first time trying this salad and I am coming back for more next time! MUST GET!

3. Chicken and mushrooms in lemongrass, galanga, and coconut milk soup (dtom ka gai) - Very delicious soup, however small portion even for the large size. The large size will serve at most 4 people. 

Entrees:
1. Pad - Kee Mao  & Pad - Sew Ew : Very simple and traditional noodle dish, nothing too special, but WOW is the portion huge!!!! 

2. Coconut braised pork shoulder and 'kabocha' pumpkin in tangy red curry * (kang kua mu) - Delicious curry! Very light in flavor and definitely a must have if you are a fan of pumpkin and pork. Entree does not come with a side of rice, which is $2.50 per order.

I would come back here again, however the only thing I would suggest is trying the specialty dishes instead of the dishes where you can get at other regular thai restaurants.
author: Lydia L.

description: Cashew chicken curry was surprisingly really really real good. Just simple but delicious curry. I wish I we're still hungry so I could eat it again... but if I were hungry it be a hard decision if I should eat the cashew curry again or try something new. Hmm I wonder if they're open for breakfast?!
author: Daniel S.

description: I've been here a few times over the years and met with some friends there before a show the other night. We got there pretty early so we didn't have trouble getting a seat (although it got very busy shortly afterwards). We took advantage of the happy hour specials on appetizers and drinks, which were all delicious, and decided to go family style for the main course. Everything was excellent!
author: Dan W.

description: Very very average like my yelp writing skills. Take these reviews with a grain of salt, this place is not THAT great.
author: T L.

description:
Yummy Thai food and great ambience.

== Food ==
We over ordered #whatsnew
 
1) Charcoal grilled squid with chili, lime and garlic sauce 
5/5 Highly recommended! This was so good! Just order it.

2) Thai spiced fish cakes
5/5 so so good. The best fish cakes I ever had in the bay area Thai restaurants. They are a tad spicy but not overwhelming.

3) Thai ice tea
They gave us two options, Cream or Coconut Milk. We chose Coconut Milk, and it was weird. I think the regular Thai Ice Tea has cream instead of coconut milk. I did not really enjoy this. The cream option might be much better.

4) Pad Thai
4/5 Good portion and tasted like how a pad thai should be. Nothing spectacular.

5) Chicken and mushrooms in lemongrass, galanga, and coconut milk soup (dtom ka gai) 
3/5 The coconut milk here was a little overpowering. Then again, i might be bias as i'm not a fan of coconut milk version of Tom Yum. I prefer Tom Yum soup to be spicy and sour. I still think it was pretty well done.

6) Tamarind prawns
4/5 Yums. The prawns are de-shelled which is always a delight. They are lightly fried with spicy tamarind, shallot and garlic. It doesn't taste spicy but the flavor is really good.

7) Roasted duck in red curry with wilted cabbage, cherry tomatoes, and pineapples (kang bpet)
3/5 Acquired taste i believe. Perhaps we had too much milky related dishes that made this taste overpowering. I thought this was ok.

The crackers they serve right at the start are yummy! 
They have proven they make awesome appetizers, the next time i visit, i will probably be ordering more appetiziers :)

== Service / Ambience ==
I was seriously surprised by the ambience. It was certainly much more nicer as compared to what I'm seeing on the pictures. Made a reservation via Yelp, super convenient! Triggers an email to confirm your reservations and a SMS notification on the day of.

Service was professional and good. Though, it would have been nice if they were a little more attentive to all the tables, perhaps its the way the restaurant is organized, it makes it hard for us to get their attention (we were sitting near the entrance.

They have a nice waiting area that sits very well with the environment, not some awkward seating area which most restaurants have. Most restaurants make you feel like you are not a customer until you are really seated at one of their tables, Basil Thai made it part of the experience, which is nice.
author: Cindee T.

description:
Stumbled upon this great little Thai place on Folsom street while we were doing a standard 'tourist walk' around the area. It's a small place, to be sure, but it was inviting and the service was first rate. 

Everything that we ordered was great, too. I had the pad Thai with shrimp and tofu and my dining partner had the coconut braised pork shoulder with red curry. We also shared an appetizer of a puff pastry filled with curried diced duck and sweet potato. Again, very good. 

And we were very pleasantly surprised that the prices weren't all the way at the high end of 'big city prices.' Our total tab for two complete meals was slightly less than we would have paid in Miami/Ft. Lauderdale.

I should mention that we liked this place so much that we chose to  dinner here one additional evening before while we were in San Francisco.
author: Michael D.

description:
Came for happy hour. Ordered a cup of coffee with a shot of baileys. $13.50. For a cup of coffee and one shot of baileys. Did I mention that it was a simple cup of coffee and a thimble full of baileys? I asked the waitress if this was correct. Her response, "I just work here" I asked if that was her final answer. It was. They could have made a customer happy or not.. they chose not. 

There were 4 of us and we ordered dinner too. None of the prices of the things we ordered that appeared on the receipt matched up with the prices on the menus. It was bizarre. That place is bizarre. 

Go somewhere else where they have it together. If the front of house is a mess.. what does the kitchen look like?
author: Ty M.

description:
Tabletop shrimp chips. Excellent! 

Food = delicious. 

Goong Gra Bog (Crispy wrapped whole tiger prawns with sweet chili vinaigrette). Piping hot, crispy and a great starter. The sweet chili vinaigrette is a must. $8.95

Dtom Ka Gai, small.  Delicious chicken coconut soup with mushrooms.  Definitely has coconut milk.  Full of flavor and tangy. Hit the spot! (Portion is enough for one but we shared anyway.) $6.95

Gai Mamuang Hima (Thai cashew chicken). Crunchy vegetables with chicken. Delicious sauce, which went well with their sticky rice. $12.95 (Sticky Rice, $2.50)

Kanom Pak-Gard (Turnip cake with beansprouts and chives, served with roasted sriracha chili.)  Turnip cake cubes were crispy on the outside, soft on the inside, and the beansprouts with chives are refreshing, and the sriracha chili really makes this dish a hit. One of our favorites. $10.50

Pad Ke Mao. Drunken noodles with tender beef. Plenty of basil.  Well seasoned. It does have a bit of a kick, but it's on the tame side. $12.50

Service = They're efficient, polite and still Not friendly. 

Seating = plentiful but tight.  We sat at a two-top, and they had another two-top right next to us, so table conversations could be easily overheard/overlapped.  It's very uncomfortable and unsettling. Perhaps they should reconfigure some of the tables.  It's also not a good sign when your servers can barely squeeze through to do their jobs. 

Prices = moderate.  All of the above came out to $59.11 after tax.  

This place gets busy so get reservations if you can, or be patient and wait.  

Parking = street.
author: Fannie S.

description:
This place is just down the street from a great customer of mine. I just revisited it for the second time and the food did not disappoint. It must be said to the wait staff was amazing. They close at 2:30p and we walked in around 2:15p and we didn't feel pressured to eat super quick nor did we feel like we couldn't hang around after. 

I love the atmosphere here, it's super hip and modern with a great feel for the SF scene. 

So I ordered this time around the Gai Pik Khing which is spicy fried chicken with string beans and basil. It was awesome. The flavor of the chicken is just bright with chilies and Thai spices that make you dive quick back for another bite. The crunch on the green beans was very good. Overall a nice dish. 

We also had the roti for starters which was a nice quick warm up for the meal. 

I ordered a fresh young coconut water and it came iced with coconut meat cut in large chunks. I love coconut water and this one had an almost cream sofa flavor. Loved it!!

This is definitely more of a modern twist on traditional Thai food but it was great for the second time and I'll be back again!!
author: Chris F.

description:
I ordered pick up and got the pad kee mao. It took a strangely long amount of time for it to be ready. I arrived 20mins after I placed the order and had to wait another 15mins in the restaurant before my food appeared. The staff was strangely unpleasant to me while I waited for my food. 

When I finally got home to eat my food it was excessively oily and really did not have much flavor. Very disappointing for the amount of time I waited and the price I paid for a meal that sadly lacked flavor.
author: Monica M.

description: I got kicked out of my table for a party late people who deported us out as we spent over $100 in food. Rude and uncalled for.
author: Juan V.

description:
Been coming here for 10 years whenever I'm in San Francisco. Very good Thai food at reasonable prices. Service is fast and courteous. 

My only complaint might be that the service is too fast and I sometimes feel rushed to finish so they can turn over the table quickly. A minor thing for an otherwise excellent experience.
author: Chris D.

description: This place has classic Thai dishes that you'll find at most Thai restaurants - they're just a little bit better than most places here. The green curry with prawns or seafood is excellent as are both duck dishes. The cauliflower is also excellent as a side. Fried bananas & ice cream and mango with sticky rice also excellent.
author: Jasper P.

description:
Yum! This place did not disappoint for our last minute group dinner for 12 this last Saturday! All the entrees are about ~$10-12 per dish, so reasonably priced where it didn't break the bank.

Overall drinks were decent, though I had the Mango drop and it was a bit tart (and a bit small) for my taste. The pinot noir though, was pretty delish. :)

Most notable dishes of the night were:
1. Roasted Duck Curry
2. Basil Eggplant
3. Jungle Beef
4. Crab Fried Rice

All are HIGHLY highly recommended..everything was really good!

We ordered one of every single desserts..and though all were good, I especially liked the roti with maple syrup. I thought it was so good and their ice cream was particularly good. If you aren't in the mood for maple roti, you can't ever go wrong with mango sticky rice...

Overall, it was a really great place. Ambiance is casual..and dimly lit. Prices were reasonable, though drinks could've been better. Will definitely be back especially since its good for big groups!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Amazing food. Never go wrong with a dish here IMO. They always season it perfectly, for sweet or spicy taste (i like SPICY and oo theyre one of the only places ive found to respect a true spice). 

Service isnt always the greatest, but theyre conscious and aware of it, and when ive had terrible service, they've always compensated me with a dessert. 

Price is average-ish for SF, and the food quality is great. I reccommend coming when its not at peak for best experience. (Eg. upon opening)
author: Tater Tot J.

description:
This place used to be good value. Then they jacked up the prices. 

The prices on Google (via singleplatform) and Yelp as of this review are out of date. For example, the Fish Cake appetizer is now $9.50 instead of $7.95. Since they only include 3 miserable pieces of fish cake, this is simply not worth it any more. There seems to be a collusion between all the Thai restaurants in the SOMA area to increase their prices. Basil Thai  leads the charge.
author: Reza H.

description:
Definitely a place of hype, great atmosphere, some parts of dishes are amazing, not all is great. Still recommend for dining! 

The squid skewers are small, non-substantial, but they are perfectly cooked, chewy, and the sauce with a dash of lemon is supreme.

The cat fish young pepper corn with egg plant and fried basil is absolutely delicious. It's flavorful, sweet, and savory. The sauce is tangy and supreme.

The Pao Ke Mao that it's famous for, is just bland and sad... nothing to see here. If you are into good food, this should be avoided rather than cherished. 

Lots of interesting drinks here, the Mango Cosmo is tropical and a nice sweet cooling slush. The drinks are interesting and delicious, but sitting at the bar, we realized that they weren't really shaken, just some basic mixing of bottle fruit punch, some olive juice, ice, and canned coconut milk. But you have to say the menu is creative. The thai iced coffee with coconut milk is such an interesting idea, kudos, it's rich, but it taste quite okay. Not for coffee affectionados. 

Overall great place, trendy, popular, good modern thai food, worth the price, but really not all that amazing. Good for casual dates (not the first date).
author: Dilys S.

description:
Great Thai food in Soma San Francisco 
I was really happy with the crab fried rice and seabass with green curry 

I suppose my friends from Socal were happy as well 
Coming back with my family and the office squad
author: MariaAnne V.

description: I love love love this restaurant.  The food and service are consistent and always OUTSTANDING.  Great neighborhood gem!  Bravo!!!!!
author: Thomas M.

description:
Really nice ambience in the front portion of the restaurant. Great lighting pouring in through the windows and breeze from the doorway! 

Food was good but nothing exceptional, I didn't say wow at any point which was a disappointment to be honest. Singha on draft is always a plus though so go for that! 

Tried pas se ew, pineapple fried rice with prawns, summer roll, pan stickers and a beef in brown sauce of some sorts and nothing blew me away or stood out in any sense. However nothing was overly greasy which I will add as another plus. 

Service was impersonal, very quick to take plates away but not very enthusiastic or interested in us as customers. No personality came through, which is a bummer for me. 

Also the bathroom sink somehow completely sprayed my entire dress as soon as I turned it on, another negative! 

The banana and coconut ice cream desert, again nothing to write home about! 

Where is the zest or spice or character to this place? I'm still thinking about the beautiful lighting though, I'd be back if they amped up the eats!!!!
author: Molli W.

description:
Just for their policy. 

I've been here a few times long time ago. Great place for bday dinner for big group...that's what I thought. I called to confirm my reservation, and I was told that if I bring a cake, they will charge us $2 per person...so $20 for 10 ppl might be more than cake price. And it's not the money it's the principle. We won't do the cake cutting here for my hubby...kinda sad. If I knew this, I'd have booked elsewhere.
author: Joo I.

description:
Yum.

This place is a decent step up from most of the "Thai" places in SF.

It's only s are blocks away from me, so it's also very convenient. I give it 4 steps because the service isn't perfect, and I feel that that's necessary to get a nice star review.

On the other hand, the food is good enough that the service is nearly irrelevant.
author: Eric S.

description:
Delicious, aromatic, and fulfilling Thai food! Chill place for casual dinner or a drink.

FOOD: I ordered the PUMPKIN PORK SHOULDER CURRY ($14) with a side of brown rice ($2). I loved that there were actual chunks of pumpkin, which was cooked to just the right degree of mushiness, and the pork was just about tender and absolutely delicious. If you like curry on the sweet side but not TOO sweet, I HIGHLY recommend this dish. I was only able to finish half of it and took the rest home. And the leftover tasted JUST AS GOOD! :D

PRICE: With tip and tax I paid about $20, which is more expensive than what I usually pay for Thai food. But considering the quality and quantity of the food and the location and service, I really enjoyed the meal.

SETTING: The restaurant has a pub on the side and has several tables for sit-down dinner. I thought it was very thoughtful that they have tables of various size, and they put the big (party-sized) tables towards the back to avoid creating traffic. I also really liked the dim lighting there. Good place for a first date! 

SERVICE: We came here on a Thursday night and were seated and served very quickly. The waitresses were also very friendly and nice. 

OVERALL IMPRESSION: Not bad! I would definitely come back again for curry if I am in the area.
author: Wendy F.

description:
This is a great date spot (if you like Thai food obviously). The restaurant is nestled in one of SOMA's less busier streets, and although it's a little loud inside, the table seating and decor of the restaurant make for a great date night. 

Food was great, typical Thai food. We got the Indian roti with green curry as a starter and then did the pad see ew and spicy lamb (which is halal!). The pad see ew was mostly meat and not enough noodles (which is honestly my favorite part), but it was still good. The lamb with the sticky rice was definitely a winner. We ended it with some Indian roti + coconut icecream dessert - which was phenomenal, but tell them to go easy with the syrup.
author: Rafat N.

description:
Please read my previous review on the FOOD POISONING I got from this restaurant before beginning this post. 

Update: Remember the few measly hours I spent on the toilet because of the FOOD POISONING I got from this restaurant's lack of food safety protocols? 

Well, I spent almost the entire next DAY (my whole Saturday) attached to the toilet, and it caused so much pain I was forced to stay up till 4 AM. 

Ask yourself: is a day and a half (and counting) of diarrhea, chills, and nausea worth your Pad Thai from a restaurant that doesn't meet health code violations? I think we all know the answer. 

PLEASE NOTE: This restaurant has violated TWENTY-ONE health code checks, including:

-HIGH RISK FOOD holding temperature (meaning the food is spoiled)
-Inadequate hand washing facilities (feces will get into your food)
-Inadequately cleaned or sanitized food contact surfaces
-Degraded, unclean floors, walls, and ceilings
 + more!

A 77/100 is basically a C. Would you pick a C-rated health inspected restaurant or an A rated health inspected restaurant? The choice is yours. 

So that should be proof, I paid for their breech of food safety protocols.
author: Dennis A.

description: I really liked the crab fried rice and pad kee mao. The price is fairly standard for sf pricing (about $18 total for one of those dishes including tax and tip), but this food reminded me of the yummy Thai food in Berkeley. The waitresses here also spoke Thai, which was a plus!
author: Claire L.

description:
TLDR - Pretty good food but doesn't necessarily stand out against other similar fancy Thai places. The steak salad and duck curry were good, and they won't be shy with spiciness if you ask twice

SF is full of fancy Thai places. They're all pretty good, but honestly they're all more or less the same to me. Basil Thai is no different. The food is good but not really distinguishable from other similar restaurants like Lers Ros or Farmhouse Kitchen Thai. Since the place is "fancy" Thai rather than authentic, it's on the pricier side for Thai food, especially given the portion sizes.

Ambiance is also similar to other nice Thai spots. Dark/dim lighting like you'd find in a nice restaurant so it'd work for a casual date or a nice dinner with friends that's not too expensive. Service is okay. A little hard to get the wait staff's attention and they're not overly welcoming or friendly, but that seems pretty standard for this type of restaurant.

Again, food was pretty good for the most part. Nothing that would make me dying to come back, but I still liked it. If you want your food spicy (like Thai spicy), don't be afraid to ask them to crank it up. They probably won't take you seriously when you ask for "very very very spicy" or "Thai spicy", but if you ask them to redo it, they'll do it right.

-GRILLED SQUID / PLAMUK PING ($8.95) - 2/5
[chili, lime, garlic sauce]
Skip this. I really like squid, but this was way too chewy. And the portion size was ridiculously small. Just two tiny skewers with tiny squid.

-GRILLED SKIRT STEAK SALAD / NEUR NAMTOK ($11.95) - 4.5/5
[shallots, mint, cilantro, roasted rice, chili, lime juice]
We asked for this very spicy, but when they first served it to us, it was basically not spicy at all. We ended up asking them to make it actually spicy, and it definitely came back REAL spicy. The steak was very tender and the portion size was pretty large (even the portion of meat), but the salad was a little too salty.

-ROASTED DUCK CURRY ($14.95) - 4/5
[snap peas, red curry paste, young peppercorn]
Portion size was pretty small (smaller than the steak salad). The curry was pretty flavorful but the flavor didn't stand out against other curries I've had. The duck was very tender though.
author: Jessie L.

description:
If you are in SOMA and in the area, this is a solid place to get dinner, espcially if you have larger groups. The food is here is pretty tasty, but it doesn't do too much in the menu or presentation to set itself apart from other Thai places in the city. The ambiance is nice, casual with a formal touch, although it is a bit dark in here.

Minced Chicken Stir Fried - Almost like warm Larb, but without the salad and refreshing flavors.  Actually its more like your typical Thai basil dishes, and a bit oily.

Crispy Chicken - A little too battered for my taste.  The red curry sauce was good, but the chunks of chicken could have been bigger, or better yet, this would have been a good fried fish dish.  Could have been spicier.

Braised Beef Short Rib - The Panang Curry sauce on this dish was really good, and the short ribs went so will with it.  Boneless and tender, this was a dish I feel was unique to Basil Thai and I really appreciated it.

Crab Fried Rice - I've had better, it wasn't bad though.  I did have an issue that there wasn't just a plain Thai Street Style fried rice on the menu.  Only this and pineapple fried rice (my least favorite of the fried rice family).  

Garlic Noodles - This was a pleasant surprise as well.  The garlic tast was pronounced but not over powering.  The seafood stirfry topping it went well with the noodles.  Again another dish i feel was unique to this place.

I would could come back here if I was in the area and with a large group.  However, this wouldn't be a destination point.

Service was okay, and each dish was about $13, so I bit on the pricier side.
author: Veasna H.

description:
FOOD: This is a Thai restaurant where you will likely have to read the menu--it's a fresh break from standard Thai restaurant menus (exciting offerings include chicken stuffed eggplant in curry, fried sweet potato with nut sauce). While I enjoyed reading the menu, I found all items we ordered (pad thai, to be standard and a little greasy.
- Coconut and sesame crusted sweet potato--the contrast was stark between what was actually a regular (not sweet) potato and the very sweet variation on duck sauce that was served alongside it. The contrast was too startling and you could not taste the coconut or sesame flavor. 
- Chicken lemongrass soup--excellent! Best thing we ordered. Just the right balance of spice, sweetness, sourness, and salt..
- Pad thai with shrimp--greasy. Shrimp were not stripped of their sand veins, which I am aware is not a health hazard but makes me a little squeamish!
- Sizzling stir fried steak--was like a curry but with less coconut milk. Tasted good on first bite, but was definitely on the greasy side of Thai I've had. 
- Cocktail, "Sublime." Enjoyed it well enough. 

SERVICE: Friendly enough in our interactions, but some serious issues with the hosts. Despite having a reservation at 7:30 made through Yelp Res, we were not seated until 7:50. Just be prepared for a wait and to make the effort to flag people down for the check and seats. 

AMBIANCE: On a Saturday night, the lights were dim (ooh, mood lighting!) and there was a lot of ambient noise--lots of people come here for birthdays, bachelorette parties, etc, so be prepared to project! That said, for the two parties surrounding us, there were also several people on dates, a couple of families, and a lot of people at the bar. Fair mix of casual and dressed to go out. I'd feel a little shabby in sweats, but definitely OK in jeans and a chunky sweater.

Overall decent but would not go out of my way to return.
author: Helen W.

description:
Good place to satisfy your Thai fix, but there are a lot of other good Thai restaurants in the City at a better cost. We had the vegetable red curry and tamarind prawns. 

The red curry was very tasty but the prawns were served cooler than I would like. The servers promptly took the prawns and brought it back at a warmer temperature. 

Service and atmosphere were good, though. Food was tasty but pricey.
author: Jerico M.

description:
It's nice place with nice ambience and friendly staff but I felt like the place was a little too crowded and the tables were super close.. If you need privacy or if you are going out on a date then probably not the right place... 
We tried their red curry, fried rice and pad Thai.. Red curry and fried rice were good but their pad Thai was the best.. 
It's one of those places where u always have to wait but the food is worth the wait...
author: Rupa S.

description:
Customer service was on point & the food was even better. We really appreciated how tentative the staff was. 

Our favorite dish was the friend vegetable rolls
author: Sutona S.

description:
Came here with a group on a Friday night. It wasn't very busy when we arrived, so we got seated right away.

I ordered the papaya salad, which was good, but could have used more spice. Seemed a bit expensive for the size.

Pros:
- decor was decent
- free shrimp chips
- staff was pretty good about refilling water

Cons: 
- very few prawns in their shrimp dishes, not worth the extra $
- Service could be improved. We couldn't get their attention to order our meal, despite them walking right by us half a dozen times. We finally had to go to the register to get any attention. They brought out one of the entrees (papaya salad) with the appetizers ~30min before they brought the rest of the party's main course. We had intended them to be served together.
- a LOT of fruit flies in the bathroom
author: A -.

description: Just had a wonderful impromptu dinner here with a new stranger that I just randomly met today. Whether it owes its due in greater part to my interesting East Coast companion, the pineapple fried rice with prawns and cashews was delectable... And so reasonably priced for such fine service in an elegantly subdued and intimate setting.
author: Jeffrey K.

description:
The seating is very nice here, the service is fast and courteous. The posted hours aren't correct. They re open at 5:30.. Lol
Family friendly, and service with a smile. The prices aren't high like I expected them to be! Once we were seated right after opening, the people started pouring in! I suppose if your filling up fast, you're doing something right! 
I had the pad Thai noodles. Not too bad, not my favorite, but it was ok. The Thai iced tea is excellent. 
Bathrooms are very clean.
author: Jason P.

description:
Vegan dishes were not good. Beans and pumpkin were undercooked. Rice is extra charge and was dry. 
This place isn't like it used to be
author: s p.

description: The best Pad Thai I have had. The service was fast and a very attentive waitress.  Nice clean atmosphere.
author: Donald T.

description:
After eating here, I felt like I've never really had good Thai food before.  Honestly, all my prior impressions of Thai food being not refined enough went out the door.  We had a friend's birthday dinner here and ordered several dishes that we ate family-style, which was a good way to get to know this restaurant. 

First, we started off with some amazing cocktails.  I had the Ginger Drop cocktail and it was the perfect spring-ey cocktail.  So refreshing, light, and delicious.  

For appetizers, we shared the Indian-style paratha with green dipping sauce and the turnip cakes.  Honestly, I could pass on the paratha, but the turnip cakes were a real revelation.  What a great way to elevate the lowly turnip!  Crisp, succulent, and an incredible marriage of flavors.

Next, we split several entrees, including the grilled eggplant stuffed with chicken in a green curry; stir fried garlic noodles with prawns, mussels and squid; and tamarind prawns.  I honestly cannot say that one dish was better than another.  However, if I had to pick, it would be the eggplant stuffed with chicken in green curry because of the dish's uniqueness.  

Overall, this restaurant is a great value for the high level of food it serves.  I highly recommend it.  Service could be better, but honestly, the food was so incredible that I can't even complain about it.
author: Anna S.

description: Decent food but poor service including refusal to correct error on bill. Unfortunate as had high hopes based on all the good reviews :/
author: Bob L.

description: Green onion pancakes were really good. Dumplings were alright but really needed a dipping sauce to accompany. Ordered kung Pao chicken as my main and was disappointed by it. While the sauce was good, the chicken wasn't breaded like Kung Pao is supposed to be.
author: Michelle S.

description: Ordered Tom Kha, drunk noodles, and pad Thai. The soup was pretty good but both noodle dishes were so delicious, and nice ambiance, too! My new favorite Thai place in SF
author: Martina H.

description:
Pretty great Thai food. I had the pumpkin curry with pork shoulder and it was at least two meals for me with the brown rice. The spice was just right and the sauce was pretty amazing. I got takeout so I know they do that but the interior was pretty awesome. The tables are spread out and the restaurant is long but narrow.

I sat at the bar while waiting for my food and plenty of people either ordered takeout or sat at the full service bar to eat. There was a brief wait at one point on a weeknight, I can only imagine they are packed on Friday and Saturday. Not sure if they take reservations but it is worth a call!

I'd come back here and try more stuff, for sure!
author: Jess A.

description: This place was great!  I had the jungle beef! Dang it was good we came here for my wife birthday with some friends and it was wonderful! We will be back!!
author: Jim E.

description: This restaurant makes my favorite version of pad kee mao. Spicy, flavorful, great noodle texture.
author: Emily C.

description: I had two group lunches there before both went very well, so I brought another group of friends this time myself. I told the restaurant we will be there at around 12. We were 10 mins late and stayed in the waiting area for them to get the tables ready. We were seated around 12:20. We didn't get any water or food until 12:34 so I started asking one mid age lady if they can bring some water and appetizer first as we have less than 30 mins left for lunch. and I did order the preset courses one day earlier because they said it will be faster. When I ask her the second time she became very upset and accused us for being late for 20 mins which is totally false. I was so upset and embarrassed in front of my friends. The food is still good and other guys are all nice and cool so I give them 2 stars but I'm never coming back to be embarrassed again
author: Ken L.

description: Cute little restaurant.  Couldn't remember what I ordered.  Just remember it was quite tasty.  Service was not bad too.  Will return again. Parking can be difficult
author: Kelly L.

description: Amazing! Loved the food and our waitress was so sweet and made great recommendations for items to try. They also were accommodating when we wanted to mix 2 dishes to make our own. Would definitely come back.
author: Dipika C.

description: Made a reservation. Hostess refused to seat us because we were 5 minutes late. Seated the party who came after us without a reservation. Reserve at your own risk. This place is pretty dingy anyway.
author: Yasmine H.

description: Average tasting Thai food with a standard variety of options. Waitstaff is on the slower side with service although they are friendly and polite.
author: Naveen N.

description:
My valentines date was here, a bit early... 2/11/17. 

We much enjoyed our post happy hour gluttony here. While some of the dishes gave me that 24 hour continued garlic breathe, it was all worth it for the yums in the tums. I will find myself back here if I happen to be in the area. Service was quick and friendly. Ambience was not romantic, per say, but didnt ruin the night.
author: Kim D.

description:
Came in with a alf dozen people on a Friday night.

We were easily accommodated, though we did call ahead by about 20 minutes and let them know we were coming.

This place is busy for a small little shop.  That's a good sign.

Everyone got something different, half chicken, seafood soup, pad thai, chicken curry, chicken and eggplant larb salad.

We all tried each others dishes, which were well portioned and served up in a great amount of time.

I asked for my dish to be served medium spicy, and have never had a problem at Thai spots getting medium to be spot on.  This was the exception as it was so so spicy.  I was not able to finish it.  It was really tasty, well cooked and balanced, but my chicken curry dish was so spicy it just hurt.  I order medium everywhere and am always pleased with the mild level of spice, but this was really over the top for me.

Everyone else's dishes were spiced just right and no one else had an issue with things being too spicy.

The thai tea was great and the prices were all reasonable.
This was a great spot for a Friday night and everyone left pleased.
author: Luke W.

description:
Minced chicken stir-fried is my favorite!!!! It's so spicy and has so much flavor! I love the eggplant and sweet basil that compliments the chicken. The Coconut braised pork shoulder is good too! Their curry is amazing.. The panstickers are an honorable mention. :)
The portions are good, and although it's a tad expensive, I think it's worth it. It's always pretty busy during lunch, so we usually order for pick up. Glad their health inspection went up a bit..
author: Kristina S.

description: I came here for the first time and was impressed both by the ambiance and the food offerings. Given the limited high quality Thai options in SF, I thought they did a great job. If you're looking for an appetizer, can't go wrong with the curry puff! Also the mains have decent portions and you'll definitely leave with a full stomach.
author: Lucy G.

description: My mom and I came here for an early dinner tonight at 5:30p.  We each ordered a dish, mom ordered pineapple fried rice with prawns and I ordered pad thai with prawns. The portions were generous, we were surprised that we finished both dishes because they were so good and we must have been really hungry.  We came when it was happy hour, house drinks are $6. I ordered the mojito, which tasted like hard limeade I like that! It was refreshing! My mom had the mango cosmo, which looked good. The pineapple fried rice had yellow curry. I liked the pad thai better, both dishes were really good!  The price per dish was reasonable, $13 per dish it can be shared or can be eaten by one person.
author: Alix J.

description: Stopped by for dinner before going to the Cat Club. The fiery lamb, curry puffs, and roti were great! The service was good for the most part and they seemed to take a lot of pride in their food. If you're looking for a good Thai restaurant I'd recommend checking them out.
author: Brian R.

description: Delicious food! This is one of my favorite Thai spots in Soma. The pork shoulder is fantastic!! Yum!
author: JonJon W.

description: Delicious order to go. Got the sweet potato app and the green curry with veggies. Highly recommend!
author: Vanessa B.

description:
I know, I know, there are many many excellent Thai places in SF, and reigning amongst them are probably not that of the merits of Basil Thai. However, when you're corralling a group of drunkies like herding cats, and this place being across the street it was a no brainer.

We were quickly seated on a Sunday during what I would call "prime" dining hour, which I was pretty pleased with. I did not want to deal with the wait of every other well rated restaurant in SF and just happy that my change of plans were accommodated. 

They brought us shrimp chips! it's too bad they only brought us one, and never refreshed it. This is something so cheap IMO they should just keep it on the table like refilling bread. 

We ordered a plethora of their well known goodies like pad kee mao, roasted curry chicken, roasted duck curry, the namtok (I probably spelled this wrong - chili lime beef salad), and the crab fried rice. Honestly excellent food all around. We cleaned up the plates because the flavors were on point and the portions were actually perfect for sharing between 4 ravished folks. Definitely recommend it as I think they have good reasonable prices and good thai food!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
I am usually not that picky when it comes to Thai food especially since I ordered the most "safe and basic" Pad Thai but it was pretty terrible. One great thing was that the food did come out piping hot which I was grateful for. The Pad Thai was way too salty. They put too much sauce on it and the sauce itself was not only salty but also very very tart! I am usually the one who is squeezing lemon and lime all over my food, too. 
The two pros were that they give you these little shrimp chips(or something like that) before your meal and that the appetizer dish I ordered was pretty good. I got the Chicken Satay skewers and they were yum. 

My wife got a pumpkin curry dish and it was a bit too spicy for our taste but ah well. The pumpkin part is not what we thought. It was chunks of pumpkin squash that were cooked in a curry sauce with veggies. It is not pureed pumpkin so just FYI there. 

The prices were decent I suppose for being in SF but I don't think I could bring myself to come back here. Ah well ... so many more places we need to try anyways right? hehe
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
This restaurant is located in a borderline ghetto area, so it was rare to see it look so nice and pretty inside. We weren't very hungry so we just ordered pan-fried indian bread (or nan) [$7.95] and 1 entree: coconut braised pork shoulder and 'kabocha' pumpkin in tangy red curry [$13.95]. 

Service was good: the food came out pretty quickly, and our waters were always refilled. The taste was nothing out of the ordinary though, coconut-y and spicy. I do like how this place does not get super packed; we were seated right away even though we did not make reservations. It would be nice, however, if the prices were lowered a dollar or two. For the portions we get, the pork shoulder is more worth $11 or $12 instead of $14. Again, nice to have, but not necessary.
author: Connie L.

description:
I had heard such a great things about Basil Thai from friends and family when I moved a few blocks away, and a year later I made my way there. My roommate and I shared the padthai and Stir-fried Sliced Chicken Breast (gai Ma-muang Hinmapan). We thought both were okay, the pad thai was made with a really thin noodle and was actually very bland. 
We may have just ordered the wrong things but overall I was not impressed.
author: Hetal P.

description:
There area lots of Asian restaurants in the area to choose from, but this place is on point. The coconut and sesame crusted sweet potato appetizer was amazing! It came over very hot and tasted much better once it cool down a tad. The texture changed, so make sure you give it time to cool. 

If you're a fan of Thai noodles, get the Spicy Wide Rice Noodles with Skirt Steak. The veggies were fresh, the steak was cooked very well and the flavor was perfect. 

As a Thai food lover, I would definitely go back to check out more of their dishes.
author: Holly H.

description: Nicely decorated restaurant and friendly service. It's located at a fairly nice location with a variety of other shops nearby. We decided to try their pad kee mao and pad thai which was fairly average, nothing too impressive and the price is definitely more on the higher end. If you're on a date, might be a place to try out since they also have a big bar selection.
author: Linda L.

description:
I'm a regular of the pad see ew and Thai iced tea at Basil Thai. The man and lady behind the bar are always very kind and attentive and it's quite fun to watch them make drinks at the speed of light.

Their classic minced chicken dish, crab fried rice, and pad kee mao are also delish. The only qualm about the menu is that there's no coconut rice as is common to other Thai establishments.

Ambience is quite fitting for the younger crowd--many a couple or group of friends can be found under the dim, romantic lighting. On some Saturdays it can get rather busy--to the point it's hard to hear your companion across the table.

I'm saddened there's a low health rating, hope that gets turned around soon!

P.S. Love their shrimp chip appetizer, reminds me of Chinese New Years at my grandma's house. :P
author: Vicky J.

description:
This place ia so good.

Except we had glass in our take home noodles. So had to throw those out.

Curry chixken was good.
Beef stirfry was ok
Fried rice was delicious
Skewered squid so delicious
Fried wontons a great start.

Def worth a stop in the hood
author: Spanky M.

description: Dinner will probably set you back ~$25, but the food (especially the noodles and curry) is very authentic. The service is very attentive and they give you a clean dish after every course! I didn't love the shrimp and mushroom tom yum soup that I ordered, but then again I don't love sourish soup.
author: Y W.

description: Went here for lunch. The food was good, but not great. The location is a little difficult to get to on a work lunch break.
author: Makenzi B.

description: This is one of the better Thai restaurants in town, though it's a bit pricey considering the service is good,  the ambiance is nice, and the food tasty it's still worth a try. I requested no hot spice or chili on my food which was the downside as some dishes were still too spicy.
author: Petra M.

description:
My friends and I came here for a birthday and we made a reservation. However, when we got there they told us that we never made one even though we had a confirmation email stating that we did. Also when we first walked in, the employees insisted that we were at the wrong location. No welcoming hello or greeting, just "are you supposed to be here or Basil Canteen?" That was very off putting to us.

They seated us anyways, which was great. The inside is nice and spacious even though the place is quite small. Also there is a cute waiting area so you don't have to stand when you are waiting.

My boyfriend and I ended up ordering the Gai Pik Khing (crispy chicken, string beans, and peppers stir-fried with sweet & spicy 'pik-khing' curry) and the Curry Peppercorn Duck (roasted duck and snap peas stir-fried with red curry paste and young peppercorn). Both tasted pretty good. The portions were a little smaller than I had expected, but the flavor of the dishes made up for it. I'd probably order this togo next time.
author: Theo T.

description:
This place is more $$$ than $$.  But the food is really good.  We had the chicken curry and the chicken slid off the bone - I would consider ordering this as takeout.  The prawn appetizer was fried and the pad kee mao was just ok.  I probably would not order it again.  They have warm sake here and it was pretty good.  I'd choose here over Koh Samui and the Monkey.

I highly recommend reservations to be seated promptly.
author: Chris L.

description:
I thought I loved Basil Thai before but tonight I introduced Basil to my family and took our relationship to a whole new level.

Our dinner started with the waitstaff greeting my daughters warmly and immediately offering us a high chair.  That set me at ease since I'd never seen any children at Basil.  When I mentioned my younger daughter's gluten allergy to our waitress Juju (great name, right?) she brought over a separate gluten free menu.  It lists GF versions of most of their regular menu items.  Yay!

I'm relatively new to gluten-consciousness, but avoiding gluten isn't a matter of choice for me:  last Father's Day we enjoyed a family visit to the emergency room because of our baby daughter's sudden reaction to new baby food.  Fun times.

While it's always nice to not end a meal in the ER, Basil's gluten free menu deserves a special nod.  GF offerings at most Asian restaurants seem like an afterthought but Basil's was so extensive we actually had a hard time deciding.

None of us missed the gluten at all, the food was yummy as always, waitstaff was more attentive than ever, and they made the meal feel special as all meals out with family should.

Thanks, Basil.  You made this daddy one happy motherfondler.
author: Tin N.

description:
This was my favorite restaurant along SOMA.

Looking back it had been about 5 years since my last review. And in that time I've probably visited Basil Thai more than 2 dozen times, easily.

I'd noticed in my last few non-local trips that the service would sometimes have an off day. Things wouldn't get refilled, remembered, etc. This last trip was a toss up between Triptych and Basil. And sadly, I chose Basil.

We started off on a bad foot, with us waiting about ten minutes to have our order taken after being seated. This escalated to all out annoyance after a large party came in and they attempted to seat them horizontally to us, thereby having whomever sat at the head of the table be a mere two inches from the only side of our table left free and creating a dangerous crowding situation on the other side of the aisle.

Frankly I had no idea how they were even going to go about serving us until the party quickly saw the issue and moved to a "better" table, after which they broke down the tables and it was no longer an issue.

Since I've been to Basil so many times I'm fairly aware of how much time it takes to serve. I've been here during Pride and other high volume street faires - so when I say it took the main meals (two dishes, one of which was soup) three times as long as it generally takes on a slightly busy day understand that by this time I was regretting I'd chosen Basil Thai.

After sitting through the aforementioned musical chairs and waiting patiently through a birthday celebration with a cake and candles brought out by a couple waiters, we finally received our food. Which was delicious. Basil was my favorite for a reason.

It should be noted that prior to stopping at Basil, since I was in SF and it was after 5pm I stopped at the local cupcake shop (which is my absolute favorite local cupcakery) and picked up a couple 2 for 1 tasties. See my review, they're awesome!

When we decided to eat at Basil, I brought the box in with me in full view of the waitress. After requesting another plate of shrimp chips and waiting almost 20 minutes for them, to cut the taste of the rich broth I pulled one out and ate one. Not thinking much of it as I'd brought soda, and other drinks into Basil at least a handful of times before and never had an issue.

About ten minutes later as we were waiting (again) to be noticed to get our check, a waitress (though not ours) bent down and whispered in my ear. "Just so you know, we don't usually allow outside food." "I'm so sorry!" I said and she quickly said "Ya." and walked away.

I looked at the honey and pointed at the table behind us, "but Basil doesn't serve cake..." I said. He shrugged. We finally flagged down someone for the check and pulled out our Discover cards. After waiting another few minutes to be acknowledged we asked the waitress who came up if they took Discover (many places don't). "No." she said and walked away.

At this point, we were done. With that final nail, my run as a Basil Thai customer was over. I won't be back. While Basil has been going downhill, the actions and tone of the servers and waitresses this last visit lost have finally lost a repeat customer.

Cupcakegate. What a way to go.
author: Meg T.

description:
I've gone to Basil Thai on several occasions and the food has never disappointed.  The pork tenderloin with the sweet chili sauce was simple and delicious. 

The service was attentive, but you know when they're too attentive and it makes you feel a little rushed?  That's kind of how we felt, even though we were there at 5:30 for dinner, so clearly before any sort of dinner rush.
author: Nancy K.

description:
Unfortunate dining experience at a spot I've frequented regularly over the years. 

I was so bothered by the interaction I had with a woman who identified herself as "the manager" yesterday (Sunday, June 7 6:25pm) - I felt inspired to write and share.

(1) I made an ordering mistake.

(2) I apologized for the error.

(3) I was "shushed."
(4) I was berated - and I was placed on the defensive because of my direct line of questioning.

I live a few blocks from Basil Thai, so it's location is convenient. Although I'm not overwhelmingly familiar with Thai cuisine, I've always felt comfortable trying different items on their menu. 

The space is clean and the service is friendly.

I find the portions to be generous and the pricing, moderate.

I stopped by yesterday to grab an early evening bite so that I could get home and watch the end of Game 2 of the NBA Finals.

I had two appetizers, their yummy Crispy wrapped whole tiger prawns with sweet chili vinaigrette and the Pan-fried dumplings of shrimp and pork served with Thai ginger soy.

My ordering mistake was soon to follow:  "The Deep-fried whole Tilapia with chili, shallots, cilantro, bell peppers, and sweet mango."  It's a whole fish. A whole fish, head and all.

"I'm so sorry. I made an ordering mistake. I cannot eat this."
My server, who later identified herself as the "manager" said, "This is what you ordered."
"Yes," I replied, "but I didn't understand this to be an entire fish deep-fried. I was expecting a battered filet - you know, like 'Hunan.'"
Not missing a beat and without the slightest hint of irony, she said, "Shhh. If you want 'Hunan' you need to order Chinese. We are a Thai restaurant." 

"Sorry." I said.  I handed her my credit card and she walked away.  When she returned, she handed me my bill - it was for the entire order: both appetizers and the Fried Fish; the Fried Fish that I had not touched.

The same Fried Fish that I had refused to eat.

"Excuse me, I'm not paying for this.  I haven't touched it." 

"Well," she said, "you're welcome to take it with you. You ordered it." 

Our conversation was going nowhere fast. 
I was beyond annoyed.
I smiled. 
I got up from the table.
Walked to the hostess/ordering area and asked to speak with the manager.  

It was at this time that she identified herself as the manager.

"I am the manager," she said. "I make the decisions. You ordered the Fried Fish. I brought you the Fried Fish. You need to know and understand what you're ordering. That is an expensive item you'll need to pay for." 

She turned to the computer, printed the receipt and she handed me a check for the two appetizers and the Fried Fish.

"I'm not paying for the fish."
"Yes you are, it's on your bill."

We stood there, locking eyes; neither of us moved.

Finally, she turned the computer again, punched up a new receipt handed it to me and said, "let me have your card again." 

"What is your name?" I asked.
"I am the manager." With that, she handed me the receipt to sign and returned my card to me.  "Here. Go please." 

I signed. Left and grabbed a pizza from Extreme. 

Not the meal I wanted, but far superior in service and expectation. 

I am not an asshole.
I do NOT treat people with disrespect. 
I spent YEARS waiting tables to pay for graduate school and never engaged a customer that way. 

Lesson learned: Thai is not Hunan & Basil Thai will never have to worry about me ever darkening their door again. 

A decision, I'm sure, that pleases us both.
author: Nick S.

description:
This was my second time at Basil Thai - based on my first experience, I expected the food and  service to be decent. Unfortunately, that wasn't the case. When we first arrived at the restaurant, there were only two or three tables with customers. We placed our order before the rest of the lunch rush arrived but still managed to wait 45 minutes for our food to arrive, while tables who came after us received their dishes relatively quickly.

Not only that, but a different server gave another table all of our food and the other customers started to pick at it when the same server came back to their table, took the dishes, and placed them onto our table while reassuring us that "the food hasn't been touched yet." Funny, because one plate of pad thai had chopsticks stabbed into it and another dish already had curry poured onto the rice. When we went to tell our original server, she looked confused and didn't offer much help whatsoever. There wasn't an apology or, really, even an acknowledgement of the mistake.

When we finally got our food, it was clear that it wasn't made very well. The noodles in the pad thai were rubbery and the chicken in another dish tasted off. Clearly, food and service at this establishment seem to not be a high priority. They're truly lucky to be in a location where many offices are located - otherwise, I would highly doubt they'd last long elsewhere.
author: Marshall Z.

description:
It's worth noting that I'm not a huge fan of Thai food in general, so depending on how you look at it that could make my opinion not as informative because I don't know what I'm supposed to expect out of Thai food or even more honest in the sense that it's purely whether I like it or not.. Anyway, pleased with this place! Went to an art show in the city one night, and decided to look up somewhere nearby to eat when hunger came around. Chose here out of convenience, mostly. 

The service was not bad at all, but nothing extraordinary. Our server did exactly what you would expect your server to do on the job - took our order, checked on us every once in a while, offered to-go boxes, gave us our check. Nothing extra that stood out, but not unpleasant at all. Honestly, I don't think our server ever even told us her name. 

Between my boyfriend & I we ordered crab fried rice (not pictured), grilled angus sirloin, & Japanese scallops, and I had a lychee Thai iced tea. My beverage was refreshing; still tastes like you would expect a Thai tea to taste, with just a hint of lychee. There is lychee pulp in it, which I don't mind, but jsyk. The crab fried rice was delicious, and you can order it with a fried egg as well! Not too fishy of a taste. The sirloin probably surprised me the most in that it didn't taste how it looks. Definitely on the tangy side, but good. Cooked well also; not too chewy, but not dry at all. The Japanese scallops were our favorite order of the night. The chili black bean sauce was a great sweetness with the smallest kick (there's some flexibility with how spicy you want it made when you order it). It paired especially well with the fried rice. Overall, left the restaurant super satisfied with our meal! Nothing to complain about there. Would definitely consider coming back next time I'm in the city.
author: Jasmine V.

description: Food was delish! Ordered the fried calamari, salmon curry, slow cooked chicken and potato in yellow curry and pineapple fried rice. Finished up with the sticky mango rice. Drinks were ok, I ordered the basil drop cocktail and friends got a couple of beers. Will definitely recommend this place for some yummy thai food.
author: Asmita K.

description:
3.5 Stars.

Oh to be a Thai restaurant in lovely San Fran. Talk about competition!

That being said the food at Basil Thai is just so so.

The dishes that I thought were good were the: 
Paupia sod ( a lovely fried vegtable roll with a nice dipping sauce). Not oily just light crunchy and flavorful.

Keow wan roti. I have never seen this at any other thai restaurant. Basically a Naan bread with green curried eggplant tomatoe and basil. I really liked this: The bread was good, the sauce was good, and the veggies were good.

So here is where is just went meh....the entrees.

Pad thai lacked flavor. The Tofu curry was watery, lacked flavor, and the tofu was limp bloated chunks of nothingness ( sounds like a french existentialist), the spicy lamb dish was at least flavorful but the lamb was over cooked and chewy.

The service is great and the setting is nice and I can see why people rate it high in that regard. But for my dollars there are many other Thai restaurants that are better and cheaper.
author: David G.

description: Food was amazing here. Decided to come try this restaurant after looking on yelp, and the reviews weren't wrong. We ordered pa me mao and chicken fried rice rice and shrimp and they were all really good. Definitely will be coming here more often.
author: Shanzay H.

description: After a recent trip here this is our favorite Thai restaurant.  It's noisy but we had the small table in the window and it was extremely pleasant.  Lovely dinner, and we especially liked the egg plant dish and the chicken larb. Nice services even though we were way out in front and not many servers coming our way.
author: Marianne K.

description: Here in San Francisco to visit and was craving Thai food my Uber driver recommended this place and it was a success! Curry lamb rack is oddly on the menu but it is super delicious! Definitely a must try!
author: Santiago C.

description:
I came here a while back with my wife and in-laws for dinner.  We shared a few things including the fried spring rolls, the Indian bread, the Pad Thai, and the Brussels sprouts.  Big ups to the fried spring rolls and Indian bread, which were both really good.

The place had a nice ambiance .  Overall, we enjoyed ourselves.
author: Sebastian N.

description:
I had an amazing time at Basil Thai Restaurant. The restaurant was adorable, the service was great and the food was completely on point! Plus, you don't have to spend a bomb to have a great time, what's not to like?

To start of, the drinks were really, really good. My friend had the Ginger Drop cocktail which was AMAZING, it was a very light cocktail with a nice dash of fresh ginger that had a great kick. Definitely one of the best cocktail's I've had. I had the lychee saketini which was also very good.

1. Fish cakes - The fishcakes were good. I really, really enjoyed them. I know you can get them at most places, but I think Basil Thai serves one of the yummiest.
2. Tom yum goong - I enjoyed this soup - I tend to find that most places in SF make tom yum a little too sweet, this was nice and savory but I would have loved if it were a little spicier
3. Brussels sprouts with garlic and chilli and pork belly - Mmm, this was as good as it sounds.
3. Garlic noodles - I wasn't particularly impressed, they felt a little soggy but my friends loved it. Maybe I just am not a fan of garlic noodles.

All in all, we ordered quite a few dishes and dined family style. I enjoyed all of the dishes - this is definitely one of the best Thai restaurants I have been to in the bay. And I am looking forward to going back again. Unfortunately, as delicious as the dishes were, a lot of them were quite forgettable. I would definitely recommend Basil Thai for a good, casual dining experience. GET THE DRINKS, they definitely helped to bump this experience from good to GREAT.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Is it the best Thai food in the city? No, but it's pretty good. I'm actually more of a fan because I think the restaurant is managed well. That's become a much larger component of my reviews lately, because I would rather have good food in a well-run establishment than great food in a hellhole. There isn't a single place in San Francisco that I think is worth waiting for more than 1 hour or tolerating poor customer service.

That being said, I really liked how they handled a problem with the chicken satay, which we thought was a little undercooked. Without arguing, they replaced the dish immediately, but the manager took the time to come over and explain that they do use dark meat, which can sometimes look raw. He wasn't making excuses or laying blame, he just explained that it's a common misperception. I ate some of that skewer, and I'm alive to write this review, so maybe he was right. Anyway, we got an extra skewer, and they had a happy group of customers. Win-win!

PROS
- Good variety of dishes
- Great service, even when extremely busy during a lunch rush
- Reasonable prices, good portions

CONS
- I feel like some of the dishes are "Americanized" to make them more palatable to a wider audience. Can't really fault them for this, but just bear that in mind.
- Parking can be difficult, especially since there's frequent construction on Folsom and it's close to a couple of freeways entrances.

TIP
If you happen to be down at the Hall of Justice for jury duty, this is a great option because it's only a few blocks away and takes reservations.
author: Drew P.

description:
Delish!!!!!
great variety delicious food
author: Natalia E.

description: I got food poisoning here on Tues, Dec. 19th. It was grisly. Chicken Satay, Fried Shrimp Rolls and sticky rice. I have been coming here for years, but sadly, won't be back.
author: Sarah M.

description:
I came here with two friends on a random Tuesday evening, as a backup to our backup to our original dinner plans (because restaurants close for spring break what?!). Here is what went down:

First of all, their menu is slightly overwhelming. It's literally just a huge block of text per page, the bolded words are in Thai, and I think it's pretty much the poster-menu of how not to ever design your menus. But that is no big deal.

One of my friends is recovering from food poisoning, so we were planning on just ordering two entrees, an appetizer, and some rice for my poor friend who cannot stomach anything at the moment. BUT THEN, upon further examination of this long block of text, we see fine print at the bottom: "For our dinner hours, because of limited seating, each person must order at least $15 worth of food" (or something of that nature). I was super taken aback - maybe I'm not used to city life, but I've never really seen something like that, especially in fine print?! Especially at a restaurant that isn't even fancy or super nice (maybe then, I would understand)?! And, looking around, there were a handful of empty tables around us at a peak dinner hour!

We called over the waitress, explained the situation, and asked if it would be alright for my friend to just order some rice to eat. The waitress paused for a long while then addressed my sick friend with, "You can order drinks."

Anyway, after a little bit of negotiation, the situation was all taken care of, and my friend didn't have to order anything besides rice. It was just such an awkward situation. Further, the $15 limit is super weird because most of the entrees are under $15, meaning each person needs to order an entree AND an appetizer each. Maybe that is normal for people. Maybe I am just not rolling in dough. I don't know. Like I said, though, this restaurant is nicely decorated, but would not be considered "fancy" or "upscale".

The food? I enjoyed the curry puffs (diced duck and sweet potatoes) a lot! They were flavorful and delicous. However, both of the entrees my friend and I ended up ordering (the crab fried rice and the pad se-ew) were super bland. Literally tasted like nothing.

All in all, not quite understanding the reviews of this place. Maybe I came on a bad day?
author: Ingrid A.

description:
This place is great! Only problem is that hours of operation have changed for 2016 so dinner hours actually start at 1730 not 1700. 

Once my husband and I walked in (we were be first people there), we were seated and offered a high chair immediately for baby. Drinks and appetizers were served immediately as well. Tofu and vegetable rolls with citrus peanut and chili sauce were amazing! Thai Iced tea is a MUST.

I ordered the Pad Ke-Sew (I think it's spelled), but they were thick noodles with skirt steak and veggies. Reminded me of chow fun, very great. I also liked their brown rice and the Pad Thai.

As dinner went on, there was a slow and steady trickle of people coming into dinner and the house was packed; however, customer service was not compromised. I'd definitely come back :)
author: Priscilla P.

description:
Turned out to be pretty inconsistent. That said, we did think the quality was good. We asked for our noodles spicy and they ended up Mild. We had the beef pad kee mow (again, wasn't spicy although it normally would be). 

Also had the squid salad as recommended by our waitress, this was spicy, so for those who expect mild, be warned.

Would try again and hope the communication was more clear.
author: Cait C.

description: This is my absolute favorite Thai place in SF next to Farm House Kitchen Thai. They've done a great job at their take on modern Thai. The little fish rice cakes they give you at the beginning are a little sensory experience. The curries are amazing, especially the Penang. I haven't had a single bad thing here. Portions a a good size. The best part about this place is that it's never too crowded and you can also make a reservation. The servers are also extremely nice. Make sure you come here next time you're thinking Thai!
author: Carly H.

description:
Now I usually don't write reviews unless the food is so horrible that people need to know, or if the food is so amazingly tasty that if your even in the same neighborhood as the place than you MUST stop by. 
I have only been to the city a few times and coming from LA, you can find Thai food EVERYWHERE. But let me tell you, this gem in San Francisco has most of the places back home beat! Our waiter who also turned out to be the manager made some GREAT suggestions on what to eat since there menu is so big. I had the Panang short rib in a red curry sauce. OH MY GOD. Delicious. One of the best I have had. My girlfriend had the basils eggplant which was also delicious but it lacked the tofu that she wanted for her protein requirements. All in all no complaints. Best part is we GET to go party over at the Raven now
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Great food! They went above and beyond to cater to the entire office gang in such short notice. Also, wonderful veggie options! 

And, lovely and accommodating waitresses! It was my pleasure to dine here and will definitely go back!
author: Preet C.

description:
I'm sorry - I don't know why this place has four stars!  I trusted Yelpers on this one, but I have to admit it was kind of a let-down. 

My friends and I ordered food for delivery. Not only did it take longer than estimated, but the suggested tip (13%) on top of the delivery fee seemed a bit high - and it was not adjustable (at least, not that we could figure out). 

The food was OK, but not at all what I'd expect for a four-star place. The basil eggplant was the best dish we had, and actually finished that one. We also ordered two versions of the pad thai, and they were mediocre at best - very disappointing. Not a lot of flavor, mostly bland noodles that seemed more like angel hair spaghetti than anything thai. I would suggest adding more flavor, more veggies, and more limes at least (if the pad thai is going to be bland, at least give me more than one lime slice to make up for it!). I ordered a spicy seafood soup which was an ok value for the money and was pretty tasty but nothing spectacular. We also tried the sides of brown rice (which you have to order separately). These were good and actually better than the average - but not something that really draws me in to a restaurant! 

I would give Basil another try, but I'm not in a huge rush.
author: Catie F.

description:
I finally convinced my hubby to try Thai food, and this was the winner of our first Thai experience.  I am really glad it was.  We started with chicken satay that had the most delicious peanut sauce ever.  It was a little bit thick and chunky and added a lot to the chicken but didn't overpower it.  For the main dish, we ordered Pad Thai and Pad ke mao.  They were both soooo good.  My hubby liked my Pad Thai better than his dish, so we actually ended up switching because I liked his dish better!  They have a few craft beers on tap which was great.  

I called to make a reservation earlier in the day for 7:30pm.  When we got there, they didn't have our reservation.  That would have been really annoying if there hadn't been 2 open seats at the bar.  The place was packed so a reservation is a must.
author: Alyse H.

description: Very affordable and delicious thai food, pad kee mao is my favorite! definitely a go to in in soma!
author: Calvin C.

description:
Good food, though I don't think this is one of the best Thai places I've been to. 

I got their green curry, which was good but didn't blow me away. My friend got the curry with Japanese scallops, which was much better than mine and I would recommend if you go here. 

If you want it spicy, I would bring it up. None of our party was asked, but those who brought up that they wanted a medium spice level were happy.

If you get a Thai iced tea, ask for coconut milk instead of condensed milk in it -- it's fab-o.

Also, service was great.
author: Sylvia S.

description: One of my favorite Thai places in the city. Its a close one between this one and Farmhouse Kitchen though.  Great pumpkin curry, great Capirinha, great lamb and beef.
author: Shmuyator O.

description: Food was okay, but I have had better Thai. The staff was very kind, but the smell of rotten fish and overbearing amount of tofu in the food made it hard to eat. But I would say this place is very true to its roots!
author: Ali F.

description: Came here for my friend's birthday. We were a party of 10 and since we're a "big group" we were offered only a selected menu. Definitely nothing I wanted was on the menu but we didn't have a choice. It was a busy night so I understand that the service was slower than usual. However, it really annoyed me how many times the waitresses came around to take our plates while there was food still on our plates. This one specific waitress kept grabbing oue plates THEN asking if we were finished. I'm obviously finished now after you touched my plate. It was really irritating because we were really trying to just enjoy the dinner and the company. We kept getting interrupted. I don't know if it was because they wanted us to leave or if they just personally eat fast or something. I wouldn't recommended to go here as a large group.
author: Jessica J.

description:
This is simply the BEST Thai food I've had. Period. I got the pumpkin curry plate.... and have craved it ever since. I'll be going back for sure!
The ambiance is very nice and the parking was easy [although it was for lunch-maybe it would be harder on a date night]
author: Sharon S.

description:
Their menu proudly states "not your ordinary Thai restaurant", and I have to say I wholeheartedly agree. Sooo...

We were in the neighborhood, fairly likkered up, having just come out of one of the local bars. My two friends were like, "need food now". So I pulled out my trusty Yelp app, and it just so happened that we were literally standing in front of this highly regarded eatery.

We all stumbled in and even though they were very close to closing and we were very not sober, they ushered us in and treated us like long lost family.

I used to live in LA and I think overall, Thai town in those parts has the best Thai food in the US. But ever since I actually visited Thailand some years ago I stopped eating the domestic stuff since to me it just doesn't taste as good. So all that just to say that I haven't been to a Thai restaurant in probably three or four years because now I'm too picky.

So great, now we're here. We decided to stick to the basics. We ordered the traditional noodle dishes- pad thai and pad se-ew. They were absolutely wonderful... I was almost shocked that the food was done so well.

So then we got adventurous and started ordering all kinds of things (most of which I don't remember because... well because we were not sober). But the dish I remember the most was the curry peppercorn duck. If you like roast duck then you owe it to yourself to try this version. Flavor!

In any case, next time we go here we'll  be going on purpose. You should too.
author: Art C.

description: Absolutely amazing food, decent wine list although we did not have any on our last visit so cannot speak to the quality, and pleasantly large servings. Slightly expensive, but you definitely get enough food for 2 meals. 10/10 would recommend. Looking forward to my next visit.
author: Nishant R.

description: Came here for what I thought was going to be a quick lunch. We sat down right around 12:10 pm and ordered at 12:18 pm according to the receipt. The food didn't arrive till around 12:55 pm. The waitress was saying that orders were about 40 mins wait, but seen the people that walked in minutes ago had their food within 10 mins.
author: M C.

description: Best curry I've had in a while. Service was decent and I had a pretty good overall experience. Will definitely come back here soon!
author: Shain Z.

description: Really good food and service. I don't eats lots of Thai but the people next to me said it was the best he had ever had so I'm going with good. No to experience 9-15$ per meal
author: Alec D.

description:
OK, with a new year, 2015, I am implementing a new rating system. I find that the straight 5 star system to be overly simplistic and many times I found myself giving a restaurant something other than what they really deserved. So here it goes:

FOOD: 3 out of 5
SERVICE: 4 out of 5
AMBIANCE: 2 out of 5
VALUE: 3 out of 5

We ordered the following:

1. Dtom Ka Gai - chicken and oyster mushroom in lemongrass, galanga and coconut milk, soup: the chicken was tender, the oyster mushroom was tasty, but the soup was overwhelmed by the lemon, and I mean they must have used lemon juice because I could not taste the lemongrass. On top of that, it was not creamy at all.

2. Kao Pad Sapparot - Thai pineapple fried rice with shrimp and cashew: yes there were about four full size shrimp, plenty of pineapple and some stale cashews, but it tasted like something from Pan** Express.

3. Kana Mu Grob - Chinese broccoli, bell pepper and crispy pork belly wok fried in a chili-garlic sauce: they actually used a few chili peppers to give it more of a kick. Tasty, but, it's more like something from a Chinese restaurant.

4. Pak Rad Kang - grilled squash, eggplant, zucchini, mushroom, tomatoes and chili peppers in a green curry sauce: even though this dish specified chili peppers, it was not even close to being as spicy as the previous dish. That said, this was probably the best and most authentic dish all night. The veggies were not over cooked and the curry did not overpower the taste buds.

Service was excellent. We were greeted promptly, the server came quickly and was not upset when we were not ready to order. They refilled our water glasses without asking and kept them topped off. They cleaned the table of empty plates and bowls promptly so our food was not cramped together on a smallish table. And finally, they were not overly pushy on dessert.

Ambiance was very contemporary, although during our visit, Thursday night around 7:30PM, the lights were dimmed too much, to a point we could hardly read the menu, and the noise level made everyone shout to their dining companion. This would not be a place for a romantic dinner nor really a place to go to to talk.

We may give them another try or we may not.
author: Tony L.

description:
The service was pretty good. And we all really enjoyed our appetizers! (The calamari with sweet Thai chili sauce and the sweet potatoes breaded with coconut. These were both super delicious/amazing!)

But I had the crab fried rice for my meal and I was pretty disappointed. It was very bland and flavorless. 

Two other people I was with got the pad me kao and loved it. So I would definitely recommend passing on the crab fried rice - even though it sounded really good and I've had other crab fried rice that I loved.
author: Kerry H.

description: Excellent food.  We ordered the crab rice, shrimp & eggplant, and basil pumpkin.  Everything was superb.  Service was prompt as well.
author: Judy H.

description: Omg I came here again day before valentines day there were seats and most people were in groups like myself . This place is still yummeh .  Still basil lamb curry ftw !!! Oh and their coffee with added coconut milk.AMAzIngly out of this world!!!  Sometimes good tasting food comes with a price
author: Juila L.

description:
Good Thai fare.

We tried the Spare Rib Panang, Basil Eggplant, Curry Duck, and Pineapple Fried Rice.  Portions were sizeable, 3 very hungry friends shared the above and a round of brews (they have an above-adequate draft beer selection as well)

Prices are fare, but not excellent.
