Service is polite, but not particularly friendly.  They try to cram in the folks a bit.

Ambiance is dimly lit but casual.
author: Alan H.

description:
Solid 4 stars. Their spicy catfish is probably the 2nd best I've ever had (Diho Siam is the best ever) and easily the best I've had in the City. Pad thai was tasty, but a little over - sauced IMO. I prefer a little thicker noodle, but overall I'd probably order it again. Pad see ew was bomb. 

Bonus for being located across from City Beer Store!
author: John V.

description:
What a great find! Based on its location, I didn't expect to find such a nice restaurant with delicious food. Overall, I was very pleasantly surprised by Basil Thai.

FOOD: 5/5
Flat-out delicious. I had the short-rib red curry and also tried my girlfriend's pad see ew. The short rib I had was soft and flavorful, and the red curry was absolutely delicious. The pad see ew also exceeded my expectations. My biggest recommendation is that the food should be shared. While the short ribs entree was delicious, I think it was too much. By the end, I was getting a bit overwhelmed by the richness. Additionally, be warned - they charge $2.50 per bowl of rice... as a result, I ended up paying $5 addition tot he $17 entree. Maybe it's the SF standard, but I rarely get charged for rice when the entree is expected to be eaten with rice. Was a little disappointed. 

SERVICE: 4/5
We were seated quickly and the service was good. The only downside was that our waitress didn't really tell us rice was extra. Not a huge let down by any means, but left a little bit of bitterness at the end... at least the rice was good.

AMBIANCE: 5/5
Very cozy; a bit packed, but for its small size, I still felt that I sat comfortably and with reasonable distance from other tables.
author: Larry F.

description:
When you order a seafood dish and it has a "fishy" smell, its not gonna be good. 

Came here on a packed Friday night, had no reservations but were seated right away. Someone eventually came after 10 mins, then i had to flag down a waiter to place my ordaaaaa. Got some standard seafood dish probably Panang something or similar. It came out in 10 mins (skeptic) and it was meh. Tasted like it came from cans and or Safeway.
author: Daanyaal K.

description: The food was great the service was so so. Would definitely recommend if you're looking for some good Thai food with exciting inventive dishes
author: Erin D.

description: Came by here for dinner before heading over to Raven and it was an awesome decision. Had no reservation but they were able to seat the four of us right away. Slightly dark inside for the romantic and high-end feel. We were a fan of the food! The pad Thai was a small portion but delicious. Beef salad was very lemony but good as well. I also liked he kick of spice in the Brussel sprouts and bell peppers! The Tom yum soup lacked spiciness but the sour was there. We also had Thai green tea and black tea which wasn't very unique but nice and warm for the cold night. My friend's lychee Thai tea was very interesting and not bad - tasted just like its title: Thai tea with lychee flavor. Service was amazing and attentive. Altogether dinner was around $70 for four people.
author: Amanda C.

description: Papaya salad - delicious. Vegetarian yellow curry - sumptuous and flavorful. Quick service as is expected in a Thai restaurant but thankfully without the disrespectful nonchalance of other places. Reasonably close to downtown but far enough to have another street parking around so that your only source of anxiety will be the taste of the dishes  you order. But be rest assured, you won't be disappointed!
author: Karan J.

description:
Not a problem scheduling a group of 8 only a few days in advance.

Tasty food. My group especially enjoyed the corn fritters, curry puffs, and kabocha squash ("pumpkin") curry with pork belly. Plenty of vegetarian options, which is one reason I chose Basil for this group, and they didn't disappoint. As other reviewers have noted, get the iced tea with coconut cream: it's delicious.
author: Jeremy E.

description:
I've been here twice, and I'm not generally one to have my rating swayed by service, but I feel like both times the main hostess seemed incredibly unwilling/unhappy to accommodate any of our requests, no matter how simple. It's water under the bridge since we were ultimately fed, but the overall experience could have been a bit less uncomfortable otherwise. 

As for the food, overall it's decent, and the appetizers are a notch better.  
Standout item: Pan-fried indian bread - excellent. I would go back and just order 4 of these.
author: Madhur B.

description: Really good food.  It was busy for lunch but they got the food out in a reasonable amount of time.  I came with a group of 7 people and everyone said their food was delicious.  I had the skirt steak salad and it was very fresh and flavorful.
author: Tara L.

description:
Craving thai food one day, I decided on Basil. I called in an order and picked up our food 15 minutes later. I got take-out here the other day and ordered: Tom Yum, Pad Thai, Pad Se-ew, and Pak Rad Kang. 

Tom Yum was tangy just how it's supposed to be. The only thing I didn't like about it was the oyster mushrooms in it. Otherwise, it was really good. The pad thai was different from what pad thai is normally like. It was wasn't as sweet. I probably wouldn't order this again. The pad se-ew was really good with big pieces of meat and chinese broccoli. The Pak Rad Kang was also yummy, but I didn't like the strange squash it came with. Overall, I would probably order from here again since it's conveniently nearby and pretty tasty.
author: Melanie H.

description:
The best happy hour you will ever experience.

Also, generally good food, a great Gewurztraminer on tap, and a good vibe. I would highly recommend it, particularly given their proximity to City Beer Store, Cellarmaker, and a bunch of other places. Great restaurant! (Particularly for happy hour)
author: David V.

description:
This is my favorite Thai in SF so far, with Lers Ros.

I've had the sauteed prawns with eggplants and the Monk's Delight dish. Both are sooo yummy. You can get brown rice if you'd like instead of white. The ingredients used are high quality. The veggies are crunchy.  The dishes are not too spicy, just perfect flavors.

The restaurant is nice & fancy. 
I've also gotten take out a few times and the food remains hot & well presented.

Great spot!
author: Leslie S.

description: OK - Basil Thai is awesome. Mainly for their stuffed eggplant. I'm not even a huge fan of eggplant, but when they stuff chicken and basil inside of it and drown it in green curry, HOLY MOLY! Mix in some brown rice and you have a super filling meal that has some seriously awesome flavor. They even made the curry mild for me which not all Thai places will do. Thanks, Basil Thai!
author: Dana J.

description: More like 3.5. Decent pad see ew but price to quantity of food ratio is not great. Okay by sf standards.
author: Alison D.

description: Delicious Thai food. The place was busy. Looking forward to visiting again. If you're south of Market, check it out!
author: Cydney D.

description: I got take-out here for a work lunch - the food is quite good, but the portions I felt are a bit on the small side and difficult to share with others. The decor walking in was fantastic. I would love to give this place a try for a sit down dinner under better conditions, but for the price range and small portions - I feel there are much better Thai options around San Francisco. There was nothing about the food, despite being delicious that "stood out from the crowd" for me. YMMV.
author: Doug R.

description:
Good duck curry.  Sticky rice is similar to other Thai restaurants.

Decor is decent.  Good for business meetings.
author: Niniane W.

description:
Panang curry is the best thing on the menu. 

Everything else was mediocre:
Pineapple shrimp fried rice
Naan appetizer
Pad Thai
Chicken skewers

Decent service. 
Clean Restaraunt.
author: Tina H.

description:
What a find in the neighborhood near my hotel. Thank you, SF Yelpers, for the tip.  I throughly enjoyed Basil Thai.

I was here for lunch so I ate at the bar.  The service was quick, friendly and helpful.

I had a red curry with fried tofu, eggplant, sweet potatoes, chilies, and various other delights.  Basil of course.  And one of those fabulous Thai iced coffees.  

Thai Basil is a pretty place -- loads of windows, blonde wood, cement bar, stylish wait staff and a nice menu.
author: Charles S.

description:
I really wanted to like this Thai restaurant, but found the food to be very ordinary.

Appetizers: 
--Crispy wrapped whole tiger prawns were small, not like prawns, but very tasty.  
--Thai spiced fish cakes:  Greasy, chewy, not very flavorful

Entrees:
--Crispy sliced chicken, w/string beans and peppers:  Soggy, ordinary, lacking flavor
--Stir fried chicken breast w/cashew nuts: Not much flavor. Very ordinary
--Pad Thai w/shrimp: Good

They have a small, but very good selection of draft beers.

The service was very attentive.

I would not go back.
author: Max G.

description: I'm crazy about Thai food and hasn't had the best dining experience at Thai restaurants for the longest time. My experience with this restaurant is a typical example: trying to order on the phone in English is difficult, maybe because of the noise, so I triple confirmed everything with the waitress to make sure there's rice, and a to-go bag. In the end, when we went there to pick up the food, we had no rice (which is essential to the food I ordered, not even extra rice, the rice should come with the dish), and double-charged for one to-go bag. I don't know what else to say.
author: RN L.

description:
First time here after 4 years of living in San Francisco. The food was pretty tasty and considering that me and my friend are vegan the waiter was so nice to let us know what we could and couldn't have. 

Great cocktails. The appetizers were 'ok' and overall reasonable for what you get! 

Can't wait to come back!
author: T. C.

description:
Seated a table of 6 people this NYE without a reservation (because my boyfriend's friends are absolute children when it comes to planning out things) - they honestly get a 4.5 star for that alone, but...

The food is INCREDIBLE. Every single person loved the dish they ordered: from the skirt steak to my green beans and crispy chicken. Amazingly flavorful with enough sauce to really coat every bite.

I also thoroughly appreciate the spice level on their food - making Thai food mild really just dilutes the flavor. None of that here!

Service was great for such a busy night and I was genuinely surprised the bill wasn't much higher for the quality of food. Will be back again real soon!
author: Puja M.

description: Pretty nice place and decent price for the ambiance. For me, it was solid not mind blowing Thai food but what makes it stand out is the atmosphere. Its a somewhat higher end ish Thai restaurant, with a full bar and interesting takes on classic Thai appetizers.  Great place to bring someone on a date or a catch up session with friends. Came in on Friday night and there was definitely a good crowd, but the wait wasn't too bad (15 min) which is awesome considering most places in the area were quoting 45 min+. Would come again.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Good ambiance, great selection.  Service was good.  The entrees were brought out a bit fast, leaving us little time to finish our appetizers.

I had the chicken & pumpkin curry and my girlfriend had the pad thai.  Both were tasty but shortly after leaving, we were sick to our stomach.  

Probably not a typical experience but, an experience nonetheless.
author: Shaun J.

description: Best Pad Thai in SF in my opinion and I've tried them all just about. Their Pumkin curry is amazing as well. I could just drink that sauce all day. Service is very good and portion size to price ratio is good (some places leave you feeling ripped off but not here). This is my go to Thai restaurant in SF
author: Oliver S.

description: Still at the top of their game after all these years. Service was impeccable and all food was delicious and unique. I especially liked the Tamarind Prawns. Any time I have a large group for a dinner party, I'll think of Basil Thai first. They handled a group of 18 with ease.
author: Jeff J.

description:
The Staff was nice and friendly however the bathrooms weren't as clean as I'd expect and a look in the kitchen showed the same result.

It appeared that they put mint in nearly all dishes which I personally don't like.

The veggie roles were good and crispy, although a little in oil.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Health Inspection rating of 54.Which is an abysmal score.

I've been here many times and like the food, but no more. At least until they fix the issues the health department has with them. Which you can see at: https://101g-xnet.sfdph.org:8443/ords/f?p=132:1:549782757513516 (sfdph.org is SF Dept. of Health)

Which is a bummer, because they do have some very good dishes like the pumpkin/pork curry. But I can't support a restaurant that doesn't maintain good cleanliness.
author: Jim T.

description: Blandest Thai food I've ever ate. Best go to Chinatown for great Thai food.  $2.50 for ten cents worth one cup of rice.  Which I would think should be included with the dish since rice is an Asian staple.  Waiter ignored our request for separate checks and made a few errors on one order.  He was definately rushed and preoccupied But maybe giving servers fewer tables would improve that problem and improve service. The food wasn't horrible,  just not what I would have expected from a Thai restaurant.
author: Eddie O.

description:
My friends and I have visited this place several times, and the food has been great. Tonight however, was a totally different story. We got a dish each (4 of us) and 2 of them had Hair in them - the Pad see ew and the Pad Thai !! The rest of us lost our appetite just looking at it. We returned the food, and complaining to the waitress about it had no effect. They just said sorry and took it away. 
We took a really long time to get our food, no one refilled the water and there was hair in the food. When we told the server that they shouldn't charge us for the food because of the terrible service and quality, she just said its a policy that we cancel food, but we can't negate the whole bill.
I would think it is common courtesy to not charge us if the service is so bad, but clearly they didn't care about it. 
Never going to this place again.
author: Bhavana S.

description:
Third time here..first review. 

Consistently good food, taste and quantity, and service. Prices are very reasonable for this quality. Come early as it fills up. People wait because it is worth it, so plan on it if you arrive during peak.

House Pad Thai it's served with tofu and prawns; lots of prawns properly cooked, tender and sweet. All dishes are authentic and prepared according to "heat" request. I ordered "Thai hot", and they wisely delivered it American extra hot, just below Thai hot, and offered to bring dried crushed red pepper as is traditionally correct. 

Desserts are eclectic, light and go down easy even after 2-3 preceding courses.

All good!
author: Scott C.

description:
This is our go to restaurant for good thai food, or just good food in general. Drinks are great (saketini is my favorite), dishes are delicious (usually we go with the short rib panang curry, pad thai, eggplant green curry). And finally, the desserts are the best part! The roti dessert is one of my favorite desserts around. 

Highly recommend!
author: Laura D.

description: Did you know they got a 54 health rating?  For the price, location and wait, adulterated meat, questionable food handling, poor thawing methods, rodents, and insufficient hot water are unacceptable. Seems like they are waiting for someone to keep over...
author: jay s.

description:
Mmm. Maybe I was really hungry. Maybe it was just really good. But I'll be back if I'm in the area and looking for some Thai food.

The restaurant itself has a casual-fancy atmosphere. It's nice enough to go for a casual date but casual enough to just go with friends after work. There's a lot of space inside but was pretty packed at the regular dinner hour.

AT, his friend, and I ordered three dishes to share: eggplant, pad ke mao, and coconut braised pork with red curry. All three were very good in their own ways. The eggplant with tofu was a very clean-feeling dish. The pad ke mao was Thai comfort food. And the coconut braised pork in red curry was a filling meal.
author: Julia N.

description:
All around Meh.  When selling itself as an "upscale thai restaurant", my expectations are higher, and I've had *way* better from mom and pop shops.

The pad see ew was super bland with dry overdone pork.  I actually had to ask for a side of hot sauce in order to give it some kind of flavor.  And since I'm not a fan of super spicy Thai food, you know it has to be bland if I'm trying to make it spicier.

On the plus side, the Thai Tea (w/ coconut milk) was excellent.
author: Ryan S.

description: This is probably my favorite thai restaurant in SF, and I've been to many. The dishes are authentic, delicious and perfectly-portioned. The service is amazing. The atmosphere is relaxing and romantic. The drinks are incredible! This place is worth the trip for their drinks alone (you can sit at the bar.) I love Basil and don't think I'll ever find a better place to eat Thai food in SF.
author: Vaishali R.

description: Quality of the food if high, service is great yet you get what you pay for....a little on the higher side for thai food but it's really good and they have a full bar.  For groups over 4, you should make a reservation.
author: P A.

description:
Snapshot: 4/5 Food, 4/5 Service & 4/5 Price Point

If your in the area and want Thai, go as it's worth the experience.

The Chicken and Oyster Mushroom Soup was superb. Get the Spicy Wide Rice Noodle w/ Skirt Steak. You will not be disappointed. The sweet potato appetizer is worth tying as well.
author: Nicolas O.

description:
After seeing lot of good reviews and 4 stars for this restaurant, I decided to give it a try.

It was a Friday night and the restaurant was pretty crowded with people. Lucky me, I did plan out and make a reservation 1 hour before going to this restaurant. 

I ordered keow wan roti, pad ke Mao and seafood garlic noodles. 

Keow wan roti - overall pretty good except the fried roti was a bit on the oily side.

Pad ke Mao - no complain, everything just taste right

Seafoods Garlic noodle  - not the best garlic noodles but pretty decent for a usd14 dish.

Will I dine here again? Definitely!
author: Joline K.

description:
Yum yum yum. Ordered lots of good things -- highlights were duck curry, coconut chicken soup (so delicious), and fishcakes! Everything was well balanced and full of flavor. Enjoyed every last bit. Some things were good but less stunning -- the tiger prawn appetizer and fried rice but the stars made up for it.

One of the biggest reasons I'm rating 5 stars is because our service was AMAZING. Nice (not sure how to spell but pronounced exactly like that) was impeccable. Our water cups never got more than half way empty. He served us all nicely and was very attentive without ever being intrusive. He was the best and literally would go back just to have him again.
author: Ramee S.

description:
Update  - true 5 star place.  
The guy with an attitude is gone!  

As good as it gets now.  Very accomodating and nice staff.  Being a neighbor next door I'd stop by Basil Thai anytime.  Always first on my list.
author: Alex R.

description:
Appetizer menu not clear sweet potatoes are fried. Peanut sauce for tofu spring rolls was too watery not peanuty. 
  I liked eggplant stuffed with chicken with green curry. Spicy and flavorful. 
  Lights over tables is harsh. moooi random Globe Lights over bar are too common these days but very romantic . 
  Paper cover over table cloth allows drawing. Feels good.
author: mik L.

description:
I hate having to write bad reviews but the way I feel right now warrants it. 

We came here earlier today as a group of 9 they sat us and everything was fine until they started bringing out our individual orders. It literally took 25 minutes from the first person to get their food to the last. It's always super awkward when some people get their food and the feel like they have to wait... everyone is hungry so the smell of the food makes you more hungry for those who have to wait and then the person with the food has their food getting cold. I ended up being one of the last people to get my food. I finally got my pad kee mao with beef and all seemed well. At this point they would have gotten a 3 star from me because no one addressed the wait time issue even though several people came to check on it. What made it into a 1 star is how I feel right now- totally nauseous. My coworker mentioned your beef did look kinda  undercooked but he didn't feel comfortable telling me at the table. I thought it seemed a little rare but bc I was so hungry I mistakenly ate it anyways not really thinking. He's also told me in the past that at their other location down the street he has seen a mouse crawling up the wall. I would have rather waited another 5 minutes in addition to the 20 minutes it took me to get my food after half of my table instead of feeling so terrible and have to make my commute home feeling like this. Never going back again!
author: Jennifer G.

description: Have eaten here several times! Quite delish - food available for vegans.
author: Pj M.

description: If I had to rate only the food I would actually give it a 4/5. The only thing that disappointed me was the service. I understand that a Saturday night at a bustling restaurant can drive waiters to their tipping point, but it's still no reason to take it out on a customer. Our server was out ride rude. I even caught her rolling her eyes at us :o....but on a brighter more everything we order was quite yummy... the coconut milk soup was my favorite. The corn fritters made a delicious appetizer too.
author: Rithu J.

description:
peppercorn duck
braised short ribs in panang curry
calamari rings
duck curry puffs

Upscale feel to this place. The food I still dream about because it is that good. Came in for lunch and walked out feeling goooooood. Glazed eyes and a smile. I was food drunk.
author: Mary Ann B.

description: Came in was seated in the back corner (like step children) felt uncomfortable seating so very close to people where I could hear their full conversation although the place wasn't even crowded. Needless to say we left. We were going for the crab fried rice....
author: Enjoli R.

description:
Definitely nothing special about this place to me. Was just mediocre. I've had a lot of Thai food before and their pad Thai didn't stand out to me. We got the Chinese broccoli with pork belly which was spicy and I didn't expect it to be. Also the skirted steak salad was just way too sour! The shrimp crackers they give u in the beginning was good, bigger than I've ever seen them. 

Ambience was nice. Slightly dimmed, good for a date. Very clean.

Our waitress was a little rude. We asked her to throw something away for us and she said ok and walked away for a bit (it was a bag of ice dripping on the floor).
author: Steph L.

description:
Dropped in here waiting for the Yelp event to start.  Honestly, it was just close to the bar and had decent prices.  Walked in never hearing of this place, walked out being highly impressed.  A small, but good sized bar.  It's a small location, but still able to hold a larger group (8-10).  Great atmosphere, the kind of place with cloth napkins but sat down next to a girl with her laptop out plugged into the outlet under the table.  Got in around 6:15, no wait for 2.  Left around 7:15 and the place was packed, every table sat.  

The food: DELICIOUS.
Panstickers - my FAVE! I could eat these all day.  Filled with shrimp AND pork.  They put something extra in the soy so its doubley delicious.  They are crispy on the outside and warm and moist inside.  

We also had the curry puffs.  I initially wanted these so bad because i LOVE duck, but they turned out to be little empanadas (which I don't like).  They were good, but not my fave.

Pineapple fried rice - pretty much a staple in any thai food place.  It was good.  Very flavorful, a good portion and amount of mixins (shrimp, pineapple, nuts, etc. etc.).  

They also serve everyone these delicious rice cracker kind of things (shrimp chip sorta style).  I have no idea what they are, but they are delicious and great to munch on while you wait for your food to come.  

The service was great!  Never had to wait for my glass to be filled.  Never had to ask for anything.  Someone came to pick up our empty plates and brought a dessert menu right away.  Came with the bill right away.  Just, amazing service.
author: Anjelica C.

description:
Came on a Saturday night with no reservations was seated without wait. 

Pros: 
Great space, nice bar and always busy. 

Staff is friendly and always checking on tables.

Cons:
No flavor in my main dish.

appetizer was undercooked. Sent it back, it never came back out. 

3 stars.
author: Alec D.

description:
YUM!
We came right before the dinner crowd, so seating wasn't a problem. Neither was parking, which was surprising.
Pineapple fried rice and pad se ew were good, but not memorable. The duck curry however was amazing. I don't normally eat duck, but it was deliciously soft, and the curry itself had a good consistency. Definitely craving some more right now
author: Trang B.

description:
Stopped by here for dinner before heading out at night. The hostess is a little short with you but our server was pleasant enough, even though we almost never saw them! Here's what we ordered:

Mango margarita looking drink- got this on recommendation of the bartender. Really poorly mixed (sorry I've turned in to a bit of a craft cocktail snob) and is pretty much vodka shaken with a mango puree.

Scallop skewers- not bad but heavily reeked of fish sauce. It was kind of unnerving at first because it seemed like they weren't fresh or something. 

Skirt steak with peanut sauce- surprisingly well cooked and balanced. I thought the peanut sauce would be too heavy, nutty or unpleasant and it was actually pretty tasty! I'm impressed. 

Pad kee mao- noodles were a bit overdone, flavors weren't really there despite this usually being a flavor-packed dish. I was super disappointed since this is usually one of my go-to dishes.

Papaya salad- surprisingly delicious and light, tastefully presented. Would order this and the steak again.

All in all I don't think I'd visit again since I'm sure there's better food in the area, nothings worse than underwhelming soggy thai food! Ambiance is nice though.
author: Jackie C.

description:
Too bad, I really wanted to like you too.

So close to my work. As someone who loves Noodles, please don't put noodle soup on your menu when it's actually:

One Bowl of Small Soup
One Bowl of Rice  Noodles

It was so disappointing! I told the waitress that I wanted Specifically Noodle Soup, like most places would have such a popular item.

I told her it's not even appetizing to EAT looking at 2 separate small "Bowls" of food that you need me to combine it. OMG for a $2.50 + $5.95 meal, presentation was horrible.

She returned and I told her please to give me something else. She came back and dumped the noodles in larger bowl, while all the soup already soaked into the noodles.

Another appetizer and Rice plate later, with tip -- $50 for a Lunch.

I'm Definitely NOT Coming back to your poor attitude and your lack of presentation skills.
author: Jacky J.

description: Excellent! Food was amazing. Service really good. Can't say enough about it. Go. Make a reservation to ensure a table.
author: Kimberly M.

description: Try the vege crispy rolls. It's the best in the world!!
author: Tomoe H.

description: Definitely don't order takeout from here. They said it would take 30 minutes but then they lost my order didn't say sorry and took an hour to get it. All they said for the last 20 minutes was it's coming. The interior looks nice though!
author: Priyanka M.

description: Delicious food and prompt service! The wait staff wasn't all that friendly, but they were good about food allergies. Stir fries there were so yummy! Would definitely return next time I'm in the area!
author: Rachel H.

description:
It's a bit sad when you live in city where a restaurant that stays open until 10pm on weekdays is "open late." Oh well, I love SF and I'm very happy that Basil Thai is "open late." I've enjoyed Basil Thai a few times and most recently after we had a group of friends had a few beers/ciders at City Beer across the street. We were ready for some sustenance and pysched that we could quickly get a table for the 5 of us at Basil Thai.

We decided to continue drinking and I chose a coconut cocktail which was pretty good but not quite as delicious as I'd expected. Others seemed to feel about the same about their cocktails (all around $9). We were VERY enthusiastic about the shrimp chip "bread basket" though and asked for more near the end of our meal (and our wish was granted!).

For food, I've tried several different dishes. I love tom yum soup and it's very good here (though I wish it were served as an even bigger pot!). We also ordered curries which were good especially with the brown/wild rice. One of my friends had the pad thai which also looked amazing though I didn't try it. 

I wish I didn't have to ask for chop sticks but I always do here (they are not provided on the tables) and it always takes a while to get this request granted. Then I just have to decide whether to dig into the delicious food with a fork or wait for my chop sticks! Bottomless shrimp chips would be great too!
author: Meghan P.

description:
Mildly spicy Thai food; mildly disappointing.

I had a huge craving for some comfort food last night, and what's more comforting than a bowl of Tom Ka Gai and a curry with just the right punch of heat? Paired with a side of House Hunters International, this is what my dream weekday night in looks like.

I placed an order for the soup, a red curry and a side of sticky rice via the Postmates app (check 'em out, by the way - they're crazy fast and professional!) and soon enough, I received a perfectly-packaged bundle of steaming hot Thai goodies. 

I set up shop in my living room and tried the curry first - a backward approach, but I have a difficult time delaying gratification and I predicted the red curry would end up headlining the show. And it did: with its tender chunks of coconut-braised pork shoulder, kabocha pumpkin and a rich red curry, this dish delivered the flavor profile I was seeking. Unfortunately, the curry lacked any real heat but admittedly, I think it takes a lot to take my taste buds for a spin.

I found the soup pretty underwhelming, unfortunately. I expected it to be creamier, with a more pronounced coconut base. What I got was a thin rendition of what is usually my favorite soup - I'll skip this one next time.

Basil Thai's definitely a solid option not too far from home, but for now I'm still looking for my HG Thai spot.
author: Jelena Z.

description: Though not so trendy, it's a cozy restaurant to have a relax dinner with several Asian friends.
author: Kathy T.

description:
I'd give them 3.5 stars if it was possible. At the recommendation of a friend, I ordered take out last night for dinner.  I called ahead and my meal was ready to go when I got there, for the most part. I do give them kudos for waiting until I arrived to box up the coconut ice cream that went along with my dessert (more on that later). My biggest complaint- I got back to my hotel room, put on my PJs and settled in for some good eats, only to discover that there were no utensils and no napkins provided.  I'm sure this was just an oversight but come on!  Definitely knocked my rating down a star.  I basically ate everything with my hands because I was not changing back into my clothes to run to the restaurant next door in pouring rain to ask for some. 

Started with the spring rolls- I'll be honest and say I was expecting crispy vegetable rolls, but ended up with the fresh, raw ones.  Disappointed, yes, but it's possible I made a mistake when ordering.  Nevertheless, they were pretty decent, coming from someone who is not normally a fan of these. Tofu, noodles, carrots, lettuce and a pretty tasty dipping sauce.  

Also tried a small size of their Tom Ka soup.  THIS was one of the highlights of my dinner. A good portion of chicken and mushrooms in a delicious coconut/broth/whatever it is that almost made me almost forget I was slurping from the takeout container and digging out the chicken with my fingers.  Get this- you won't be disappointed.  
 
My entree (hey, I was hungry and on expense, don't judge) was the pad see ew, with beef instead of pork.  This was good.  Not great but good.  I've had it elsewhere where it tastes burned or scorched but this was cooked to perfection.  The sauce, IMO, needed a little bit more...something.  Sweetness maybe? There was something very slightly missing in the flavor that kept me from devouring it like I usually would at my hometown Thai restaurant.  Still a solid piece and don't let my pickiness deter you from trying this. 

And finally, dessert!  I ordered mango sticky rice (my fav) but was called back after hanging up to be told they were out of it.  Huge bummer. So I ordered the fried bananas and coconut ice cream instead. The bananas are not cooked as you might expect (as mini spring rolls drizzled with honey or some sauce) , rather, it was like chunks of banana that were breaded and deep fried- almost like I got 6 banana nuggets with a LOT of breading.  No sauces, but the coconut ice cream was amaze-balls.  I ate half of it on the uber ride back to my hotel.  Hey, I was worried it would melt before getting to enjoy it! 

Overall-  decent meal, definitely didn't knock my socks off but would definitely consider eating at the restaurant next time if I'm ever in SF with an urge for Thai to prevent any ordering errors!
author: Lola W.

description: Came here last night for a birthday dinner. Food was served family style. We got to change some items on the menu, which was great since most of us were vegetarian. The food was good, but I think since it was family style and so much food came out at once, it was overwhelming. The coconut ice cream for dessert was tasty! I would recommend coming here!
author: Amrit T.

description:
Oh my god, so good!

Four of us met up for dinner and ordered a bunch of different dishes ranging from soup to curry to fried rice. Everything we ordered was amazing! They even have a separate menu that lists all of their gluten free options, which was great for my friend who suffers from celiacs.

Definitely try the dtom Yum Goong soup.
author: Casey S.

description: Compact and flavorful dinner menu. Mediocre service and sub-par drink menu...And this was Valentines day.
author: Anthony V.

description:
Came recently for lunch with friends without a reservation. We got seated without waiting. Place is clean and simple. 

I ordered keow wan roti, pad ke Mao and seafood garlic noodles. 

Keow wan roti - overall pretty good except the fried roti was a bit on the oily side.

Food is delicious and service was great!
author: Jen M.

description: Had an hour for lunch. Went there. Ordered my food. Waited for 30 minutes and still no food. Other people arrived after I did got their food. Turned out all four servers were too busy chit chat and never put in my order.  Now I'm super hungry and ran out of time for lunch. Thanks for nothing. Not coming back there ever again.
author: Hung T.

description:
Loved the glowy feeling the restaurant promised from outside. It looked more expensive than it was :) which makes it a big winner in my book! I sat at the bar with my husband. When I walked down to the washroom in the far back I noticed all the food on everybody's table looked yumm.. stuff you'd want to dive into! And big portions.
Our bill came to about $52 and we ordered
Saketini - super recommended
Gingerdrop cocktail.. the husband didn't like but it was exactly what it said it was going to be
Golden bean cakes with mushroom, onions, cashew nuts
Chicken Satay
Chocolate mousse

Golden bean cakes.. sounds exotic huh.. we were like what is this going to be!? On ordering it was just tofu. When we asked 'erm.. where are the bean cakes?' they told us tofu is made from beans. Now that was funny because the menu had tofu all over but 'Golden bean cakes' in this one particular dish. 

Chocolate mousse - one spoonful and I was hit by an aromatic surprise. I will leave that for you to discover when you try it! Subtle thing.. i really liked it. Fitness cheat-day justified.

Best part - the woman behind the counter was really nice and easy to talk to. Don't you hate it when the food is good but people aren't nice? No such thing.

And some cool music was playing in the background with perfect volume levels... nice, twinkly evening :)

Oh yes, it's good for vegetarians as the menu says - they can make almost any dish veg!
author: Malvika B.

description:
We went here for a team lunch and we were a party of 9. So we decided to order family style. Here is what we got : 

- Vegetable Spring Rolls : Delicious, cripsy
- Pan fried shrimp and pork dumplings - pretty good but I have had better dumplings 
- Crab fried rice : Excellent , but not much crab meat. It was garnished with cilantro and scallion which gave it a great flavor. 
- Crispy Spicy Catfish : Perfectly cooked , a little sweet though 
- Pad Kee Mao : Really good , not too oily like at other restaurants 
- Minced Chicken : Chicken minced with Bell peppers and quite spicy. Surely recommend this one.
- Tamarind Shrimp : This was my most favorite dish. A must have if you enjoy sweet and sour flavors and tiger shrimp ! 

Took a star off since the service was slow as the restaurant was quite busy. But will surely be back.
author: Priyanka P.

description: This place is delicious! Super cool ambiance and great Thai food! Been here a couple times and will for sure be coming back! The Mango cosmos are delicious here as well!
author: Ricky R.

description: I love coming here!  This was my second time and they have the best curry dishes.  The flavors are spot on and not overpowering.  I like spicy and they were able to add more heat without compromising the flavor.  Will definitely be back!
author: Tramecia G.

description: Incredible.  This is the best Thai i have had, tied w a place in Chicago that is three times as expensive.  Celebrated a friends birthday here and had reservations.  We ordered 2 appetizers and four entrees and all the food came out in about thirty minutes.  Not only the best thai but also the most efficient.  Went with a group of six and did family style dining and every item was incredible.  The complexity and finesse of each dish was a pleasant surprise.  We had the tiger shrimp, garlic noodles, chicken eggplant green curry, turnip appetizer, and roti appetizer.  The place has a modern look, 10$ entrees, and amazing food; therefore gets crowded on popular nights so easiest to make reservations.
author: Sharmeela S.

description:
Stopped by here after catching a show at the Orpheum.  It's a cute little storefront Thai place.  The service staff was friendly, albeit a bit slow, the bathroom was clean, and there is a TV over the bar in case your date is a bore...

The food was plentiful.  Started with dumplings (shrimp and pork) - and they were amazing.  Also ordered the calamari.  Pretty skimpy rings, and they weren't that flavorful, but not bad.  Dinner was spicy (not really) noodles, and pad see ew.  Good sized portions, not a whole lot of flavor or seasoning, even when we requested extra spice.  The draft beers weren't bad for downtown ($5.50), so we kept them flowing.

Over all, a solidly good experience.  I'd go back, and it's only .4 from the theater, so it is an easy walk over.
author: Jes G.

description:
Remember that last time you went to a Mexican restaurant and you had to ask for hot sauce cause they were hiding it all in the back? Me neither. Why do I have to ask for spice, peanuts or lime when it's the reason you chose this specific food style? When you want sweet, you got Chinese or American. Perhaps the best thai place in SOMA (sadly), but its just another washed out non authentic copy that's not worth revisiting. Sorry. 

PS: If you're gluten sensitive, they use regular soy on most of their dishes and it's not in the menu description. 

PSS: Staff is friendly
author: Fredo L.

description: Perhaps some of the best Thai food I've ever had. It is not Americanized. Service when you enter is clueless. Find someone and introduce yourself and you'll get seated. It's worth it. .
author: Jim A.

description: We picked this restaurant based on yelp reviews and were not disappointed. The food was excellent. The spicy version of pad Thai is really spicy. We loved it but if you are not used to spicy food, order the regular pad Thai. The lamb dish was good but not spicy enough. The service was excellent. I would highly recommend it. It indeed is a neighborhood gem!
author: Malik B.

description:
I don't think I would have stumbled across this little Thai place or thought to go in on a regular occasion, but I was having dinner with my mom and she was trying to track down this mysterious Thai place she had in SOMA years ago and thought this might have been it. It wasn't, and I have to admit I was a bit skeptical when we first walked in due to the very refined decor, and the lack of Asians dining alongside us. I tend to gravitate more toward the slightly grimy holes in the walls when it comes to most Asian food because for some reason I feel like they'll be more authentic. But I have to say I was pleasantly surprised by the meal here! 

We had a wide variety of dishes, from the standard (pad thai) to things I've never tried before (mu yang)... everything tasted fresh, with a classy presentation and served by courteous waitstaff. 

After diner we hung around a bit for some mango and sticky rice and some wonderfully strong coffee. We would have loved to loiter some more but by 8pm or so there was a small line waiting for tables. I'll definitely be back if I'm in the area and in the mood for Thai!
author: Christina P.

description:
Reliable Thai food in SoMA. Appreciate the free prawn crackers they give to you ahead of every meal. Food is pretty speedy and there are some solid dishes on the menu - solid noodles, prawns with eggplant and basil, etc. 

Recommend also getting the coconut juice (with a couple of coconut pieces) and if you're still feeling like dessert - the roti. Great flaky pastry smothered in maple syrup with coconut ice cream.
author: Lisette P.

description:
I got take out from this restaurant and the food was delicious.
Pork and shrimp dumplings - good amount of meat and very tasty
Tofu and eggplant curry - very flavoursome and you can order the level of spiciness, medium was just about right but watch out for the jalapeños!

The website was easy to use and order and the delivery arrived within 30 mins.

Price wise - on the top end front but I didn't find it overpriced for the quality of the food.

All in all fab Friday night take out!
author: Laura C.

description: Came here last Friday for dinner. It was crazy busy so they seated me at the bar. I had a Thai iced tea with coconut milk, it was yummy. For dinner I had the tamarind prawns and substituted the roti bread for the rice. They ended up charging me extra for that, which they didn't tell me. The prawns were good. Paid $24 total and wasn't full. Service was lacking, but they were very busy. Don't think I'll be back.
author: Leopard S.

description: Good, better than a lot of Thai restaurants, not too much msg, not sleepy after eating the food.
author: Rose L.

description: Party of 9 adults went on a Friday night.  Good thing we had a reservation so we were seated right away.  Our server gave us ample time to review the menu.  We ordered family style the following items:  fried calamari, paupia sod, crab fried rice, pad thai, mu yang, neur yang, chicken curry, and a few beers.  We were given complimentary shrimp chips as we waited for the food to arrive.  Our server was very attentive.  He made sure our water glasses were periodically refilled.  He checked in on us a couple of times or so to ensure everything was okay.  I tried most of the food we ordered.  All of the dishes I tried were excellent.  The best part is we only spent less than $25 per head (including tip).
author: Janice T.

description:
So this place is good but not great. I had a craving for pad Thai. I had been traveling and went in early (5:45 pm). There were only a few other people in the restaurant. After being seated, I had to get up and ask if I could go ahead and order. (I had been at the table for at least five minutes while the wait staff stood by the bar and chatted.) When I asked if I could substitute snap peas for the tofu, I was told "no" without any sort of option. I asked if I could pay to have snap peas added and they complied. 

The portions are huge and the food was good. The shrimp were a bit overcooked and the sauce was a little sweeter than I like. They were happy to bring me lemons. Typically limes are provided with Thai food, but the lemons were fine. With a glass of wine, my dinner was $24 - a bit much for Thai.
author: S. L.

description:
It was a Sunday evening around 7:30P. My co-worker and I got hungry after a 6 hour coverage at The Do Over party. We weren't sure what to eat. I took it upon myself and search the closes enticing restaurant near us. Thai food only .7 mi away. Sold!

I navigated us there (w/ a few wrong turns of course LOL). We parked a block down the street on this cold evening (so glad I brought my leather jacket). The front looked classy and elegant with dark grey and the windows was lit dark orange and red. Already setting the relaxation mood before I even walk through the doors (so far, so good).

Once through the door, we were greeted by a young lady. "Two," we said and she seated us right away. The indoor was pretty modern; light walls, lamp fixtures, table spread and corner trims did not remind me of Thailand. I guess if it wasn't for the restaurant name, I would expect the place to serve sandwiches and steak (I like the chair though).

I can tell my co-worker was in an unfamiliar territory so I decided to take point on this. I mention that this may be served as family style restaurant and told him to order a dish and I will order one and we'll share it. He ordered a rib curry dish and I suggested that he order a side of brown rice to go with it. I ordered fried rice w/ shrimp and egg rolls to start with (sorry, I can't remember the name of the dished we ordered).

Our appetizer came out very quick. Although it was a veggie appetizer, it had full of flavor and almost didn't taste like we were eating lettuce at all (just thinking about it makes me drool). We took our time on those rolls and waited for our main course. A minute or so after we had our last bite, our main dishes came out. The rib / steak curry was delish. It was amazingly tender and well cooked and so much flavor. My fried rice hit the spot. So much flavor with every bite and the prawns were gi-normous. Plenty in one entree.

The final verdict: I definitely recommend this spot to everyone.
author: Cathy N.

description: Not the best ambiance or service, but the food is amazing and comes out quick. We had the stuffed eggplant and tamarind prawns, awesome. I've been coming here for over 10 years and never been disappointed.
author: Blake H.

description: Best Thai restaurant we have visited in SF.  Great service and of course food.  My wife is GF and they were right on top of that.  Had GF Larb...excellent, GF Bails' Eggplant and Fiery Lamb.  All outstanding and on top of that it was very reasonably priced.  Would highly recommendation and when we are back in SF in the fall, will definitely go again.
author: Richard K.

description: Decent Thai food, if kinda pricey. Good for a date, probably too expensive for takeout. The interior is really nice and the service is nice.
author: B H.

description:
My family came to Basil Thai to celebrate a special occasion. While the food was excellent, the service really put a damper on the overall dining experience. Since we were a group of 8, an automatic 18% gratuity was included in the bill. I have no problem with such being the case, especially since I usually tip higher than that for good service. However, our waitress was not friendly and actually seemed impatient and unpleasant. I don't know if she felt that she did not have to work for her tip due to the automatic gratuity. Whatever the reason, my entire party noticed her strange attitude. 

We tried multiple dishes throughout the meal and my favorites were the green curry squash and stuffed eggplant. Everything I sampled was good. My lease favorite dish of the meal was the "Fiery Lamb". The meat was overcooked and the dish lacked the promised heat. 

Lastly, the wine choices are really limited so consider bringing your own bottle (20$ corking fee). There is literally just one type of wine for each category. Their Pinot Gris was decent but the Pinot Noir was so awful, we had to send it back. 

I really enjoyed the food so I may return in hopes of getting a different server.
author: Nina M.

description:
Basil has a trendy SOMA vibe with fancy decor and well-dressed waitstaff. The restaurant is filled with young well-dressed people coming from work. 
The food is delicious. They bring you rice crackers to begin with, and then the entrees are flavorful and well balanced. I ordered the gai pik khing, which was a little fried, but had a good amount of veggies mixed in. My friend ordered pad se-ew, and that was also delicious. 

The menu is descriptive and well-organized, and the waitstaff is friendly and prompt. I don't normally talk about this in reviews, but the bathroom was actually really nice and clean.

The prices here are somewhat high, reflective of rising south of market rent. While I can get similar quality Thai food for lower prices elsewhere, the atmosphere and location make Basil worth it for me.
author: Allxie C.

description: Lovely spot. Delicious food, and great service. Had time to kill while waiting for traffic to die down. I would definitly go again.
author: Allegra B.

description: I came here for Friday night dinner. I had the pad see ew with tofu instead of pork. My friend had the steak and rice. Flavors of both dishes were great, only complaint was that the food was lukewarm and I enjoy my meals piping hot. We also had the corn fritters which were tasty but a little greasy. Cocktails were excellent - great flavors and not too sweet. Will definitely come here again as the menu is extensive and I saw lots of items I wanted to try.
author: Katie G.

description: Really solid Thai place - generous portions, enough ambiance for both casual/intimate scenarios, and efficient/attentive service. I rarely ever get the pad thai at a Thai restaurant (because it just seems so vanilla), but here, it is worth ordering. I think I've found my new Thai takeout spot!
author: Diana K.

description:
Good decor very comfortable and nice, but the food was mediocre.

Went here on a Sunday night when I was in town for a conference. I ordered the roast duck with snap peas. Pretty standard meal, more sweet sauce than I prefer but otherwise okay. The only thing was the price was a bit high. I think they were charging for decor, the place was fairly nice. The service was standard not friendly, but good.
author: Travis K.

description: Yummy food and attentive service. Loved my salmon in curry and my husband raved about his pineapple rice with shrimp. Would definitely come back!
author: Susan O.

description: Good food and good seasoning.  Seating for our large group was a little tight because we were in a booth where one side was a long bench and it was a squeeze getting in there.  But the food was quite good and tasty.  We would definitely go back.
author: James W.

description: Suuuuuper yummy! Asked for spicy & they gave it to me! Didnt leave with that MSG headache, everything tasted freshhhh.
author: Tawny S.

description: My husband and I used to eat here when we lived in the city about 8 years ago. It's easy to find good Thai food in SF but this one was definitely one of our favorites. We just went back during a visit to the city and it was every bit as good as we remembered. The food was WONDERFUL, atmosphere very good and the service was great. Glad it still is what we knew it to be!
author: May S.

description:
Cute little restaurant! Was able to accommodate same day rezzies for two on a Friday night. Had the Grilled Salmon filet and Pad Thai...both very yummy. Servers were super friendly and attentive. 

Tip: Don't forget to pair your dinner with a large sake! ;)
author: TuUyen L.

description:
The ambiance is fancy, the food expensive.

Came here for lunch with co-workers, ordered the pad kee mao w/ tofu no eggs. When it came out it was loaded with eggs. They apologized and took it away immediately. The second time it came, the noodles were much lighter, meaning they used a lot less sauces in creating the dish. The noodles were really mushy and, as expected, the flavors were extremely mild and boring.

My co-worker ordered the tom yum and I could smell the fish sauce from across the table. Gross.

Another co-worker ordered the turnip cake, he said it was good. He had to ask twice for a side of brown rice and it didn't come until we were almost done with our meal. They weren't very busy either.
author: Camille R.

description: $17 for pad thai noodles for lunch?! The food is good, but I can't spend this kind of money all the time.
author: Erica H.

description: This is solid 4 star restaurant. If you are staying in the civic center area it is easy to get to. The location in and around the restaurant was clean considering other areas nearby was not. We skipped lunch so we decided to have an early dinner and arrived when they opened at 5:30. We were the first to arrive but shortly after the restaurant began to fill up. It's a small restaurant with simple décor. The servers were very friendly. For drinks we tried the ginger drop which is great if you like very tart drinks. We also tried the mango cosmopolitan, which was sweet and fruity. It was also very good. The food was served hot and came in large portions. We shared an order of spring rolls and crab fried rice. They were both very good but the crab fried rice was better than any I have had before.
author: Dona W.

description:
3rd time's the charm I guess. Love everything about the dinner tonight. We had 7 family members, two celebrating birthdays and we were given the gamut of their truly terrific desserts. 

There was not a miss to be had in the 7 dishes, 3 appetizers, and 5 desserts (OK maybe the BBQ chicken could have been a little moister and watch out for the extra spicy-hot mushroom side that accompanies the steak -- minor nit-picks in an otherwise sterling meal).

This has now become our favorite Thai restaurant in the Bay Area.
author: Glenn H.

description: Really nice place. Went there for a business lunch and was pleasantly surprised by how nice this place was. My last few experiences with Thai food in SF have been mediocre at best, so this one was a gem. I tried the basil eggplant and tofu- was awesome, could have been a bit more spicy, but really good flavors. Will definitely check it out again next time I am in the city
author: Charu M.

description:
I've visited Basil Thai several times now, each time enjoying the food and the price.

There's not too many places that offer fare for $10, and both the pad thai and the tom kha gai fit the bill, are flavorful, and lose nothing being ordered to go.

My only quibble are appetizers about the same price as the main courses, but that's a general issue at many restaurants.

I happily recommend Basil Thai to you.
author: Michael S.

description: A full on medium, but they give you gluten free options, pad thai was decent, and they do have gluten free omission (my fave) even if it is old and skunked.
author: Viv R.

description:
Let me start off by saying this place would've gotten 4 stars, but the host definitely knocked off a star. 

I get it.. party of six, it'd be better to make reservations, but this dinner was last minute. As we walked by the window, there were two girls cleaning the table, eyeing us down probably hoping we wouldn't come in. To their delight, we decided to eat there. Told them we had six in our party, asked if we had a reservation and after we told her we didn't, she rolled her eyes. Ruuuuuddeee! 

We ended up only having to wait 5 minutes for a table, and everything after that was great. 

- Goong Gra Bog (Crispy wrapped whole tiger prawns) - Great appetizer. Crunchy and piping hot when it gets to you. Keep the sweet chili vinaigrette for dipping sauce! 

- Pad see-ew - Most good Thai restaurants can't get this dish wrong. The sauce wasn't overwhelmingly salty either. 

- Neur Yang (Grilled angus sirloin) - SO. GOOD. Although I do have to say that the smoked mushroom and tomato relish is not pleasing to the eye, it is definitely pleasing to the palette! 

All in all, yes, I would return during a visit to SF.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
Cute restaurant. But, service wasn't the best and the food wasn't either. Pad se ew was the lightest, least stir fried and egg dish I've had before. My friends pad Thai looked okay too. 

There is a $15 min for dinner time. Which isn't hard to make if you get an entree with a drink. 

Dinner was definitely enjoyable with my friends but it wasn't the best Thai ive had nor service. 

Tip: maybe try to curry.
author: Amanda C.

description: The restaersunt service was slow. But the food was good. Most of the waitresses barely understand anything it was meh.
author: Klarissa J.

description:
I read all of the reviews and this place was recommended to me by others and I thought, ALRIGHT! I walked more than a mile to get there, passing other joints up so I could eat here. 

And it was meh. So very meh. 

Everything was bland. My wine (pinot gris from Oregon) was bland and unforgettable and so was my basil pumpkin dish - and overpriced. I paid nearly 13$ for a dish that was a few tablespoons of veggies and a 1/2 cup of rice. And many of the veggies were only lukewarm. I thought it was supposed to be spicy, but there was only a hint of spicy. The rice though, was great. 

Contrary to what others have said, I found the folks in there friendly enough, but the food was run of the mill. If I am going to pay that much for lunch, it should be spectacular.
author: Kim S.

description:
If you're a fan of Thai in SF this is a much better option than Osha. Especially if you want your moneys worth of food. The individual order portions commonly feed 2, but ok enough for one if you are very hungry. It's also a safe place to take a friend who requires a Gluten Free menu.

I've been consistently coming here for over a year and the food remains that way. My usual go-to favorites are...

Tom Ka Gai - Chicken and oyster mushrooms in lemongrass, galanga, and coconut milk soup.

Gai Pik Khing - Crispy sliced chicken, string beans, and peppers stir-fried with sweet & spicy 'pik-khing' curry. It's your typical delicious basil thai signature dish.

Kao Pad Sapparot - Thai pineapple fried rice with prawns and cashew nuts.
author: Terry C.

description: The best Thai restaurant I've been to in San Francisco. My go to is the pad see ew and if you get it here you won't be disappointed. The noodle to sauce ratio is perfect and they give you a large portion size.
author: Laura H.

description:
Lunch time wait staff is courteous, quick, and attentive. 
Servings are large. 
The restaurant looks/feels nicer than your average Thai restaurant. 

Definitely a winner in this neighborhood.
author: Jane N.

description:
Hell yes!  A little warning though. The last time I had thai food before this was a DISASTER. This place is delicious. Definitely worth the money. I have eaten a lot of thai food. Thai lovers will not be disappointed. I'm overly emphatic about it and I'm sure there's better Thai, but my mood this day gives it 5 stars.

Ordered the Pad Ke Mao, Shrimp/Scallop bbq dish; which is actually a delicious curry. Also ordered the spring rolls, perfect. Their drinks are not bad, but not the best. They are the value of what you are spending though. Seems like a great date spot or business lunch/dinner place.

Also, across the street was this unusual beer store that I really want to go to next time I'm in SF.
author: Ronjini M.

description:
A great lunch spot in Soma. I tried the fiery lamb with a fried egg and really enjoyed it. The entire menu looked great and I expect it's hard to go wrong there. Nice, helpful staff and a comfortable interior that isn't too noisy.

The space can fill up very quickly, but you can always get a table at 11:30 when they open.
author: Andrew H.

description: Stupendous food. The cuts of meat used are second to none. Total attention to detail. Each meal was vibrant, fresh and perfected. A true treat!
author: Michael C.

description: The food is fine and yummy enough. The actual restaurant layout is warm, comfortable, and fine. The only reason why I am giving Basil two stars is because our table was surrounded by flies. It was disgusting, and they were everywhere. We couldn't help but swat at them. We ended up surrounded by a fly graveyard by the end of our meal. We found it difficult to eat. I won't return.
author: Mary M.

description:
We discovered this spot a few months ago and have been back a number of times because Thai food is comforting and because the dishes here are flavorful and the menu has variety without being vast and overwhelming.

It can get a bit pricey when you order seafood dishes but the service is decent, the place itself is nice and you're likely to find street parking if you come on weekend evenings!

Many people here seem to come and enjoy drinks with friends but it can also be a place to enjoy a cozy date night if you come on Sunday evenings.
author: Cynthia L.

description: REALLY GOOD. Portion are big. If you are eating there they had a $15 per person min but 3 dishes for 2 people is really too much food and you will have left overs. I liked the shrimp chips they had for you to snack on while you are waiting for the rest of the food to come (fast service). We had the pad kee mao, eggplant stuffed with chicken, and oriental broccoli and house-cured crispy pork belly wok-fried. Everything was really good and the portions were very big.  I would def go again!
author: Lily P.

description:
Their Spicy Pad Thai was really good!!

Panang Beef Short Ribs (Braised Boneless Beef) Curry was awesome!

Their Pad See Ew was not very good...the menu says that it comes out spicy, but the Pad Thai was spicier than it. Also, the noodles were a little over-cooked, and overall the plate did not equate to anything special.
author: Michael K.

description:
Is a pretty decent spot for food. I came with a small group of friends...which promotes lots of tasting. Yummy. =) I want to note that I was still kind of full from a late lunch, so I was eating cause I knew it was dinner time...but was utterly STUFFED after!!

What we had:

Pineapple Fried Rice: Really yummy. Prawn...cashews...yummy.
Pad Kee Mao: Really well seasoned, and stir fried well. 
Lamb Skewer: Delicious. It comes with a peanut sauce. The meat was tender...soo good.
Pork Skewer: Also quite tender. Came with a spicy sauce that was delicious.
Duck Curry Puff: Wasn't as impressed with this one. It had a bit of a greasy outside, and just tasted like a meaty samosa. 
Pork shoulder curry: Delicious. meat was quite tender.
Sparerib Curry: Delicious, and also had tender meat. Is good.

Service was really great, and prompt. They were really nice and friendly!
author: Lily W.

description:
Less one star because of the poor quality of tea that they server in the restaurant. We were both recovering from cough that day and preferred to have tea. Water was not hot enough and the tea bags were...  

Less one star because of the serious faces on the employees' faces. Don't get me wrong. The service was attentive, but from the hostess to the servers, they all look serious. Unless the employees are not happy at work, otherwise, have fun and enjoy yourself too. Maybe the leadership should do something about it. 

The food we had were good but not over the top.
author: Lianna D.

description: The food was good, but the service was amazing!  I did not get the name of my server but the entire staff from busboy to servers were on top of it.  I really appreciate good service. Thank you!
author: Celia G.

description: This was the perfect spot to celebrate my birthday.  The food was excellent, the Thai Iced tea with Coconut milk was divine.  All my party guests loved their food.  And it just happens to be right across the street from the dance club I frequent.  All in all the perfect start to a lovely evening.
author: Erin S.

description:
Yummy, the service and the food was good. We got their crab fried rice, beef curry and some other curry I don't quite remember. The beef was good but I was scared. It was a bit too spicy although it was labeled as Mild.

Good food, very flavorful spices, 4 stars cause they may need to tone down the spicyness, but thats just my preference.
author: Mia L.

description: Called to order to go. I waited around 5-7 minutes on hold. Then hung up and redialed but the line was busy. Tried few more times but no luck. Sadly I was forgotten on hold. Then I was looking at yelp to see if they have another phone # and saw yelp's warning of their Health Score of 54. Ouch! I loved your food but sorry never coming back... Very sad
author: Burak B.

description: Great place! Husband and I had a little lunch date there were there and enjoyed the food and service very much. It get's a little noisy once the place fills up but we arrived early so from 11.30am - 12pm it's still quiet and great to have a conversation while eating.
author: Sunny F.

description: In 2011, we decided to visit CA and were both introduced to our first Thai food experience by my daughter and her fiancée. We ate lunch there and I found my lunch extremely pleasing as did my future wife.  I had a pork dish called Mu Yang that was very tasty with just the right amount of heat.  We have only had Thai food a few times since mainly because my wife does not do hot food ever.  My regret is that I have yet to find any variation of Mu Yang at any other Thai restaurant.  I guess we just have to make a future trip back to San Fran someday!  Hey Zagat and I agree on this one!
author: Thomas B.

description: Great place and the food was amazing. A lot of locals go there, and we will definitely be back.
author: Robert F.

description:
I called in an hour before I wanted to eat and was able to get a reservation for two. 
I ordered a noodle entrée off the menu that sounded tasty and had "flank steak" in it, and was met with a heaping plate full of tender meat. 
I guess I've become accustomed to cheaper Thai places where you get 2/3 noodles 1/3 crappy, gristly beef, but this was 2/3 high quality, moist meat, 1/3 noodle.
Great flavor, too!!
Also, on the menu there is a "$15 per person during dinner hours" rule, but they didn't enforce it for us. I had a friend who had eaten already just meet me there for a beer.
author: D C.

description: We do takeout or delivery from this place very often. The ambiance at the restaurant is great as well. I have been meaning to swing by and eat at the restaurant itself. The food is absolutely delish. I knocked a star down because the service is incredibly slow. It starts when you call to place the order on the phone. You have to be on hold for a while. And then when u show up to pick up the food 35 minutes later as they ask you to, they still make you wait another 15 minutes.
author: Shehrose R.

description:
The best thai restaurant for food and value in the city. For their prices ($10-15/entree on average) - it's a steal. Upscale environment, extensive menu (not just the random pad thais - but real thai specialties), and friendly service with corkage (bring your own wine).

I have actually eaten at this restaurant almost 500 times - we used to take everyone we interviewed here for dinner.

Corkage is $20.

The best dishes according to my coworkers and myself.
With Meat:
- Curry Peppercorn Duck
- Coconut braised pork shoulder
- Penang Short Ribs
- Basil's Lamb
- Pad Kee Mao

Vegetarian:
- Brussel Sprouts
- Garlic Cauliflower
- Pineapple Fried Rice
- Tom Yum Kha soup (vegetarian)

Good apps/sides/dessert:
- Thai style omelette (amazing spicy sauce that comes with it)
- Veggie Spring Rolls (fresh rolls)
- Roti Itim (fried bread with coconut ice cream)
author: Vivek S.

description: One of the best In town. Had the Pad Thai and Brussels.  Great Cosmo too. They have high marks for a reason. This place is great.
author: Laura G.

description:
corkage fee for wine and beer (!) is $7 per bottle so keep that in mind if you want to grab a brew from city beer across the street. 

...........thai spiced corn fritters........
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Another comfort spot for amazing Thai food in the city. Great spot, great service. Their salad portion is slightly small but is yummy! 

Their appetizers were very interesting and refreshing. The entree (curry and Pad Thai) were great but not unique.
author: Raj S.

description:
Cute little modern restuarant we walked into randomly since we were near by. I had my doubts at first cause all my favorite Thai places look more like delapitated hole in the walls. But this place pleasantly surprised me! They have a limited menu with less items then I'm typicall use to seeing at Thai places but they have the typical favorites - pad thai, pad see ew, curries and soups/salads. They bring out a little dish of shrimp chips once you order which was nice and appreciated. I don't think they make it in house though, it was similar to the store bought ones. We ordered:

Pad Thai - I got the spicy version and it was good! Spicy and flavorful. Good amounts of fresh shrimp and tofu. The sauce covered everything to perfection and it was really delicious. The noodles were really al dente though so if that bothers you ask them to cook your noodles more well done. I didn't have a problem since I like more of a chew to my noodles.

Pad See Mao - Beef dish similar to pad see ew. More sweet than the pad thai with a slight spice. Loved the basil flavoring on this dish and it was a nice compliment to the spicer more intense pad thai. The noodles on this dish was very well done.

Service is attentive and portions are pretty generous. I took half my pad thai home for lunch the next day. Overall a good go to thai place if I'm ever in the area.


EDIT: I just heated up my leftoever and found a toothpick in the dish - which I DID NOT USE and had no where near the table. This is disgusting and I have no idea how it got into my dish or if it was already in there since I did not box up the leftovers myself. I don't think I will be returning anymore..
author: Vivian K.

description:
It was a dark and stormy night...fortunately, it ended with dinner at Basil Thai. Otherwise, it would've been a major disaster. Cold and rainy weather meant getting around in traffic at night was a PITA. Finding a decent place for dinner on Saturday could've caused more migraine were it not for my trusty Yelp app. A quick search in the immediate vicinity yielded Basil Thai so there we went.

Parking was tough as usual but we lucked out on side street that no one seemed to know about couple of blocks down the street. Once we get there, there's no line. More good news. Inside is nice and dimly lit.

Being ravenous, we scan the menu and crab fried rice and spicy crispy catfish were the 2 that came into focus. Thai restaurant menus can get tiresome with the usual gamut of green curries, pad thai, tom yum, etc. While Basil Thai doesn't have the most unique name, they do have interesting and different items on the menu. Check it out in the link above. 

Crab fried rice had shredded crab and not overly greasy or salty as fried rice tends to be. Next is the crispy catfish that was quite robust tasting with kaffir leaves adding some limey freshness, ginger with it's earthy notes and spicy kick from the curry powder. Not over powering in heat and quite mild actually.

All in, a great find and made more so on a cold, stormy winter night. The story continues...
author: Norman S.

description:
Recently moved close by so decided to try this place after reading some Yelp reviews. I was not disappointed at all. We ordered the tofu pad ke mao and what seemed to me as red curry with vegetables. 

Pad ke mao: the flavors were there and tasty but the spice level was a little too less for me personally. 

Red curry: very different from most I've had - thicker and very flavorful. I really enjoyed this dish and we decided to get an order of roti on the side and used the red curry as dipping sauce. Would definitely recommend doing that if you like the Thai roti.

The menu was very large and I wanted to try a lot more dishes so I'll be back again!
author: Malika R.

description:
Lunch time night club

No music just humans yelling over each other 
Not a great place to hold a conversation over lunch.
author: Danni C.

description:
Good Thai food, but pricey for what is essentially rice and noodles (#12~ for a pineapple fried rice, ~$11 for a paid thai). I suppose part of the higher markup is because of its location in San Francisco...

They don't give a lot of meat in either the rice or noodle dishes. I ordered take-out from here once and it took a long time to get our food. The employee quoted a 15 minute wait, but it was more like 30+ minutes - slightly irksome, but not a deal breaker, since we were in a rush.
author: Mina K.

description:
This is my favorite Thai place now. Some good unique dishes. Chicken stuffed eggplant. Top quality. Good beers on tap.

Sort of trendy. Plenty of space. Just across from city beer store.
author: Brian L.

description:
First off I was impressed with the cleanliness of the bathrooms, especially being an Asian establishment.  I expected piss on the floor, rusty plumbing, no soap, and no paper towels.  It was cool.

We ordered the Pad Talay Ruammi, Kao Pad Sapparot, and the Pad Ke Mao.  I'm pretty boring in that when I go Thai, I like basil, garlic, and chiles in pretty much all my dishes.  Everything was pretty flavorful, yet not too overpowering and salty.  I was surprised to find the Sapparot was not served in a carved out pineapple as it traditionally is.  The Pad Talay had this really yummy sauce, but I couldn't get over the fact that the calamari looked so much like a rolled up condom.

Ok, so dinner was good.  When the check came, I got annoyed that the tip guide at the bottom of the receipt was calculated POST tax which is very misleading.  That's not cool in my book.  Not sure if they're breaking any laws, but it's certainly a bitch move on their part.  ALWAYS review your receipt people and do your own calculation!
author: Alex L.

description:
So I checked out Basil Thai in the city yesterday with a couple friends and this place is great! Love the atmosphere of the restaurant and the food was delicious!

We ordered a couple drinks to start, a basil drink, mint mojitos and thai iced tea and were all happy with what we got. 

For appetizers, we got the fresh rolls with vegetables and tofu. And they brought out shrimp chips while we waited for our main entrees. Yum!

For dinner, we went family style and ordered pad see ew, basil's eggplant, and a basil curry with beef. Word to the wise, some of their food is super spicy! Ask for it mild if you're not ready for spicy curry!
author: Heather J.

description:
I have ordered takeout from this place a few times and have been pleasantly surprised .  Each item I have ordered has been carefully prepared and the spices were perfect.  The spicy skirt steak and prik king have been excellent.  

The place gets pretty busy so I would recommend planning ahead if you are dining in.
author: Andrew V.

description:
Came here with a couple of coworkers on a Friday evening before sunset. It was busy but not crowded, so we sat right down. The three of us were seated along a wall of translucent glass bricks on the west side, which created a really nice glow from the wandering sun. +1 for Feng Shui.

We decided to eat family style, ordering the crab fried rice, the eggplant and shitake, and the roast red duck curry. Everything was quite delicious, and shareworthy between three hungry guys. Eggplant and shitake were firm and flavorful, the crab fried rice was filling, and the duck only seemed a bit dry, but was the curry was seasoned well.

I usually don't get dessert but I noticed they had sticky cocoanut rice and mango, so I indulged. No complaints here -- a large helping of the chewy, sweet, cocoanutty goodness. Would definitely order dessert again.

Also +1 for location -- we wandered into city beer across the street, open just long enough for a few drinks.
author: Christophe C.

description:
Awesome thai restaurant - and my girlfriend and I are very particular about our thai food. We will be coming back here for sure.

Food - 4.5/5 - food was amazing, probably one of the best and most authentic thai places I've been to
Ambience - 4.5/5 - modern and comfortable - clean to boot
Service - 3/5 - a bit lacking in terms of friendliness, but very attentive
Price - 4/5 - very reasonable with most entrees under $15, dessert at $7.50. Thai tea with coconut milk was a bit pricey at $4 though, regular thai tea is $3.50

Restaurant is located in a seedy part of SoMa but the inside is modern and inviting, great for a date. Also has a nice bar with TV.

The food:
Unlimited complimentary fried prawn crackers ... A nice touch and differentiator. Could not stop eating them.

My girlfriend and I started off with some thai tea with coconut milk, which was unique and a refreshing change from the typical thai tea. Tastes exactly like the name would imply, and I enjoyed it. There's 

We had the roti appetizer, which was excellent. Expected the bread to be more pan fried, but it was crispy and more on the side of deep fried, which was delicious. Curry and toppings were well flavored and very complementary.

So, I've been hunting down a place with great thai beef salad for almost 3 years now in both Boston and SF, and all the places we travel to. This is by far the best thai beef salad, and for sure, I will come back for it. Spice level is a bit too much for me, you'll definitely feel the burn after eating it for awhile.

For entree, we had the pad kemao and the prawns dish (forgot the exact name, but it was second from the top of the seafood list). Pad kemao was done well, but it was average and nothing to write home about. The prawn dish on the other hand was amazing. Definitely recommend it.
