The seafood curry was good, but pretty similar to what I've had at other Thai restaurants. What set it apart was the fact that they made it milder than I've ever been able to get other places do - big thumbs up as we weren't in a spicy mood, so to speak. The scallops were done to perfection - not too flaky, but not too mushy, either. Much unlike any other Thai seafood curry I've had, the shrimp were actually still moist in the middle - most other places dry them out too much. The mussels were excellent, too. 

Now, Thai iced tea... I'd never tried it before going to Basil Thai, but my friend ordered one and we shared it to start out. If you don't like tea, Thai iced tea is NOT for you. It has a very strong Chai flavor, and the tea is sweetened (a lot) and then mixed with cream. The server explained that they buy a special Thai iced tea mix, so they do not make it themselves. However, it was very good and my friend said it was better than others she'd had.

Aside from the price - and it's not cheap, as we didn't get out under $50 after tip - this place is excellent. Very trendy, very modern inside, and great service. Definitely would go back, as it was one of the best dining experiences I'd had in a while.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I'm weird because I have last minute cravings for every meal and can't decide in advance what to eat. If I locate what I'm craving but it wasn't tasty, then I have a craving void that will force me to seek out suitable alternates for an indefinite amount of time - which could be hours, or days, or weeks *gasp*. Sometimes, if I can't find what I'm craving, I just drink a glass of milk and call it a meal. Aaaanyway...

All week I've been on a pizza kick and suddenly, at 1:30pm, I NEEDED some Thai food. Being new to the city, and not having figured out how this public transportation business works yet (I'm from Atlanta), I searched Yelp for a Thai place that would be walking distance from me. Up comes Basil Thai at only a quarter of a mile away with fantastic reviews. And oh lookie, they're still open for another hour!

I call and order a small chicken coconut soup ($5), pad thai ($9), and mango with sticky rice ($6). Yes, I know. When I'm hungry, I'm really hungry.

I arrive 20 minutes later and they already have my order waiting for me (and judging by the way my pad thai was stuck together, it was probably ready for me 10 minutes after I called).

All in all, freakin' delicious pad thai and tasty soup - both good sized portions too. The sticky rice and mango dessert, on the other hand, was quite small for how much it cost and the white goo/sauce that goes on top of it was...salty?! I've had this at least a half dozen times before from other places and don't remember it being salty. Is it supposed to be and I just never noticed or is this a mistake? The mango itself was really sweet and the rice was super sticky and good but I unknowingly poured the sauce over both and ruined everything =( It's a disappointing way to end a meal but I definitely pwned that Thai craving of mine. Win.
author: Amaryllia L.

description: I had the pad-se-ew which was really good! The service was on point and the prices are great.
author: Noel W.

description:
I stumbled into this place after spending all day in a nearby studio.  I was starving and looking for somewhere to satisfy my hunger.  The ambiance of Basil Thai was very simple, yet elegant.  

After sitting down, our server brought us shrimp chips.  Being famished, we quickly devoured them and asked for more, which the server reluctantly brought to our table.  Service overall was adequate, nothing spectacular.  I had to request a refill for water a few times and when I asked for boxes to go, they didn't bring a bag as well.

We ordered Pad Ke Mao, Jungle Beef, and Gai Kra-Pow - extra hot.

Everything was delicious and well seasoned.  The noodles in the Pad Ke Mao were just right - not too thick and not too thin.  The Jungle Beef was the best dish of the bunch.  Even though it wasn't spicy at first, the spicyness crept up on us.  The Gai Kra-Pow was also well done.  Everything was delicious.  If your looking for great Thai food in the area, I would highly recommend Basil Thai.

They also had a dessert menu which looked wonderfully delicious, but I was already full. I took a picture and posted it so you can check it out yourself.
author: Aurora L.

description: I usually like coming here for good and affordable thai food, but this time I had a less pleasant experience. We got a big table at the back of the restaurant, which was unexpectedly freezing. The waitress showed absolutely no intention to improve our condition, and half of the table had to sit wearing winter jackets. After the second complaint we suggested she could provide us with complimentary hot tea, since it is impossible to heat up the back of the restaurant, which was welcomed with a blunt refusal. This made us feel unwelcome and significantly lowered our dining experience. I hope the restaurant will invest in their employee training/customer care before losing their guests.
author: Marina R.

description:
I was impressed by the prompt service as well as the cleanliness of the men's bathroom. I've been here in the past, and it seems as if the management has taken the extra step in ensuring prompt service...there has been quite an improvement thus far.

I had the Nuer Takai with brown rice; it was very tasty, the steak was cooked to absolute perfection. I had the Flora Spring, Merlot 07 (Napa Valley) with my meal-the Merlot was perfect and TASTY. If you are in the neighborhood...try out this Merlot, I'm sure you will enjoy it as it is buttery and smooth in taste.
author: Darrel D.

description:
Held a small New Year's Eve dinner for eight with a reservation, and they were nice about our delay in reservation time. (Reservation at 7, sat down at 8.) Ambiance was nice, with a sort of modern elegance. Small but cozy restaurant with subtle overcast lighting. 

Unfortunately, we were served beautifully plated, mediocre Thai food. Service was spot on the entire night, constantly filling our water for us and making sure our finished plates were taken away. With so much potential and so much going for Basil Thai, it's sad to say that such a promising establishment falls flat on the most important aspect of a restaurant: the food.

I had the Basil Eggplant ($9.00) and a side of brown rice ($2.00) but my friend accidentally ordered the pad thai ($10.00), which was not vegetarian, so we had a switch. They give more shrimp than usual, which is a plus if you enjoy seafood, but their bean sprouts were limp, and the noodles were not even equivalent to that of King of Thai. The bite of what I had previously ordered was bland, and the brown rice was overcooked.
Another friend had a platter of homemade red velvet cupcakes to share, but the servers quickly mentioned a $1.50 per person cake cutting fee for...cupcakes. To avoid any more extra fees (18% tax for 6+ groups) we refrained from eating the cupcakes until we left.

If not for the service and atmosphere, I might have given this place two stars.
author: Colleen M.

description:
larb is bomb.
stuffed eggplant in green curry sauce is the truth.

don't even mess..this place is great.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
Wonderful decor and service at this SOMA gem. The chips have a slight hint of shrimp flavor. They do great at servicing last minute medium size parties and are always willing to assist you with the menu. 

I had the green curry and vegetables dish with rice this time and the service throughout the last three years has not diminished. The food is always fresh. For appetizer try the croquettes. Street parking is available right outside. The only down side is not too many dishes for vegetarians as much as I would hope for. Other than that, great food.
author: Carolina S.

description: Terrible food. They have not improved all these years. I had the pad thai and it was drenched in sauce as if they had poured the whole bottle of pad thai sauce onto the noodles. Worse than mall food. They really don't know how to cook.  I ate here many years ago and they were just as bad. Never again.
author: Apple M.

description: This is one of my go-to Thai restaurants. They're a bit more pricey than your average Thai restaurants, but it's also a lot nicer. Their menu is great and very different than your generic Thai menus. I believe they still have your standard Pad Thai dishes, but there are so many other more exciting things to try on the menu. I have eaten just about everything on the menu, and I don't think I've ever had anything I didn't like.
author: H. L.

description: I have been here 3 times.  The first time it was just okay, the second time it was amazing and the third visit it was nearly inedible.  For example, a week ago I had their eggplant salad and fell in love with it.  I went there again tonight after craving it all week.  When I got it,  I saw immediately that it was different.  I was hopeful that the flavors would be the same, but I was disappointed.  It was just plain sloppy...the eggplant was the most undercooked I've ever had in my life and my shrimp had bits of shell left on them!  Worse yet, I let the waitress know it was not the same and that it was undercooked and she did nothing.
author: Kelly M.

description:
I used to work near here and was fortunate enough to be able to have multiple work lunches here. The food is absolutely amazing. Everything is made with quality ingredients and flavored to perfection. 

 Yum Makuer - grilled Asian eggplant, minced prawns, chicken served with lime, coconut cream dressing (Absolutely DELICIOUS!)

 Som Tum - green papaya salad tossed with ground peanuts, lime, garlic, and tomatoes  (YUM)

 Basil's Lamb - grilled marinated lamb served with corn and ginger-soy sauce  (SO tender and absolutely perfect!)

Param Rungsong  - grilled marinated skirt steak topped with peanut sauce  (Can be a little tough so request rarer then you would normally have, but pretty good.)

My absolute favorites are almost ALL the curries. I've had almost all of them and they are all delicious. They have wonderful combinations of curries and I always order the sticky rice with it. 

The atmosphere is really nice and cozy. A little pricey compared to the large population of Thai in the area but well worth the taste.
author: Natasha S.

description:
I come from Socal.  A land with many things. A land with a restaurant called Thai Basil. A land where I go to Thai Basil all the time at lunch for work, since it's nearby. A land where I really enjoy Thai Basil.

I visit Norcal. A land with many things. A land with a restaurant called Basil Thai. I guess north is south and south is north here in Norcal, they switched the order of the Thai and Basil. Anyway, in this land, I really enjoyed the restaurant as well. Service was super good. In this land I ordered Eggplant and Noodles, and in this land that Eggplant was some of the best Eggplant I've ever had at a Thai Place! Would get the same dish in this land if I were to go back to SF. Really loved that dish, in this land. 

Okay am I getting repetitive? I started with a theme and I'm sticking with it. Either way love this place. Restaurant has a good atmosphere too, the lighting is perfect - it's not one of those places that tries to have nice atmosphere by letting you experience what the characters in Pitch Black felt when they experience their double sun eclipse. A lot of restaurants do that, but not this one, lighting is just enough and I appreciate that out of an atmospheric, romantic type of restaurant.

Enjoy the place!
author: Edrees H.

description: Meeting friends over at The Arc on Saturday night. Came over to the city from San Leandro. Thought to come early, find the place and scope out the parking situation to return for the 9oclock show. Found it. Pulled over and asked the Audi to give all Thai restaurants in the area. Guess what popped up!!??  It was within walking distance. We parked and walked there. Best decision we have made in a long time. Wowzers!! Since we had never been there we made the decision to order something we wouldnt normally eat. We ordered the fish cakes and scallops for apps. Amazing!!! We each had three martinis...the mango, the ginger and the basil. Heavenly!! Our server was fantasic!! For entree we ordered the shrimp and eggplant and my bestie had the beef with peanut sauce. Totally the best dining experience on accident EVER. We will definitely be back with more of our girlfriends for our monthly girls night. Awesome service, food and ambiance. Love this place!!
author: Kimberley M.

description:
If you are a fan of spice head on over. 

I was absolutely blown away. We randomly walked in on a recent rainy night and the spices and flavored cured any concerns of the weather like a home-cooked meal. 

Go for the Southern Pork Shoulder! 
I can't wait to go back.
author: Jennavive P.

description:
I'm always happy for a sub $10 meal in SF.

I tried the Pad See Ew last night after some drinks at Bloodhound down the street and enjoyed my meal. 

The food wasn't amazing but was very tasty and the portions were generous for the price. 

The decor is nice and modern and I was happy they were open pretty late for a Tuesday night. 

I'd go back if I was in the neighborhood. 

They were VERY prompt about refilling my water which I always enjoy.
author: Carlos A.

description:
The food was delicious..and that's not coming from just me but 15 other people as well.  I was worried about having dinner for such a large group somewhere in SF with reasonable prices given that most places aren't that big, but they made it super easy!   I called 2 days before to make reservations and it was suggested that we put in our orders so everyone could get their food at the same time.  Given such a large group, they gave me the option to have a standard meal, but with allergies, pickiness, and my personal preference of letting people get what they want, I opted to place people orders early.  The majority of my group placed their order, but the remaining folks ordered at the restaurant.

The day of the dinner, I called to let them know my party was running a few minutes behind but they simply thank'd me for letting them know and they were OK with us getting there 30 minutes later.  We arrived a bit after 7 on a Friday and it wasn't crowded at all.  We ordered drinks and the last of the food orders, and everyone had their food in 30-45 minutes.  Very impressive!  Ordering ahead was definitely the thing to do.  Everyone loved the food, many asked how I found the place so I only have Yelp to thank for that.  

I had the Roti and Stir-fried garlic noodle with prawns, mussels, squid and fresh basil  (seafood bamee)..the noodles were quite spicy (I'm kind of a wuss when it comes to spicy food) but it was so tasty I didn't let the spiciness phase me..just drank lots of water.  We were there until almost 9 and the crowd definitely picked up by then. So if you want some good thai food and don't want to wait on a Friday, go earlier in the evening, but even if you go later, the food is worth the wait.
author: Nicole J.

description: Where do I begin to rant about this place? Well, I NEVER give anything the honor of 5 stars but there is nothing negative about this place. The food was outstanding, the flavors were mind blowing and the options were endless. You want noodles? got it. Curry? got 12 of those. Soup? 7 choices! And may I add, FULL bar! I forked out 25$ for dinner! NOW that is rare in this city! The decor and servers were sweet and fresh off the boat, perfect touch. Trust me, I can go on, but you get the point.
author: Sara N.

description:
Basil Thai gets 5 stars all around in my book! 

Celebrated my 26th birthday here a couple months ago with 20 of my closest friends and I was nothing less than impressed with the attentive service, glorious food, and chic ambience of this Zagat rated local jewel. 

I have a few diet restrictions given my current health condition that absolutely prohibit me from eating high doses of iodine (aka sea salt, fish, and tofu). Then why the heck would I have my birthday at a THAI RESTAURANT, right? Well, I figured it was my birthday and I'd give myself a little taste for one day...and oh boy...I am SO glad I chose to bend the rules with Basil Thai. Brown rice all around for my pre fixed birthday menu, no tofu in the pad Thai, and light on the fish sauce. The event coordinator and servers did everything they possibly could to make my birthday dinner a success! 

As for location, I love how this place is tucked away on a tiny street corner on Folsom hidden from the usual eateries in the SOMA; it makes dining here THAT much more special and exciting ;).

I love this place and I am definitely coming back. If u are looking for a more intimate birthday dinner (that can still accommodate fairly large parties) with great food, a full bar, perfect ambiance, attentive service, and bang for your buck, I highly recommend Basil Thai. 

Love it!
author: Jasmin W.

description: Friday date night with my boyfriend and we decided to try this place out. I called in and made reservations... Thankfully they had room for us because it was packed! They took us within 30 minutes of me calling in. The food was delicious... The drinks were yummy and the staff was great!! We will definitely be back!!
author: Nivia J.

description:
I haven't had a bad meal here yet! Loved
 the duck!!
author: Mike D.

description:
LOVE! LOVE! LOVE This Place! 
I have had my share of Thai places.... And every time I find a great one I go there only. But I tried this place and I will never go anywhere else for Thai again!!! 
But,It was sooo good! I bring people from out of state here to try what I am loving. And they agree! I've turned people out!!!! 
The Yellow Curry half chicken is awesome! And the lamb chops are amazing! The coconut pork was just heavenly! 
Great staff, they are very attentive and are always sooo polite and kind.
The drinks are NOT watered down and the atmosphere is pleasant and cozy. 

I love you Thai Basil! And I will try your other location in Berkeley too!

Thanks again you guys! I will always be back! 

Brenda
author: Brenda S.

description:
This is modern thai to impress your friends/clients that doesn't quite have the popularity of Osha. 

The hike here is a bit far from downtown, but if you're driving, there's plenty of street parking. There aren't too many dining options in the area, with the City Beer Store across the street being the most prominent. 

We started with the chicken satay, a pair of skewers lying on peanut sauce. It was cooked but not really a dish I'd order again.

TOM KA GAI was served in the pot with fire in the middle that seems so popular now. It was tasty, sour but not too sour and definitely set the tempo for the rest of the meal.

PORK BELLY with chinese broccoli. I really wanted this to be good but it just JUST DIDN'T DELIVER. You can get the best version of this dish at Lers.

Shrimp calamari and mussels dish had good flavor but MEH

SHORT RIB CURRY was tender and had a good spice on its own. I'm surprised it didn't come with rice on its own because for the portion it was quite small. But YES, this I would order again.

Pineapple fried rice was decent and filling and certainly a dish I would order for myself if I needed lunch during the workday.

Overall, the dishes were small and difficult to share. The location doesn't make it easy for them succeed but people still flock here. They don't have a happy hour for the downtown crowd. But I was told their sister restaurant Basil Canteen does . The food is not bad by any means, I just prefer eating Thai elsewhere.
author: Dennis L.

description:
Basil is awesome!

When you hit a great balance of awesome food at a really good price, you can't lose. My only complaint is that I have to drive in from Santa Cruz to get it. Luckily, excuses come up now and then that allow us to come over the hill and enjoy a delicious supper.
author: Stephen D.

description:
We  found this place before heading to the Orpheum.  We had less than 45 minutes, and as soon as we told them we were trying to catch a show, they were very accommodating about the pacing.

We started with complimentary fried rice puffs.  The mango cosmo was pretty strong and not overly sweet, and they had some other interesting cocktails, including the ginger one my friend got, which was pretty strong.  I got the shrimp skewers, which came with a standard peanut sauce, perfect for dipping anything.  There were also some pickled cucumbers that weren't quite as seasoned as I'm used to.  The pad seew wasn't overly oily, and it had a generous amount of Chinese broccoli and lean pork.  It had a good chewy bite to it, and it was garlicky and sweet.

We didn't have time for dessert, but service was very prompt and polite.  The space is clean, small, and tables are well spread out.  The lighting is dark, and it'd be a cute place for a casual date. Prices are typical for Thai food in the area.  With the caveat that we ordered generic dishes, it was an unexpected but good find.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
I enjoyed this restaurant quite a bit. My partner and I ordered the Pork and Clam fried dumplings with cucumber and pineapple salad, a scallion skewer, the fire calimari dish, and the sticky rice with mango desert. Everything was delicious. Only my partner wasn't used to the alcohol taste in the fire calimari, but I thought it added flavor. I especially recommend saving some room for that sticky rice desert. It was probably the highlight. The atmosphere feels like a $$$ restaurant, and service was top notch. I guess the waiters could smile more but they are very efficient. 

I was surprised to see everyone dressed a ittle formal here. I wasn't expecting that at a $$ place. So be aware of that.
author: K S.

description: Came here with my girlfriend on a Saturday evening after reading good reviews on yelp. We were actually trying to dine at another local gem but were forced to change plans after discovering it was closed. I'm really glad it was, because this was outright the best Thai restaurant I've eaten at since moving to California. I thought I had eaten at some decent places in LA but after coming here, and eating this quality of food, I don't think anything will top it. The service was exceptional, attentive without being too pushy. Dinner started with complimentary shrimp crackers, which were simple but delicious. I don't often see these being served at many Chinese or Thai restaurants anymore. We ordered the pork shoulder pumpkin curry, which is by far the best tasting curry I've ever eaten. The pork shoulder was succulent and broke apart in every bite. Would visit SF just to eat this curry again. We also ordered yelp favorite Pad Ke Mao. The flavors were incredible and complimented the sweetness of the pumpkin curry well, it's rare I order noodles when eating Thai food, but I would recommend everyone try this along with the pumpkin curry. Great portion size, left feeling very satisfied with two entries and jasmine rice between the two of us. Will definitely be back here whenever I'm in the Bay Area next.
author: Ashley S.

description:
I ordered the thai fried rice with shrimp. The rice was burnt and oily and the dish had two (2) shrimp... wtf? Veggies were like gerber's baby food in my mouth. Kind of tasted like someone had reheated their leftovers and put them on my plate. Imagine mall food but much worse. We also ordered the mango sticky rice. Mango was unripe and had no flavor.  

Conclusion:  this place stinks. Don't waste your money. Try some place else! I would give this place 0 stars if I could. Just plain trash- Don't eat it! 

Basil Thai, I want my money back!
author: K B.

description: Food: 4 stars, wine list: 3 stars, service: 1 star.  It was super busy when I came on a Monday night.  I was seated pretty quickly, but after that things moved pretty slowly.  I ordered an appetizer and it never came, but at least they didn't try to charge me.  The panang curry short ribs are delicious and tender, and the wine was great too.
author: Rob K.

description: Although the food here is usually pretty tasty and ambiance is pleasant, the service can be questionable.  Staff was inattentive to my party's repeated attempts for attention.  Food was also a bit burnt and the wine was a giant rip off ($8 for a SHOT of wine :)
author: Ubz D.

description:
Haven't even had entrees yet.  Chicken and Pork satay is amazing!  Service is great. Decor is perfect.


Ok, had seafood bamee and the egg plant green cury.  This may be the best Thai food I've had!  Some of the best food I've had in a while.  
Waiting for fried banana and coconut icecream!
author: Lorenzo R.

description: Waaaaay overpriced. Food isn't terrible, but it's consistently just ok. Its not hard to rack up a bill of $75+ for two people WITHOUT drinks. If you're craving Thai food and it's close by, it'll do.
author: Garrett B.

description:
Before watching Wicked at the Orpheum Theatre, me and my sister went to Starbucks to ask for the closest restaurant that's for its buck and the staff directed us here.

The restaurant was very elegant and neat. Staff was wonderful and so was the plating. Food was good for it's price, one of the better Thai restaurants I must say. Their green curry is a must try!
author: Julie V.

description: Made reservations here for a group dinner. The manager was very helpful with helping set up the prefix menu, and he answered any questions I had very quickly. Overall the food was delicious, and everyone was stuffed after dinner! I would have given them 5 stars except they threw away our leftover plate (almost 1/2 to 3/4 full) of crab fried rice without asking if we wanted it boxed to go. That's never happened to me before at a restaurant!!! The crab fried rice was so delicious, and throwing that away would usually be enough to make me furious. But everything else went so smoothly, and the staff had been so helpful I couldn't write a bad review. Just remember to tell your server you want your leftovers boxed because, trust me, you will want them!
author: Audrey M.

description:
My boyfriend and I had dinner here on a saturday evening, it was not crowded. I made reservations but didnt need to, there was enough seating. Also didnt have trouble parking in the area.

Food:
We ordered 
1) Chicken Skewer: I've had better sums up this dish. It wasnt bad but nothing spectacular.

2) spicy pork shoulder: It was veryy spicy with a lot of flavor! If you cant handle your spice dont order this one. The dish was yummy so I managed to tolerate the spice, but if the dish didnt tasted good I would not have enjoyed the dish. I'm sure they can make it mild or less spicy if you asked. (glad we ordered side rice :)

3) Chicken Pad Sew Ew: This was yummy :), good flavor, noodle was not super sticky, had enough greens/chicken/noodle balance.


Service:
The service was standard, nothing spectacular but not horrible.

Ambiance/Decor:
Nice decor (i.e. light fixtures, tables, paintings). The restuarant is dim but not overly dim. Also this restaurant wasnt super casul or super fancy, it was a nice saturday night dinner location :)

Tab for all of the above with tax/tip: $36
author: Parita P.

description:
Delicious entrees and great service. My friends and i shared 4 entrees and it was a great variety: eggplant green curry, pork/pumpkin red curry, spicy noodles with steak, and coconut tom yum soup. Nice portions for the price. 
Clean, casual, and comfy atmosphere. 

Good drink list and reasonable prices.

Definitely would recommend this place! This is good Thai food :)
author: Gina B.

description:
Since I had a party of 10 for dinner, we were required to go with the preset menu. Once our party was seated, the food came quickly...as in within 5 minutes! There were plenty of food to go around and it seemed like everyone was satisfied. The preset dinner included:

STARTERS 
-chicken grilled on bamboo skewers with peanut sauce 
-crispy rice paper wrapped tiger prawns
-crispy spring rolls
-crispy pastries filled with curried duck & sweet potatoes 
 
MAIN COURSE 
-pad thai 
-pad pak raum- wok-sear bok choy, shitake mushroom, babycorn & seasonal greens 
-tamarind prawns
-red curry with chicken and pumpkin 
-grilled steak topped with peanut sauce 
 -steamed jasmine rice 

DESSERT 
-Fried banana served with coconut ice cream 
 
$25.00 per person.  Tax and gratuity not included

Very clean, organized space, good for bigger parties. Though the space isn't as big as it looks like in the pictures, it's a decent size restaurant. There is a small bar with a good amount of cocktail drinks.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Best Thai I've had in US travels.
Need I say more?
The Pineapple Mojito is certainly worth trying.
author: Brian D.

description:
YUM!!! 
Great Service 
Hearty Portions
Fast Service
author: Corey K.

description:
I have had better Thai here where I live. The meat was good, no dark meat or mystery meat, and there were some good flavors with the appetizers like the corn fritters and the shrimp chips, but overall, it is just OK.

Thai food needs a certain level of heat. Not sure if we were supposed to ask for a specific level of spicy but we weren't offered and so I assumed there would be a little bit of a kick in my dish but there wasn't. There was red chili sauce on the table and I added plenty of that to my food to make my taste buds happy.

Service was great, they were packed on a Saturday night and they were attentive and friendly to our table.
author: Jenn Q.

description:
I love Basil's style (the Thai style popular in the US). It's delicious, and the service is great.

For those vegans out there, they've got plenty of vegan options - just mention that you're vegan and they'll help you out. You could also make a lot of the meat dishes vegan by substituting the meaty stuff for tofu.

For some reason, I always get my hopes up here when I order something spicy... Those dishes marked spicy on the menu just aren't hot enough for me. But if you do ask for hot sauce, they'll give it to you.

Overall, I quite like Basil Thai. :)
author: marianne c.

description:
Update!! Because we all know how much you LOVE updates...

I had food from here last night. Why? Because we were hungry, and it was close. The carniverous being came out in meh, and SOMEONE recommeded the stuffed eggplant (eggplant wrapped around chicken)...MER! It was MER I tell you! *unimpressed*

But I still liked their Thai pineapple rice with prawns, and the eggplant with peanut sauce, and the corn cake fritters. Apparently after you've eaten three bags of cheetos, two diet sodas, and a lean pocket...you make bad food decisions?
---------

I don't know WHAT the hell is possessing me to eat vegetarian, but for some reason I'm totally lusting over eggplant instead of red meat. Psuedo-phallus food item, or super innuendo food item? 

I like the look of it. It's pretty. And it tastes good. You don't get all lazy and guilty when you eat...eggplant.

So I had the eggplant with peanut sauce. Anything that remotely contains a peanut product I will try, and blame my father for that. Also blame him for my growing need of good psychiatrists. But we're talking about food, and this food was fantastic. Their yellow corn cake fritters were also super bitchin. Did I seriously just say bitchin? Yes. Blame the dad for that also. 

I will admit, I wasn't soooo keen on their spring rolls. Then again, I don't know why. It just didn't taste...*right*. It was good, but just not *right*. Love-hate relationship with spring rolls. But I have a love-hate relationship with just about everything. So four stars.
author: Jaime L.

description:
I like to think of my self as a foodie, but in reality I'm probably just a wannabe foodie (is that a foobie?).  

When I was younger, I didn't eat ANYTHING that was out of the ordinary, despite my parents' best efforts to make me eat healthy.  That attitude has increased somewhat, although if you ask one particular friend she'll tell you I still don't eat anything.  This is coupled with the fact that I am allergic to the weirdest food things and have to be careful in restaurants that go for the interesting tastes.

Enter Basil Thai.  I have never been a big curry fan, ever since a sixth grade school project where we had to make a dish from a country we were reporting on (me- Australia), and I completely overdosed on the curry.  Plus side is I now know how to make pavlova.  But I digress.  I figured after 20 some-odd years of being picky, I have to just suck it up (literally) and try new things.  I was very happy with the selection I made (granted, I had some help) and will most likely go back because I'm a big fan of pumpkin and peanut sauce.  Not together, mind you.

The three stars is for the service.  Perhaps it's because of my party's attire- 2 extras from a Culture Club video, one zebra hooker (me), and one normal fellow with a penchant for skinny ties- but I felt that the service didn't reflect the food.  Granted, it was the end of the night and it was blatantly obvious that they wanted to close, but I thought it could have been better. Not horrible, not great, just eh.

Of course, the two drinks I had consumed already may have clouded my judgement...I'll try again someday.
author: Pam S.

description:
While not being a traditional Thai restaurant whatsoever, the food is really delicious. It's a great value and a great twist on Thai food. I got the salmon curry and I thought I wouldn't be able to finish all of it, but I ended up eating the whole thing because it was so good.

Great atmosphere. Upscale without being too upscale. Nice place to meet friends for dinner or a date.
author: Hilarie S.

description:
If you're looking for Thai in the SOMA, there are 3 places on Folsom that are outstanding:

Manora:  Best curry's and satay's  (12th x Folsom)
Cha-Am:   Best Soup   (4th x Folsom)
Basil:   Best Fish   (8th x Folsom)

Tip:  I usually order off menu, and request the Halibut which is wrapped in a leaf and steamed then served with a small but perfect surround of Broccoli and Tomatoes, add some Basil Eggplant and Pad Thai with a side of peanut sauce and a single rice and you and a friend are in heaven. 

Also love the Lamb, Angus Cubes, Curry Puffs and Roast Duck. 

Nice beers on tap in tall chilled glasses, $5 happy hour. 




On my block... how blessed am i?
author: Adam X.

description: Food is alright, but the Pad Kee Mao is deceptive - Comes with beef unless you pull teeth with your server to get something else. Also they often run out of wide rice noodles and substitute Pad Thai noodles which defeats the purpose.
author: Marc V.

description:
Already reeling from a shitty flight, a few doses of Xanax (that didn't seem to do much for me *during* the flight) and some bad, cold, red wine ala American Airlines, the Not Normal Yes Normal crew carried me from the airport to Kristina R. & Andy R.'s car.  By the time we reached Basil, I was starving.  Mick F. ordered me some awesome ale, and if you ask him, maybe he'll remember what it was - I forget, but I want another.

Appetizers kept me from getting into major drunken and gastric upset trouble - thank you, chicken satay, you're a mensch.  Pad thai with shrimp and tofu was awesome.

Dessert rocked - my favorite part of this meal.  We shared fried banana & ice cream, and a couple other desserts - see Andy R. review for full details.

Cheap and fantastic!  And don't worry, although we discussed the next kindergarten t-shirt fundraiser, the "I Am Serious" proceeds will not be covering this meal.

Thanks again to Andy R. for sharing their gift certificate.  Michael E. was wonderful in carrying me to Butter...thanks a million, man.  But I have to extend heartfelt gratitude to Kristina R. for smiling for photos.  I wont post those here, but I've got 'em.
author: Ellen M.

description:
At first I thought the place looked too fancy to be authentic, but I was wrong.  

This is a great place for curries.
It doesn't matter if you're getting the yellow, green, or red, you will enjoy.  Although, I seem to gravitate to the chicken yellow curry.

The noodles aren't bad and the fish cake appetizer decent.
Good stuff.

A good sign for me is that the folks I've brought here have gone back on their own.
author: Dan B.

description:
Roast duck curry I give 5 stars.
skirt steak I give you 4 stars.
Nuer yang, whatever you were, it was delicious and worth 5 stars.

I'm noticing a trend with Asian restaurants. No matter how upscale or classy they try to be, the wait staff will always refuse to acknowledge you until the the full party arrives. Service was sparse, if not completely dismissive, even after everyone sat down.
author: Candice T.

description: My favorite part about them is their gluten-free menu. I love ordering a bowl of dtom Ka Gai and fresh rolls from the GF menu, and know that I'm indulging in tasty food that's dietary friendly. I typically go in off-peak hours, so the service is pretty good, especially with keeping my water filled up. I did go there with a friend last week during the evening and the staff was still attentive. Again, we went off the GF menu. We both greatly enjoyed the Jungle Beef, but found the lamb from the wok fried lamb overcooked and not as flavorful. I've had this one before, and it seems to be consistently unimpressive. Avoid the lamb, stick with the regular meats or vegetarian dishes, and you should be good to go.
author: Jeri J.

description: Great food, great service, would come back again. Tons of items on menu. Everything wad great!
author: Bridget L.

description:
My sweet bf took me out here just because. I'd give it a 3.5. There's nothing particularly bad about this place, it's just that nothing really stood out so it's a little above average in my book. 

The venue is very clean and kind of zen-like/trendy. There were many customers so the noise level was a bit high. The service was polite and courteous and the food was just ok. Nothing memorable at all. I think the only thing that really stood out to me was the interior design, but other than that, nothing spectacular. I'd come here again, I might recommend it if someone was in the area looking for a decent Thai place, but I prefer Grand Pu Bah, which is pretty close too.
author: Judy R.

description: Nice atmosphere and very fast service. They have an extensive gluten-free menu with vegan options. The golden bean cakes with cashew nuts, mushroom, and onions in roasted chili jam were absolutely delicious!
author: Kerri M.

description:
Passable Thai food.  Seems that the spices/flavors are a bit muted.  More accustomed to curry dishes with a bit of a kick.  Did dig the Calamari appetizer, Basil Chicken and Panang Spare Ribs.  Pleasing decor, well-lite.  Will do in a pinch.

Nits: While acceptable, veggies don't appear super fresh.  Can run heavy with the tourist crowd on weekends.
author: Dwayne R.

description:
Don't let the sketchy neighborhood keep you away, because the food is amazing here. Based on what reviewers said, we had the marinated skirt steak w/peanut sauce, duck w/ pineapple in red curry, Pad Se-ew, Basil's eggplant and curry duck w/sweet potato puff pastry. This place manages to intensify flavors, without over-powering, something that many Thai restaurants have not mastered. 
Service is excellent and decor is not too opulent.  The only thing that completely confounded us was their pricing for rice, bowl that is replenished vs. large bowl that isn't (huh?).  Oh, and for those who think the food packs too much spice, ask for mild...I am about as wimpy as you can get!
author: Arlene C.

description:
A friend was visiting from out-of-town and wanted to stay close to his hotel in the Soma neighborhood. He suggested Basil and upon reading a few other positive reviews, we thought we'd give it a shot. 

I would be lying if I said there is not a dearth of Thai food restaurants in the city, so the idea of a new Thai food restaurant seemed passable but not exciting. 

We grabbed drinks at the bar as we waited for one of the tables to open up. Once seated, we started off our meal with the Grilled Indian Bread with eggplant, red bell pepper and green curry dipping sauce. Each of us agreed that green curry had a zippy heated finish with a slightly sweet under note. Our friend ended up ordering an entree with the green curry because he had liked it so much. 

Out came the entrees- the tamarind shrimp, suggested by the hostess turned out to be a coconut battered shrimp plate with the sweet-and-sour tamarind sauce drizzled over the shrimp, onions and bell peppers which gave the dish crunch. Next came the pad-see-yeuw- a wide noodle dish with bok choy and chicken in a savory brown sauce. My interest had been piqued by the braised pork shoulder with kabocha squash in a panang curry, as I have rarely seen pork offered in curry dishes at other Thai restaurants. The curry was rich as the pork and squash were tender. That last minute addition of chicken in green curry turned out to be one of the more interesting dishes of the night as it arrived in green curry slathered bundles. Each bundle was wrapped with grilled eggplant and zucchini slices and inside- surprise- was a chicken meatball grafted together with onion and cabbage. 

We gave all the dishes two thumbs up and left with a few leftovers from an unexpectedly good meal. The wait staff bordered on being slightly aloof, but I'll give it to them that we were walk-in's on a Saturday night for dinner.  

If you're craving Thai, I would recommend heading down to Folsom to try Basil.
author: Annelies Z.

description:
I came to Basil Thai for lunch with a group and ordered a Thai iced tea and Jungle Beef which the menu describes as "sizzling stir-fried skirt steak with wild ginger, apple eggplant, yellow squash, and green curry". 

When I read "sizzling" in the description I foolishly thought maybe the beef would be served on a sizzling iron platter, but I think the "sizzle" refers to spiciness. The menu says it's served medium-spicy and it was definitely medium-spicy for me because after three bites I started to hiccup! That's how I know it's actually got a real level of Asian spice to it - if it makes me hiccup. The curry sauce was a nice mix of heat, creaminess, and sweetness. I think third-rate Thai restaurants tend to overload their curries with coconut milk in an attempt to make it rich and give it body, but I usually can't stomach more than a few bites of that type of curry. The curry sauce on my jungle beef was just right for me. The beef itself was tender, the portion was just right for me and I finished the entire meal and wasn't overly stuffed (although a little more food wouldn't have hurt). They gave me a choice of jasmine, brown, or sticky rice. 

For $10 the quality of the food was very good. I think I might call in a pick up order for lunch in the future if I'm stressed for time. Would love to try the roti with green curry. Service is courteous, not necessarily overtly friendly or warm but I'm fine with that. There's parking on the street but the restaurant is within walking distance from Civic Center.
author: Monica W.

description:
I really like Basil Thai.  The parking near here is good.  The service is good even for takeout.  The restaurant is very clean and nice looking.  

The only issue I have with it is the food.  It isn't bad Thai food.  It's just very Americanized Thai food.  I ordered the following for takeout:

Gai satay /Chicken Satay -  2 sticks of chicken satay consisting of breast of chicken meat with peanut sauce and small cucumber salad.  Best part of the meal.  

Tom ka gai/Chicken coconut soup - Tasty soup with higher acidity than normal for this soup.  Just made me want to drink water to dilute the taste.  

Tamarind Prawns -  It's really just sweet and sour  shrimp(more sweet than sour!) IMHO.  The prawns are too small and really only qualify as shrimps.  There was about 8 shrimp per $12 order.  I think it was reasonable however the sauce is a little too sweet.  

Overall, I like this restaurant.  People are extremely friendly and they seem to do a good takeout business with 3 people ahead of me.  I would try them again if the food could be made more authentic.  I am impress with the takeout experience here since it was easy parking and friendly staff.
author: Jim J.

description:
Basil Thai Restaurant & Bar is a nice smallish restaurant in an area that is in need of the facelift that it appears to be getting.  Eight of us went without a reservation on a night when the restaurant was serving a party of thirty and we were seated within ten minutes.  You will not fine better service. The servers are fast, polite and personable. The décor of the restaurant is hip and vibrant, the bartender was beyond cool and this place was alive.

As far as the food is concerned I disagree with most and I thought long and hard about my review. In my view, if you are in Asia or accustomed to having authentic Thai food, the food is slightly above average. If you do not regularly have Thai food I could see you giving an outstanding rating.
author: Chocoolate I.

description:
Basil is definitely one of the better Thai places I've been too. The restaurant is nice and moderately sized, excellent service, and gooood food. The appetizer I got was the paupia (crispy spring rolls stuffed with vermicelli and cabbage), which is a staple appy at any Thai place. The sauce that went with the spring rolls was really good and spicy. For the main course of the meal I shared:
1) stuffed eggplant (grill eggplant stuffed with minced chicken and vegetables glazed with green curry )
2) keow wan nuer  (Angus steak cubes, snake beans, and apple eggplant in green curry)
Both dishes were tasty, but the steak cubes were the best. The food didn't take long and the presentation was nice.
author: Krizia M.

description: I have been here a couple of times but thought I should finally yelp it since I had a awesome dish. I decided to try something different and went with the Golden diced tofu, grilled skirt steak, and egg noodles in coconut red curry (kao soi). Very flavorful.The presentation alone deserved 5 stars, Its a big dish so be hungry or get ready to take the leftovers home.  The service was nice.  Prices are fair. Its clean. Its in SOMA, looked like a lot of techies and business folks like to come here. Will definitely come back.
author: X X.

description: I have been wanting to try Basil for some time and it did not disappoint.  I was going to have Green Curry which my usual Thai dish, but they have such and interesting Ground Chicken, Eggplant, and Chili dish I had to try it.  It was very good and I had some left over to take home with me (even though I forgot it).  We also had the fried Spring Rolls and they were very good too.  The service was good and friendly.  Now, I'll have to go back to try the Green Curry.
author: Scott L.

description:
Ambiance:
Contemporary interior :D  The wall behind the bar is cool and innovative.  Mood lighting was just right. 

Service:
I was immediately greeted by a sweet hostess.  It was super packed tonight (friday night) but I was seated almost immediately.  The waiters were attentive, making sure our water cups were filled and to tend to our needs.

Food:
Pla-duk pad ped (spicy crispy catfish) was my favorite!  I'm always so amazed when the skin is crispy even though it's sitting in a thick sauce ...sooo good.  It was cooked well, tender, and the sauce was divine x).  I had dinner with my boyfriend's mom who is a traditional Vietnamese woman who only likes Vietnamese or Chinese food but to my surprise, she was impressed by this dish! At the end of the meal, she stood up to grab one of their business cards.  This act alone is kind of a big deal.  I highly recommend this dish!

Kana mu grob (Chinese broccoli & house cured crispy pork belly)... so fatty and goood!  I felt guilty eating all that fat but thank goodness the portions weren't too large haha. 

Pad ke-mao (spicy wide noodle dish) was my safety dish.  You really can't mess this dish up.  These noodles were not lacking in flavor and I liked the noodle to veggie ratio.  I brought home leftovers and I'm pretty sure it will taste just as good the next day.
author: Lynnie T.

description:
After spending all day in the sun in my shorts and flip-flops sweating in my backyard, I wasn't sure I wanted to walk into Thai Basil -- dim, well-dressed people, servers donned in all-black outfits. I had no reservations. This place just happens to be a 2 minute walk from my apartment. But this has easily become my staple neighborhood Thai.

I was quickly seated, quickly served, and the food was affordable ($8-15/plate) and all around delicious.

You're solid, Thai Basil. All that I need from my local Thai joint. AND you do take out.
author: Chieh T.

description:
DEEEEELLLLLICCCIIIOOOUUUUSSS!

Best Thai food in the area.  I've had everything off the menu.

Try the ribs...weird I know.  You'll thank me later.
author: Inga B.

description: I had Pad Ke Mao, Duck curry puff and Corn fritters week back and decided to give a review. I don't word to describe how wonderful these dishes are. Excellent in taste and must to include in your order. Five stars for you guys
author: S M.

description: My favourite Thai restaurant has been consistently great with traditional tasty dishes.  I've been a regular for years and never been disappointed.  The atmosphere is also awesome, to kick off a fabulous night out in the city.
author: Mayumi H.

description: Came were with 7 people, we each ordered something different and every single dish was amazing. Fresh vegetables, lean meat, tons of vegetarian and gluten free options... Impressive variety of curries and thai style dankness.
author: Max Cougar O.

description:
Food wise, this place is great. Probably one of the best thai places in the city. But service is HORRENDOUS. And it is rare that I'll knock a place based on service when the food is as good as it is here. 

Word to the wise thai iced tea lovers out there: don't you order your thai iced tea without ice. If you do, they give you 1/4 the amt as you would get with ice and they give it to you in a wine glass. If you order the thai iced tea with ice you get a normal sized drink glass. 

And should you complain, instead of just giving you the two extra ounces of thai iced tea that would be required to even give you the same amt as the people with ice, they get pissed and then try to show you that the 1/4 they gave you is actually the same amt as what everyone else gets (which is not true). 

I mean really, if someone there orders a coke without ice are they going to give you a wine glass with less than what you would have gotten with ice? 

It's such a small thing, I know, but good service means being good about even the stupid, small things. Particularly the stupid small things that probably would have cost them only $.10 but have now cost them a future customer.
author: A H.

description:
Weekend in San Francisco - single, no dog, no partner.  So its a leisure weekend.  The flight was cheaper than I expected with the new Virgin America (reviewed later).  Cheap hotel in Civic Center.

Now for the restaurant, I have eaten at Basil before about 3 years ago and it hasn't really changed decor wise.  Its on a very iffy area since its SOMA but mostly businesses around the area, not a lot of housing.  Our first time was during Folsom Street Fair, needed breakfast and it was the only place opened close to where we were and it was crowded but I don't remember the food that time.

3 years later, getting hungry for dinner and had checked out a review of Le Charm Bistro by Yerba Buena gardens and was hoping to get some french food.  However, in my long protracted walk, I noticed Basil.  I thought I would check out the menu and see if there is anything I would like.  

Well it looked nice enough, crowded with mostly 20-30 somethings on dates or with friends, even a bridal shower group of girls.  I get in asked if I wanted to eat in the bar or a table.  Chose the table because I think the bar is only for bar food and Thai food is certainly not bar food.

Look at the liquor menu, no bloody mary.  found Singha beer - thai beer with thai food.  Ordered roast duck on curry (shoot! I  just had curry chicken salad for lunch).  Food comes out fast and smelled good.

As I enjoyed my dinner the place gets crowded and a group of six had to sit in 2 tables, one for four and the other for two.  I guess they were hungry.

Overall service was 2 1/2 stars.  I could have been asked if I wanted more beer since I finished my beer before the meal was half over.  Then I couldn't even get a refill of water.  Food is 3 stars, the roast duck was cooked perfectly and not too spicy curry worked well with the white rice.  I still give them overall 3 because I enjoyed eating eventhough I was alone.
author: Melanio F.

description:
I really enjoyed this place. Though it was a Friday night at 8:00p, there was only one party waiting for a table ahead of us, and since we were willing to sit at the bar, we only waited about three minutes before taking that opportunity to avert even a fifteen minute wait by grabbing seats at the bar.

We saw "Zen Green Tea liquer" on the shelf and were intrigued, so we ordered some green mar-tea-nis and it was quite nice, something different. The curry puffs as an appetizer were exquisite, and the "saparood" (fried rice) dish was a nice portion, very flavorful, and served very quickly as well. 

Servers were generally attentive and the place had a nice vibe. Good energy. Nice location if you're wanting to hit Eight Lounge for their Friday night happy hour afterwards.

Nice place...
author: Sean B.

description: Nice atmosphere. Excellent service. The stuffed eggplant green curry was amazing. Good sake. Will be back!
author: Melisa W.

description:
We made reservations and were seated right away.

We got seated and browsed through the menu, which had a huge variety of dishes. DECISIONS DECISIONS!!

Before our food came they served us those shrimp chips in dim sum baskets, cute and creative!

Ordered...

Mushroom Sake: weird, smoky, taste. Maybe it was just the alcohol.

HOI YING(SCALLOP SKEWERS): very beautifully presented and came with greens. There were two skewers which consisted of three- 1/2 scallops.  I like scallops, but I realized I didn't like them grilled with a smoky taste.

KEOW WAN ROTI: absolutely DELICIOUS! i loved the flavor of the indian bread.  The spicy flavor of the green curry and the sweet eggplants went well with the bread.  We devoured it and it left me wanting MORE! I would highly recommend trying this for the appetizer.

PARAM RUNG SONG: the grilled skirt steak with a sweet peanuty sauce was nice and tender cooked just right too my liking. It wasn't too rare nor was it too well done! Another good dish to get.

PANANG SHORT RIBS: the meat was so tender that it fell off of the bone.  The curry sauce was nicely seasoned and not too spicy for my liking. I could have just eaten rice with the curry sauce alone and I would have been happy.

We ended our meal with FRIED BANANAS with COCONUT ICE CREAM, which was a nice and light finish to a wonderful meal=]

Waiters were very friendly and attentive and were constantly filling our cups with water.

I have to agree that it is one of the better Thai restaurants in the city with great decor, friendly and attentive staff, delicious food all for a reasonable price!

I will be back for more=]
author: Sarah F.

description: Excellent roast chicken (Gai Yang), green curry sauce (side), and roti.
author: Inigo M.

description: Love this place! Pad see ew is my go to dish, but everything I've had here is good. I appreciate the wine and white tablecloths (with paper on too). Service is usually excellent. Gets loud but great spot.
author: Jen M.

description: I thought this place was really great. Everything could have been spicier though. I'll sign off on the braised pork red curry, the calamari, and the mango salad. 4 stars.
author: Michael A.

description: My new favorite Thai restaurant! I think they must put crack in the green Curry, we just couldn't stop eating it.
author: Kelly D.

description:
An excellent find in SOMA.  I went there for lunch with a party of 11 and no reservation. (I know, I know, what was I thinking... I wasn't thinking and wanted to go here for a co-worker's farewell lunch.)  Thankfully, they worked quickly and had us seated in no time.  The place was packed and bustling.

The ambiance is bright, stark and modern.  The cuisine is refined, somewhat Americanized with better cuts of meats, balanced flavors and modernized presentation.

I ordered the yellow chicken curry and it came out on a square plate, a chicken leg on the bone served with rice on the plate.  All the entrees do not seem to be intended for family style, but more as an individual entree. 

It was flavored very well, a little on the mild side for my tastes, but the sweet coconut milk and the yellow curry flavor were balanced well.  The potatoes were cut in large chunks, simmered until just cooked through, not cooked until ready to fall apart as they often are in other Thai restaurants.  I thoroughly enjoyed the chicken, cooked tender, on the bone and seasoned to perfection.  Lunch price: $9.50.

Service was prompt, efficient and with a smile.  They even gladly accommodated my request to pay for 2 of my companion's meal from the separate table.  

A great Thai restaurant if you are looking for something slightly more upscale, clean and fresh take on Thai classics.
author: Catherine W.

description:
Overall solid place.  I really liked the ambiance.

Wen there with two friends on a Sunday after heading to a local bar.  We had Vegetable Spring Rolls and Chive Cakes as appetizers.  These were all great.  

The entrees were good.  Nothing spectacular.  I would recommend this place especially for the vibe inside.  Might be a great place to host an event.
author: Eric S.

description: This place is a bit of a surprise, given its location. I'm no thai food expert, but it seemed authentic. The interior vibe contrasted the exterior and neighborhood.
author: Jeremy L.

description: I used to come here often with my old work crew when i worked in SOMA. The prices are decent and the food is pretty good. Anytime we had a craving for thai this was our go to place. I used to have the "pak rad kang" (Grilled squash, eggplant, zuchini, mushroom, tomatoes, and bell peppers in green curry) which was pretty darn good. I would also sometimes have the pad se ew with chicken or tofu instead of pork, and sometimes the pad thai. I LOVED the pad thai here. i've been to thai places where its overly sweet or overly bland. The pad thai here was just right lol. The environment is pretty nice and loungey so it was always a cool place to go with a group of friends.
author: Rehana K.

description:
I am a regular here. I love this place. I try something new pretty much every time and am never disappointed. 
They are awesome with my daughter-giving her crayons to color with on the big paper table covers and accommodating her 5 year old pickiness. 
They have cocktails here (!!) and they're so yummy. I can't believe it took me 2 years of coming here to have a cocktail. I love the ginger one. I never remember names of stuff till the menu is under my nose, so sorry...It's super yummy and helps on the tipsiness!
I will come back here over and over again. I ALWAYS bring out-of-towners here. Classy, and not very expensive. Love it!
author: Emdeezy F.

description:
With so many great restaurants in san francisco there are few I go back to repeatedly, but this is one of them. The people are friendly, and the service and the food are always fantastic.

go there if you like thai food.
author: Lance K.

description:
This place is so friendly. The staff that work here have been here for ages and always remember your face when you come back. They treat you exceptionally well all the time, especially when you come for an occasion like birthday, anniversary or just a large get together dinner! I used to travel from Gilroy once a month just to come and have Thai food here. I wont eat Thai, unless its from here!  

I took my friends here the other night and they were all thanking me on how good the food was since they had never been here! 

Definitely recommend this place!
author: Jess C.

description: I must give this place 5 stars, I hadn't had thai food this amazing since Japan, i hated the fact that everything on the menu looked/sounded great. Food is meticulously delivered, uber-flavorful, moderately priced. I had the eggplant stuffed with cabbage and chicken in green curry: best green curry I have ever had. A friend had the pineapple duck: delicious! My partner had a soup and I could smell the lemongrass/galanga infusion from where I was sitting. Never expected to find this place south of Market. We are soooo coming back next time.
author: Carlos L.

description: My first time here was 10 years ago.  Last night my second time here at 10pm, they quickly seated us, which is kind.  The gentle decor and lighting put me at ease.  Spring rolls delighted me.  Fish curry with pumpkin was delicious, yet I wasn't expecting it to be sour.  Brown rice had red rice mixed in which I love, yet we had 2 orders and it looked more like 1 large serving.  Still two of us filled up for $46 with tip.
author: Ethan K.

description: Excellent quality food and service. Coming from the foodie town of Seattle I am definitely impressed.
author: Lauren B.

description:
So you go out as a group and you figure it's just easiest to order a bunch of things and share - but then you are faced with "don't eat this" "Can't eat that" and it becomes a nightmare.

Enter stage right, our party of six came equipped with "no shellfish", "wheat allergy/ gluten-free" "no sugar" "no meat except fish" etc etc. Basil was accommodating, helpful with recommendations and we all left satisfied. Everything was fresh and delicious. Spring rolls, both cold and crisp fried versions, green papaya salad, pad thai, pad si ew, grilled salmon curry... no complaints. 

The rapid-fire buzz of conversation died off when the food arrived, we all dove in head first. Mmmm. Oh, the brown rice is super tasty too, laced with a bit of red, it's just delish.

It's totally out of my way, but if I were in the area, I would return.
author: Alissa A.

description: Amazing food, but slightly dicey service, but then again it was in the aftermath of the Folsom Street Fair, so I'll give them some slack.  Great drinks and wonderful food.  Another place I'll try to revisit in any future visits in my favorite city to vacation in...
author: Sam A.

description: This place was really good! We ordered the lemongrass chicken and Brussels sprouts, both dishes were exceptional. Not quite authentic Thai food but we really enjoyed it.
author: Erika B.

description:
Just give me a bowl of their green curry - doesn't need to be anything in it - and I will slurp it down until the smell radiates from my pores. What a lovely thought.

Did a family style meal here with 6 friends and I was very impressed with the quality and flavors all around. Cuisine is a modern Thai with some creativity around the dishes but stays far away from being a fusion or just a hodgepodge of Southeast Asian foods to the point where it's unrecognizable as Thai. 

Tom yum gai soup was yum. Delicious coconut flavors with a tiny kick of spice on the end. Very satisfying. Pad talay, even being not a huge seafood guy, was delicious as the seafood absorbed the flavors of the sauce. Vegetables were nearly perfect, neither soggy or tough.
Pad rad kang - rad (I know, I gotta stop) but that green curry is just awesome. 

Two favorites had to be the Pad Ke Mao - the wide noodes with beef in a chilli sauce. Awesome and satisfying - perhaps the ultimate thai comfort food. Jungle beef was a huge hit.

I appreciated the thai ice tea because I could actually taste the tea for a change versus these concoctions that are 4/5ths condensed milk. 

Service was good and pretty quick - never felt like we were waiting for much.

Good experience overall.
author: Ross R.

description: Great Thai restaurant. The curries are out of this world. A step up from Osha. My favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Gerard N.

description:
I usually make the same order of panang curry or pad thai at every thai restaurant but this week I tried something different! I tried their mix and match and got tamarind prawns and stuffed eggplant! It looked and tasted amazing! The mix and match is a great idea but the proportions weren't enough to fill me up. I finished my rice before my meal... Quick! I was pretty sad about that and thought of ordering more rice but I didn't. I've never had that problem before. My friend ordered pad thai and she liked it but we've had a more savory pad thai in San Diego - a very rare find! 

The food is delicious no doubt about it! 

Service was ok/good. But we found ourselves sucking on our ice. We were in an awkward corner so I guess that can be a reason! I wouldn't mind coming here again to give it another chance! I love love love thai food!
author: Naz M.

description:
Basil Thai - I realize as I write this that you have 641 reviews already and that my review probably means so little to you, but I just have to say - yummy, yummy goodness. 

I found myself with a hankering for Thai food (my second favorite food in the world), what is a girl with a hankering for Thai food to do when she does not know where the nearest Thai restaurant is? Well pull out my trusty iPhone of course. 

I feel I must interject here and state for the record that I pulled the car over before pulling out my iPhone - I did really want Thai food and I did not want to deal with a nasty ticket or car accident getting in the way of me finding Thai food quickly. Now back to the story....

I pulled out my iPhone and went to my Aroundme App (what would I do without you) and Basil Thai came up at which point I suddenly realized I'd been there before 10 years earlier. 

This is the part where I apologize to you for not having visited you in 10 years. What was I thinking? You are so near my home and yet I have left you out of my life for a decade. I feel bad, really I do, especially since upon my visiting you after such a long time you treated me so well and gave my tummy such yummy goodness. 

Your crunchy bean cakes were oh so tasty and I hear your sea bass was mighty tasty as well.  In fact you got my fiance to eat slowly and savor his tasty sea bass. I repeat - he ate slowly. This is a miracle - really, you worked a miracle here.  

I promise next time I will not let 10 years pass between our visits. You are just too good for that.
author: melissa t.

description:
Went here after happy hour across the street at City Beer Store. All the food was great, with plenty of interesting options (this is not your usual pad thai and curry dive). Nothing we had was greasy at all, contrary to what some of the other reviewers complained about here. 

The best things we had included a pumpkin curry special, which was pretty spicy, and something with eggplant. The soup we had was AMAZING (I can't remember if I was tom yum or tom ka, one of those coconut ones). Everything was fresh and tasty. 

Of particular note: one of our friends is on a gluten-free diet and she was overjoyed that they gave her a separate menu with multiple gluten-free options. 

Would definitely like to go back and sample a few more dishes.
author: Sam Z.

description:
This is a place I recommend to out of towners or people looking to have a good thai food experience. Granted, it's not traditional thai food but it'll make you warm up to the idea if you never had any. Such a hidden gem. 

Go for their grilled skirt steak with peanut sauce and finish it off with fried banana and ice cream. The decor inside is pretty nice and perfect for either date, birthday dinner, or even just a casual night out out. The drinks are equally amazing well. Go for the lychee drink.
author: Roth E.

description:
I used to come to lunch here when I worked in this area.  My friend and I were in the neighborhood at 8.30pm on a Thursday and we just wanted to find some place nice to sit/chat but does not charge you $30 an entree.
I am surprised it's still here after 7 years.  Nice decoration, soft lighting, decent service and a big list of cocktails.  I don't mind coming here next time to just sit and chat with a friend....

We had the coconut milk with chicken mushroom soup (my favorite soup but the I don't like the texture of the chicken.)  The curry duck (good flavor) and the grilled lamb. (love it!! love how they marinate it!!) 

I don't even like Thai food,  but I will definitely come back here!
author: Jo L.

description: There was absolutely nothing wrong with this restaurant! The food was great and service was exceptional. So attentive and friendly. I would recommend anyone come here. I had the Green curry and pad thai (1 star) and it was perfection. Definitely coming back!
author: Michelle B.

description:
I've chosen to come eat here via Yelp reviews thinking that I've never been before... twice. How does that happen!?

The first time I went (my legitimate first time) my boyfriend and I ordered our dishes so spicy I nearly lost my hearing halfway through. It was so intense. But very delicious, from what I was still able to taste. The restaurant has a really snazzy and intimate feel about it, but I couldn't carry a proper conversation because I couldn't hear anything and I didn't really enjoy the decor so much because my eyes were so watery the entire time. The pains of having a Korean boyfriend... Anyway, the food is always good, I've never been disappointed. And the portions are usually just right.

Just paid another visit last night with friends that were in town. Never fails to satisfy us. I know now to order everything medium spicy so that I can partake in socializing while dining.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Good food.  Bad experience asking to be changed tables.  They said no bc it was reserved for a four person group, but within five minutes, a two person group that asked to be seated there got seated.  Don't wanna imply that it was blatant racism, but that's what it felt like.  I regret not walking out.
author: Ghizal A.

description:
Overall, I think it deserves a 3.5 stars and I'm willing to give it another try.  Service was decent when you can get the one waitress's attention, but it seems like they could use another waiter/waitress.  They always filled our water without us having to ask so that was good.

The menu overall is good - lots of options and is a bit more innovative that you would find in most Thai modern restaurants.  The food was overall good, but a couple of dishes were a tad salty.  There were alot of items that I'd still like to try and would like to go again to give it another shot.  The decor was nice and seating was comfortable.

Appetizers/starters:
- Fish cake: Good, would recommend
- Roti appetizer: Too oily, average, won't order again
- Grilled Asian eggplant, minced prawns, chicken served with lime, coconut cream dressing: Too salty, won't order again

Entrees:
- Crunch bean cakes (it's tofu): Good, would recommend
- Stuffed eggplant: Good, would recommend
- Garlic egg noodle: Taste is OK, but too salty (there's chunks of salty fish, which I don't think alot of people would like); probably pass next time
- Salmon with wintermelon over red curry: Curry flavor was good, salmon was overcooked; would recommend trying a differnt red curry dish

Dessert:
- Coconut panna cotta with mango coulis: Good, would recommend
author: Irene C.

description:
I've been to this Thai resturant multiple times and the food is great. It's always pretty crowded and lively but there isn't usually a wait for a table without a reservation which is nice. My favorite thing is the Chicken/Shrimp Pad See Yu (spelling?). If you're not extremely hungry, then I would recommend sharing because the main dish portions are pretty large. 

Overall, good and inexpensive food, nice ambiance, and okay service (not terrible but nothing to rave about).
author: Jenna Q.

description: I've been here a few times for lunch. Most of the food I've had here is okay. The price is a bit higher than other Thai places.
author: Carolina T.

description:
The restaurant is in a lovely space, with a long bar and generously spaced tables.  The service is friendly, helpful, and efficient.  As so many other Yelpers, we walked across the street from the City Beer Store (go there if you love beer) and had a very enjoyable dinner.
We started with the pan-fried pork and shrimp dumplings and some satays (lamb,chicken), all nicely prepared.  Larger plates included a curry of chicken-stuffed eggplant (really filling, the curry a bit bland) and the garlic seafood noodles (pan fried), a bit greasy and also on the bland side.  Both dishes were easily enlivened with the house hot sauce.  
After all the beer we stuck with Thai-style tea here (I like everything that has condensed milk in it).  Prices are reasonable.
author: Thor T.

description:
I love Basil Thai.  If it were closer to home, it would be my go-to Thai establishment.  Alas, I am still in search. :(

Curries are rich and flavorful.  (I am particularly a fan of the green vegetable curry and the red chicken & pumpkin curry.)  Tom Ka Gai is creamy and coconutty and filled with tasty veggies.  Pad Thai is enormous and is one of the better examples I've had in SF.  Spring rolls are fresh and well-made (though the sauce it comes with is a little bit weird).  Those are my favorites, but I know we've had plenty of other things there that were also fabulous.

Prices are reasonable (though not super-cheap) for the amount of food you get and the quality, and they do both takeout and delivery via Waiters on Wheels.  When we've eaten in, the service has been good (as in I have no notable memories of poor service), and the restaurant itself is really nice (with a full bar!).  I like getting thai there because I know what I'm getting and the prices are reasonable.  Plus, it's right across the street from City Beer Store and makes excellent post-drinking food. :)
author: Angela B.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Eggplant something = yum
2.) Pad See ew = nom nom nom nom


SERVICE:
Hostess very cheery & friendly. Server lackluster but we were well attended, water refilled right away & dishes pre-bussed by all the workers.

ATMOSPHERE:
Ah SF, where even a Thai restaurant has nice decor. Nice contemporary feel, casual enough to just grab dinner, nice enough for a date. Hanging nest looking light fixtures, a nice bar area with interesting multi-wood back panel design, candles in little square glass cubes glowing on the tables.
author: Angela L.

description:
Yum yum yum!

Went here with a large group for dinner on a Wednesday. Service was prompt, appropriately attentive (but not cloyingly so), and professionally pleasant. I was impressed by the selection and quality of the food & drinks, and would heartily recommend this as a dinner destination.

Things of note:
-Low-carb friendly dishes! (from the grill, the wok, and more -- including brown rice for those loving "good" carbs)
-Carb-lover friendly dishes! (WHY did no one in our party try any of the many noodle dishes?!?)
-Vegetarian and pescatarian friendly dishes! (Oh, the fish was SO GOOD!)
-Carnivore friendly dishes! (Including pork belly!)
-A lovely selection of wines & cocktails served at just the right temperatures
-Prices that reflect the quality and class of the restaurant, but don't gouge the wallet

I think I would recommend reservations -- they were still pretty busy by the time we arrived around 8:40pm. 

Will I be back? You can count on it.
author: Liz E.

description:
Pros:

- Food is delicious and well-presented

- Portions are filling and prices are reasonable for Thai fare in SF 

- Recommended dIsh: Gai Yang Somtum (Thai BBQed chicken with sweet corn, nuts, carrots)  It comes with rice (white or brown)

Cons:

- If you have leftovers you want to take home, be sure ask them to box everything, otherwise they will only box the uneatened items

- Hard to find inexpensive parking, but the SOMA Garage on Mission St. only charges $2/hourly!
author: B W.

description: Generally good. However, green papaya salad with prawns should mean more than three prawns. Twice now.
author: jeff c.

description:
Good place for spicy Thai cuisine lovers. 

We started with a good (not-so)spicy & sour soup with prawns (with the usual strong lemongrass flavour and the usual mushrooms that really match well with the prawns), followed by some delicious crispy rice paper wrapped tiger prawns served with sweet dipping sauce.
 
Main dishes: 
1- grilled Asian eggplant, zucchini, mushrooms and tomatoes, & bell pepper in green curry: great!

2- fire calamari, namely calamari wok-fried with bamboo shoot, scallions in lemongrass-chili puree: tender calamari rings and damn hot sauce!  one ring ... "well, not so spicy" ... two-three rings ... "uhm maybe I start understanding where the dish got its name" ... 4-5-6 rings .... "yeah, my tongue starts asking for a break but it's soooo gooood" ... At the end, you feel you have successfully accomplished the mission and you have even enjoyed it but ... wow ... your mouth is truly on fire! but it was worth. 

My dessert, a young coconut panna cotta with mango coulis, was a bit disappointing: the panna cotta was tasting a bit too sour and acid. Was it "expired" or was it meant to be like that? I did not feel like asking the waiter to find it out. Moreover, the coulis was way too sweet, despite a perfect consistency. Surely the weakest point of the evening, but, honestly, I have got used to disappointing desserts in Thai restaurants: it's simply not "their thing" . Still waiting for one counter example to prove me wrong ...

Service was friendly but not impeccable. Good ratio quality/price and sufficiently large portions.
author: Andrea L.

description: I have been here like 3 times and the food is good-really good. It's a high energy fun place. What I experienced this visit wasn't up to par with previous visits. The food was still on point, what was lacking was the service. Our waiter wasn't really on point. We waited a long time to get our orders in, he didn't come to check on us, dropped the desert menus but we had to hunt him down to order desert and then he dropped the check on the table we had to hunt him down while he was talking and laughing with other employees at the bar. Not a great experience service wise. There are ALOT of Thai restaurants in the area, and a lot of good ones so service matters.
author: Jill T.

description: The food and service are top notch... but if you enjoy spicy make sure you order it.
author: Boston M.

description: Split a duck dish, pad see ew, and chicken dish with 3 buddies. Really solid dinner.
author: Rohan S.

description:
:-)

A date took me here one night thinking it would impress me enough to get ________  and he was right. I was impressed... and so was he !;-)

Great ambiance and great food located on Folsom Street in the South of Market (SOMA) San Francisco. I've been here a number of times since, and absolutely love it.... but be sure to bring quarters for the meters... Folsom Street gets busy during the commute hours since its so close to the freeway entrance and Bay Bridge. 

http://www.basilthai.com/index.htm
