Enter and you'll be impressed by the "chic" architecture from this renovated warehouse between 7th and 8th Streets--San Francisco. The tables are set in rows opposite the sprawling contemporary bar where they serve every kind of drink imaginable....

http://www.basilthai.com/lunch_menu.htm

Have a seat and order the Plamuk Tod... light, crispy calamari rings and the Goong Kra Bog, prawns wrapped in fried rice paper and dipped into a Thai sauce. I've ordered just these with Fried Rice! 

You'll find all kinds of things here to tantalize your pallet, whether it be the food, the drink, or the people. Basil Thai is willing to accomodate any group, large or small... (cause their cool like that.)

Here for some serious food? 

http://www.basilthai.com/dinner_menu.htm

Start off with the Tom Ka Ga soup (the Thai coconut soup with lemongrass and galanga) or the Som Tum (green papaya salad tossed with ground peanuts, lime, garlic, and tomatoes)

.... add the Param Rungsong (grilled marinated skirt steak topped with peanut sauce), the Curry Peppercorn Duck (roasted duck & stringless snap peas wok-tossed with curry paste & peppercorn), the Hoi Ka-Ta (scallops with tempura long beans wok-fried in Thai black bean, chili and wine) and the Kao Pad Supparot (Thai pineapple fried rice with raisin and prawns) and your GOOD to GO!

http://www.basilthai.com/wine.htm

They've got tasty desserts as well: 
* Lightly fried banana served with coconut ice cream
* Sweet sticky rice with fresh mango
* Young coconut panacotta
* Thai coffee granita top with kahlua and whipped cream
* Tapioca pudding with corn and taro

THAT'S A THAI PARTY IN YOUR MOUF! 

4 WOOFS.. Reasonably priced and tasty! I continue to frequent this place every time I'm in town. I don't drink but if I'd did, I'd be hammered on the variety of tasty drinks offered..... OOOOOO mo ji TOHHHHHHHH!
author: JöHnNy A.

description: Food is really nothing special. Indian pancake was way too greasy and oily and I had to use tissue to suck up all the oil. The lamb was overcooked. The taste of each dish is just no better than any take-away Thai restaurants. The dishes were definitely worth only star. I gave it a 2 stars only because the interior sitting area was friendly. Otherwise don't expect me to come back. Just a waste of money! For $80 bucks you can go to a much nicer restaurant with better food. STAY AWAY!!!
author: Max Z.

description: Just tried this place for the first time today. It was good. I had the tamarind prawns and they were great. The service is excellent as well. I've been looking for an authentic Thai place resembling what I've had in Bangkok...this is the closest I've found so far. I'll certainly go again and try other stuff.
author: Firas A.

description:
We walked to Manora's but they were closed for a half hour between lunch and dinner.  Jen said "I heard there's this place, Basil around here"...

I bike by a few times a week and had always thought this place was a firehouse or something.  Points for a cool place in an unexpected location.

The menu was both briefer, more tempting, and a little more costly than usual Thai places I've been to.  

The portions were also a bit smaller than usual (so, one filling meal without leftovers), with pungently complex flavors and high quality.  I got garlic noodles with basil and clams and was incredibly pleased.  The cocktail list made me drool though I wasn't drinking, so I'll have to return.  Recommended as a place to make a good impression.
author: Pat L.

description: Truly excellent food, great portions and outstanding service.  Made for an excellent evening.  Duck, calamari and the steak were all winners.  Nice wine selection too.
author: C K.

description:
The interior was so plush! It made me feel like I was in a really fancy restaurant, but without the ridiculous prices. I loved the atmosphere and the service was impeccable. It's very romantic, I'd suggest it for dates.

My friend had a shrimp dish, and I had a fish and eggplant meal, and we split a sake and curry puff appetizers. The food was a little greasier than what I'm used to, but I'd be more than happy to come here again to try out their other meals.
author: Selina C.

description:
BEST Green Curry sauce in the city, bar none.

From the start, once I bit in to the Keow Wan Roti (fried Indian bread with green curry & eggplant), I knew we were in for a treat.  The sauce was creamy and fragrant, with a hint of kaffir lime, which was so nice with the bread and smoky eggplant.   The krispy spring rolls were also tasty.

For the main course, we had the Choo Chee Talay (grilled prawns and scallops in curry with lychee and kaffir lime zest), and the Stuffed Eggplant (grilled eggplant stuffed with minced chicken and vegetables, and more green curry sauce!).  Both were very unusual and good - such a departure from all of the same-old, same-old Thai food that's usually available.  I definitely recommend the brown rice, which is nutty and chewy with great texture.

The sleek and modern decor makes Basil Thai suitable for multiple events, from a special occasion group dinner to a casual stop after hitting the bars.  

For the freshness and creativity, I liked it about one hundred billion times better than the other "upscale" Thai restaurants like Osha Thai, and can't wait to go back and try some of the other dishes.
author: Liz S.

description:
This restaurant is one of those unexpected gems. Basil manages to be everything that a restaurant should be: nice subtle decor, cool diverse crowd, good portions and quite affordable. It's good enough to be a nice first date and friendly enough to become a regular.

For starters, we had grilled Indian bread with green curry and oriental eggplant. The bread was slightly fried, crispy and flaky. The green curry was so delicious we cleaned up the plates. For entrees, we had the roasted duck & string-less snap peas wok-tossed with curry paste & peppercorn. The curry was amazing. The peppercorn gave it a subtle little edge. We also had grilled marinated skirt steak with peanut sauce. The meat was perfectly marinated and the peanut sauce on the sweet side. I only wished they would serve it with something a little bit more exciting than steamed broccoli and sliced tomatoes.

It is probably one of the best Thai restaurant I've ever been to. It's not super authentic... I'd call it Modern Thai but it's definitely worth a try. I'd give it 4.5 stars if I could!
author: Didier N.

description: My hunger may have made me delusional, but it seemed to take forever to be waited on here. I tried to make the best of the time by looking through the extensive menu and picking out a few things to try. Someone eventually came to save us and then brought food that made the wait somewhat worthwhile. Good, but not great. At least it was cheap. After spending a small fortune on dinners recently, it was nice to find reasonable prices.
author: Brett B.

description: Went there on a Friday night and it was so noisy that my friends and I couldn't hear each other. Food was so-so, not very authentic.
author: Fiona T.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday party dinner last evening.  Their specialty is Thai Food and the restaurant is nice and cosy....

For appetizers, we had a combinaton of chicken satay skewers, egg rolls and fried shrimp.

We then had multiple dishes that included tastes of green curry, yellow curry, steak dish, pad thai, shrimp dishes.  Therefore, I got the opportunity to sample many of their dishes and felt that it was just good.  

I would definitely come back for casual dinner parties and such.
author: Edward L.

description:
One of those places that almost always hits the spot. Great menu items (def try the Indian flat bread with green curry on top). Be prepared to see people in full gear during the Folsom street fair, or Halloween, or... A "normal" day in sf. I remember walking in and seeing a table with 3-4 80 something year old women having a girls night out, right next to a table with 2 couples who looked like the just finished a mid to low budget porn shoot. 

Good food, good service, good drinks and the ambiance is lively and fun. I recommend it's sister restaurant (basil canteen) if on a date, it's darker and has better lighting and settings. I've seen bachelorette party tables here a number of times... It's a good spot for groups. Try the beef salad here. A little spicy but very good. Also a good spot for lunch.
author: Anish B.

description: Can't go wrong with some tom ka gai soup with enough taste to knock your socks off. Stuffed eggplant was delicious and the pad thai makes the grade. Fun little hangout, good decor, ok service. Good for large groups and family style eating.
author: Naomi K.

description: We had the Sirloin and the duck in red curry with rice and it all tastet very good. Good seasoning and not too spicy. The waiter was very good too. We spent $56 for two people with one starter, beer and white wine and even with taxes and gratuity. We came a little before 6 pm and there were happy hour on snacks and drinks. Cozy restaurant, cheap and great food!
author: Louise D.

description:
Food is pretty good but why the 2 stars? Our pretty, older sister version of Maggie Q, waitress made it a very unpleasant experience. Of course she felt she was allowed to act however the way she wanted because we were a group of 10 so 18% gratuity was already included. This waitress even slammed a bowl of rice on my boyfriend's plate which we all thought was odd but that wasn't all...

She kept reminding us that they charge $1.50/person to cut cake and we told her we just had mini cupcakes which were bite size. She said no outside food or else they will charge. We understood the first 2 times she said it but once my friend took a peek in the box, she came back and said it again. After ordering our food and waiting for the rest of our party, she suddenly said that on Fridays and Saturdays, the bill has to equal $15/person. First of all... there was nothing on the menu that said that. We couldn't even find where it said that in the restaurant. She should have said that before anyone ordered. Most of the non-curry dishes were just 10 bucks. The waitress said we should order drinks and most of us did but that apparently did not meet the minimum charge yet... so she kept shoving the dessert menu at us. Annoyed by her attitude, we asked another waiter if this $15/person was really required and he said they usually don't apply it to large groups like us. We told our waitress that and she said she's the supervisor and stood by her claim. All of us were stuffed so we asked 'what if we didn't want to order anything?' and she said most people just do it. Then she suggested we can eat our cupcakes in here so the charge would be more than enough... she crazy? Finally, we asked to speak to the manager but he was not there so she "called" him. Result: our waitress said the manager would let us slide this once but next time, we cannot. NEXT TIME?? I don't think so. Oh yeah, we found out that we ordered more than enough to meet the minimum charge... even though she said we were short $15... 

Besides this tip-grubbing lady, the food is good, portion is enough, and prices are reasonable. I mean the $15/person on Friday and Saturday is not too big of a deal if you order curry and rice since that's over $15 anyway. (Pad-kee-mao -$10- is pretty good btw!) 

Basil Thai might deserve more stars but the waitress made us leaving this place with such a horrible impression that none of us will ever come here again.
author: Pansy L.

description: I went here for lunch with my boyfriend, my dad, and his girlfriend. My dad and his lady are new to Thai food, but both of them managed to find entrees on the menu that they thoroughly enjoyed. I had the lunch combo so that I could sample two different entrees and they were both awesome. The service could have been a bit better, but the food was so delightful that I'm giving them 5 stars anyway.
author: Kristen B.

description:
Best Thai in SF with recycleable to-go packaging.

Basil Thai is not just your average SF thai restaurant - the quality of the food here far exceeds any hole-in-the-wall, off-the-beaten-path sort of place you thought was a secret jewel.  

The real jewel is Basil Thai - sure, they've got upscale decor and it's exceedingly well turned out.  The service is spotless - they are attentive, timely and considerate.  I have never had bad customer service nor poor quality food at Basil Thai.

Basil Thai offers consistently great Thai food at reasonable prices. When you dine in the restaurant, you feel like you're in a much more "high end" restaurant than most Thai places. My favorite lunch is the crispy bean curd & cashew nut -- and they do a fantastic sticky rice with mango. I also recommend the cellophane noodles, and the corn fritter. They do good fried and fresh veggie rolls (porpia and porpia sod).

They also have put some thought into the containers for take-out orders. Owner Arun told me "Our to-go packing are totally recyclable." At lunch time for large order or a buffet style they use aluminum tray, for a smaller order or individual bento box, coated brown paper box. For dinner they use a combination of high quality recyclable, reuseable plastic container and coated brown paper.
Edit My Review Manage Review 

The lunches are fantastic.  I recommend getting the lunch specials - mostly rice plates - really nicely done with just the right amount of food (I'm a pretty big person and an athlete).

I adore their kao pode tod (yellow corn fritters) -- I don't know of any place else in the city that does these, and they are not soggy greaseballs like corn fritters tend to be at Southern restaurants.  Their pad thai is fantastic, and the "crunchy beancakes" (aka fried tofu) are really nicely done.  The green papaya salad is always out of this world.  The curries are also very tasty and I try to get curry at least every other visit.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I really liked Basil. I had the Pad Thai and I loved the fact that they didn't mix in the sprouts and pine nuts already. It had a lot of flavor, and the portion was just right. If you order curry, you have the choice of brown, white or jasmine rice, which is pretty cool. My boss ordered the eggplant curry stuffed with chicken and brown rice, and it looked and smelled amazing.

Their Spring Rolls and Roti were both very good as appetizers.

Great service and cute atmosphere.
author: Christine A.

description:
Had dinner here for about the third time and this is a really good place.  The service is attentive, atmosphere is pleasant, and food tasty.  

We were seated promptly, given water, and crispy shrimp chips.  To start we had the crispy vegi rolls and fried calamari for app's and they serve it with a kiler sweet orange sauce.  

Our dinner consisted of steak cubes eggplant and curry sauce and also the catfish which was lighly fried and spicy.  Jasmine rice was ordered and washed it all down with beer and my wife had a mojito.  

The prices are pretty reasonable and would highly recommend checking out this place.
author: James H.

description:
Was looking around for places before a show and decided on something different.  We made reservations for 6pm on a Friday night (we didn't need them since it didn't start picking up until we left at 7pm).

The service was pretty good and had at least three or four different waitstaff serve us (or ask us if we needed servicing).

The food was phenomenal.  The taste was fantastic and a HUGE amount of food.

For two, with drinks and apps, cost around $70 (after tip).  I thought it was VERY reasonable for the quality and quantity of food.
author: Matt G.

description:
Loved every morsel of the yummy food!!....came here for lunch to celebrate hubby's b'day........with so many great reviews it was hard to ignore this place......the interior is very unlike a typical thai place, no figurines and a few paintings from thailand.....its almost a western-thai fusion decor.......we were instantly seated since it wasn't crowded.....service was prompt and polite.....

the menu is unique with several good combinations of meat and veggies....... started with veggie spring rolls which were crispy and had a delicious, well seasoned filling.....came with sweet sauce and we asked for the thai hot sauce to complement......for main course I ordered the eggplant, shiitake and tofu stir fry and hubby ordered the lamb curry......both entries came with choice of rice, we went for brown rice.........stir fry was done just right with tender crisp veggies and a slight sauce......but lamb was the star of the afternoon........marinated in peanut sauce and then grilled .......slightly charred (just the way I like) but tender and sweet in a light peanut sauce.....the green beans and carrots that were part of the curry didn't quite go with the lamb though......sans that, the dish was amazing!
would visit this place again next time we are in SOMA, san fran.
author: nanu b.

description:
This is definitely the best Thai food I have had thus far in the bay area - and I LOVE Thai food, so I have been to a bunch of places.

2 of my girlfriends and I came here for lunch on a Wednesday - we made a reservation for 12:45 for 3 people, but upon arriving realized we didn't need it.  Since this place is in SOMA, I guess it is too far for most financial district people to go (unless they have a car or take muni I guess).

The food was absolutely delicious.  We started out with the roti bread with green curry sauce and eggplant (as fellow yelpers recommended) - you just can't go wrong with that.  Fried bread with curry sauce?  Amazing.

We shared the following 3 entrees:
-Grilled skirt steak with peanut sauce - to die for, and definitely my favorite item.  The steak was incredibly tender and cooked to perfection, and the peanut sauce on top was just right, not too overwhelming like peanut sauce can often be.
-Pad ke mao with chicken instead of beef - delicious, well-flavored noodles, better than the pad ke mao I have had at other Thai places.
-Minced chicken stuffed eggplant with green curry sauce - if you like curry and eggplant, then you will definitely enjoy this dish.

Overall, a great experience.  The service was timely and nice, and the atmosphere was lovely as well.  Excellent quality of food for reasonable prices.  Came out to $14 each, which included an appetizer, 3 entrees, a drink, and 20% tip.  Awesome!
author: Sandra M.

description:
This place is PACKED!! Good thing my boyfriend thought ahead and made reservations the night before. When we walked in and got our table, we literally got an audience of death stares. As we sat down, I could feel their stares burning a hole into me.

Even though it was pretty crowded, we were able to grab the waiter a few times to order appetizers first - lamb skewers, calamari, and curry puffs. First, the calamari was suppose to be calamari skewers and the curry dish never came out. Good thing, he didn't even put it on the bill, so we didn't have to argue with him about it.

I ordered the nuer ta cai (Angus sirloin cubes stir-fried with lemongrass. bell peppers, & roasted chili paste). This was delicious!! It was so good I didn't really want to share it with anyone. My boyfriend got the kang ped, which was also very good. I liked the curry sauce on my white rice.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Thank you Basil Thai...
For always being there when I need you...
For being open on NYE and being affordable...
For having tons of parking right outside of the restaurant...
For your professional staff who are willing to put up with my wacky friends squirting you with fake cigarettes and sticking third eyes on you...
And, thank you most of all for having such delectable treats on your menu...thank you, especially, lamb curry and fried bananas! 
I wouldn't be what I am without you...
author: Michelle D.

description:
This gets one star for nice decor and cleanliness. Otherwise I would say this place is not a good choice for a meal.

We ordered multiple dishes to share, including the mixed seafood soup, pad kee mao, the seafood noodle dish, the skirt steak, sea bass and crab fried rice. Aside from the rice, all the dishes were overly salty and without any of the good thai spices that thai dishes usually have. The skirt steak especially was so salty and had no other taste to it that we didn't even touch it after the first bite.

What was even more frustrating was that when the bill came out, they charged us an extra $3 for a fried egg on the crab fried rice that we didn't even order. Be careful of that when you order your dishes. Even though its only an extra $3, I thought it was poor service because they didn't ask us if we wanted the extra egg, but added it on and charged us for it. 

I've had a lot better thai food and wouldn't come back here again.
author: Elaine C.

description: I love thai food and this place is awesome! I don't think you can go wrong with anything you order. We had crab fried rice, eggplant and pad kee mow (i think thats how its spelled!). Their cocktails were delicious as well, mango cosmo mmmmm!!!
author: Kiran J.

description: Excellent cuisine but stay away on noisy weekend nites.  My ears are still ringing after a Sat nite dinner.  It was hard to enjoy the great food.  There is one table at the front of the dining room that might be below the threshold of pain.  Seriously, I couldn't hear the waitress unless she was speaking in my ear; it's that loud.
author: Joel C.

description:
Corn fritters were a real treat and a must order. Green papaya salad was wonderful and the spring rolls crispy, lite and fresh. 
Service was spot on. So drop in if near by and try them out.
author: Red D.

description:
Took the gf here for her bday weekend dinner.  She was craving Thai food, so we decided to take a drive to the city.  

We were sat at the VIP table for two, if you're a regular there then you know which table I am talking about.  You can see the table from the front window which is a good way to attract people to come in and have some yummy Thai food.

For drinks she had the Mango Cosmo and I had a Hef.

For starters, we ordered the curry puffs and keow wan roti.

For our entrees, we had the nuer yang, kang ped and nuer ta cai (I think).  Try saying that order 3 times!

It was pretty loud inside, but that was due to the large group of LOUD people.  

The service was great!  The staff checked up on us several times making sure we had enough water and making sure the food was to our satisfaction.

Overall I would come here again to have some GOOD Thai food!
author: Alden W.

description: This is a solid four stars.  Probably one of best places to eat Thai food in the City.  Staff are friendly.  Atmosphere is good and looks clean. Good place for an afternoon lunch with friends.  If you are coming with a big group...call ahead as this place could get crowded during lunch.  Great for walkers, real bad for drivers - there's no parking provided so take your chances if you're driving.
author: Nixon L.

description:
Have been here three times for company lunch and have always had good experience.

I'm a non-spicy eater, so I don't have too many choices. The first time i had Praram Rong Song (steak with peanut sauce and vegetables), second time had lamb yang, and today went back to the steak again because it's good. 

The portion of the food is just right, actually even a bit too big for me. I could have leftover take-out every time for a second meal.

All in all, good service, good price, good food. Would be even better for me if there were more non-spicy options.
author: Koala B.

description: really great food and service. The dry fried Prawns were awesome.
author: Travis J.

description:
More like 3.5 stars.

Just had dinner last night here with some friends for a birthday. The place is located in a pretty convenient location. I know a couple of my friends walked just a couple blocks from the bart station over, so it's in a pretty good location if you're downtown and looking for a decent place to eat. 

We had a party of 12 and a reservation for 7:00. We were seated promptly. The restaurant was packed, but there was no wait when I arrived. A party trickled on after us, and the hostess told them 15 minutes. Not too bad, I think, for a Saturday night dinner around 7. 

Anyway, we all sat, and were served extremely quickly. I think we were all impressed by the service. Most of our got pad thai, which some of my friends complained was a bit sweet, but I honestly have a hard time differentiating between bad pad thai and good pad thai, so it tasted pretty good to me. Some other friends ordered Pad Ke Mao and some Thai chicken salad and curry dishes. I think mostly everyone felt the food was decent, nothing not to rave nor complain about. It only took about 10 minutes, at most, to serve all but one of us, which was almost impressive, but the last missing meal was another pad thai which 4 of us got, so I guess they had miscounted the number of pad thais. Regardless, his meal took almost longer to whip up than all the other meals did... a bit strange. 

The waitress and servers were all very courteous and prompt. One thing that sorta bugs me about restaurants: places that don't serve a small something for a birthday. I mean if a Korean BBQ joint sticks a candle in a 25 cent Chocopie for a birthday, I think most places can afford to put a little cookie down and top off more than half the dessert cup with whipped cream. We ordered him a Coffee dessert with whipped cream, shaved ice, and kahlua. Not worth it. 

At the end of the meal, we thought we'd overpaid and of course, they had already added gratuity in the meal, so after the waitress took our check and the cash and card we put down, we seemed to be $7 short, which we were convinced we were not. But no one wants to make a complication out of something like that on our beloved friend's birthday. So we forked our money over and left. I'm not sure how situations like these are usually resolved, but I think most of the members in our party felt that they wanted to recount the money again, since more than a couple of us had counted all the money we put down. I guess it would have been a bit more courteous to come back with our money or at least grab someone from the table and deal with it by the computer than to come over and just straight up tell us we were down $7. 

Overall, it was an okay experience. Nothing spectacular, nothing awful, The price is acceptable for the food, but I doubt I will return.
author: stacy c.

description:
Beautiful ambiance, casual dining with a splash of elegance. Every dish was so beautifully presented. The servers were kind and patient. We highly enjoyed our time here. I'd like to check out the sister restaurant "Basil Cantina" and compare the two. 

Sake: 
Yuki No Bosha - Junmai Ginjo. BEST Sake I've ever had! **Dangerously smooth** 

Starters: 
Crispy spring rolls stuffed with vermicelli and cabbage 
Shrimp & minced pork dumpling with Thai style ginger soy sauce 
Roti - grilled Indian bread with green curry and oriental eggplant. This was my favorite of the three. 

Main: 
Calamari wok-fried, scallions in lemongrass-chili puree 
Tangy red curry of julienned chicken breast and pumpkin (MY FAV) 
Crispy catfish filet sautéed in kaffir red curry paste 

Dessert: 
Thai coffee gelatin with Kahlua and whip cream. So yummy!!
author: Kelly M.

description:
I went here for a birthday dinner and was pleasantly surprised.

*Decor was super modern and trendy.

*Prices were very affordable - plates ranged from $10 - $16.

*Great for larger groups!  A rare find in the city since most places forces you to put a credit card down and choose prefix menu with large reservations.

I glanced at the menu and quickly decided I wanted the panang short ribs.  I love Thai curry and also love short ribs - I just never had them together!  I was glad I decided to go with this entree because it was super good.  The meat was so soft and tender it fell right off.  Curry was very flavorful and had a strong coconut flavor.  My only complaint was that it just wasn't that spicy enough.  I had to ask for some extra hot sauce to add that extra kick Thai food usually always had.  Besides that, I would say this is a pretty decent place to eat at.
author: Jenny H.

description:
My bf and I came here on a Tuesday night before watching West Side Story at the Orpheum.  We walked a couple of blocks from the bart station- a nice walk to work up the appetite! We had an early dinner, so we didn't have to worry about waiting at all. However I made a reservation just in case! 

We had their curried dumplings for an appetizer. It was really yummy, I didn't even know I was eating duck until my bf told me. haha! I guess I didn't read the description at all. I had the eggplant green curry and my bf had their Pad Kee Mow.  I liked his noodles more than my curry.  He seemed to like the curry though.  The green curry had too much of a ginger taste for me, which is why I didn't love it.  

We also ordered their tapioca pudding for dessert but they were out! Our waitress recommended their sticky rice with mango.  I didn't like it at all, but being the asians we are, we finished it.

The service and ambiance of the restaurant deserve 4 stars. 
The food...I'd give it 3.5 stars but I can't. 
So I'll round up and give it 4 stars.
author: Connie C.

description: Compared to Thai food in NYC, this place's dishes did rather well.  On my visit to SF, we stumbled upon this resto, which happened to be very close to where we were staying.  Apart from the additional costs for rice, I don't have much complaints about this place. Prices are decent, decor is stylish, and service is pleasant.  Go here if you're in SOMA.
author: Geraldine K.

description: Really good thai, some of the best I've had. Got the chicken pad see ew. Pretty pricey
author: Aneesh S.

description:
Loved the atmosphere and authentic Thai flavors. It really brought me back to my trip to Thailand! It also doesn't hurt that it is just around the corner from where I live. Came here for our date night and I thought it was the perfect date spot. 

The BF and I had the calamari, pad kee mao, and a spicy chicken dish. I think the calamari was the best I have ever had. It was light and not greasy tasting, but still the perfect amount of crisp. The entrees were good, but perhaps a little too spicy. Although, the pad kee mao really tasted like the real thing. I think the chicken dish left something to be desired. I'll definitely give this place another try since it is around the corner, had great atmosphere, and delicious food!
author: Angela L.

description:
Good place, came here after stopping by the REI store. Sat at the bar, and had the veggie spring roll appetizer--3 full-size rolls hot out of the fryer cut in half.

Easily feeds 2-3. It was a lot for 1 person!

Mojito was good, main course was Basil Eggplant. Tender, perfect, with a nice sauce to complement.

Live in East Bay and work off the Embarcadero BART, so it's a bit out of the way. But if you're ever in the area, you won't be disappointed.
author: Julius O.

description: Duck is my favorite meat and so when I run across unsatisfying duck dishes, I get way more crankier than if it was any other kind of meat. I ordered the "curry peppercorn duck" because there is not one word in that phrase that I do not like. I love curry, I love peppercorns, and I love duck. What I got was tough duck, overly salty food, and just a general "meh" quality to the dish. There are very few dishes that I would turn away from if it includes duck; unfortunately, this is one of the few dishes that have affected me in this way. I usually don't give bad reviews for just one dish, but I just found it completely unacceptable for a dish to have so many elements of what I love and I still was not able to enjoy it. (Although for the record, the other two dishes that were ordered and the appetizer was good, but that does not make up for the poor quality of the dish that I had.)
author: Kristen S.

description:
I went here once for dinner a few years ago and enjoyed it, but never made it back until just recently when I went for lunch with friend.  

We arrived around 12:15 and street parking was easy.  The restaurant was almost empty when we got there, but I could tell that it was a popular lunch destination because it was completely full by the time we left.  

We started with the Grilled Indian Bread with Green Curry appetizer.  That dish was really delicious.  It was a light, naan-type bread with a flavorful green curry with chicken on top.  I could have eaten the whole thing by myself!

For my main course I had the Pad Talay Raummit (shrimp, mussels, and calamari fried in a wok with chili, onion and Thai basil).  It's marked as one of their "spicy" dishes, but it wasn't too spicy (for me, at least...I like it super hot!).  The flavor was good and the mussels and calamari were cooked just right.  

I think the next time I make it back there I'll probably try one of the curry dishes because I wished that the sauce on my entree was a little thicker like the curry sauce that we had in the appetizer.  (That's just a personal preference.)

If the location was closer to my home or work I'd probably return more often.  Unfortunately, it's just not that convenient for me and wouldn't be a "destination" restaurant, but I would go back again if I were going to be in the area.

(This would be a 3.5 if I could give it!)
author: Kimberly B.

description: Good stuff. Been there ~5 times. Pad-kee-mao is good. Curry wasn't. Catfish is awesome. Lamb rack was over-cooked but somehow pretty good.
author: Nick C.

description:
The Hubster and me continue to enjoy Basil.  We dined with them again last night.  The food was delicious.  Hubby has become addicted to their Panang Short Ribs.  I must say from the bite I had I understand why.  Complex flavors with a hint of heat and a nice round beef flavor.  I had the fire calamari.  Nicely spicy and extremely tender.  We also enjoyed the curried duck puff appetizer.  It was a taste-bud festival with the Fisticuffs Cabernet we sipped.  

Service last night was perfect!  Sometimes we're in a rut with our restaurant choices but this is an awfully tasty rut.  We'll be back.
author: Russell D.

description:
My BF and I were in the neighborhood and I remembered coming here years and years ago so I suggested we give them another try.  They used to give out shrimp chips like how a Japanese sushi house would give out complimentary edamame but I guess they stopped doing that.  Booo!

We wanted to share a dish so we ordered the Chicken yellow curry.  Watch out for the tiny chicken bones!!!  The menu doesn't say anything about bones and we weren't expecting it at all.  The dish was delicious but it was just strange for a decent restaurant to not de-bone a chicken for you, especially in a curry dish.

Overall, service was quick and the food was good.  I liked the atmosphere, I think it would be a good lounge after hours.  Maybe it is; I don't know.
author: Rosalind S.

description: Amazing! The curry here is fantastic.  Everything was fresh and presented perfectly.  The staff was also very attentive.  Very affordable.
author: Tim R.

description:
4.5 star -Classy, upscale interior. Really tasty dishes. A top 10 Thai place of the 50+ i've been to in my life.

Tom Ka soup & Tom Yum soup - both were some of the better Thai soups I've tasted. Excellant use of coconut. Ingrediants were high quality. The spices were perfect too. Whole, fresh veggies. A must get starter.

Angus steak cubes - great thick Thai teriyaki-like sauce. Get it extra spicy with some brown rice on the side. 4/5 star dish.

Pad See Ew - a safe dish. Pretty good. Meat was all fillet (no fat), and noodles were well cooked. 

Fried spicy catfish filets - really good, except a bit soggy. It it was fried a bit more that would have been perfect. The fish and sauce itself were great.

Crackling Pork - really perfectly crackling. Fatty as all pork is. I recommend it, but it's probably gonna make you real full.

Service is very attentive as well and the menu stated you could split the check 4 ways max too. I highly recommend this place. All that food (and along with the 18% gratuity) and I only paid $20 a head.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Two of my good friends celebrated their birthday here at Basil.  The first thing you'll notice is the modern decor and soft lighting (see my pics).  We had a party of over 30 people and we occupied the entire rear section of the restaurant.  They decided on a set menu served family style.  I was drunk so I don't remember the specifics of the food but I do recall everything tasting good.  The dishes came out one after another starting with appetizers and ending with entrees.  There had to be more than 7 courses served.  I've eaten Thai food at a dozen other places and this place is probably in the top three.  The service was efficient for the huge party we had.  

We spent most of our time at the bar where we got our fill of moderately priced drinks.  I can't review on the mixed drinks but the bartenders were cool and service was fast.  

We continued the party at the club across the street, can't remember the name.
author: Rod P.

description:
Went here for the first time for dinner.  Didn't have reservations, but quickly got in at the bar.

Based on other recommendations, ordered the Porpia Sod spring rolls to start with.  They were excellent!  Loved the dipping sauce!

Ordered the Pad Ke Mao (spicy noodles) and Monk's Delight with both brown and white rice for entrees.

First off, the noodles were really great with lots of flavor and a mild spice.  Personally, if I ordered it again I would have them leave off the beef since I'm not that big of a beef and noodle fan.  But that's just me.  YMMV!  :-)

The Monk's Delight was excellent as well - and surprisingly spicy (good thing).  The only slight drawback was that the tofu in the dish was not of the firm variety.  Again, just a personal preference thing.

One additional note:  The white rice was surprisingly really sticky.  Once all the delicious juices from the Monk's Delight absorbed into the rice, it was simply divine.  So, don't forget to order the rice as it is a la cart - at least on the dinner menu.

Would happily revisit this delightful establishment!
author: David V.

description:
Best Thai in town.  
Their vegetable fried roll is about the best.  Crunchy.  Thin and Crisp.
Pad thai is yummy and tasty
Crab fried rice is about the best thing.  Get it with the Fried Egg, so worth it.
The papaya salad is fresh, tangy, just the way it should be.
Thai coffee and ice tea are perfect.  Just the right about the sweet.
Mango sticky rice reminds me of my trip to Thailand.
The duck curry is also a favorite.
And I regularly get their Tom Yum.
Is there anything on the menu that I don't like.

I think I don't get the satays because they aren't that special.  I prefer the calamari, the roti, dumpling or fried rolls for apps.

So many main dishes worth trying that i can't even begin.
All I can say is prices are good and fair. 
And service is not overly friendly but calming. 
Interior for a Thai restaurant is minimal and beautiful.
I love this place....not just a neighborhood find.
author: Nancy L.

description:
I came here with some friends as this was a close walking distance from our hotel. The place is small and cozy. Prices were reasonable except for the soft drinks. I was hoping that I could get a refill of Thai ice tea, but I didn't want to have to pay another $3 to get one. 

I had the fried calamari for an appetizer. It wasn't greasy and was crispy. I enjoyed the dipping sauce that came with it.

I also order the grilled skirt steak with peanut sauce. It seemed like a good portion of beef if you aren't a big eater, but I am so I had to order a side bowl of brown rice to go with it. The sauce didn't leave a heavy  peanut taste in my mouth which is good because I finished my drink a little quick and didn't want to pay for another. 

A look around at the dishes my friends ordered and we all agreed that if you are looking for something to fill you up, it would be the noodles. 

I wouldn't mind coming back here again the next time we go to San Francisco.
author: Peter Q.

description: Favorite thai restaurant in the city. Pan fried Indian bread with curry is good for appetizer. Had the Asian eggplant with shiitake mushroom and the yellow curry with tofu. Both were delicious. Service here is quick and friendly. Recommend making reservations for dinner.
author: Mike J.

description: A lot like the Paul Simon song, still yummy after all these years!
author: Ted R.

description:
I went on a date tonight. My first internet date in three years in fact.

We had the green seafood curry--AMAZING scallops and curry flavor was perfect. We also had a praram--of which we invented a tofu version of the beef one on the menu. They were happy to swap that out with no problem. Nice ambiance amazing service. With some fresh rolls for an appetizer the bill came to an easy $42. I'm a fan.
author: Alex S.

description: This was an easy place to get dinner on a Saturday night before going out to the clubs/bars. They are flexible with there reservations and the food is pretty good.
author: Ashley R.

description:
I came here before seeing a movie at the Westfield.  I wanted Thai but I thought I should upgrade myself and try this place out instead of Coriander.  I will admit that the food is a step up from Coriander and it should be since its a little pricier here.  
The service was a little spotty and the hand offs between the host and waiter was not as smooth as could be.  Also if you are on a time budget I would let them know before hand, we waited a little bit before they came over asking for our orders.  And you may ask what is a little bit? Menus closed.  Sideways glances to the waiter.  10 minutes roll by.  Our water glasses are attentively filled 2x before the waitress comes over.  I think it was just a busy night for them and I'll definitely swing by again.  
Red curry and pad kee mao were A+.
author: Sarah C.

description: I love this place! I have eaten at the restaurant several times before but recently on nights when I don't have time to cook I order it for pick up and it's ready in 15 minutes. They have only messed up my order once, but that's okay- I will still be ordering my Thai food to go from here because it's the best!
author: Victoria C.

description: Who would've thought a restaurant as nice as this one would exist in SOMA of all places? The lush, welcoming interior and the friendly waitstaff make Basil one of the best kept secrets in SF. We ordered vegetable rolls to start which were served piping hot. The tasty sauce was a mix of sweet, sour and spicy. It definitely had a unique taste to it. My boyfriend ordered Red Duck Curry, his dad ordered some vegetable and chicken dish and I had the Pad Se Ew which was served with thinner noodles because they were out of the thick ones. All of the dishes looked and smelled really tasty. The prices are within reason. I think we paid less than $40 for one appetizer and three entrees. Not a bad deal. Street parking was plentiful as well.
author: Amy J.

description: This used to be my go to Thai place, but I'm sad to say that with each visit the quality of the food seems to steadily heading downhill. Especially with to go orders. The staff is always friendly and efficient, but unless things turn around I doubt I'll keep coming back.
author: Phoebe H.

description:
Surprisingly good (Nothing great, but fairly priced good food.).  I had the garlic eggplant tofu with brown rice, and the coconut ice cream with fried bananas for dessert - yummy! Overall, a place i would definitely try again - to test consistency, and see if i want to bump them up to 4 stars. The portions are of decent size and you may have left overs (i did)! 

Food: Good
Decor: Good
Service: Fair
author: Harvinder K.

description:
As a true yelper when I was asked out on a date and given the power to select the location I dug around yelp looking for a place to go for dinner (he left the planning up to me since he's new to the city). and I found this adorable place on Folsom called Basil Thai. I took bart up there to meet him, and the walk was through the loveliness that is the tenderloin. I asked this elderly lady if I was walking in the right direction to get to Folsom and she said yes "be careful hunney". Haha great. that only worried me a wee bit. 

The restaurant was really cute. From the outside it's a fairly simple looking grey building on a janky street. But the inside was beautiful. It's the perfect date place. Quiet, dimly lit with candles, and simply but elegantly decorated. The service staff was very efficient, which was an amazing plus. I hate going on dates and having a waiter/waitress trying to be extra friendly and strike up a conversation with you. Obviously we're on a date, so stop interrupting! Didn't have that problem here. They were polite and quiet, quickly refilled our waters a dozen times over, and didn't flash giant, toothy smiles that make you feel uncomfortable. 

The food had it's ups and downs. Less of the latter. We had calamari as an appetizer and a duck dish and chicken dish for entrees. The duck was amazing! This is the first time I've ever had duck and I'm in loveeeee. The chicken was minced and not much to my liking, though it did have little bits of red chili in it. Every once in a while I'd bite into one and there'd be a 'pop" of fire in my mouth. It was quite entertaining. No dessert, much too full to try anything though they sounded tasty. 

I'm sure by now you're thinking, "this review is great and all, descriptive and whatnot, but what about the GUY??" 

Haha, well, I won't make you suffer in anticipation any longer....I'm not telling! A lady never dates and tells :p
author: Scooby D.

description:
Came here for my second VDAY dinner.
This restaurant is somewhat Americanized  but with a touch of authentic. 
We ordered the tigar praws tempura, which were alright; not sure if they were thee ACTUAL tiger...got the sauteed calamari which were nasty, i love calamari but ONLY fried calamari, so i decided  to order my minced chicken and my date got the pork shoulder. Everything that we ordered was spicy, but its all good though because i love hot spicy foods. As for our dessert, we got the fried banana+coconut ice cream. I've had better fried banana elsewhere. Their fried banana was simple, not sweet at all. So i was little dissapointed about that considering the fact that i have a sweeth tooth. Our tab came out to be $54+tip, which i thought was a little pricey and the restaurant itself did not have much going on...no decors. 
I still prefer my FAVORITE...LITTLE THAI on Polk.
author: Rose P.

description:
My boss took me here for lunch, and it was fun to have thai food in the middle of the day as opposed to during dinner time when I generally eat thai.

I really like the ambiance of the place, the decor is really nice- it is trendy, but there's a tranquil vibe because the decor is simple and relatively minimalistic, and the frosted glass-cube wall lets in lots of afternoon light.  

We both ordered thai ice teas. In my opinion, it was slightly over-sweetened, but it was fine. It gave my boss a tummy-ache though, but she thinks she's just sensitive to dairy.

I ordered the gai prik khing rice plate ($8.95 I think)- crispy chicken and string beans, in a slightly spicy sauce with fried basil and a few other veggie bits here and there. It was tasty, and brought out steamy hot with a molded pile of rice. The chicken was too soaked in sauce to really be "crispy" but it was pretty good regardless. It was a solid dish, not the best thai I've had, but far from the worst. I'd definitely go back and try something else, my boss ordered a chicken and veggie green curry dish that looked tasty.
author: Jessica T.

description: The food was pretty good, and though the portions were on the smaller side, the prices were reasonable. There was a bit of a service fail, however: we arrived as a group of 8, and got split into two tables of 4. One table got service, the other didn't. By the time one of our tables was being served food, the other hadn't even ordered yet. From what we could observe, it may have been because they were short staffed that night. This is not quite enough to drop it into the two star range, but we were not impressed.
author: Rob R.

description: great food, good prices.  The service is spotty.  Sometimes the service is good, other times it seems like they are very short staffed.
author: Jim D.

description:
I have never been to Thailand, so I am not going to tell you that this place is authentic or traditional Thai food, or that it isn't. What I am going to tell you is that, traditional or not, it is excellent. Every aspect of the place is superior - stand-out dishes (two that I have to order every time are the corn fritter appetizer and, the roasted duck in red curry sauce), cocktails, service and atmosphere. The menu has both traditional Thai items that you find in all Thai restaurants (great pad thai, pad se-ew, etc) and a number of unique dishes that I have not encountered elsewhere. The drinks always come out great (I am constantly amazed at how many places can't get a manhattan right. Not a problem here). Serves until 10:00 every night of the week, which I love in a town where it's hard to find the door to a good restaurant open after 9:00.
The décor/atmosphere is cool and laid back - much more stylish that the usual Thai restaurant in SF. 
The above alone make Basil Thai one of the better restaurants in San Francisco, but what moves it beyond that is the people. The service is impeccable -Todd, Arun, Juju, Domingo, Tek and all the rest of the staff are great at what they do and are just great people. I have a great deal of personal experience that bears this out. When my 90 + year old parents lived with me, I would bring them here. The staff was so considerate and attentive, it became their favorite place. Whenever they saw us coming in the door, they would start making our manhattans without asking, and they would arrive at the table the same time we did. That's the kind of place it is. When my dad passed last year, I chose this place to hold his memorial (we couldn't find a church with a bar). I can't tell you any more than that.
author: Don M.

description: Indian bread, wontons and Thai iced tea were all amazing. Those were all appetizers. Unfortunately the dinner plates all fell short of expectation after such great appetizers.
author: Michael D.

description:
Very cute, clean and modernly decorated Thai place. 
This place would be a perfect place to take someone on a date. 

Food was very delicious and flavorful. We ordered the pad thai, pad ke mow, gai prik khing (this was a tad too salty, but still good), and the Thai pineapple fried rice. We really cleaned out our plates, and were considering ordering another plate but it ended up being a perfect amount for us where we were full but not stuffed.  You can find cheaper and larger portioned elsewhere, but the prices here were still reasonable.

Service was good too-- very prompt and water filled frequently.

This place was really good. 5 star-worthy? Ah...sure, I really liked it.
author: Susan Y.

description:
I read the reviews and figured I would try it while in town.  I ordered the Basil Chicken and Green Curry with veggies... IT ROCKED!!! Not to mention it was extremely affordable!!

 I highly recommend this Thai restaurant....
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Avoid the sticky rice it's literally a block of rice welded together.  I was thinking it would be regular white sushi rice but no it was literally more stuck together that any sushi (or atomic bonds).

Also avoid the BBQ Chicken but do get the Short Ribs Curry.  The meat was really good.

Another thing is they didn't bring out the spice tray.  I really love the spice tray.

I'll try it again since I love Thai.
author: Jason S.

description: Always a great place to go for Thai that is slightly nicer than the normal $9 pad see ew or pad Thai. Staff are pretty quick which is good because this place can get busy. They have some creative dishes and their soup is good...a safe bet!
author: J. S.

description: My friend Bo loves this place and so when we hang out a lot we here often.  Food is good and the price is reasonable.  9/07
author: Suz L.

description:
So good!! After having a few drinks at HH down the street, my husband and I stumbled over here. I've heard good things, and I have to say they were ALL true. Walking in, we were seated immediately, brought water and a little rice cracker munchie within minutes. So far, so good.

We split a large Tom Yum Gai and the fresh veggie rolls. What a delicious start....but it only got better with our main courses: I got Basil's eggplant and my husband got the Basil Monk, both vegetarian dishes. By far, one of the best sauces I've ever had! The taste lingered on my lips and tongue for a while after I finished. 

Overall, very nice place. Intimate setting, not too loud, and the price for the both of us came to $40 before tip. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone looking for GOOD thai food for prices that are far below what they could be charging.
author: Brenda C.

description:
One of the best american thai places around -- much better than osha. There is a large variety for whatever diet you might be on(steak diet?).  Oh yes.

Save room for dessert. The coconut panna cotta is your best friend.
author: Artur R.

description:
You know how sometimes there's "that party", a group at a restaurant acting like they own the place, making a ton of noise,  spilling all over the place, and generally having a better time than everyone else?

Last night, I was in that group. A surprise birthday party, 20 people strong. Making matters more complicated, there was no final count beforehand.

I mention all of this to underscore how difficult the group must have been and point out how well they treated us anyway! 

20 people. Drinks for all. Food for all at the same time. Accomodating our every request. Even a big partition to hide behind before yelling "SURPRISE" at the lucky birthday boy.

Food was pretty good, to boot, if a bit small on the portioning and a bit American on the spice level.

A great place for a great party!
author: Jim P.

description: Great for lunch.  Haven't had dinner there yet.  For less then $10, I always leave stuffed and happy.  This is my favorite Thai in SF.
author: Saus A.

description: YUMMY! It's right down the street from me and always wanted to go - and I should have long ago! It's a great place!
author: Peter S.

description:
So, I checked this place out and brought a friend I hadn't seen in a while here. Once we got in, I noticed the decor was pretty nice for a Thai joint. Okay, sat down and ordered some appetizers. I forget the name of it, but it was almost like a Thai pizza. Not bad... but nothing to write home about. Then we ordered a combination of the Jungle Beef and the typical Pad Kee Mao. Both were very flavorful and well portioned. For dinner drinks, we ordered some Mojito's which weren't overly watered down, or swimming in alcohol. 

So you ask, why the 3-stars... ? 

Well, I just didn't see anything special about this place. I would definitely return.. so don't get me wrong. But, with a lot of great Thai places in the city, I wouldn't go out of my way for this place.

P.S. 

Service was very good. =)
author: Jason C.

description:
I have come to the realization that I am surrounded by Thai restaurants .....you could honestly say that I could use triangulation techniques to find my office based on all the thai food places within a 4 block radius.

I walked a few extra blocks to Basil, because I heard it was fantastic there. I ordered a mojito with a bowl of their Tom Yum Gai and jasmin rice.

I thought the soup had a nice light broth with a little zing leftover from the lemongrass shavings. 

The decor was very open and spacious inside. Lots of natural light which is lovely for a mid-day lunch.
author: Laura G.

description:
I'm such a creature of habit that I'd be the easiest person in the world to stalk. Fifty percent of my reviews lately have been for the same places. I guess when I like something, I like it. And I like Basil Thai. I.eat.here.alot.

Basil Thai consistently delivers tasty, slightly upscale, Thai food in a hip, modern setting. My favorite dishes are the shrimp potstickers, basil eggplant, cashew chicken, curries -- and for dessert, the panna cotta and sticky rice. They also offer brown rice, because when I'm chowing down on fried noodles, I like to stay healthy. They also have a nice drink menu, with such refreshing concoctions as mojitos, green tea martinis, and fruit-vodka infusions.
author: Suzanne R.

description: My very favorite restaurant for any occasion. Reasonable prices for absolutely delicious food. Some personal faves are the papaya salad, pumpkin curry w braised pork shoulder, angus beef cubes in green curry, coconut ice cream w fried bananas. Mmmmm.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
Excellent food, awesome staff, and fair prices. Very romantic atmosphere with candlelit dinners and comfy seats. 

Coconut soup and crab fried rice are two superb dishes. I was a little disappointed the crab rice did not come with more crab, but still superb.
author: Anne V.

description:
BEST GREEN CURRY I'VE EVER HAD! 

YUM! Get the eggplant green curry app with the indian potatoe cakes. So SO good. I forget even what the rest of our meal was, but the coconut lechee cocktail was delicious. We loved it so much, we went back the next night for take out. It did take way too long which was a downer, but well worth it. The yellow curry with pumpkin was fabulous! I definitely recommend this place, just try to go at a decent hour or you'll have to wait a long time.
author: Caitlin C.

description: A good, solid Thai restaurant with reasonable prices. My fried tofu was a little tasteless, but I suppose fried tofu is always a bit tasteless. Other folks liked their dishes and they have a good menu -- with Thai classics and some more interesting dishes. My lychee cocktail was also good.
author: Rachel M.

description: Just ordered their Gai Gra Pra and  an order of Pad See Ew.  Both dishes were greatly lacking in flavor. The Gai Gra Pra, typically more of a spicy dish, had no heat at all.  Very very bland.  The Pad See Ew, which is usually savory and flavorful, barely had any flavor.  Just tasted like plain noodles.  Overall, this place is just Krap, not Arroy.  If you like your Thai food on the blander, less spicy side, this is the restaurant for you.
author: Steve W.

description:
Delicious!

I'm jumping right in!
Location: Great, easy parking (on Sunday at least)
Ambiance: Perfect, though if you have vision problems you might want to hold on to somebody.
Service: Very professional, not overly friendly, but attentive.
Food: I had pan stickers. Everything i expected and more. Right mixture, right pan fry, awesome dipping sauce. I also tried their Thai fried rice. It was filled with fresh vegetables and i was delectable. Can't remember what my friends had but they loved it. Highly recommend.
author: Leslie S.

description: Watered down Thai food for non-native eaters.  More about the drinks than authentic Thai...
author: Laurence H.

description: Great soup and excellent sticky rice for a surprisingly reasonable price.
author: Joe H.

description:
This Basil Thai Restaurant has many things going for it. First, I love the location, within walking distance of Davies Hall. Second, the inside is elegant with white cloth table covers, candles, and romance is in the air. Third, the service is outstanding. Fourth the food is tasty and reasonably priced. 

If you are in a real hurry I recommend ordering 3 or more appetizers, woofing them down, elegantly, and then you are in and out in 30 minutes or less. Been there, done that, and didn't even feel rushed.
author: Olivia W.

description: Been back for a few times for take out - pad thai, chicken basil, etc.  Every time, I enjoy my dinner tremendously.  Great place.
author: Vivian W.

description:
This place was great and very accommodating.  We had a surprise birthday party for our friend, they pulled out a divider and about 20 of us hid in the back of the restaurant.  He was very pleasantly surprised.

The place is clean and sports a modern decor.  Bonus:  It was a very quick walk from the Civic Center Bart!  They have a great full bar and some custom drinks.  Their mojito is mostly sweet and less with the alcohol, but minty deliciousness.  The Tuk Tuk was also mostly sweet -- so it might be safer for some to stick to wine or beer.

Our food all came out hot and relatively at the same time -- pretty impressive.  I order the Panang beef, the meat was really tender and the sauce was delicious.  They brought me extra chili peppers -- I was very pleased.  The portion sizes weren't huge but I still ended up taking my food to go.

I think the place was very understaffed but the service was still good considering such a huge group on a random Monday night.  They were apologetic even though I waited a very long time (30+ minutes) to close my bar tab, on top of the time to order and get my drinks made.  It took even longer to get a box for my meal, but since I wasn't going anywhere I was more than patient.  Another thing I appreciated was that we were not rushed out after we finished our meals.  We sat for a long time enjoying our drinks, conversation, and company.

Everyone seemed to enjoy the food.  I was surprised how many dishes had egg plant though.  They also have brown rice!

I think not going with a huge chaotic group would have easily bumped this review to a 5 star but it was still a great experience.
author: Van W.

description:
After pigging out, I got thai'd down. And oh, did I enjoy it!

Located just a few doors down from Bloodhound, we came over here after the porkfest to have our real dinner. I was surprised to see what a nice place it was, and wondered why I'd never been before. I could see it being a good spot for a casual date or a nice dinner with a group of friends. Plus they had a great looking full bar. I'd been to their sister restaurant, Basil Canteen down the street at 11th & Folsom, and although that space is a lot cooler (it used to be The Public), the food here was a lot better.

The menu had most of the typical Thai dishes, and everything was really inexpensive at around $10. We started with the roti, which was like a Thai green curry eggplant pizza. The roti was deliciously golden crisp on the outside and soft on the inside. The four of us picked an entree and shared everything family style. We got 3 noodle dishes (pad thai with prawns, pad see ew with tofu and pad ke mao with chicken) and the pad rad kang (a vegetable green curry), and everything was very tasty. They ran out of the flat wide noodles for the pad ke mao, so they substituted with the thin rice stick noodle, and I actually enjoyed it that way more. I loved the amount of heat in that dish as well. The pad thai was excellent. 

Although I didn't have dessert, the girls ordered the mango sticky rice, and devoured it. For 4.5 people (the 1/2 had a beer but no food), the bill came out to $60. It's probably the best deal you'll find along this part of Folsom. Plus, you can go back to Bloodhound afterward to continue drinking!
author: Connie C.

description: I came here with a friend for a quick bite since I didn't eat dinner. We sat at the bar since we knew their kitchen was closing soon. They served us fried shrimp chips (equivalent of bread being served before your food arrives). We ordered the basil's panstickers which had a thicker dumpling wrap than most places. Very flavorful with the right amount of cruchiness. We shared a papaya salad which was very good. And we shared their roti side! The staff was friendly and when the kitchen was closed, they all shared a drink! I love that the staff is a family and knows how to enjoy themselves! Would definitely come back again!
author: Linda L.

description:
Went to this place with a friend of mine today for dinner.  I loved it.  We ordered the prawns deep fried and wrapped w/something as an appetizer.  It was wonderful.  I came w/this orange half tangy/half spice dipping sauce.  
The the entree we ordered pad se ew and brown fried rice w/chicken.  The chicken was rather bland in both entrees and we had to spice it up ourselves w/soy sauce and chili pepper but other than that, it was EXCELLENT.

The service was great.  The waiters kept refilling our waters, kept making sure our food was good and we were comfortable. 

The decor was cool.  Nice ambiance.  

The prices are reasonable.  My friend and I split the bill which came to $18 after tip each.

Don't get me wrong...this is NO OSHA which by far is the best Thai food I've ever tasted in SF but its definitely really good!
author: Sandra S.

description: I give this a solid four stars. Good tasty food the green and yellow curries pretty amazing. Everything well cooked. Service prompt and ver courteous. I will say this however I always feel heavy after eating their curriesmuat be a lot of cream in there. Definitely one of the richest heaviest Thai restaurants I've eaten at.
author: Jason W.

description: nice inside. food was very tasty. we had a define wine from St Helena. I would go back as this was a good stop. we had 3 items. pad Thai and lemongrass soup and another chicken and rice dish. give it a try!
author: David S.

description:
Celebrated a friend's big 24 here. And was pleasantly and deliciously surprised! 

Would rate Basil a 4.5 if I could. 

Friend, P, gathered us up and worked out a set menu with Basil. We had a numerous amount of appetizers and main courses and a delightful dessert. 

Here's what I can remember..

Appetizers - chicken satay (didn't give us enough peanut sauce so I asked for more and they GAVE it TO me! I had my own ramekin full hehe and yum-e!), vermicelli spring rolls as well as shrimp, potato curry puffs.

Main courses - yellow chicken curry, beef with peanut sauce, tamarind shrimp, chicken stuffed eggplant, slow cooked veggies, pad thai. Now, if your mouth isn't watering... something's wrong with you!

The portions were large and the food.. omg, the food was droolingly delicious. How happy I was to see the plates arriving and to taste what was next!

For dessert, we had fried banana with ice cream. A classic American Thai dessert and the perfect dish to wrap up the meal. 

Also had their Saketini which was sake with a lychee puree... yummay!! 

The staff was attentive and very nice. The set menu was the perfect menu. A wonderful evening with good food and good friends. Would definitely come back for more!
author: Christine C.

description: Food is bland. None of the spicy dishes were even remotely spicy.
author: Martin W.

description:
B is for BAR: The bartender was fantastic, If I'm not in the mood for beer I usually have a hard time deciding what to order (Im not a huge fan of hard alcohol especially rail, and the basics... He concocted this amazing mango cosmo.. delish.. I love it when a bartender can make something for you rather than requesting I order a vodka cranberry

A is for ATMOSPHERE: I love the modern design, the lighting was my favorite. You can definitely go dressed up, but also casual or with the family. Definitely a good variety of people. Lots of room and large, clean bathrooms!

S is for SERVICE: this is where you lose a star. I don't know if their goal is to take forever to get you to order more? But at first I didn't mind because my friend and I were deep into convo and in no hurry to order. but when it came time for the bill you took an extra 20-30 minutes.. at that point I was ready to bounce!

I is for damnit.. I can't come up with anything for I or L

so let me just say.. The food is delish, great Thai! Very fresh, and you know its a good meal when you can be satisfied and full but not feel like you are going to fall into a food coma.. because those aren't always good, unless of course you are eating a huge breakfast and are super hungover.

Kudos to Basil, I will be back to try more dishes YAY
author: Hailey P.

description: Some very different dishes compared to other Thai restaurants I've been to. It is almost fusion style. Our appetizers and salad were very good, an I had a great glass of wine at a great price. Our entrees were bad. The grilled "Jumbo" prawns were not very large, and the grill they use infused the food with a butane taste (much like the blow torch does when sushi restaurants incorrectly sear sushi) and they were drowned in sauce.  The cubes beef dish we orders had some pieces that were over cooked, some raw, with a gamey flavor that you don't want in a beef dish. The dessert, a fried banana with coconut ice cream, was sooo delicious...but they served it in a flat plate with only a spoon. This meant it was impossible to get it on your spoon without using your hand. It was a nice place to eat and the service was good too. 2.7 stars.
author: Jeff C.

description: yummy food, order what every other yelper says to order and you cant go wrong
author: Long C.

description:
4/5 pretty fusion like and quite tastey!
great service, wonderful decor

im from the OC, so i dont understand the "soma" attitude or culture, but it seems like this place is too nice for the neighborhood.

i ordered pineapple fried rice, fried prawns for appetizer, and basil lamb curry.

all 3 were VERY good

i had a few drinks, limelight, mango cosmo, hef (beer), and a mojito. strong but very tastey drinks as well

bottom line,
ill go again, take friends,
author: Skippy T.

description: Good food and decor.  Parking was super easy.  Take a break from Osha and eat here.  Get one of their basil cocktails.
author: Erika C.

description:
Unlike a lot of people, I grade my Thai restaurants on my favorite dish, Pad See Ewe. Basil Thai is a great restaurant. The Pad See Ewe was absolutely fantastic.

I should also mention that their lamb dishes have wonderful aromas and are very tender. Phenomenal food.

Service was great. No complaints here.
author: Amar T.

description: Had dinner here last night with a couple friends.  The food was really good.  Make sure to read the item (crispy = fried) obviously.  But that caught us by surprise.  The staff was a little slow and we needed to flag them down.  But we were having a good time and being loud so they probably didn't want to interrupt us.  Was a good time and will go back for sure.
author: Matt B.

description: My friends and I love this restaurant.  It's our go to for a nice romantic night on the town. The food is superb and we've yet to find a Thai food restaurant that rates as high in our book.  We literally lick the plates clean.  We miss our server Bambi.  She was the best. However, service overall is pretty amazing.  Our water glasses are always refilled without us having to ask and everyone is super professional.
author: Storm A.

description: Ordered the grilled eggplant stuffed with chicken and cabbage in green curry, was some of the best curry I've had.  Was one of the first people there when it opened at 11:30, but the place was packed by 12:30 - so get reservations if you go there with a group.  Will def return here.
author: Andrew B.

description: One of my favorite Thai spots in the city. The atmosphere is very nice. The food is good, though too much sugar - I wish they'd use less, but less of an issue than many other Thai restaurants. Prices are good. Mostly, the service is great. It really feels like the servers care. Getting served here has always been a pleasure though sometimes  I am surprised at how hard it is to get someone to take money at the end. Strange.
author: Eater S.

description: Good food but horrible service. This is not the first time either. They either ignore you or forget to place one of your orders. Though the food is good, it doesn't make it right for the establishment and the employees to not care for their customers.
author: Kelly T.

description: The roasted duck with red curry blew my mind. It's that good!
author: Bobby K.

description:
I've had a lot of Thai in my time and for me, this place just doesn't check the boxes I'm looking for. Firstly, the dishes seem to be incorporating some kind of fusion or maybe the chef feels he has something to prove. We ordered three dishes and each one had some elements that just seemed off somehow. Unexpected ingredients and flavors that don't match what you expect when you order a favorite dish. Definitely not hard core traditional Thai. 

Service was a bit off as well. A little slow. Also, I'm a big fan of deciding how spicy I want my dish to be at the table. They didn't ask at all and just bought out the standard plates.
author: Joe W.

description:
Basil Thai is the classic go-to Sunday night joint here on the Folsom strip--both because the food is excellent and because, well, it's open for dinner on Sunday nights.  (Few places are.) I'm also a fan because they are very good about leaving out the fish sauce when requested, which is great for someone like me whose lips puff up at the slightest seafood encounter. 

Everyone I know loves this place, especially the curries. Me, I'm addicted to the pad ke mao, spicy wide rice noodles & sliced beef stir-fried with basil, garlic and Thai chili.  But tonight I started off with the tom ka gai (a bit tart for my taste but I managed to finish it nonetheless) and then test-drove the gai kra-prow, minced chicken wok-fried with fresh Asian eggplant chili, Thai basil, & fresh chili.  I was not disappointed--it was fresh, flavorful, and delicious.  The only reason I give Basil Thai four stars instead of five is that I have found they overcook their rice from time to time.  But overall, I highly recommend it.
author: Kelly N.

description: Delicious clean thai restaurant within walking distance from our hotel...we were in luck when we came across this eatery.  Perfect portions and moderately priced fare.  With a trendy, more Americanized feel to it, Basil Thai is sure to please the college-aged and small business luncheoners, alike.
author: Beth R.

description:
Thai food is as easy to find these days as a McDonald's. Now good Thai food is another story, and just so we're clear I do not think Osha qualifies as good Thai food. Thanks to its growing popularity there are many Thai choices in the city, unfortunately they seem to all blur together with standard dishes such as Pad Thai, curries and other mains. 

Basil has quite a good menu with lots of options. I highly recommend trying a few of their grilled vegetable skewers. At $4/order for two skewers (or veggie pieces) its a perfect light snack and totally delicious. A word to the wise: they come with peanut sauce so if you are not interested in that let your server know. There are many meat options and a lot of their curries sounded amazing. It's always safe to try the Pad Thai if you are not sure where to start.

The interior of basil is very nice, especially compared to most causal Thai places. It's a little more formal and very dim. I will happily try more dishes at basil.
author: Theresa T.

description: Came here on a date with my hubby! Loved our private front seating! Food was good, however I can't deny that I've had better thai food before. I would rate it 3.5 and not just a 3 but unfortunately I can't on yelp. My biggest problem here was the cost of food, we ordered small sake, chicken screwer, the Indian bread with green curry, veggie green curry (had no tofu) and fried rice! Portions were decent, however we ended up paying almost 65 dollars. I wouldn't complain about price had I felt the food was worth it but it wasn't! Seems a bit unreasonable for mostly all vegetables. The small sake only gave about 3 shots, was not worth the price we paid at all! If you don't mind spending a little more than usual on Thai food when your in the city then you should definitely check this place out!
author: Amrita A.

description:
All around great restaurant.  Ive never been let down once.  Every time I come here, I:

1) Never wait for a table
2) Always get great service
3) Always order a different menu item
4) Always am extremely satisfied with the food
5) Always enjoy their tasty cocktails

Hard to not come back to a place like this, especially since its right around the corner from my place!  Keep up the good work Basil!
author: Mike H.

description:
I lived in Thailand for nearly a year, and I'm pretty particular where it comes to my Thai food. Although whilst I lived in Thailand, I pretty much lived on noodle soup on the street, I also got to try some pretty awesome dishes.

Basil makes some pretty freak-out good dishes. I had the sirloin cubes with lemongrass, and the tastes were fabulous together. The man had the lamb, which was pretty awesome in itself. 

Our waiter had a huge crush on my date, which was super cute. He couldn't really look at him without blushing a bit, which I found very flattering.

Next time I'm going to leave room for the sticky rice and mango. That stuff is the bomb.
author: Rachel F.

description: My fellow yelpers directed my mom and I here when we were on vacation, and thank goodness they did! We absolutely loved the food. We started with the fried calamari which was lightly fried and came with a delicious chili sauce. We then split two dishes (a little gluttonous for two people, I admit) the green curry (which I try at every thai restaurant I go to), and this other dish with Japanese pumpkin, which was amazing!!!  I was introduced to the caipirinha here, and after trying quite a few elsewhere, this one still ranks the best.
author: Shannon G.

description:
Hands down the best Thai food I've ever had my friends! A little pricey and one of those restaurants where you semi dress up. One thing for sure is, it's worth every penny and time you spend looking all fancy just to chow down, like you own this part of town! My favorite entree is the "tom ka gai" It's this delicious chicken dish dripped down with cocoanut milk.  It was so good I had to remember the name. (easy way to remember "TOM's-car-Gay). Now the dessert I tell you.. this is what topped things off! Not a sasquatch dessert, a dessert just the right size after my huge dinner.. it's a ball of sticky rice covered with mango ice cream.. mmmm! Just thinking about it  makes me want  to worship the lord for the wonderful things that he/she puts on earth. :) 

2 thumbs up pimpskillet.
author: Sani S.

description: My husband and I use to live around the corner. Now we live in the burbs. The food is scrumptious. The Indian bread with eggplant curry is a definate every time we go. If you want great Thai with a cool atmosphere visit Basil.
author: Braun S.

description: Delicious beyond compare. My wife and I visited from San Diego and hit this place up upon seeing the ratings. I got the pad kee Mao and my wife got the yellow basil curry with chicken. Both dishes came in under 10 minutes and were full of flavor. My pad kee Mao was served with top of the line skirt stake that left me hungry for more. My wife's yellow curry came with one of the most tender pieces of chicken I have ever had (watch for the bones). Go here for great Thai food. Be sure to ask for it spicy if you like it that way.
author: Joseph K.

description:
What a find on this side of town!
