A short 10-minute walk from the Hall of Justice to Basil was just what my co-workers and I needed after sitting in uncomfortable wooden chairs in a courtroom all morning. 

The restaurant was surprisingly not busy during the typical noon lunch hour. This meant we were greeted and seated right away, all with a smile.

Food portions were plenty and the prices were reasonable. I had the eggplant with ground chicken lunch plate, which ended up looking more like ground chicken with several pieces of eggplant. Either way, it was delicious and I nearly cleared my plate! Another co-worker had a dish with green curry, which he so graciously offered me a bite of since I don't recall having tasted green curry. Tasty as well, and a bit milder in flavor than the red curries I have eaten. 

Two dishes of noodles nearly overflowed my other co-workers' plate/bowl. No complaints from them!

Prices are fairly reasonable for the quality of food you get here. I would definitely come back if I'm ever at the Hall again!
author: Kimberly S.

description: I went here around 8PM on a Saturday night and was able to get a table for 3 immediately. Warm, relaxing atmosphere and the drinks, food, and service were all great. I'd defintiely consider returning again! I have no complaints! Dinner meals were around $10/each and drinks were around $9/each with $5 beers.
author: Maridawn L.

description: Love Basil Thai!  Quiet, mellow and relaxed.  Better than average Thai food at reasonable prices.  Do not miss the sticky rice with mango. Of course, everyone makes this dessert, but there's is extra creamy and the mangos are always fresh.
author: Melinda M.

description:
Favorite thai in the city!!!
Fresh and tastefull dishes. I love it!
author: Mina T.

description: Really nice thai thai restaurant, however the food is not good at all!!!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Good food:  Great flavor:  Good service

Win win all around...

(I love the Larb Gai salad!  Minced chicken tossed in lime, chili and parched rice.  I'd go there just for that, at least!)
author: Kyle P.

description:
My husband and I are slowly visiting restaurants in San Francisco. My husband loves Thai food, and Basil Thai was one of the closest Thai places to where we are currently staying, so we decided to head here and see what it was like. We liked it fine, but it wasn't good enough to warrant a return visit.

We ordered the fresh rolls as an appetizer, and I liked the kick in the dipping sauce. My husband ordered the Pad Thai, which is what he always orders when he's at a Thai restaurant. He gave it a thumbs up, but he admitted that he's not that picky. I ordered the green curry with eggplant/chicken/cabbage dumplings. The dish was definitely something I haven't tried before, but the curry was too heavy (I like my green curry to be lighter and fresher), and the eggplant/chicken/cabbage dumplings were good, but not especially memorable, and I couldn't eat the eggplant without the other ingredients (I'm particular about eggplant).

Also, I initially ordered sticky rice rather than Jasmine rice, and the sticky rice was a congealed ball of rice. I will say that when I talked to the server about this, she did get Jasmine rice for me free of charge. Good service, nice setting, but food that is nothing special.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
BEST THAI IN THE CITY!!

If you are craving thai you have to eat here!
I highly recommend the lamb curry, to DIE for!

The place is always packed, yet you somehow never have to wait for a table, and the food always comes quick.
author: Alyssa O.

description: I have dined here several times and always enjoyed the food and the experience HOWEVER I took an out of town guest here this past Sunday evening and am really disappointed to say, the stuffed eggplant dish I ordered was stuffed with RAW CHICKEN. Not just undercooked chicken but literally strips of flesh, like it had been stuffed raw, the eggplant grilled and then plated. With this being a dish where the meat was hiding inside a wrap, I am just thankful that the raw garlic (which was also a red flag- as I have had this dish many times before) led me to tear this dish open to investigate further before I ate any more which was very hard to do in the dimly lit setting this restaurant has. I'm not sure what upset me more, being served raw chicken! that in itself being extremely dangerous OR the lack of apology about not only potentially poisoning a customer but ruining my evening out with an old friend. In the very least, I would have expected the manager to stop by our table  AND our entire check to be 'on the house' alas, the raw chicken dish was removed from our check as it should be but there was no verbal mention of that when our check landed on our table. Our evening out prematurely ended as I declined the offer to remake the dish and my friend didn't want to continue his meal alone so we paid and left. In all honesty, I was too nauseous/retching to start a debate about being billed for this horrendous experience. So not only is this a review about being served RAW chicken, it is also about the sheer lack of customer service and handling of this experience. It also makes me question the kitchen practices allowing a raw dish to reach the table. Needless to say, I will not be back here and I'm a very realistic person, accidents happen but this review may not have been written had they stepped up to the plate (pardon the pun) and brought their A Game in the customer service department.
author: K G.

description:
The food was good - we had the poh taak and the seafood bamee (with wide rice noodles instead of the wheat noodles - I am gluten free).  They were both wonderful.  We went in early - 5 pm - the staff was eating dinner and we had the place to ourselves.  Service was excellent - attentive and prompt without being overwhelming.  We went back for desert at 7 to find the place full (as expected).  We noticed that the off-beat parties got great tables, so that was refreshing.  Of course we got a good table (probably leaving a generous tip after dinner didn't hurt, either).  Had the sticky rice and mango and the pana cotta - both were excellent.  The sticky rice and mango was superb - one of the best I ever had.

We will be back!
author: S. G.

description:
Picked this place because on yelp it was second to Osha, a tried and true favorite.

The staff is friendly and helpful, and although the place was relatively busy for a Wednesday, wait staff was on top of things.

The food was good--the flavors in each dish were very distinct.  You could taste the tamarind in the Scallop Satay, and the basil in the Seafood Curry.  We had to have the Pad See-Ew , and the veggies were fresh and tasty.
author: Ali C.

description:
Basil Thai is one of those lots gems in a city full of Thai restaurants. They are a little more upscale and a more refined decor, but the food is just to die for. The food here is anything but sloppy, everything looks as if a lot of thought has gone into it and can back that up with a wonderful taste. Many items that I am used to seeing show up on my take out menus are not offered here, but I like that as a chance to try some new dishes, and have never been disappointed. 

I am normally of the school of thought where you stuff yourself for dinner and forget about dessert, but here is one of the few places where you really want to make a conscious effort to save a little room for dessert because everything they have is worth it. My recommendation is 3 entrees per 4 people. Sharing is key. (as is mango sticky rice)
author: Allyson S.

description: As a vegetarian it's always hard to find good Thai places that can make curries without meat and fish sauce. This is one such place. Perfect for vegetarians. There Grilled squash curry is amazing. Delicious food, great price, good service and take reservations. What more can you ask for.
author: Renu J.

description:
We came here for dinner and had a fairly ok meal, nothing spectacular.
We ordered the following:
Scallop skewers-overcooked and lemongrass flavor was overpowering
Calamari skewers-ok
Cucumber salad-bitter taste and not good
Basil's lamb curry-good

Service was average.
author: Lizete S.

description:
What a fabulous wedding reception

I give Basil Thai www.basilthai.com two thumbs up for hosting my best friend's wedding reception. The space was transformed to fit 54 guests as promised. All the bathrooms were nice and tidy and the staff people were at our service and always smiling. How special is that! In addition, the food may I say the food won me over. I was a little skeptical because I wasn't sure if it was going to be stellar items but they really pulled it off. Even when I told my friend, Angel, the misses now Mrs. who was married last Saturday that they should immediately remove the broccoli from the plate because it doesn't belong w/ Thai food. Anyway, the run down:


goong gra bog EXCELLENT crispy rice paper wrapped tiger prawns served with sweet dipping saucE
gkae satay EXCELLENT lamb - served with peanut sauce
makuer yang EXCELLENT eggplant - served with peanut sauce
gai satay EXCELLENT chicken - served with peanut sauce
som tum EXCELLENT green papaya salad tossed with ground peanuts, lime, garlic, and tomatoes

My mom couldn't help but rave about the food and I feared that she wouldn't be able to touch a thing but she was in love with the tiger prawn rice paper wraps. Unbelievable she wants to go again!

So overall, I think everyone had a good time and the reception was chic but budget conscious. What a way to do it! Fortunately we carried the party on TO the W Hotel until 4 in the morn!!
author: Adrienne H.

description:
Thankfully our experience here was better than the experience of reading my homey's review about this place!!!

JT. F (crappily) wrote: "Had the Pad Thai dish today.  Was pretty damn good.  Nice portions as well.  I chose Pad Thai because that's pretty much the breadth of my knowledge when it comes to Thai food.  I also use it as a benchmark for comparison to other Thai restaurants.   I believe they stuck in about 4 shrimps, which was good, but would of liked more.  

We also ordered the "panstickers", but it's just a potsticker rolled up differently.  It's filled with pork without vegetables or all that ginger and garlic.  Ok maybe it wasn't just a potsticker in disguise, but it was very tasty.  The sweet soy sauce mixture served with it was an excellent bonus!   

We took a cab from the Financial Dist (about $7 one way).  Hardly anyone in there at lunch time, so you didn't feel crowded.  Wait I just remembered we went at 1pm, so I have no idea what I'm talking about when it comes to the lunch rush, but it was quaint at 1pm.   May have to walk a block towards Market to get a cab back, but would totally go back."

Painful, right???
author: Bucky K.

description:
Ooh... Another entry for the SU-UCKS! list. It's been quiet around those parts lately...

You, Basil Thai, have done nothing to change my opinion that SOMA is a culinary wasteland. 

The best thing about my entire experience here were the complimentary shrimp chips. Which I can buy myself at Genki Crepes for $1.29. My dinner was nothing but a noodle-tableau for chili pepper. 

The WORST thing about my experience here was that my lame dinner DID, in fact, have SOMETHING else in it besides chili pepper. Because it created a great amount of discomfort and inconvenience for me during the swing dancing class I attended immediately after. I was in NO SHAPE for spinning and twisting and for anyone to be getting that close to me. 

Thank god the class was being taught by a good friend and my partner (for most of it) was SuperBF.

I hate you, Basil Thai. These kinds of memories were supposed to end with high school. At least then they didn't cost me $40.
author: Lisa T.

description:
I am amazed. Thai food has always been a miss for me, but not this time. Everything that I had was light and refreshing. The veggie spring rolls, tofu roll, portabello mushrooms, and scallops with tempura string beans was magic in my mouth. The chemistry between sauce and ingredient were paired perfectly. 

The ambiance was subtle and nostalgic. The staff was attentive and price was reasonable. Definitely a place to go with large groups or on dates.

=)
author: Stanley K.

description:
When we were much younger, we would judge an Asian restaurant by the "fake wood paneling" test.  If the place had lovely painted walls or real wood paneling, it couldn't be good, and it was not authentic Thai/Chinese/Burmese whatever.   It had to have a hideous stained acoustic ceiling and the kind of fake wood paneling you'd find in a '70s basement.  If it was peel 'n stick wood wallpaper, so much the better.  The focus was on the food, not the decor, and if too much effort was put in to the decor, the food had to suck.   By this measure, we wouldn't have gone near the beautiful and elegant Basil Thai with a 10 foot chopstick.

Happily, as more and more Asian restaurants have discovered the power of  - for lack of a better word - fusion, they have learned that people will pay for nice surroundings as much as they will pay for a little more creativity in the menu.  Basil Thai definitely got that memo.  In addition to being a nice relaxing environment, the menu is not your usual Thai menu and has a lot of very interesting dishes you won't find anywhere else.  Everything is very good, fresh and spiced just right. The wine list is impressive and the servers are attentive.   

One of the better Thai Restaurants in the area, and always a great standby when we're out of ideas for an SF dining spot and we just want a relaxing and tasty dinner.
author: Jay Z.

description:
Five of the 'Not Normal Yes Normal' brain trust met face to face for the first time (salvo uno conspiratore in Italy). The big boss was in from Chicago to discuss project 'I Am Serious.'

Basil was exactly what we wanted: delicious authentic Thai food in a comfortable space perfect for plotting our next coup. Besides, 'Agent K' remembered a $100 gift certificate* from some parents in my class.

The pot stickers were among the yummiest I'd ever had. The spring rolls were also great. The satay is 2 larger skewers instead of the usual 4-5 smaller ones, if you're sharing. 

Others had a rich red curry dish and huge plates of pad thai with lots of shrimp and tofu. While all the dishes were delicious, the standout for me was the crispy sliced chicken with yummy green beans, soft and singed basil leaves and a nice, slow heat. Dastardly good.

After all the imaginary mustache twisting and hand wringing it was time for dessert. Everyone indicated they were full, but we ordered 3 anyway. Fried Banana w/ Coconut Ice Cream and Mango w/ sticky rice were both really good and really gone in minutes. My favorite was the Tapioca Pudding w/ corn and taro. The wonderful texture of all these sweet and salty beads of flavor was unlike any I've had before. Absolutely wonderful.

Add 4 beers and the tab came to $3.60* + 900% tip.
Our subversive plan, you ask? 
The next kindergarten T-shirt fundraiser. Watch for it: http://images.yelp.com/photo?id=M0DPISfMOqN4kxCsF56nTg&s=l
author: Andy R.

description: A nicer ambiance than your average mom and pop thai, but the food didn't distinguish itself from the other SOMA thai places. The decor tries to be stylish, but fails to go the whole mile (Osha is closer, but still overshoots).
author: Jeremy S.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian

Basil Thai is so affordable that I thought I didn't have to make reservations for 7pm on a Saturday night. So this review is about service at the bar. Points for having a little hook for the DC to use for her purse. Points again for actually having those  tables that were empty upon our arrival and denied to us fill up complete during our meal.
Service was good, but it's the bar and I expect everything to be quicker there. It's a very nice space, a little loud but not to a point of interfering with conversation.

Appetiziers were very good. I love me some fried foods. Corn and bean fritters were crispy on the outside and creamy on the insides with a nice sauce that kicks at the finish like Sebastion Coe. Veggie springs rolls were the perfect size, perfect angle slice to put on just enough of a another kicking sauce (that WAS different). The rolls delivered just the right amount of greasiness to make me feel indulgent but not guilt ridden.

Here's the rub: the noodles peanuts and greens salad probably had a fish sauce on it. It tasted kind of funny and the noodles rolled up into an odd shape. I asked the waiter if the spring rolls were vegetarian and he said yes. I don't want to be an annoying nudge so I do not query everything I order. I kind of expect the server to tell me if anything else is not veggie.

The DC enjoyed the chicken soup a lot. I'll come back for appetizers before or after a Cat club visit in the future and stick to the fried items.
author: Bob R.

description:
I've eaten here a number of times and each time it is as delicious as the last. Great Thai food in a unique location - unique as in WTF is this doing here?

I recommend the following from the menu:

Curry Puffs
Tom Yum Goong
Basil Lamb Curry
Gai Kra-Prow

The Pad Thai is always great as well!

Try Basil Thai you'll love it...
author: Todd E.

description:
Best place to have thai so far in city we have found, Close to home (SOMA), prices fairly reasonable and they make an effort for service. Ice cold water in glasses constantly filled up w/o having to ask. Great decor.
As I mentioned in another review of a different crappy thai place, we are spoiled, coming from Carroll Gardens Brooklyn and having the best thai restaurant in the world walking distance, JOYA.
Basil Thai will be a regular event for us, prolly once a week
author: G K.

description:
The food was good. It was a bit too smooth for me. Depending on the plate, things are supposed to give me a kick. But it was too smooth. Decor was nice. Very calm. 

I should try other dishes. Perhaps I can give a better review if I had another plate. Something different for sure.
author: Mr. T.

description: Just an update... the food here is not only tasty but the plate presentation is pretty.  They put effort into the food and it shows.  For instance, they take the shell off the shrip tail so it is easier to eat.  Nice!  You have to try the tamarind prawns, so good!  I do have to agree some of the servers need a little attitude adjustment.
author: Wendy H.

description:
My fiance and I went out here for our pre-valentines dinner last saturday before going off to 1015 and the food was some top notch Thai cuisine! 

We had the Keow Wan Roti for starters and the grilled indian bread went great with the green curry and vegetables the bread was nice warm and fluffy with a croissant like texture, we also had 2 skewers of the lamb satay and the meat was really tender and juicy and went well with the peanut sauce.

For entrees we ordered the Param Rungsong which was a skirt steak topped with the same peanut sauce that came with the skewers this dish tasted like the lamb skewers minus the lamb so I felt this was more like an extension of the skewers, instead of rice we went ahead and ordered the Pad Ke Mao which is basically spicy Pad Seew with chili added there's not much that can be done to this dish to make it stand out from other Thai restaurants but I do appreciate that it wasn't too heavy in oil like other places and that they put a lot of beef in it. 

We both also ordered a side of Cool Cucumber salad which was very refreshing with a taste of sweetened vinegar.

Every dish we ordered complemented the next one and seemed to have fused together in my mouth perfectly.

The service was definitely great our server was quick to take our orders and always kept our glasses filled, I almost made it to the bottom of my glass but as soon as I put it down our server came by moments later with a pitcher to refill it. 

The atmosphere was very nice and perfect for taking out your significant other, date, mistress or whatever you may call them.

So what keeps me from giving this place a 5 star review? Well for the price of each dish I would've expected bigger portions, this place is definitely a bit on the pricier side but I guess I'm paying for the whole experience with it and I do recommend this place for special occasions, but if it were a bit more inexpensive I would definitely make this a regular spot when I'm craving Thai food in SF.
author: Mark R.

description: Came across this place when recently traveling in SF. Cute place, great feel. Be careful because the food is really spicy. Had the roti appetizer which was not spicy and a good adjunct to the rest of the meal. Also the prawn skewers were cooked well with a little char. The pad kee mao was a good portion size but very spicy (we said we were ok with spicy when the waiter asked). Also the cocktails are well made and refreshing. Liked the area too. Would definitely go back!
author: Pete M.

description: My scallop and prawn salad only had ONE scallop so Basil gets ONE star. Food was delicious though.
author: Mary S.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place out since driving past it on Folsom many times. Went in to place orders for to go dishes. Was craving some sort of tofu basil dish and the menu offered basil's eggplant - oriental eggplant, tofu, shitake mushrooms and scallions sauteed with basil-chili puree. Second dish was the pak rad kang which is grilled asian eggplant, zuchini, mushrooms and tomatoes and bell pepper in green curry. 15 mins went by and the food was ready to be picked up. 
The to go dishes came in very nice and sleek container which doesn't spill, 2 stars! compared to other places which provides other paper-like container which spills when jostled in the car. 

Unfortunately, the food is just so so, the basil's eggplant dish had eggplant which was half cooked! It was semi-hard! Eggplant has to be cooked thoroughly esp in a stirfried dish. Bummer. 
The green curry dish was similar with all the zuchini and squash half cooked, it was merely grilled and thrown into the curry mix. So disappointing. Bf seemed to think it was ok but guess he was hungry and it's 10pm dinner for him. I've read abt the F.B.I. dessert so maybe that warrants a return trip but for entrees, I guess I'll stick with other staple Thai restaurants.
author: Yan M.

description:
I had a hard time finding the place. They definitely need a bigger sign outside. Cuz when it's dark out, you can't see it. I circled the block 3 times before I finally found it. And for your reference, It's right across the street from Paradise Lounge.

A couple friends and I went here for a few drinks before we went to check out Paradise Lounge. The staff was friendly and attentive.

Their drink selection was enough to satisfy our different drink tastes.

We brought in cupcakes, which later (way after we had eaten them) they told us they don't allow outside food into their restaurant. Oops! But they did see me bring in the box, set it on the table and wait for my friends to get there. They coulda said something in the beginning, while i was waiting or even when they saw us eating them? I dunno, maybe they were trying to be polite, but if it was my restaurant and that was my rule, i would have said something earlier. I thought that was strange. It wasn't like we were going to make a big mess and then leave them the box to clean up (although, i could see how they might think we would...or some people would). So a note for your reference: Basil Thai does not allow outside food to be brought in, and eaten there...Sorry.

Otherwise, their drinks were tasty and looked good. They were also decently priced for their size and being in a restaurant.

The set up of the restaurant was kind of cool, when you walk in, you walk up these stairs (so, sorry, it is not a wheelchair friendly place but then again, if you come in a group, maybe your buddies can carry you up the stairs, cuz there's only like 5-6 of them.) and there's the bar, and some seating straight ahead of you and then also to your left. and then there's also an upstairs area (which i assume has seating (didn't get a chance to look)). The bathrooms were nice and clean. The bar area was small but had all the necessities. It was a hip new looking place.

I would go back to drink and/or try their food. The food on their menu was also decently priced.
author: N C.

description:
Basil Thai, how I love your green curry roti appetizer thing.  Mmm.  It is the rich, tangy, sweet, fragrant stuff that dreams are made of.  The roti is fried, crispy but not oily.  It's a taste combination that makes my mouth happier than rainbows and unicorns.

My favorite Thai dish, Larb Gai, is prepared quite decently here, too.  And the bartender pours with a heavy hand.  While I don't typically equate Thai dining with mojitos, when I ate here last night I figured "why not?"

We usually come here to celebrate workmates' birthdays.  It's near "the office" and my co-workers and I always have an excellent experience.  The appetizers are well executed, the atmosphere is vibrant and the restaurant is tasteful and tidy.

Thai food in SOMA?  Give it a try!
author: Melanie K.

description:
I've been here a few times since I used to have some friends who lived literally across the street.

Food?
Typical thai food, but very flavorful.  I thought the portions were great.  If you want to compare it to a SF stalwart like Osha's...I think this place tastes better.  I thought the flavors were more rich.

Environment?
Great.  They can accomodate bigger groups in the back of the restaurant.  It also has a full bar in case you want to start the night early.  It's fairly quiet so couples can show up too..unlike Osha's where half the people are usually somewhat intoxicated from happy hour!  The decor is nice and the restrooms are clean.  

Service?
Most excellent.  None of my group had to finish their drinks completely and the server was back to refill the water back up!  Food came out in a timely fashion and more or less at the same time.  We had an order of brown rice and the rest white rice...but he came out with ALL brown rice.  Immediately took it back without balking or making a face.

Typical of most people, as we were paying the bill we all had credit cards (5 in total).  The server said the official policy is usually no more than 4 credit cards per party - which is understandable given the time and transaction fees required to process all the cards.  Luckily, he was very nice about it and said he'll accommodate our payment request!  Yay!  You just earned yourself more tips Mr. Server!

Overall, check this place out.  Btw, the Duck plate is most tasteful...with the sauce that you can poor over your rice (not sure if Thai people would approve that action though!).
author: Yup S.

description: Basil Thai does a good service. Decent portions - a bit slow on service. Good flavors - good choices.
author: Melody M.

description: Their peanut sauce is excellent. We had it with the braised beef short-ribs They make a good mojito. I've had the flame grilled pork shoulder filet and it's also good. Sticky rice with mango and coconut pana cotta are great desserts.
author: Ed M.

description:
ZERO stars for service... so I guess that makes my two-star rating dependent on food only.  Their food is slightly expensive by thai standards, but is actually very good with decent portions.  The service, however, is a different story.

I've been here on three occasions now for large-group lunch (maybe about 15 people?) with coworkers, each time, the service has gotten increasingly worse.  On this most recent visit there were several customer service no-nos, that I couldn't, in good conscience, let slide without writing a review.  

First, we were seated at quite a long table to begin with, which was fine.  The waitress came around and took everyone's drink orders and brought out drinks, except for the four of us at the end.  One of us actually ask if we could order drinks, which we did.  And I swear they came around with water refills I think only once. 

Second, the menu specifically states that, "most dishes can be made vegetarian."  Fine.  I wanted to order the lunch special, which consists of a choice of stir fry type dishes and a choice of curry.  I politely asked if I could sub tofu for chicken in the spicy string bean dish.  I was abruptly told that there are no substitutions on the lunch menu.  I said, "it doesn't say that there's no substitutions here, but it does say that dishes can be prepared vegetarian."  She said "sorry, no substitutions."  I asked her to come back to me after she'd taken everyone's order, which she did, but not after she actually collected everyone's appetizer plates and input everyone's order.  I was getting pissed at this point.

Finally, when they brought food out, they brought out about 3 dishes at a time with about a 5 to 7 minute delay between each round.  As a result, many people actually finished eating before the final wave of food came through.  And lucky me, I was the last one to be served, my plate arriving a good 5 minutes after every other person at the table received their food.  When I began to express my frustration with the situation, I was  rudely told that when they have large groups, they encourage people to order from the prix fixe menu.  A) that's not true because no one said that to us and b) If that's the lunch combo, sorry buddy, I freaking tried, no substitutions, remember?  One of the most frustrating things about this was that this actually happened last time we all came to lunch, except I (thankfully) wasn't last.  Really ridiculous when the place was empty when we came in, and you were expecting our reservation...

If there's a next time my office decides to patronize this place, they can count me out.  Clearly customer service wasn't a priority, which is a shame, because as I said before, the food is pretty good.
author: Laura C.

description:
Basil effortlessly merges the idea of a place where you can say "the usual" with midtown Manhattan table service. The wait staff is professional and courteous and synchronizes with you like a team of NASA engineers bringing your Apollo Unit full of Moo Yang back home from the moon. I think we had 18 waiters, but no one ever didn't know what was coming next or needed to happen.

The food is affordable and extremely enjoyable. I love the peanut sauce. It is so thick with flavor, I heard the city of San Francisco has oil drums full of it in case things get really boring around here, they are just going to start adding it to the water supply like the Scarecrow in "Batman Begins."

Basil looses a star for two reasons. Their water glasses are too small. The refill guy is always running from table to table keeping glasses full and interrupting your conversation. Two more inches of glass and that guy could kick back with a Sudoku book or an US weekly. And they charged extra for rice.
author: Justin L.

description:
not bad. Not great. I wouldnt call it authentic Thai food though.
Service was good and drinks were good as well. Food wasnt spicy as you would expect from Thai.
author: Ddc C.

description: This place is really delicious. I'd describe it as a 'fancy' Thai restaurant. It's not a hole in the wall, the portions are a bit smaller than normal, and the decor is elegant. Nice atmosphere and food.
author: Turi F.

description:
MMMM MMMM GOOD!
That's for the wait staff!

OWWWWW WOWIE!
That's for the food, a bit spicy but damn good!

OHHHHHH SHEEEEEEEEEEEEET!
That's for feeling like a fool for calling the manager "Yahoo" (hey I misread his name tag)

LOOK LOOK LOOK!
That's because Dragon was on next door @ Eight and the parade had started. (RQ insiders know)

I'm going to visit here again. The Chef puts a modern twist on Thai cuisine and it's refreshing. Be careful with the bar, the drinks are powerful good you may forget to order food!
author: JayChan H.

description:
Nice, extensive menu with more curries and a wider variety of meats than I'm used to seeing at Thai restaurants. The larb gai (minced chicken  salad) was refreshing, but lacked the complexity that I've had elsewhere. Pad rad kang, a green curry with grilled Asian eggplant, mushroom, tomatoes, bell pepper, was very tasty and still managed to be light. And yep, we the pad thai was pretty good. Good chew to the noodle, not too salty, though really...is this dish really worth almost $10?

Good flavor without sodium headache. Major portions for what I was expecting from a SOMA joint. "Eh" service and prices. Solid 4 stars, def recommended if you're in this barren land.
author: Steph P.

description:
I lovvvee Thai food, and this has got to be one of the best Thai places I've ever been to. The dishes were all incredibly savory, and curries were excellent, and the Pad Thai was really something. And the free shrimp chips... yum! Can't go wrong with free. ;P

The decor was really soothing too, and the servers were attentive. Prices are decent: expect to pay $10-15 for dinner.


edit: Alright, this place is losing one of its stars. I brought my girlfriend (now ex) here a month after my first visit, and we were somewhat disappointed. (She actually thinks this place deserves a B- or C+). The chicken satay was good, but the calamari satay was just.. weird tasting. And their non-curry dishes are a little above mediocre. Stick with their curry dishes--that's where they shine.
author: Jay K.

description:
THE PLACE:
Pretty interior, I really like this place. 

THE SERVICE:
The people were super nice and the waiter really had a good attitude.

THE FOOD: 
I had perfectly cooked lamb on skewers, it was damned good.
author: Michael S.

description: My favorite is the Crisp Chicken with Stringbeans.  The perfect combination of delicate, well chosen ingredients
author: J D.

description:
The veg selection for entrees is abysmal. The service is indifferent. I order with a request for "spicy" and it's not anywhere near that.

I'm so so so tired of lackluster Thai food in SF. I just don't get it.

My search continues. PLEASE message me if you have a good rec!
author: Shal J.

description:
I went for a birthday party and I had a good time.

The waiters were pleasant and friendly.
And the food is great. Although I would only suggest this place is good for groups.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Last night the Beloved, Fab Miss K and I went to Basil Thai, in part because it was near Annie's Social Club (yay Gord!) and in part because of reviews here and elsewhere. 

Some meals transcend mere food and become blissful memories. Last night was one of those dinners.

The cast of characters:
Yrs Truly, an omnivore who prefers to avoid red meat, adores curry;
The Beloved, who will order charred cow whenever it appears:
The Fab Miss K, a staunch vegan.

We were all delighted.

For appetizers: Miss K ordered porpia sod, vegetables & tofu rolls with crushed peanuts, chili, and lime vinaigrette. They were light and crispy, not at all bland or mushy. I ordered the keow wan roti, grilled Indian bread with a luscious green curry, garnished with basil, and translucent savory eggplant. The B ordered curry puffs, flat, dumpling-like pastries filled with duck and sweet potatoes. Unbelievable - fried crispy but not hard, with a nice kick of cumin. 

The B and I split our usual tom ka gai, and this turned out to be nothing out of the ordinary - excellent quality meat, the coconut milk well-blended and not too sharply spiced or choked with bamboo shoots. 

Now to the main courses. First, the B's charred cow, nuer yang:  grilled Angus sirloin accompanied by a lovely smoked mushroom, tomato, & aromatic herbs relish. Now, I find most cow to be a waste of my chewing effort, but this was thin, tender and meltingly good. 

I had the kang kari gai, which was both ridiculously inexpensive and far too much chicken for one person. I was mostly delighted by the mild yellow curry, which I asked them to bump up to a medium-hot.  One-quarter chicken? More like half a chicken! The meat was well-grilled, but hard to cut and the presentation was a bit underwhelming. What was amazing was the yellow curry itself. I nearly floated out of my seat. I dumped the sauce and potatoes on my plate, added the cucumber side salad, mixed in some brown rice, and was perfectly happy. Next time I'll get a tofu curry. 

Fab Miss K was the recipient of a small plate of jewel-colored vegetables. She had the house oriental eggplant, with tofu, shitake mushrooms, and scallions sautéed with basil-chili puree. She couldn't finish it, but it was delightful. I loved just looking at it.

Despite our plenitude, we did not resist dessert. And Basil Thai doesn't stint. The B, unsurprisingly, had the fried banana and coconut ice cream, which he barely restrained himself from slurping the last of. Miss K babbled her praise for the sweet sticky rice and fresh mango, and I had a pana cotta - your basic flan - a lovely milk pudding of coconut with mango glaze. 

And the price? Recall all this food. Realize that the B and Miss K had several drinks as well. The whole thing came to under $150.00.

For SF, this is aaaamazing. I'm pimping this place to everyone I know. It's an up and coming neighborhood, and Basil Thai is a must-go restaurant. You heard me. Go now.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
We were looking for a place to eat before heading to 1015 a couple weeks ago. We tend to browse yelp for reviews when choosing lately and this place peaked our interest. 

I'm glad we went. It was perfect. The food was very well presented and very flavorful. The sake is good and the ambience is nice overall. 

The prices are also reasonable and not going to break the bank.

Would definitely go back and recommend it for any thai food lovers.
author: Mack L.

description: This place was cheap and delicious! Great menu, lots to choose from, the pad Thai was perfect. Service was good but I didn't know if they were being attentive or annoying. Kinda strange but I'd definitely eat here again.
author: Leah M.

description: Yummy food and good drinks! I was with a birthday party group and the service was excellent. We had set up a set menu beforehand and everyone was happy with all the options. I loved the grilled eggplant. Wish I could remember more but I forgot to review earlier.
author: Adrienne K.

description:
Came here to eat with a friend who lives within walking distance.  It was Friday, prime lunch time, and we were seated in time, beating the last of the lunch rush traffic.  Being 3 of us, we each ordered an appetizer and entree, which we shared family style.  We had corn fritters, a scallop and shrimp frisee salad, peppercorn duck, crispy chicken, and tamarind praws.  Along with 3 Singha beers.  For dessert, we chose banana fritters with coconut ice cream, which finished off our dining experience perfectly.  The flavors were light and balanced.

The service was quick and friendly.  Even when one of my friends had to ask for extra silverware, because his table setting was incomplete (or dirty), the server was very nice.
author: Audrey E.

description: Wanted to eat at a super fun/fancy restaurant while in San Fran but was a little hungover from a wedding the night before so Thai sounded amazing!! We looked it up on Yelp and decided on Basil...Came here on a Sunday night and the place was packed!!  Good thing for me it was only my Hubby and I and we were seated right away. The Hostess was super friendly. Our waitress was not super friendly or super mean so I guess it worked out!! I had the Pad Ke- Mao with chicken and it was really good. My Hubby had the Pad Se-ew and ate it all so I guess he really liked it!! the portions are really big so I got to bring the leftovers back to my hotel to eat later. The place is really cute with great decor....I would be back if I lived here!!
author: Shelley K.

description:
Went to dinner with friends here yesterday and was blown away. Food and service was great. Ambience in the restaurant was perfect. Ordered the following: Mojitos, pla dook pad pik (crispy catfish filet sautéed in kaffir red curry paste and fresh peppercorn), kang kua gai (tangy red curry of julienned chicken breast and pumpkin), gai prik khing (crispy sliced chicken & string beans wok tossed with sweet kaffir prik khing chili), and rice. All of the dishes were delicious but especially the catfish dish. It was TO DIE FOR! 

I can see this being a great place for group dinners and romantic dinner for two. Located in SOMA area the parking was actually not too bad. I highly recommend this place. Been reading the reviews for it for years but haven't tried it until now. Very satisfied customer.
author: L C.

description:
We had such a nice time here last night.  The food was so incredibly good.  It is nice to eat in a modern Thai restaurant.

The calamari was great and so was the pad thai.  We also had the vegetarian wok dish with eggplant, mushrooms and tofu and it was incredible.
author: Reggie G.

description:
Delicious thai food! We've eaten here several times but usually for take-out and it is nowhere as good as eating there.  

We were advised to order the stuff eggplant and it was sooo good!
The other dishes were the thai seafood salad and peppercorn duck - real yummy authentic thai cuisine.

Dinner for two was about $50 (incl' two beers, no tip)
author: Oanh N.

description: Solid great place.. Amazing menu, Angus Beef, tamerind prawns.. Don't forget to order your sides... Sticky, Jasmine, Brown, or fried rice.. Very health eating options as well. Cucumber Salad side is a favorite...
author: Troy S.

description:
Very good thai food, nice atmosphere, but on the expensive end of thai food prices. 

I've eaten here a lot.  Most of the menu is solid.  Every once in a while the noodles taste a little of burnt oil (or is that somewhere else?, i can't remember now).
author: daniel g.

description:
I love this place! It's cute and fancy with a full bar. My niece and I had tried to get in on New Year's Eve, but it was booked, so we went the next day. I called and made a reservation, but I think it would have been okay without one.

I wasn't too hungry, so I got the tom yum gai- small salad with a delicious lemon grass dressing. Plus, 2  gai satay- chicken skewers with peanut sauce. It was the perfect portion.
author: Kelly N.

description:
Basil Thai is kind of in a randomly located on Folsom & 7th street. If I wasn't a frequent patron of City Beer Store I would not have noticed this place.

Basil is actually a really snazzy place. The decor is really chic, a good size bar...I wouldn't be surprise if people hang out here at night after dinner (wait a minute it is Basil Thai Restaurant & Bar - duh). The food is pretty good and reasonably priced. My hubby got the Pad Ke Mao and I got the stir fry turnip cakes (Kanom Pak-Gard). Both were really good, flavorful, and plentiful.

Also had a mango cosmo. It was good but not nearly strong enough.

Overall i like this place. I would come back because I haven't found my favorite thai restaurant in SOMA yet.
author: Terry D.

description:
easy parking on the street...seated immediately on a thursday at 7...tastefully casual and clean interior feel...baseball game with sound on a television above the bar...entire place had the wonderful background wafts of good food...white noise of conversations from other tables was just loud enough that "sorry, could you say that again" requests were generously sprinkled throughout the evening....service was busy yet attentive and efficient.

The food was served alongside a clay pot filled with about three cups of the fluffiest jasmine-infused rice...delicious and necessary for everyone's dish considering how saucy everything was. Note: the bill surprisingly included $4.50 for 3 servings of jasmine rice..this was odd since there were four people at the table...it was also odd since no one was asked if they wanted rice.
 
The calamari salad was a spicy sweaty fish/garlic sauce flavored fresh/large/tender calamari topping assorted herbal greens...a bit much with the raw white onion quarters though.  

The lamb curry was perfect with crispy string beans, carrots, basil and bell peppers in a tangy red/orange curry sauce that was saucy...very saucy.

Because of the din (and possibly some language barriers) someone's dish was ordered with 'fried tofu' but out came plain cooked tofu...this was mentioned and a small bowl of replacement tofu appeared a few minutes later. The tofu curry was quite good; apparently Basil keeps an enormous vat of butter in the kitchen carefully maintained in a fondue temperatures with some of the SOMA art students hovering around paintbrushes in hand that they dip in the tub every few seconds solicitously coating every edge of every solid food particle in every hot dish on the menu. When Basil closes they  sneak into the Metreon to pour the unused butter over all the unsold popcorn and then munch on it while taking in a late nite showing of Basquiat. 

It could happen.

So, if you don't care about accuracy in ordering results, but love fresh thai, then this is just the pagoda for you...very saucy.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Me + Fairer happily found this place after we missed the reservations she had made elsewhere.  No regrets.  Lovely, subtle interior, attentive staff.  We started off with a few cocktails, gin based...  then split the goong gra bog (crispy rice paper wrapped tiger prawns +  sweet dipping sauce)   - so fabulous I made a mess of the sauce trying to get the last prawn out of Fairer's clutches...  Then moved on to hoi ka-ta:  scallops with tempura long beans wok-fried in Thai black bean, chili and wine - equally delish. 
What a gem to find in this neighborhood.  Prices are decent too - you can do quite nicely for ten bucks a plate.   Nothing here disappointed.
author: Meg W.

description: Waaay yummy. I've eaten Thai food all over the world, and this is some of the best I've ever had. Everything I've had here in my handful of visits has been excellent, delicious, and delightful.
author: Aaron E.

description:
Great service, great food, inexpensive. The only downside for me is a lot of the food is a bit on the sweet side and they don't have too many vegetarian options. But the vegetarian options they DO have, oh la la! The Basil's Eggplant is excellent and the turnip cakes are to die for. You can also get brown rice if you ask.

The ambience is great too, as it really feels you've left the city. It's not romantic, but it's very comfortable with nice light and decorations. It's the best place we've tried in a 2-block radius and is now our default lunch place.
author: Charlie C.

description:
This little place gets pretty packed. Service was nice enough to accommodate an ever-growing party-size too (initially we had said 6). We had to wait about 35 minutes for a table of 8. The wait was worth it! Tried all kinds of plates (less $ than expected)... very enjoyable. Lighting is nice enough so that you could probably take a date here, but the vibe is chill enough that you can get loud and drunk too : )

Huge plus for having shrimp chips (krupuk)! I hadn't eaten those in years... always had a huge kick out of sticking them on my tongue and walking around with them sticking out...
author: F J.

description:
I think if you look at all my reviews, at least 50% are Indian or Thai food. Does that make me kind of an expert?

Basil Thai was really delicious. We just ordered take out, but the inside is very cute and I would love to dine in there sometime. The food was good, and although a little pricier than its nearby neighbor, Manora, I would say the quality more than makes up for it! The portions were probably not quite as big as Manora, but they were still far bigger than what I could eat for dinner. It didn't feel greasy, which is a plus! It's among the best Thai food I've had in the city... I would probably give it 4.5 stars if I could, but I'm feeling generous tonight, so I'll round it up to 5!!
author: Bridgette A.

description:
This place has a surprisingly large crowd during lunch, so be prepared to get squished in at a table that it only inches away from someone's business meeting ... or wait until the rush is over and get a little more space for yourself.

I remember that the first time I came here was for dinner with a couple other people, and we were delighted by dish after spectacular dish and enjoyed the novelty of the sake flight ... yum!

Most recently I came here during lunch with my fish-phobic boyfriend and felt apologetic upon entering the place because it smelled like a Clement Street fish market.  Hoping that maybe they were having a ventilation issue that only affected the front of the restaurant, we accepted the next available table and ordered from their lunch menu.  We were served dishes that we didn't order and weren't able to get anyone's attention to correct the mistake so we just ate what we were served and tried to get out of there, ASAP.

I realize that often a lunch experience can differ completely from a dinner experience, but I was so disappointed f by my last visit to Basil that I'll just try a new place in the 'hood instead of returning to what was once an old favorite.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Got taken here for another birthday dinner and had never heard of the place. Super cute inside and unlike some other asian restaurants, they have a full bar. Yeah!!! The bartender is hot! Another hell yeah. Unfortunately I did not get to dine in his company. 

Upscale looking restaurant. On a Monday night, you don't need a reservation. Was told that it is good for lunch as well. With some Thai restaurants you don't have to worry too much about what you order but this place, along with some others you need to be careful. When they say their dishes are "medium spicy" what they really mean is "so damn spicey you can't eat the dish not matter how good it is." I have run across this before. Make sure to tell them mild or no spice on any dish that is marked spicey.

We had the pan potstickers. YUUUUUUMMMMMY. Liked them, liked them a lot. We also had some kind of bean cake fritter, very good as well. They have all kinds of skewers, chicken, prawn, scallop, eggplant, etc. I got convinced to order the mushroom and eggplant skewers. Yah, not a fan but then I should have ordered chicken. Because we all know I like chicken. Anyway, the sliced beef salad ordered mildly spicey was very good. Got carried away and didn't notice that the chicken with green beans dish was spicey. We didn't finish it. 

The wine, beer and cocktails are totally reasonable and there are some really good name choices. Would highly recommend.
author: Heather L.

description:
Dainty things walking in the front entrance. We, feigning sophistication drop and break the rice dish whilst simultaneously taking a glance at their helm lines. 

"Don't look at her chest..."
"...Don't look at her chest..."

We succumed after a perfectly acceptable display of gentlemanly restraint. It's the ten second rule for public displays of oogling.

Five stars for her rather lovely top, accentuated quite perfectly by the spiciest salad I've ever munched.
author: Marc M.

description:
Update: Taking the extra ducket away. Went in for lunch the other day. It was 2:40. There were several other tables carousing and eating. We were about to be seated by the waiter when someone said "NO WE'RE CLOSED!"  Yeah they weren't closing for another 5 minutes or so, but c'mon business hours (and minutes) are business hours.

Good venue for larger parties and to start the party. The staff and management are friendly and accommodating. Food is BIG on flava and presentation. I tasted the duck curry, spring rolls and sea bass.They have a full menu of fancy cocktails - Mohito's, Lychee Martini,which where a bit unimpressive. Interior is a bit more upscale and contempo than the usual Thai joint in your hood .... more along the lines of Slanted D.  Across the street from Cat Club.

There was a dude outside of the restaurant that looked like a "troubled" version of Prince, minus the purple. He arranged some raggedy ol' sneakers near the front door of the restaurant, adjusting their pose. He took a look at his "arrangement" and said, "Oh no, those just won't do!" before throwing the sneakers onto 9th St. Great performance art piece!! 

3 duckets: interior & food. Extra ducket for the not so purple prince.
author: Johnny C.

description:
This was a very memorable meal. Not just the food but the fact that I went with a friend during the Folsom Street festival. It's not often that I get to sit next to a group of Latex/Leather daddies while enjoying a most delicious Basil Eggplant dish. I was glad the slave was allowed to take his ball gag out to enjoy his Pad Thai. But I thought to myself, wouldn't that be the ultimate torture to smell the delicious food and not be able to eat it?

Between Dore Alley and Folsom Street Festival, I think the wait staff has seen it all. They were friendly as ever and really didn't give a hoot.

I digress, their dishes are well executed, nicely presented and flavorful. I must say their beef dishes run a bit bland for me but everything else, especially their lamb, seafood and vegetarian dishes are superb. The price runs average for a modern Thai restaurant similar to OSHA but I think Basil's flavors are much better. 

My favorite Thai place in SoMa, with or without the S&M/Fetish crowd.
author: Tai K.

description: Very decent Thai place in a somewhat ghetto and very gay-friendly area... The decor is very nice, this is quite unusual for a Thai place as they all mostly look the same with the exception of a couple Osha's. The food here is quite tasty. The menu is large and extensive, they have all the classics with a few new entrees that I have never tried. The portions are enormous and perfect for sharing. The appetizers are delicious and they have a nice selection of beers. If I am in the mood for Thai and in this area, I would definitely go here!
author: Alex Y.

description:
Rock up in casual garb and you'll fit right it...rock up in your fancy number and you'll fit right in (best of both worlds).  All the unpretentious diners flock to this place to do nothing other than eat great food...so if you're one of those people who want to be seen, order take-out and eat on the street ;-)

Greatest tasting Okra/Seafood green curry!!  I'll be dreaming for days, of those little okra beads bursting in my mouth.  Another dish worth trying is the scallops with green beans...devine...totally devine!

I would give it 4 stars for great tasting food but I give it 3 stars due to location...not a hip and happening area....although totally different story if you go there after the Folsom Street Fair!
author: Karyna K.

description:
Just as good as Osha, but much more reasonably priced.

I had the corn fritters and eggplant yellow curry.  Both were delicious, and I had enough leftovers for tomorrow's lunch.  

Our server was friendly and attentive.  The restaurant was modern and clean.  And the menu pleased both the carnivore and the vegan. I'll certainly be back.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
My friends and I came here for an "Oh my god, have we really known each other for ten years" dinner and had a nice time. My virgin mojito was a delicious way to start the evening (and the guy who made it was pretty delicious too). We ordered tasty crispy spring rolls as well as corn and bean fritters to start, and my pumpkin curry entree was wonderful. Each dish was not only tasty and nicely presented, but it was the perfect portion for dinner. I know there are those who think that the whole point of going to an Asian restaurant for dinner is so that there will be food leftover for lunch the next day, but this is not one of those kind of places. It's too nice for that.

There was only one thing that bothered me: for such a nice restaurant, the basketball game on the television above the bar was very distracting.
author: Katie I.

description:
can't decide where to go on a friday night? Basil is in the air.
want to get a large group of seven in without extra fees or a 9:30pm reservation? Basil is your friend.
feel like a no-hassle tasty meal without making your purse feel bad? Put Basil in your back pocket.

my beau and i stumbled upon this place after having driven past it over and over and over when scoping out the nearby eclectic furniture stores. finally, after we tired of hunting for a go-to thai restaurant that wasn't in the East Bay (oh how we miss $5 basil fried rice at Basil Thai in Durant Square), we popped in for a WONDERFUL meal! 

through our multiple visits to the namesake of an old favorite, we've discovered the delights of many a dish. the delicious red duck curry - in my opinion, near orgasmic every time i take a bite. also, gone are the days of the basic green curry with 3 peas floating on the top - treat yourself to the eggplant green curry, with eggplants stuffed with ground chicken and spices, topped with a green curry *sauce* instead (oh yes, we're grown ups now!). another must-order is the pad thai - simple as it may sound, Basil's pad thai strikes the ideal balance of sweet, sour, and salty, with noodles moistened with just the right amount of sauce, prawns, fried egg, tofu, bean sprouts, and lime juice. 

and on the off-chance you have to wait a minute or two, take a peek into what looks like a plant pot by the front door - you might make a new friend out of the 1-2-3-or-4 gold fishies swimming about!

5 stars for being an in-my-face proper thai dining experience - and for staying more or less hidden from the hoards of osha followers :) 

till my next juicy bite....
author: Diana L.

description:
Awesome for big groups, this is my 4th time there, and 3rd time with a party of over 20 people. Its not an extremely large restaurant at all, but the decor (for a Thai restaurant that avgs $8-$12) is extremely nice. Definitely a good place to go if you're dressed up, and we normally are because we go to a club afterwards. 

The problem with eating in SF is always budget. The first party we went to was a year ago on a Sunday night. No pre fixe menu needed, ordered separately and paid the 18% gratuity. However, on Saturday nights they did require us to go with the pre fixe menu (shown below) for a VERY reasonable $25pp. 

For this latest time, we got in and because our group ballooned from 18 to 24, we asked for more tables. We lounged in the bar area until our table was ready. We were seated and since we were on the pre fixe menu, food was served quickly and efficiently family style and in pretty large portions. Everything was great, especially the tamarind prawns and skirt steak in peanut sauce. They even put some candles in the dessert to celebrate the two birthdays we had. Everyone was full at the end of the night and we even had leftovers to boot. 

As far as individual orders are concerned, I love the beef cubes in green curry. It is what I always order when I'm with a small group. I order it spicy and the beef is always cooked just right (not dry like other places), making it my FAVORITE Thai restaurant. 

If you're a wine drinker, we really enjoyed the Grans-Fassian Riesling they had. Order a whole bottle, its worth it and I had 3 glasses myself before leaving the restaurant. 

STARTERS 
gai sate- 
marinated chicken grilled on bamboo skewers served with peanut sauce 
Basil's rolls sampler- 
crispy rice paper wrapped tiger prawns 
crispy spring rolls stuffed with vermicelli and cabbage, served with sweet dipping sauce 
curry puff- 
crispy pastries filled with curried diced duck & sweet potatoes 

MAIN COURSE 
pad thai- 
rice stick noodles with prawns, tofu, beansprouts and chive 
pad pak raum- 
wok-sear bok choy, shitake mushroom, babycorn & seasonal greens 
tamarind prawns- 
light battered prawns wok tossed in spicy tamarind with crisp shallots and garlic 
kang kua gai- 
tangy red curry of julienned breast and pumpkin 
param-rungsong- 
grilled marinated skirt steak topped with peanut sauce 
steamed jasmine rice 

DESSERT 
Fried banana served with coconut ice cream 


SET MENU = $25pp + 28% tax/tip 
Grans Fassian = $8/glass, $32/bottle
author: Patrick C.

description:
My friend Andy swore this was the best Thai food outside of Thailand, and I now know he was right.  

Friendly, helpful service -- great selection of beers and cocktails.  

We went with a group of 8 (be sure to make reservations if you're planning a large group) and were able to try a ton of dishes.  Each was spectacular.  

Standouts:  
-- goong gra bog (crispy rice paper wrapped tiger prawns with a sweet/spicy dipping sauce)

-- kao pode tod -- (yellow corn and bean cake fritter (I was initially reluctant but actually really loved this one!)

-- plamuk tod (fried calamari -- delicate, crispy, delicious)

-- param rungsong -- (marinated grilled skirt steak topped with peanut sauce -- this dish alone would bring me back!)

-- nuer ta cai -- (steak cubes stir-fried with peppers in a tasty hot sauce)

-- kang gai -- (chicken strips in red curry)

-- pad Thai -- (classic rice noodles tossed with tofu, chives, sprouts and a couple of prawns, sprinkled with chopped peanuts)

-- Thai fried rice -- (excellent fried rice, fills in all the spots

Nice ambience, relatively easy street parking in the evening.
author: Bevy M.

description:
First and foremost, I am very partial to the layout of this place.

It's spacious enough that you don't get that inadvertent eavesdropping from a table which is crammed too close. I visited this restaurant with some friends before the Mars Bar Elite Event recently, at 7pm. No waiting for a table, even though it was peak hours...I'm guessing it's probably much more crowded on the weekends. Also, I like the bar placement in this restaurant...it's long and smack dab in the middle--a good spot to enjoy yourself & dine with other lone eaters while watching the boob tube.

The service was great--our server continually checked up on us to make sure everything was going OK, but managed to walk that fine unobtrusive line.

We shared a few different things:

Paupia: Crispy Veggie Spring Rolls...I especially enjoyed the dipping sauce.

Tom Ka Gai: Essentially it was Thai Chicken Soup, with both coconut milk & lemongrass. The dinner table opinion was mixed on this one, but I enjoyed it enough to eat my friend's portion as well.

Kan Kari Gai: Tender chicken on the bone with yellow curry & potatoes. The potatoes were awesome, the chicken & curry not so much.

Pad Thai: Run-of-the-Mill Pad Thai, nothing special.

--------

While I had the warm & fuzzies while dining at Basil Thai, it unfortunately was only from the cold sake we were sharing. Nothing about this place especially stands out, the food was good but NOT great.

3 stars...Service, Stylishness & Good Soup.
author: matt m.

description:
This is the kind of Thai place you would drive from across town to eat at. I discovered Basil when I worked in the area. It was by far the best place to eat in the 5 block radius, although my co-workers and I didn't go there too often because we cherished this place as our "treat" after a long, stressful week. 

The restaurant is clean, modern, sunny and has a full service bar. It gets quite busy at lunch but it always accommodated our lunch groups from 3 to 12 people. They have great service with a friendly staff.

Although Thai food is pretty much the same anywhere you go, I would say that Basil is a notch above the rest. They offer unique dishes you can't get anywhere else like the vegetarian Turnip Cake dish (in the noodle section of the menu.) I also had a vegetarian salad there I've never had anywhere else (I wish I could remember what it was called.) It had thin, clear, extra-wide noodles and was seasoned like a Thai shrimp salad with lime juice, chili, fish sauce and tamarind. I loved their Basil Eggplant dish, definitely one of the best in the city. Their appetizer menu is quite extensive.

They also offer great desserts. Their Mango with Sticky Rice is to-die-for! I would definitely come back, especially in the evening to have a drink after work.
author: L. L.

description:
I don't like overpriced thai. It's just the same thai food in nice shiny white dishes. I don't need shiny white dishes. I just want good food.

This place, while not the least expensive of thai places, get extra browny points for having my favorite dish done right (duck in red curry) and my favorite meat (lamb) in red curry. Can't beat that.

Except that rice is an extra charge.  Who eats curry without rice?  Isn't that like charging extra for the tea in Thai Iced Tea?

Three stars because despite the extra charge for rice, they have both duck and lamb. That makes this place worth coming back to when craving lamb.  But other thai places already have the duck in red curry.    I will now be hunting for a thai restaurant that has lamb in red curry so I won't have to frequent this establishment.
author: Robert L.

description: When it comes to thai food i'm always torn.  Do i give it 5 stars?  or 4?  They're all so delicious!  This place in particular was amazing!  Very good green curry with naan app.  Yellow curry with chicken was very nice - they give half chicken, bones and all, but kind of reddish from the vessels or whatever, almost pinkish so i was kind of paranoid.  I did feel a little funny after too, but this place is absolutely delicious.
author: Sage S.

description:
I ate here on a Saturday night with my cousin and wife.  Overall, it was solid Thai food, but I have had better Thai food in New York.   The two appetizers we ordered were excellent -- we got the calimari (fried perfectly, not too oily) with a chili sauce (I believe Sriracha), and the pork/shrimp dumplings.  

The rest of the meal, however, was just OK.  We ordered the pad thai, chicken from the wok, and the pumpkin-infused curry.  Overall, I would say this place is probably a safe bet for take-out, but not worth the hype in the actual restaurant.
author: Russ K.

description: Thai fusion food, clean, great atmosphere! Love that place. I also appreciate their kitchen to be open late.
author: elena a.

description:
Should I say more?

Delicious food, nice ambience and good service.

Choose the yum makuer (stuffed eggplant) and param rungsong (marinated skirt steak).  And for dessert the deep fried bananas with coconut ice cream...truly amazing!
author: Lisa C.

description:
I did not think it was possible to beat Osha Thai.   I love them like I plan to love my children, but recently a friend of mine moved acrosss the street from Basil and I'll be damned if we didn't eat there he next 3 nights in a row.

Excellent service, awesome peanut sauce, the menu is just full of fancified thai treats that go abaove and beyond standard thai fare.  With over 400 thai restaurants in the Bay area the choice for best can be a bit daunting but right now BASIL is it for me.

I cannot remember the Thai names for all these dishes but recommend (with gusto) the Sirloin steak in peanut sacue, the ginger chicken, the angus lemon grass beef dish, the spicy pan fried beef noodles and OH MY GOD their satay is the best Ive ever had. 

Its like a a million subtle little falvors dancing on your tongue.

Ambience is miimalistic, but not bare.  A real gem in SOMA and if you get there after 6pm be prepared to wait a little for your table. 

I LOVE YOU BASIL
author: Rick R.

description: Some of the best Thai food I've had in the United States
author: Carl V.

description:
I'm lazy sometimes and just think about distance when I'm hungry. I wanted something exotic and close and I failed. Err... They failed. Tasteless, meatless, meaningless dishes. I am pretty sad after the big curry bowl full of duck grease and skin. Maybe the meat melted in the process 'cause I could hardly find it. Even if Mood Thai is far away from my place and has disappointed me a couple of times, it is still way better and cheaper than Basil Thai.
Oh, guys, seriously, if you put canned pineapple, you could at least cut it do we don't feel like eating a $3 ready made dish.

I promise I won't be lazy anymore about my food choices.
author: Guillaume R.

description:
Brought our friends from LA to this favorite and they loved it.  Always easy to park, always great service, and always incredible food leaving little to no room for dessert.

Calamari is perfectly prepared, the Tuk Tuk cocktail is my favorite (Mojito is a close second), the braised short ribs are unreal (I know, I know, yeah, ribs), the pad thai is a great entry dish for the uninitiated (sorry Ash), the seafood curry (mussels, shrimp, etc) has a sauce that you'd take alone, and the ginger chicken is dead on.

Go.  Be there.  Take friends.
author: Mike B.

description: Everything I tried here was sooo good.  I had the calamari, brown rice, coconut braised pork shoulder, curry and the fried banana with ice cream.    My favorite dishes of the night were the coconut braised pork shoulder, brown rice and the fried banana ice cream.  I love white rice, but their brown rice was so light and fluffy that I actually preferred it over white.  It didn't feel heavy either.  Everything was extremely flavorful, just the way I like it.  The service was also excellent.  I can't wait to dine here again.
author: Janice A.

description: Amazing service. My two friends and I split a bottle of Chardonnay to compliment the Thai food. Very delicious dishes, no complaints. We ordered the spring roll appetizers, pad see ew with chicken, and the green curry veggie dish. All fantastic! We will Definitely come here again. If you're looking for good Thai food near the mission come here! Also recommend making a reservation, as this place gets packed!! We dined on a Wednesday night and the tables were all full.
author: Lauren W.

description:
The worst thai meal I've ever had and definitely among the worst meals I've ever had. 

Ordered the grilled marinated skirt steak topped with peanut sauce. Small pieces of cold, overcharred steak coated in a lumpy disgusting sauce.
author: Rocky A.

description:
I love Thai food. I don't live in SF.  This place made me wish I did. 

I went with 3 others and of the things we ordered, I could have demolished the entire plates of Chicken Pad Thai and Gai Prik Khing (crispy, sweet, slightly spicy chicken with string beans and red peppers and basil....mmm).  Yet alas, I didn't want to burst my stomach that night, so I stopped eating and let the others try it too. I'm so nice.
author: Donna Z.

description:
Minus one star for having the SPICIEST PAD KE MAO KNOWN TO MANKIND.  Seriously, it was inedible - we ended up ordering extra iced teas and iced coffees just to get the taste out of our mouths.  Ok, to be fair, my friend did order it "spicy" but what came was the hottest dish that I've ever had, and I've eaten a lot of food.

Other foods were good.  The papaya salad was fresh and tart and the corn cakes were crispy and savory.  The grilled scallops were less of a winner as they were a little burnt.  For the entrees, the chicken and pumpkin curry was good and so were the sirloin cubes - but anything would have been good next to the SPICIEST PAD KE MAO KNOWN TO MANKIND.  We took turns taking videos of each other eating it because it was just so funny to see each other tear up and almost die.
author: Sonia C.

description:
I generally come here for lunch and I love it. The interior is light and airy, the water glasses are kept full (a MAJOR plus in my book), and the food is tasty. They also have a full bar and serve some good sakes too. 

I'm a big fan of almost all of their appetizers, and every entree I've had (or my friends have had) has been delicious. 

I also love their soup and salads: prawns in spicy & sour lemongrass soup, the papaya salad and the strange but good clear noodles, peanut and greens tossed in homemade mild chili paste & lime dressing. Yum!
author: Andie J.

description: Best Thai restaurant I've been in for many a moon. The short ribs were amazing with a great balance of peanut and spice. Had the corn fritters for an appetizer. A bit crispy but the flavor was right on.
author: David D.

description:
Updated 10/16: The grilled steak with peanut sauce.  Sweet Jesus get it.
----------------------------------
Yum!  

That's really all I have to say.  I so don't pay attention when I'm not paying and I've only been here with my boss.  Whoop for company expense!
author: Alexis B.

description:
I've been here a couple of times & everyone I'm with always loves it, but I'm usually underwhelmed. Sometimes I find the sauce too salty, other times the meat is just bland. Maybe I've ordered the wrong things. Like I said, I'm outnumbered by friends who rave. 

The drinks are yummy. I had the sake & lychee juice one, which was great. The waiters are nice & attentive. The decor is pretty and not pretentious.
author: Melinda K.

description: Great atmosphere.  Reasonably priced.  Quality of food is EXCELLENT!  Wish the portions were bigger.  Try the Thai hot tea to compliment any dish,  it has a hint of sweetness.  The short ribs are out of this world and the duck puff pastry appetizer was delicious!  I'm coming back here :)
author: Whitney B.

description:
Fabulous.

We ate here recently; sort of in a hurry, and most definitely starving.  As usual, we were NOT spontaneous and ordered the pad thai.  (However, if we eat pad thai at every thai restaurant we visit, we'll have a basis for comparison no matter what!!)  The noodles, tofu and shrimp were perfect consistency, and although I think it's difficult to make pad thai look "neat," they did a very nice job of it.  It was delicious!  We also split the chicken satay, and it was incredibly juicy and flavorful!  What a delight!!!!  Actually, I can't say enough about the satay, and even after filling my stomach to maximum capacity, I was still covering spoonfuls of rice with the DELICIOUS satay sauce, in an attempt to rupture my most precious organ.  (Digestion is obviously more important than anything else in there!)

The atmosphere inside is very modern and feels spacious, even though the restaurant itself isn't very large.  The service was great, and my water was filled without my noticing, most of the time.  My boyfriend loved the cement touches throughout the place, inlcuding the bar.  Kind of a "soft" industral feel, if that makes any sense.  

I loved it, and aside from the dumbasses sitting next to us, talking about all of the times that they got wasted and did something illegal . . . in their youth (5 years ago!?) . . . dinner was perfect.  Even that lame conversation couldn't ruin a sweet meal for such a reasonable price.
author: Laleh E.

description:
Great place. I rediscovered it again this past year. The grilled lamb is fantastic and I hate lamb.  I like the mix and match lunch option but you can't get it to go. Love the stuffed eggplant on the lunch menu.  It is a great place for a date and for lunch. Nice atmosphere.  I have called in for dinner take out so haven't been there at night. Like the other poster, I like the way they pack things up to go.  Definitely a great lil spot for a special lunch.  I've been with a group at lunch and they are very accommodating.

Oh yeah...I have to say that most Thai restaurants have the coolest bathrooms? Any other posters notice this?
author: anna l.

description:
Basil is solid. Their Tom Ka Gai is perfect with the thai mushrooms. I would order it for take out once every couple of weeks with rice. 

Everything is good. Bar is nice and atmosphere inside is clean and kind of modern. Good for dates or small groups.
author: Alex B.

description: Some of the best Thai food I've had! Been a few times and never been dissappointed.  If you're into spicy make sure to ask them to bump it up a bit.
author: john W.

description:
Excellent food. And it looks WAY more expensive than it really is. The prices were much lower than I expected. And the beer's were averagely priced. 

The food itself was wonderful. Such a wide variety and so many options it took a long time to make a decision. Trying a bit of everything, it was all good.

The service was excellent. Water was constantly refilled, AND the best part was, for eating dinner on a Friday Night at 8:00pm, we had a party of 7, and got seated within about 10 minutes.
author: Dan B.

description:
Ordered family style dishes 

Pro:
-nice atmosphere
-good for large groups - mostly for small groups but they put a bunch of tables together for our group in the back which is nice
-enjoyed prix fix meals

Con:
-street can be a little dark and scary at night
author: Jenny L.

description: meh, service could be a lot better. food was mediocre.
author: kim w.

description: Being a Tenderloin dweller, the selection in the area has molded my picky taste for Thai cuisine. The restaurant is beautiful, but the food caters to the less Asian palate. There's no hot sauce on the table and when you request for hot sauce, there's only one kind that they bring out. What kind of Thai establishment only serves one type of hot sauce?! The larb and salads are ridiculously salty, the curries are mild, the rice noodles are mushy and sloppily prepared, and their "duck noodle soup" is like no other...I don't mean that in a good way. The one and only dish that stands out to me is their "kanom pak-gard." They're yummy turnip cakes served with what they call a "sriracha" sauce, but it's not the "sriracha" sauce I know since it's sweet and not spicy at all (at least not to me). I keep coming here because it's half a block away from the j-o-b. I would never make a special trip to dine there.
author: Helen L.

description: Attentive, good quality service with a smile. Swapped by starter at no cost after I didn't touch it (I love scallops and Thai, but they were inedible), and recommended I change my main course order based on my dislike of the starter. The waiters choice of main was perfect for me. I would go back. (start with a specialty beer from across the street)
author: Andrew M.

description: I simply wasn't all that impressed. It didn't ravish my tastebuds or make my eyes dance with it's ambiance. Sure, service was good- they replenished my drinks and water (which I drink ridiculous amounts of) but the Pad See Yew was common, and the lamb slightly tough (and with only 1 knife for 7 people?). The coconut milk soup, however, was delightfully calming and both salmon and duck dishes enough to appease my palate for the evening. Also, not a huge hit to the wallet- we shared 4 dishes and 2 soups over 7 people and seemed like more than enough food with a price tage of under $30 with a drink a piece.
author: Vee B.

description:
I had a red curry with chicken and pumpkin. Actually, it was served with Kabocha squash, but I like that too. It was quite tasty. The Tom Ka Gai soup was some of the best I've had, and I've gotten it from many Thai restaurants.
They were very accomodating of our schedule. We needed to make an 8 o'clock show, and our server was able to get our food out in under 10 minutes.
author: Alex E.

description:
YUM!

Went here with a big group for a birthday party and were treated right. Great food, great drinks, great service.
author: K. C.

description:
My coworkers ordered lunch from Basil Thai this afternoon. The food arrived in neatly contained boxes, which is nice because I hate it when asian food to-go arrives and it's greasy and all over the place. I ordered the Tom Ka Gai soup and the Basil's Eggplant.
