The soup was just ok. I've had better Tom Ka Gai at other places. This soup was a little bit more sour than I'm used to. The chicken in it was all very dry white meat. The mushroom portions in the soup however, were very generous and delicious. I wish they added more to the soup  besides chicken and mushrooms. Perhaps bamboo shoots or something else for some extra texture.

The Basil's Eggplant was very good. It was a really good blending of tastes. All of the food was cooked perfectly, especially their eggplant which tends to be mushy when overcooked. My only complaint about this dish (and the rest of the dishes) was that everything was very mild and not spicy enough. We also ordered a few other appetizers, all of the ones I tried were very good. 

If I didn't get this food for free today, I would have complained about the prices. It's a little expensive for thai lunch ($8-$12). There are more authentic Thai places that charge around $6-$7 for an entree which includes appetizer, soup, and salad. These entrees were just served with rice. The rest was ordered separately.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Similar to Melissa G, I live in the neighborhood and come here often. There's a reason: Basil is absolutely fantastic. Clean and unpretentious and an attentive staff. I'm not sure what I can recommend, as I've had pretty much everything on the menu...and I'm never disappointed. They aren't cheap, but not expensive either...especially lunch. If I order Pad Ke Mao and Curry Puffs, that is lunch and dinner for about $18. Did I mention that everything is super tasty? Oh, one last note: If you do take out, be sure not to order too far ahead of time. They are FAST. I don't like it when anything breaded gets a little soggy, and I often have a hard time getting there quickly enough. Notice: I live about a hundred yards away.

If you like Thai, you MUST come here.
author: Erich N.

description:
UPDATE 5/23
i am so happy w/ the consistency of this place!  i've been coming here for close to 6 years and have yet to have a bad meal here.  their corn fritters, crunchy beancakes, and tamarind prawns are favorites of mine and will always push for these items to be chosen when eating there!

---

good thai food and the "default" restaurant for most of my friends when organizing dinners.
author: Swarup B.

description: I went there last night for dinner with my husband and what a huge disappointment. We were seating in the back, noone around our table. My husband left his iphone on the bench. We walk out of the restaurant, get in our car ame realize within a minute he had left his iphone on the bench. We go right back in there ask the waitress where the phone is to which she says she hasnt seen any. You could see on her face she uncomfortable. This just sucks. Basil restaurant, if you read this review just know your staff is terrible and very dishonest.
author: Elodie P.

description:
** This should be 3.5 stars **

Pluses: Very good food, attentive but non-intrusive service and a modern, sleek  decor that manages to be warm and inviting. Minuses:  The chili flavors could have been more assertive in the dishes in which they're featured.  

Since "Transit Man" (hereafter referred to as "TM") gets up at o'dark o'clock for work, we're often among the early eaters on weekdays, and so it was for our visit to Basil Thai on Folsom between 7th and 8th on a Thursday.  This was a good thing because within 20 minutes of our reservation-less arrival the restaurant began to fill up.

This restaurant is a lovely setting for the many-layered and fragrant dishes.  That much I could see.  What I couldn't see (because I had forgotten my glasses -- Oh! Cruel! Age!) was the menu, at least not very clearly.  TM's glasses didn't help so I squinted. 

We perused the menu (or rather, I pretended to do so) as water and shrimp chips were brought to the table.  We started with Thai spiced fishcakes and yard long beans served with cucumber relish.  I couldn't find the yard long beans in the dish (no, not because I didn't have my glasses), but it didn't matter because it was delicious.  The fish cakes had a slightly nutty, smoky taste that was offset by the sweet/sour and aromatic cucumber relish.  We also had crispy spring rolls stuffed with vermicelli and cabbage and wood ear mushrooms.  These fell into the "darned good" category by comparison to the fishcakes.

We ordered two entrees: ginger chicken: lightly breaded julienne chicken, cashew nuts, & celery with caramelized ginger sauce; and pad talay (shrimp, calamari and salmon stir-fried with chili, onions, zucchini and basil.  The ginger chicken just shone for me.  There was a great balance of sweet and aromatic flavors (the ginger having a foot in both camps) and the intensified nuttiness of the sauteed cashew nuts were great.  The pad talay paled by comparison, but the seafood was tender and the sauce had an inviting smoky flavor.  

We drank a Folonari Pinot Grigio ('04 I think) and it was crisp, without any sharp edges - just slightly fruity and warm as a second impression.

TM declared it, "...the best Thai restaurant..." at which he'd ever eaten.  Go there and eat! Now that I'm looking at the menu on-line, avec glasses, (www.thaibasil.com) there's a bunch more stuff that I'd like to try!
author: Nancy W.

description:
I went to Basil Thai for the second time. Both times I ironically ordered the nuer ta cai. Very favorable and tender. I will definitely be back for this dish. 

The ambiance is nice for a date or a group of friends without being overly pricey.
author: Kalifornia S.

description:
I went here for dinner last night, really enjoyed the food, and wanted to give it 4 stars. 

We had the panstickers, duck dumplings, several entrees with duck, beef, and I especially enjoyed the tamarind shrimp, which were tasty though not spicy. I felt like the portions were on the small side, but everything was good. The fried bananas with coconut for dessert was nicely done.

The bathroom is clean and the service friendly. Parking was not too big of a hassle. I really liked the decor too. So the only downside was that it took forever to get our bill. We waited over a half hour. We tried waiving them down multiple times. And after we asked, it still took a long time. They had cleared our table, we had finished dessert, but no bill. And we were right by the bar and the service station. It was busy, but not outrageously so. It should not have been so difficult to get the bill. One of our friends had to leave, she just couldn't wait any longer, and left her credit card with us to pay her share. So this would have been a 4 star review, but 3 stars because I had to wait and wait before making the drive back to Sunnyvale at the end of a long day.
author: Alissa S.

description:
In the middle of SOMA there's this restaurant you will easily drive by without even realising there's an awesome Thai eatery right there.

Can't remember the name of the appetizer, but sounds like Goo Kung. It's basically fried shrimp sticks. Those were very yummy. If you try this, be sure to get enough of that sauce to dip it in.

I'm a big fan of larb (chicken) salad. The tangy lime and chili makes my mouth water. I suggest eating this with some rice if you're not a big fan of a burning mouth.

Pad Thai was good, but I have a hard time believing it was the BEST I've had. However, it was better than most.

The F.B.I. (if you don't know what this is, look at my earlier reviews) was a good way to end the meal.

Service was good. If you have a cute guy friend, bring him along, you might get extra good service.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
My visit here was some time ago, so I apologize for the delay in my review. I know you were desperately awaiting it...

I can't lie - this place is pretty good. I will say that I've been tainted by Osha Thai, but this place stands up pretty damn well regardless. 

We were a party of 10 of 12 and they had no problem getting us seated and taking care of us. Our waitress was quick and cheerful and even put with this drunk asshole sitting at the end of our table. I figure, if she could bear to listen to him talking about fisting someone, then she rocks. 

The food was delicious, though the portions (for me) were a little small. But hey...I'm a hungry, hungry hippo. So sue me. 

Nice Thai place for a good price in SoMa - can't beat that. Though I will say -please refrain from the vulgar sex talks at the table - I mean...we're trying to eat here...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
I have been here a few times with one person up to 5 people. Each time we have tried various menu items, from appetizers, soups and salads to meat and vegetarian entrees, and each and every one of them was divine. They make mojitos that are juuuuust right.  The atmosphere is stylish, cool  and comfortable. No complaints here.

Another positive note: You can usually find parking on the street without too much trouble. But, don't leave valuables in view or in your car at all if possible- I have parking paranoia in areas like this.
author: Amy J.

description: If you want the best Thai food in the city.  Basil Thai is the place.The green eggplant chicken curry is AMAZING!  The staff is always friendly and prices are reasonable.
author: Mike V.

description:
First night in SF ever. Went here for a large birthday party and they were really accommodating. They served us a fixed menu family-style. Everything was really tasty - they even had my favorite pumpkin curry and some of the best spring rolls I've ever had. 

The ambiance was really nice too - cute and kinda trendy. My sister and I had gotten there early so we got a few drinks at the bar and the bartender was really great. We had some kind of lychee cocktail that tasted amazing.
author: Joy C.

description:
Have to admit, chose Basil Thai to take out of towners because of the positive drink reviews. The very nice surprise is that the food wasn't bad - and not "wasn't bad" in a "my drinks were yummy and strong and I could've eaten a Power Bar and given it 4 stars" but solidly good. My friend sprang the fact that she was a vegetarian and only eating 1500 calories a day on me when I picked her up at the airport which had me frantically scrambling for something we could both eat. So when I saw Thai food and decent drinks in the same review, I was hooked. 

Have to say, for a meat eater from Texas the vegetarian based night out was not as soul crushing as I would have thought. Arrived starving and I promptly finished the entire basket of shrimp chips by myself (1500 calorie restriction for my friend, you know. Score one for me!) We started out with the porpia sod (basically tofu spring rolls) which had a nice spicy chile flavored dipping sauce. We shared the Monks Delight (tofu, oyster mushrooms and green onions) and one of the green curries (kang talay - apparently my friend is only a "land vegetarian". Whatevs). Both were really good, and I liked the fact that the green curry didn't taste as heavy and oily as some other curries I've had in the past. Can't remember the names of the drinks we had but I think we tried almost all of the specialty cocktails and they were all very good. The Saketini was my fave.

And love the ease of parking. Showed up on a Saturday night around 730p without reservations and only had a 10 minute wait. Nothing not to like about that night. Maybe these vegetarians are onto something....
author: Elena N.

description:
Came to Basil Thai on a Friday around 7:30 without a reservation and were seated right away in the back of the restaurant. The atmosphere was not a mom and pop Thai restaurant, but was not fancy, kind of the style of Osha, but a little less trendy.

We ordered the roti appetizer which was fried and delicious, but kind of greasy, definitely not a healthy appetizer. The vegetarian eggplant dish was delicious, but was a little greasy; I ate almost the whole thing and was WAY to freaking full. The vegetarian bean cakes were also really good, but were also a bit too greasy. The jasmine rice was good, but I guess it is hard to screw up rice.

Overall, above average Thai food, nice atmosphere. Not cheap, but also not a rip off, pretty standard for San Francisco. I am sure I will be back some day, although it is not my first choice.
author: Elaine S.

description:
Thai food lovers, do yourself a favor and go here. It seems every dish I've tried there tops the last one. Just close your eyes and choose a couple things. No kidding.
Also includes a full bar and an experienced tender. 
Can be difficult to just drop in on certain days.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
Last week was my second time eating lunch here this year. Both times were very good. 

Service was surprisingly fast considering how busy it was, and our wait person patient - even gracious - with one of my colleagues (out of six of us) who needed more time than the rest of us to choose.

The food was excellent - I had a beef dish in green curry, and the beef was perfectly done and tender; the curry was exactly the right texture and flavor - not too sweet (amazing! it's so usual for Asian restaurants to err on the side of sweetness in curries), and just spicy enough. My colleagues were all very happy with what they ordered, too - a couple of eggplant dishes, some chicken and yellow curry, and a noodle dish.  

It's a pleasant environment, too - for how crowded it was, the noise level wasn't bad at all, I didn't have the sensation of being jammed in, and the decor is nice. I found the television set - which is mounted behind the counter with the volume on - a bit distracting, but it wasn't a major detractor.

The prices were moderate to inexpensive (particularly for the quality) - the least expensive entree about $9, the most expensive $12.

I highly recommend this restaurant, and based on the other reviews here, I seem to have good taste :) - or at least be in good company!
author: C P.

description:
Hubby's Review:

A somewhat upscale Thai place SOMA.  The food has taste and pretty reasonably priced.  Portions can be skimpy.  Service is apt enough. My friends and I here nearly every year for our NYE dinner party.
author: Mr. and Mrs. L.

description:
Everything at this place is good, except the drink selection - which in itself isn't toooooo bad. Just not overly exciting.

Great place to eat for under $10/head (just)...
author: mike o.

description: Another highly overrated restaurant on Yelp. The green curry that we ordered was lacking flavor, but heavy on salt and sweetness. It wasn't freshly made either. I am not sure why so many reviewers are raving about this place when we have authentic Thai restaurants like Lers Ros in the city.
author: Ssbk B.

description:
I had heard nothing but raves about Basil.  Upon many recommendations we finally ate there.  I was unimpressed, fairly disappointed.  

Overall, the food lacked the intense favor I've come to expect from Thai food.  The dishes were bland and small, but thankfully not as over priced as I had expected.  The best part of the meal was the Tom Ka Gai soup.  The Panang Short Ribs and Basil Lamb Curry had almost identical tasting sauces and the lamb was over cooked.

Oh well.  Can't love them all.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
*Updated 1/28/08*

The food is great.  I wish the service would follow suit.

The appetizers at Basil Thai are awesome.  So far I tried the curry puff, calamari and spring rolls.  They all rocked!! I will definitely try the rest of their appetizers.

As for Basil Thai's curry.... simply delicous.  Man, does Basil like to tease me.  I wish they can give me more rice with chicken or duck.  That's my only complaint... because I'm still hungry when I'm back at work... and all I can think about is the curry.

The Basil Lamb is a miss for me though.  The meat is grilled and has that kind of charred meat flavor and nothing more.

Also, the service irks me at Basil.  I would expect better considering they present themselves as a decent mid class/ business type/ nice ambiance kind of restaurant.  But they do not clear your appetizer plates before they bring out your main dishes.  And they do not wait to bring out everybodys order at the same time.  And they have the ghetto... hey who ordered this dish???  While, the table looks blankly... yea i think I ordered this dish... but say that again please, cause I couldn't really hear what you said over all this conversation around us.

One of the waiters we had was not helpful with our question about the menu.  My friend was looking for a green curry with seafood that she saw last time we were here.  So, she asked the waiter if he knew what that dish was.  He, just pointed to her menu and said... the curries are over here... Yea, thanks.

But I can't hate you guys for too long... your food is too damn good.  Damn you all!

Now, I'm thinking it was just that one waiter.  Whatever dude... did I say the appetizers and curry rock!!
author: Sam T.

description:
I've been here many, many times and am never disappointed in the food, the ambiance or the service. This is not a typical hole-in-the-wall Thai restaurant--it's done with style. 

2 of my favorites: the minced chicken with Basil, and the hot & sour soup with shrimp. Ask them to toss in some veggies for a substantial meal.
author: N B.

description:
'hmmm ... what am i going to have tonight?  

the crunchy bean cakes (fried tofu with peanuts and mushrooms) or tamarind prawns? 

... crunchy bean cakes or tamarind prawns?

... hmmm ...'

because it's ALWAYS one or the other.  what can i say? when i find something i like, i stick to it. i probably get food there so often because it's on my way home so it's uber convenient - especially for one who doesn't cook.

however, i must say that the last time i had the crunchy bean cakes (2 nights ago), it was way overfried and didn't have any sauce. but that was one bad batch out of ... probably over 30 times i've had it. 

oh yeah - and we found the newest addition to our home (an awesome tabby kitty) trapped under the hood of an employee's car parked right out front. his name? ... basil.
author: cynthia q.

description:
What's the Thai equivalent of Montezuma's revenge?  The Pad Kee Mao and spring rolls were tasty at the time, but the next morning...I was on the porcelain shrine begging Siddhartha for forgiveness!

I guess I should have ordered the Pepto with my meal instead of Singha.  I'll try Basil again...when I'm reincarnated as a goat.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Thai is often a challenging cuisine for me as I find it to be rich and, frankly, fattening.  We came here with a group for a birthday dinner.  Some of us arrived a bit late for our 7:30 reservation, so those who arrived on time were comfortably seated at the bar until we had enough to fill our table as the rest of the crew trickled in.   The ambiance is nice - it was Saturday night so while several tables were full, it wasn't crowded and you could have a conversation without yelling. 
We ordered apps and wine and they arrived in a flash.  Our entrees also came out very quickly and there was never a wait for a server, our water glasses were always full and the staff were generally friendly, competent, efficient and knowledgeable.     The quality of the food was good - I often feel that thai food is "gloppy' and while the curries were heavy, as expected, the overall quality of the food was fresh and less stodgy than other Thai places I've been to. 
I ordered Chicken Satay and salad with peanut sauce - light and crispy - and we had many other dishes that we shared with the table.  They just brought us one big bowl of rice to share. 
The bill was ~ $260, including a bottle and a few glasses of wine and beer for 7/8 people, gratuity was included.
author: Maria C.

description: What struck me about this restaurant is their service. Their timing seemed perfect. We munched on their shrimp chips after ordering. I wish they gave us more. Then appetizers came out, and as we cleaned off the last morsel of calamari and corn cake, the entrees came out. We didn't need to even put our forks down between apps and entree! The dessert menus came out right as I scraped up the last bit of curry sauce. We ordered two desserts: a Kahlua and coffee granita over coconut cream and a fried banana with ice cream. The granita was delicious: refreshing---reminds me of a White Russian. The entrees were a bit small but tasty. I wish the curry had more sauce. It's not proportional to the amount of rice they give. Everything is delicious enough for me, just not the greatest value. Service is good though! I always laugh when happy hour really is ONE hour!
author: Ato Z.

description:
I thought I'd celebrate writing my 100th yelp by reviewing my birthday dinner. It was fantastic! Great company (14 of us) to go with the great food.

Since I didn't do the ordering, I can't quite remember all the dishes, and there were a LOT of dishes, but they were all tasty.

We had 4 or 5 appetizers but my favorite was the 
- Keow Wan Roti (grilled indian bread with green curry and eggplant): I LOVE roti and the flaky layers. Goes great w/ green curry and eggplant - my favorites!!
- Kao Pode Tod (corn cake fritter): never seen this before on a menu for a thai restaurant. Worth trying.
We also had some more normal apps like Pot Stickers and Fried Calamari. They were solid.
We had 2 noodle dishes:
- Pad Thai: a classic.
- Pad Ke Mao (spicy wide rice noodles & sliced beef stir-fried with basil, garlic, & thai chili): at least this is what I think we had. We might have had the Pad Seew. Either way, whatever came with the rice noodles was good.

Then there was a slew of entrees to share:
- Gai Prik Khing (chicken & string beans): love the string beans 
- Pad Talay Ruammit (seafood medley): this was a lighter but flavorful dish
- Gai Ma-Muang (chicken with nuts & zucchini): I liked the slight sweet taste to this.
- Kang Ped* (duck in red curry): While I love duck, duck in curry is more for flavor than for meaty eating. Pieces are fatty but the curry sauce is still delicious, especially drenching rice.
- Pla Dook Pad Pik (crispy catfish filet kaffir red curry paste): Wow, this was a great dish! the fish was really tender, and it was encrusted w/ the red curry paste which added a kick and just tremendous flavor to the palate. 
- Nuer Ta Cai (beef cubes w/ lemongrass): this was super tender melt in your mouth beef. Man, just writing about them makes my mouth water.

There was also a lamb dish (which I avoided) and maybe another curry. But honestly by the 10th plate, you start forgetting what you ate. Prices ranged from $7 - $13. Pretty reasonable and certainly filling. The service was great too considering the size of our party.

Overall a wonderful way to celebrate a bday dinner.
author: Cindy W.

description:
I'd driven 2000 miles in an unwieldy Penske rental truck through a veritable Asian Food wasteland, and I was desperate for some spring rolls.

Don't get my wrong, the drive from Chicago to San Francisco provided me with the opportunity to sample some of the heartland's finest cuisine: there was the Wendy's in Nebraska, at least two Dairy Queens at some point, and I'm pretty sure there was even (*gasp*) a White Castle in there somewhere.

So when I finally crossed the Bay Bridge and navigated the Yellow Beast through the streets of San Francisco to my hotel, I was ready to eat some quality Asian food.  I fired up Yelp (thank you, Best Western free-wifi) and found Basil.  

After my first bite of spring roll and sip of white wine, the 2000 miles melted away.  Both the app and entree was excellent, and the atmosphere was lively but not so loud I couldn't hear my lovely dinner companion.  And prices were higher than the #5 combo at BK, but still relatively cheap.  My only regret is that I didn't have an apartment yet to bring home my leftover scallops with black bean sauce.

Thanks you Basil, for a wonderful intro to San Francisco eating.
author: Eric S.

description:
Basil Thai was great!

Admittedly, I've been in sort of a rut when it comes to Thai food in San Francisco, going to the two or three same places whenever the mood strikes. Basil was a nice change of pace.

We ordered the roti (very tasty but quite small), the charbroiled salmon with red curry and watermelon (fantastic, large enough for two people to get full off of!), a thai iced coffee (standard, nothing special) and the fried banana w. coconut ice cream for dessert ( really good, super creamy ice cream and the banana was served  in little fried pieces rather than just one big lump!) 

As for cocktails: my BF had the tuk tuk (brandy-based, I think...not really my thing) and I had the saketini, which was easily the VERY BEST thing I had out of the entire meal! I will go there again just for that drink! It was nigori sake mixed with lychee puree...heaven!!! I love lychee!

Service was fine, no problems there, except they charged us for an extra item on the bill, which I luckily caught when checking it over, so they promptly corrected the mistake and we were good to go.

It was a nice eating experience!
author: Shannon R.

description: Delicious and affordable Thai food in Soma. More authentic than OSHA and less overstated. I like both, but would recommend Basil Thai to real (Thai) food enthusiasts!
author: Malachi R.

description: They have a lunch special:  $10.95, includes soup (a bit sweet), a choice of appetizers and choice of entree (choice of mild, medium, or hot).  I had fish cake, which was over fried.  My friend had tofu satay and that was good.  I had the mild sweet basil, chicken, yellow curry.  I should have ordered medium. It just seemed bland.  Mild was too mild, no kick.  My friend had medium, seafood, spicy eggplant $12.95.  Hers was yummy, but a bit too sweet.  Wait staff are really attentive.
author: Helen L.

description: Great curries! I really like how fresh and not heavy they taste, with plenty of flavor. I could eat the grilled squash curry all the time. However, the pad see ew had something a little off about it's flavor. It was still decent, but I wouldn't order it again.
author: Puneet S.

description:
They knew me by first name when I lived not too far away from there.
I used to stop by on my way home from work and get something. 

Number of times visited: Gosh....30 maybe.....

What to order:
- The beans and roots, if you're a party of three or more (it's good but needs to be spread over a few people),
 - goong gra bog, pretty good shrimp appetizer. Kinda dry but ok

- moo yang, good.

 - param rungsong, meat and peanut sauce. yum.

Friendly staff and pretty consistent, good food gives this place 3.5 stars..wait..can't do that..so..3 it is. I'm in a frugal mood today.
author: Rich S.

description:
I find that I eat here more than any other restaurant in San Francisco.  The reason?  It has great food, great drinks, good prices, easy parking, and you can always get in.  I just haven't found this combination in any other restaurant in SF.

I just feel the need to say this again.

You can park!  On the same block!  And walk in!  And get a drink and some tasty food!  And you don't mind the price!

The lamb curry is a stand-out, as are the turnip cakes.  The tempura long beans with scallops are delicious.  Screw it -- it is all super tasty.  It is very California-influenced Thai food, but it all works so well here.

Friday!  8pm!  You have 5 guests in town, and no reservations.  Basil will make it work!  You can take two cars!  And park outside!  Your friends will complement you and say how great your taste is!  And even if you're picking up the tab, you'll go home with an inner glow.

JUST GO HERE OKAY!
author: Trent W.

description:
This review is soo late, but I just had to put my two cents in.
I love starters and main entries are just delicious! One favorite that i always get here is the Porpia Sod which is  fresh rolls of vegetables + tofu served with crushed peanuts, chili, lime vinaigrette.Skewers aren't so bad either, although small portions and price isn't so bad (bet 4-6 bucks). A nice additon in the soma district!
author: Ateh M.

description: Went with a friend to Basil Thai for the 1st time and I've got to say the food was absolutely terrific - my companion had been there before and ordered for us and his choice was spot on! I'll go back when I'm in the area. The only down side I would say is that at lunch time the dining area was pretty noisy and the server was juggling a lot of tables so our service could have been better but this place is way too good to knock.
author: Jonathan S.

description: Spring rolls, green curry, pad Thai, sticky rice - all of it was excellent - amongst the best in the bay area. and i eat lots of thai food (once a week almost!)
author: Saurin S.

description:
Like a burrito for taquerias--my benchmark for a Thai restaurant is their red curry.

Like many of Basil's dishes, they do a little different spin on theirs. Basil puts pumpkin slices in with the chicken. I must applaud. I've never seen it at a Thai place before, so if they created the combination...excellent work. If it's not an original combo...good dish, ya' Milli Vanilli motherfuckers.
author: Josh B.

description:
Yes, yes, yes!

This was a great spot, even for a large group of 10. The food came out super quick, and everything was very tasty. Try the seafood salad, wok-tossed scallops, pad thai, or the noodles with beef. 

Also, the mango pannacotta is AMAZING!

I really like the grapefruit/gin cocktail too. 

I WILL BE BACK--SOON!
author: Misha F.

description: Went in to this place only because right above the restaurant is my friend's apartment. Convenience is the key. To my surprise, I really liked the place. The servers were cordial and the ambiance was great. They have Singha! I ordered "Prawns, scallops, mussels served with bamboo shoots and okra in green curry  (kang talay)." It came with a serving of steamed rice. Loved it! Prices weren't bad either. I don't mind going back to try the rest of the food in the menu!
author: Eddie D.

description:
I've been to dozens of Thai restaurants in my day. Manora's used to be my favorite for many years until I discovered Basil Thai - just down the street on Folsom.  

What differentiates Basil Thai from many other Thai restaurants? I find that their preparation is just much fresher - vegetables are not overcooked, the noodles don't stick together, and the meat/seafood is always fresh.

Some of my favorite dishes include the braised short ribs, pad thai, Basil's eggplant, taro cakes, pad ke mao and all of the curries.

The decor is light and modern with lots of table and bar seating. The only pet peeve I have is the TV above the bar. I hope that someone goes on a crusade to rid TVs from all restaurants.
author: Spoon G.

description:
This is the most excellent Thai food around! A little oasis in cement-town.

I have never been let down with both their food and service. The menu is extensive but not overwhelming, it is easy to branch out and try new combos, and the waiters are always sooo happy to help. Lunch is pretty cheap, and dinner is usually $8-13. Get the chicken or calamari skewers while you wait, and try the incredible wok dishes or curry dishes. The atmosphere is nice, a good date place and it is always full but never a long wait. You will love it.
author: Sneaks N. Beat S.

description:
One liner: Great food, reasonable price and you can always get a table on any night of the week - a very rare trifecta in San Francisco.

When I moved to my new place, one of the first things I said was "score, it's right next to Basil"

The Best:
-------------
Pad Shanghai : nice twist on a classic with clear noodles
Scallops with Tempura fried green beans:  mmhmm
Duck Curry.
author: Anthony T.

description:
Looks like there are a ton of reviews for this place, so I'll make mine brief.

Here's what we had:

param rungsong (grilled marinated skirt steak topped with peanut sauce) --- this was OUTSTANDING for the beef-eaters.  

goong choo chee (charcoal-grilled large river prawns topped with kaffir choo chee curry sauce) --- this was another winner.  FAT, yummy prawns.

We also had the papaya salad, which was great.

Our dinner guests had the pad seew and the panang short ribs.  I didn't taste them, but judging from what we had, I'm sure it wouldn't disappoint.  Looked great.  

The only issue with this place was the portion size, which wasn't skimpy but not plentiful either.  Typical with restaurants in this price range.  

You'll definitely leave this place quenched.
author: Jeff C.

description: Oh, goodness gracious, was this place delicious. The selection was so broad, my group of four just chose four appetizers and entrees we all wanted, a bottle of sake, and went to town. Each thing was more delicious than the last. I recommend the pork shoulder and pumpkin curry. MMMM.
author: Jon M.

description:
Great curry, fast service.  Easy free parking usually can be found durring lunch on the street.

I've had many lunch meetings here.  The good food and atmosphere make it a great place to bring my clients and business partners when we want to talk over food.
author: Amie C.

description: Basil is one of my favorite Thai restaurants in the city mainly for a specific dish.  The spicy crispy catfish sauteed in red curry and fresh peppercorn is THE BEST!  Other restaurants can't perfect this dish like they can. I've tried others and have been disappointed.  Their green curry dish with the prawns, scallops, mussels, bamboo shoot, and okra is quite tasty as well. Pair either dish with brown rice and you're good to go. I am always a happy camper when I come here!
author: C E.

description: Creative and unique Thai food.  I find the dishes to be a little sweeter than I like, but that's a minor drawback considering how good most things are.
author: Patrick S.

description:
I forgot about Basil Thai for some reason until very recently... Man I've missed this place!  A nice selection of the usual Thai eats alongside less common dishes, some great "light" options, and consistently top quality.  Good drinks, too.  

They deliver through WoW, but I love the dine-in experience... Warm, casual, with a trendy urban edge.  And the young man who often works the register/bar is a burst of sunshine.  Definitely my latest go-to Thai place...
author: seema s.

description:
I used Yelp to find the "best" Thai restaurant in the city. Basil Thai had the most reviews behind Osha Thai which made it a no-brainer. And Yelp did not let me down.

Basil Thai's interior is classy, but comfortable. The menu is large and requires some perusing. The table had the Indian bread with green curry as an appetizer followed by the veggies and green curry dish, pad thai and a dish containing bamboo shoots, asparagus spears and mushrooms.  Each dish deserves a solid 4 on the Yelping scale. If I lived in SOMA, I would be eating at Basil Thai all the time,
author: Charles B.

description:
The food was delicious, the service was great and the ambience was comfortable.  We did not have a reservation, luckily at that moment we did not need one and I was happy through the whole experience.  
I ordered the seafood curry, it was so fresh and simple.  I tried to leave left overs, but I couldn't, it was too tasty to imagine warmed up again!  
I loved the crunchy scoops, the app. of potstickers and my friends meal too!!!  The flavours were spot on!!!

Thanks to the referral by Dillon at Bloodhound, a super place to grab a libation after your Yummy Thai dinner!!!
author: Ali H.

description: My boyfriend took me here for lunch last week.  The food is very good plus the ambiance is modern and stylish.  Something you wouldn't expect from a Thai restaurant.  Service is also four stars.. they are very friendly and attentive.  Highly recommend.
author: Christine P.

description: Delicious!  We came here before going to an event in the neighborhood -- simply for the convenience.  The food was excellent.  The place was crowded and busy, but they managed to get us out in time.  Did I mention the food was amazing?
author: Leilah P.

description:
this place was ok, for the price it was a pretty decent thai restaurant.

Their rice cake appetizers and fried banana with coconut ice cream dessert are phenomenal.

I had their pad thai, it was pretty tasty and my friend got the stuff eggplant and said it was pretty good--didnt get to try it. their chicken/pork panstickers were 'ok'.

service was ok, we were constantly having to call over our server to get stuff and some service which was kind of annoying. but the atmosphere was good and enjoyable--very quaint and modern chic
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description:
All types of goodness!

What else can the kid say that hasn't been said already? You already know you're going to pay a pretty penny for a small portion. The  taste, service, and atmos is worth the price tag indeed.

Ordered the Nuer Ta Cai (Angus sirloin cubes stir-fried with lemongrass, bell peppers, & roasted chili paste) and that was a roundhouse kick to the mouth. Tender cuts of beef and crunchy veggies all brought together by a super lush sauce made this the perfect combo for my rice. No talking. No looking up at the table. Engulfed in under 5 minutes. Fin.



.
author: Steve H.

description: my bf and I dined here during our trip in SF.  It was a random decision because we had to yelp for places to eat since it was our first night there and hadn't met up with friends yet so Basil was the closest place to our hotel.  I loved how dim it was inside and there's a bar, A BAR!!!!! The server was very friendly and our food didn't take long. I think we ordered shrimp pad thai and fried rice but i forgot which.  They were good though. I wasn't expecting them to be, i really thought it'd taste like "American" thai food. All of this gets 3 stars but i'll throw in 1 more for the atmosphere and the crowd.  I'll probably come back again next time in SF.
author: Tyra N.

description:
I went here last night and thought it was awesome....and am happy to say that I will be having it again for lunch today!  

Ambiance: meh....
Food: yay!
Sake: double yay!

We had the; 
Thai calamari (5...over cooked, but the diping sauce was good)
Stuffed eggplant (10)
Duck in red curry (9)
Scallops with tempura green beans (8...the scallops would have been better pan seared).

All in all, it was a great meal and the prices weren't bad.  We closed the place down and the staff was really nice about use being there so late.
author: Megan H.

description: Had the grilled eggplant stuffed with chicken and cabbage in green curry. On brown rice. Great service Excellent!!!!!
author: Anne L.

description:
4 1/2 stars

I've been going here since it opened, and since it used to be right down stairs from my workplace, that used to be very very often! 

This place is great!! The food is consistently fresh, delicious and on form. I've never come here and had my favorite dish be "off". Ever. But then, I have a lot of favorites here. When the chef is creative and understands the chemistry of the flavors he's using, and texture and color, it's hard to go wrong. 

The atmosphere here is also wonderful. This is a great date place. It's simple, not very expensive, classy and pretty casual. Highly recommended!
author: Mindy L.

description:
Fairly priced, every single dish I've had here (more than half the menu) has been spot-on. One of my favorite dishes is the Stuffed Eggplant. 

Nice, clean modern deco. Even the bathroom is impeccable. Great service staff!
author: Stephen L.

description: Some local residents recommended this lovely restaurant to us.  We enjoyed the fresh spring rolls for an appetizer.  They were well balanced and more carefully spiced and flavor-balanced than most springrolls we've had elsewhere.  I had curried fish and my companion had eggplant, which we both found delightful.  We'd look forward to going back.  The atmosphere is relaxed, on the modern side, the service was very good and attentive, and the cocktails were offbeat and well executed Thai-inspired.
author: whit e.

description:
I've been here numerous times - it's near work, so it's the "nice" place to go for the occasional work lunch. Well, probably only been here once in the past year, but it has never disappointed. 

Can't say we've ordered much from here, always get the same few things. My favorite was the Tamarind Prawns - really delicious sauce, but they're breaded, so don't want too many of those bad boys. Huge prawns though. Damn sauce is addictive. The papaya salad is spicy but great. Eggplant+tofu dish is excellent (great sauce again), as is the larb salad. I've never had the stuffed eggplant with green curry, but co-workers go crazy for that one. I haven't been crazy for some of their appetizers that we've ordered as a large group (some fishcake things? also some tofu one I didn't care for). Oh yes, I had their pad thai way back when, and didn't care for it (but I'm not a huge pad thai order-er.)
author: Jen D.

description:
Yesterday was my second time at Basil.  The place is really trendy; almost too trendy for a Thai restaurant.  There's a bar, dim lighting and even an alcove like entrance.  If you like triangles, this is the place for you.

Thai food here is a bit Americanized, which is not necessarily bad.  Everything we had there was tasty and flavorful, although the portions were a bit smaller than you would get at other Thai restaurants.  Be prepared to order more or eat less - the choice is yours!

We had deep fried corn patties (excellent), roti bread (oily, but still good) and beef cubes in two different sauces, green curry and lemongrass (both very good, very juicy and very tender).  All this delicious goodness, plus some steamed rice, one Thai iced coffee and one Thai iced tea cost us about $58 .  

The service was fine, too.  No complaints there.  Good food, but -1 star for small portions and high prices.  Koh Samui & The Monkey or Manora Thai give you a lot more food for less money.  I guess the hip factor and the triangular alcove are worth a couple extra bucks.
author: Yan G.

description:
Came here for dinner with some friends and boy was it delish.  We ordered family style so we had many dishes that we were able to try.  

Goong gra bog-crispy rice paper wrapped tiger prawns with sweet dipping sauce...I didn't get to try it...I guess I snoozed I lose.  They looked very good tho.
Tod mon-fish cake with cucumber relish...thank goodness I grabbed a piece...it was good.
Curry puffs-a crispy puf pastry with curried duck and sweet potatoes.....this was very tasty.
Papaya salad-this was good, the tomatoes was a nice touch but I would have liked it more if it was spicy.
Curry peppercorn duck-come on now people I seriously like almost anything that has duck in there....this was good.
Gai prik khing-crispy chicken and string beans with the yummy yummy sauce....lol...I ended up eating rice with just the sauce....delish.

We also had this mixed seafood dish which was not bad ....better if it was spicy...I really like spicy food.  We got to try 2 curries and both were very good....one red and one green.  My friends also ordered a catfish and duh why did I believe them when they said it was chicken katsu and bit into it.  Because it was covered in sauce I swallowed it......this was spicy but I personally don't eat catfish.  Perhaps you can say its psychological....never again.  Why only 4 stars if I liked almost everything I had....they didn't have mango with sticky rice.  Hopefully...next time I come back they will have it here.  

Hehe...how can I forget I tried the saketini...which was sake with lychee puree...pretty good.  I definitely hope to come back again for a good meal.
author: Allison T.

description:
I came here with a large group for a friend's birthday dinner. The staff did a good job accommodating our group.

The drinks were OK and the food was great. The atmosphere is casual but nice. The place was definitely busy that Saturday night. The staff wasn't overly friendly, but the service was speedy.

Overall, a good choice for a nice but casual dinner.
author: Amy D.

description:
One of my neighborhood faves.  An easy choice any time you want something good, someplace clean, and decently priced.

The Basil Eggplant is great as is the stuffed eggplant and I used to not even like eggplants.

Good Stuff!
author: Gene X.

description:
Date:  October 27, 2008 @ 6PM

Occasion:  Girlfriend's Birthday Dinner

Girlfriend:  Rebecca:  Thirty-Something and Fabulous!!

Venue:  Cozy Thai Restaurant in SOMA

Decor:  Contemporary Asian minimalist. Elegant yet relaxed.
              Comfortable wicker chairs.  Square table covered with white linen.

Social Scene:  Trendy and Hip Youngsters and Oldsters.  
                            Mature couple who enjoyed a whole bottle of red wine.
                            Single woman in business-suit at the bar.
                            Girlfriends having dinner.

Service:  Friendly. Very efficient but not -overbearing.

Salud!:  A clean and sober night--we just had 2 glasses of H2O.

Starters:   Complimentary shrimp chips
                   Fishcakes
                   Papaya Salad
                    
Taste:      1. Charcoal-grilled large river prawns topped with kaffir choo  chee curry sauce :  Large generous portions of prawns. Very flavorful sauce.
                   2. Shiang Hai clear noodles stir-fried with prawns yard long beans, chili, & basil : Not your everyday type noodles.  Unique, interesting clear noodles in asymetrical shapes.  Light and delicious
Worth-trying!

Dessert:  None.  Too full!!!!

Tab:  $55.34 (With tax and tip)


Worth-mentioning:  A perfect venue to celebrate over 10 years of girlfriendship.  We were able to enjoy our meals at our pace, yet we were left alone to have a heart to heart talk without feeling ignored.  The restaurant felt like a sanctuary for the two hours of dining we spent there.  The food made not just our tummies feeling satisfied but our souls content and peaceful for the evening.
author: Leah E.

description:
I'm so glad we found this place on Yelp!  Three of us went here for dinner on New Year's day, and a very enjoyable meal was had by all.  We were a bit hungry, so we ordered about 5 dishes to share (more than enough).  Once we placed our order, a cute little bamboo steamer full of shrimp chips came out, which I thought was a nice touch.  Just a little something different to make the restaurant stand out in my mind.  

The food service was rather slow, but the staff was very friendly and the atmosphere was pleasant and comfortable, so I didn't mind the wait very much.  We had the Tom Yum Goong soup, an order of Lamb Satay Skewers, Cashew Chicken, Angus Steak Cubes with Eggplant, Peppercorn Duck, and Pad Ke Mao.  Everything was sooo good!!  

Their menu is pretty extensive - I will definitely be back to try more.  Also, the prices are very reasonable; in fact, I might almost call it cheap, given the quality of food and beautiful environment.  Lastly, they make a mean Thai Iced Tea; I had a hard time holding myself back from reaching across the table to steal sips of from my bf's glass...
author: Kalista W.

description: It doesn't happen often but you really let me down Yelp. Very mediocre Thai food, limited drinks selection, 0 ambiance. Unfriendly staff. How I wish we went elsewhere for our celebration... Oh well.
author: H H.

description: Opted to do fam style, but someone in the group had seafood AND mango allergies (way to bring it up after we pick a thai restaurant). So although I couldn't go tiger blood on some tiger prawns, I did enjoy the rest of the menu. Coconut curry was great though superfluous to the portion of meat given. Friendly service and fairly priced.
author: Palak K.

description:
Excellent thai food, and very good service. We went here for a friend's birthday, and a lot more people showed up than we had originally planned for. The restaurant was very flexible, and brought us an extra table to accommodate the overflow. When even more people came, they swapped the table with a larger one.

Service was pretty quick. We didn't wait that long to get our food, and the wait staff was attentive, refilling our water and asking us whether we wanted drink refills.

I ordered the kang gai - chicken breast with peppers and bamboo shoots. It wasn't as spicy as requested - I asked for "extremely hot", but it was just sort of hot. However the curry was pretty darn good, especially for the price. I took some home, but was the only one who did so.

The decor was nice. I enjoyed the free postcards in the back, near the restrooms. The prices weren't bad - $10 - $15 for an entree. Rice is a la carte on the curries ($1.50). We ended up paying about $25/person, but that was for a large party with lots of drinks and appetizers.
author: Dana L.

description:
I just had red curry duck here for lunch, with sticky rice.  Lovely lovely sticky rice, my most favorite Thai edible (don't laugh!), surprisingly tricky to find sometimes... and here they offer it with virtually any entree they serve.  Heavenly.

Oh, and the duck was tasty.  Could have used a bit more pineapple in it, and maybe a few more peppers - or perhaps a lower price, eh? - but overall I can't complain.
author: Jess L.

description:
Oh Basil Thai...you are that restaurant that a number of my friends have turned to me at various points and said "what was that Thai restaurant you brought me to that was so good?" and I remind them "Basil". This I feel is indicative of a really good restaurant. I have eaten there numerous times and always bring friends and out of town guests that want a nice sit down Thai restaurant that feels upscale, has fabulous food and it not over the top busy or expensive. 

Thank you, Basil, for being my go to. 

My recommendations (although I have never tried anything there that I did not think was really well done):
Beef Shortribs in green curry (grandma's favorite)
SPRING ROLLS! my favorite.
Banana leaf wrapped cod
Fried Calamari in a tamarind sauce
Rice wide noodle with basil
Lemongrass tofu
Brown rice

Their mojitos are strong.
author: Vanessa J.

description: Had pad Thai for the first time here. 10 bones and left satisfied. Nice combination of flavors with just enough sauce. Giving it 4 stars because I've never had pad Thai before to establish a baseline. Definitely going back
author: Chris A.

description:
Mellow, friendly, and totally delicious!  I have loved Basil since my very first taste 3 years ago.  It was the Keow Wan Roti that did it....Indian flat bread, eggplant, and slices of red pepper smothered with irresistible green curry.  Out of control good!  

My husband and I recently took my sis and bro-in-law when they were in town from LA.  I tried something new and wasn't sorry.  It was the Kao Pode Tod (yellow corn and bean cake fritters served with some rockin cucumber salad).  I couldn't believe I had never ordered it before!  

Vegetarians will find plenty of options to satisfy their Thai-loving hunger at Basil.  I could fill up on veggie appetizers and the veggie skewers alone!  

To make it even better, parking is not too much of an issue and the saketini tastes great!  I love you, Basil!  Don't go anywhere!
author: Abby W.

description:
I think Basil Thai is just lovely! I often judge Thai restaurants by the way they smell upon entry. Obviously, if I'm mentioning it, that means it was good. There's really nothing like the fresh aroma of Thai cooking. Mmmmm.

 I especially liked the side wall. Hard to explain, but I"ll give it a shot. It's those square window blocks that allow lots of light in but you can't actually see through them. I found this to be a nice touch for a restaurant that's more or less in an alley. Great like, but no views of alleys or walls.

 The place was very nice and modern with clean decor. The food was delicious and the service was great. I would definitely recommend Basil Thai and I will definitely return.
author: alexa c.

description:
Excellent food for the low, low prices. Husband and I ate here, had one entree and three appetizers, one drink, only $26. The Tom Ka Gar soup was amazing, and I always get Tom Ka Gar.
Thursdays- Manny is the bartenders, really cool guy, makes good drinks. Perfect place to eat before going clubbing.
author: Moira N.

description:
The food is pretty good, but overpriced. I've had similar-or-better Thai food at several meeker establishments throughout the city for about half the price of what Basil charges for their slightly Americanized Thai food. If you buy a drink and appetizers you're looking at spending around $30/person.

The service here is really good though, and the decor is surprisingly fancy considering the location. This place would be good for a date or maybe a business lunch, but it isn't the kind of place I'd go to when alone. Or that I'd visit very frequently.
author: James C.

description:
Very nice thai place that we decided to have a college reunion at, basically. The food was fantastic, definitely try the fresh rolls and the corn cakes, as well as the different salads. Green papaya one was my personal favorite, but my friend ordered one with a seafood variety that was also delicious. However, be warned, you can easily stuff your face on apps and salads only to discover you have no room for dinner!

I had the skirt steak with peanut sauce, I asked for it medium rare but it came out completely well done. The staff was super nice about it and quickly got me a new one, definitely on the rare side, and delicious. Of course, by that time I was full, and had to take it to go. Pity, because I promptly forgot it in my friend's fridge, and sitting in Houston now, I really wish I had it!
author: Irene F.

description:
I've only ordered delivery or take out from this place, but the food has always been really tasty and in the dozen or so times we've ordered I can't think of any problems. The "marinated skirt steak grilled and topped with peanut-coconut milk sauce" is amazing, as are the panang short ribs. I've tried a bunch of other dishes and they've all been above average for thai in SF. The kang ped (duck curry) is the only dish I've ever ordered that I didn't think was very good, and thats just because the duck was fatty and gross - the flavors were still great. 

The only time I've ever been in was to pickup food, but the interior is pretty slick, in regards to both the architecture and the decoration.

All in all, probably my favorite Thai place in SF right now.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I really like this place.. well it is also about a block from my house! 
It makes for great takeout! They have messed up my order once or twice.. 
But i blame it on the fact that is it too loud in there and they cant hear you when u call in your to-go order... :( I mean i love the pad thai so yummy ... and what is pad-thai without the shrimp!!! 

They also have a great selection of wine for you winos out there! 
Oh and very reasonably priced too.  Happy Thai food! :)
author: Samantha R.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant in the city hands down. It is a great combination of authentic Thai cuisine with a slightly modern/fine dining  twist. The lamb curry is amazing, three smokey lamb chops grilled and served with green beans over a creamy/tangy/spicy curry sauce. I order every time I go. The atmosphere and service are top notch, easily a great date night restaurant. The bar is long and the drinks are strong as well, but the best reason to go is the food.
author: Asa S.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night right around 7pm with a group of 8 and no reservation. The wait was short and the staff were extremely accommodating. We had to squeeze 4 into a booth area meant for 3, but when another, larger table became available a few minutes later they offered to move us to the larger space! So nice. Now to the food. Corn fritters! Corn fritters! With cucumber-peanut-rice vinegar sauce! So good!  

We also had the himapan (cashew) chicken, various curries (the grilled lamb red curry was the best), stuffed eggplant something or other, pad see ew and pad thai. Everyone left happy. I was so happy, in fact, that I returned to the restaurant five days later for another meal.
author: Clare M.

description: I love Thai food. The spices, the presentation, the iced tea. Thai food is excellent, exotic, and simply delicious. My favorite Thai restaurant is in Davis, where they had bottomless iced tea. My favorite one in the Bay Area thus far is Krung Thai near Valley Fair. A good in SF is Basil Thai. Suffice to say, the atmosphere was nice as always with excellent service. We ordered their papaya salad, roti bread, crispy catfish, and chicken/basil dishes. Yum Yum!!! Great presentation, portions, and taste! At the end, an excellent sweet rice/mango desert closed the books on a great dinner.
author: Stanley C.

description:
After reading some review in Yelp we decided to give this place a try. Nice atmosphere, cozy and had the Monday night game on.

Started with the calamari which was YUM! They had a spicy sauce to dip it in that added just enough kick. The main course was a green curry seafood medley along with some pineapple fried rice.. although the portion of curry wasn't very large it was actually enough for both of us along with the appetizers.

The service was decent, I'd definitely come back again to enjoy some of their other menu options.
author: Jen S.

description: Quite possibly the best Thai in SF! This place is just down the street from me and is one of my regular stand-bys. Not only is the food great, but they also have a full bar and some great signature cocktails. I highly recommend the Tom Kha soup and the Kanom Pak Gard (Turnip Cakes) is a real treat for the vegetarians. Based on feedback from all the people I've brought to this place, I can pretty much vouch for everything on the menu. Enjoy!
author: Paul M.

description:
I have only gotten take out from here, but damn it is tasty!

We have made this our pre new years dinner two years in row, and my friends who live nearby highly recommend it, and indulge every chance they get. a few days ago on NYE, I actually saw the joint as we picked up some dishes on our way to a pre party. the ambiance was simple, clean, and romantic. the restaurant is long and narrow. There was a small bar, and tables of between 2 and 12 enjoying themselves in a relaxed environment. Candles and music (with a just right volume) set the mood nicely, and the smell was to die for. I understand they have a dynamite leechee martini, and i'm sure other fantasic cocktails that will nicely compliment  you thai meal.
author: Caddy M.

description: I got the most amazing coconut chicken mushroom soup for $5.  They even have a list of the gluten free options here!  And I'm not super sensitive with my reactions to gluten but I didn't get the dreaded gluten headache of doom after eating here!  The wait staff wasn't very enthusiastic but I did not mind because the soup more than made up for it.  Seriously, try the soup.
author: Marie B.

description:
Basil: Le Herb Royale

My friend and I hand-picked a restaurant among thousands where we had not yet dined.  That was a prerequisite, since I was in a critiquing mode this weekend. The restaurant we chose was Basil, located in San Francisco's SOMA district.  The dreamy midnight-blue bar and wall-to-wall precision lighting seemed to be its signature items, but luckily we discovered the food to be the restaurant's real savior.   That was good news to me, as it breaks the heart to see yet another visually stunning Thai space go belly-up and shut its doors. 

We ordered a near-perfect sumptuous beef and cilantro salad, a dish with angry prawns and snow peas, and of course a lamb dish with coconut red curry sauce.  It just so happens that we picked the best wine in the house for these dishes: a Ravenswood 2003 Shiraz from South Eastern Australia.   It was surprisingly one of the best pairings we have managed all year--- strange because this wine is not well-received by critics.   Whenever grapes leave their home and start traveling halfway around the globe for processing (for instance, to California), wine critics do nothing more than take a swig of the yield and spit it out. 

The waitress was cute and humble, and she was all the more clever.  While we were enjoying our appetizer, she delivered the prawn delight and so gracefully verified with my friend that he wanted red curry with his lamb dish.  It came out four minutes later, most likely because they botched the original order. Oops!   We gave her a generous tip just for her sneaky finesse!   As we left, we realized that the owners, the chefs, and the staff choreographed a total experience, so we concurred that this was now one of the best Thai restaurants in the city.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Just how good is this place?  I'll let my actions speak for me - the food here is so good, I'm willing to pay the ridiculous delivery charge for waiters on wheels just to get the Basil Pad Thai.

But if you want to save yourself the ten or fifteen bucks that WoW charges, head on out to Basil - it's "in the middle of nowhere" even for SoMa - the closest landmark I can think of is 1015 Folsom.  Order yourself the duck curry - make sure you spoon lots of the sauce over your rice.  The scallops with tempuura green beans is excellent, served super fresh and covered with a light but tangy sauce that really brings out the scallop flavor.  Even though some of my friends don't eat eggplant, they couldn't shun the eggplant and chicken curry.  And lastly, the Pad Thai...seriously, the best Pad Thai in the Bay Area.  Perfectly cooked noodles, just the right amount of tang, jumbo prawns, tofu, crushed peanuts...if any of you know of a place with better Pad Thai, let me know, and I'll try it out.

Thanks to Michael K for tuning me in to this place.
author: brian w.

description:
amazing, wonderful, the best.  I Literally pulled this place off of yelp and said let's go.  The tamarind prawns were mind blowing as was the stuff eggplant in green curry.  I had killer bok choy, it was delicious.  Go, you will not be disappointed!!!! 

This is the best blind lunch selection I have ever made and will continue to go back for a long time to come!!!
author: Nicole F.

description:
I think this place has great ambience. But frankly, their food is not that great. We went with a curry and seafood noodle dish. and it wasn't even that spicy!  say what? I hate when food that is supposed to be spicy isn't. The only memorable dish was the chicken satay appetizer. And at least the veggies/meat seemed fresh. I felt like crap the next morning, like a Thai food hangover or something, and I have bowels of steel.

Oh, yeah, and while we were there, a homeless guy came in and stole someone's purse. It was crazy busy, and no one noticed it, which was too bad. (This comment has no bearing on my rating!)

The only time I see myself coming back here is if I get too drunk at City Beer Store across the way and need food immediately.
author: Nima K.

description:
I came here for dinner about a month ago and truly enjoyed my dining experience....

Pros: Nice ambience - easy to carry on a conversation, has a clean feel, wholesome, good cuisine...

Cons: Nothing huge, waitstaff will make you wait until all parties in your reservation are there - so make sure you all get there around the same time!

Recommended Entrees: Try one of their soups - I had one called Tom Yum something (exact name?)....has a coconut curry feel and is easy to share between friends with some rice inside...also the Lamb Satay - small portion but  something slighly different to try w/ that sauce!
author: Kimberly K.

description:
With the numerous Thai restaurants in San Francisco, I'd say that I'm pretty picky with my Thai food. But Basil was really yummy. I worked a block away from the place so I've been there several times for lunch and dinner. They have an extensive menu with noodles, rice, soup, salad, entrees, etc. It's nice to have selection. 

I recently had their green curry with seafood and I must say it was delicious. The right amount of curry with the right amount of spice. I brought a few out-of-towners friends here before and they love the place as well. I had to deduct a star though for so-so service. The waiter was nice but not very friendly. It seems like he just wants to take our orders and walk away. But overall, great food. Will continue to eat there.
author: My V.

description:
Ever since my fav Thai restaurant in the neighborhood closed, I've been in search of a replacement. It's been a couple of years now and since I haven't been able to find one in my area that I can call my favorite, I venture out to Soma for Thai food that won't disappoint.

I love the grill and curry dishes, and the noodles and soups are yummy too. Whether I'm dining with a group or solo, i order 'em all. Yes, ALL!
author: Deanna T.

description:
My "measuring stick" for Thai restaurants is whether they can whip up a mean Tom Ka Gai or not.  It was excellent.  Not too heavy on the coconut milk, heavy on the lemongrass and chicken...I will order it with some extra heat next time as I likes it spicy yo!

And the extra special bonus was the super yummy waiter. If I was single, I would have ordered him for dessert....whoa, did I just type that out loud? I had to leave him a little love letter on the table....yup, it was like THAT...*swoon*
author: Guinnivere B.

description:
Love the Tie Peanut Sauce here. "gai satay"
The Calamari Salad "yum plamuk" So refreashing. 

Ohh Sooooo Good. 
The Atmosphere is Lovely. 
The Staff are really Nice.
author: michelle h.

description: Overpriced for the quality.  What a mediocre meal.  I've been here twice, first I had a noodle dish which was "meh" acceptable, but the other night was so unimpressive.  First, I'm a sucker for signature cocktails, but my basil-tequila drink had none of the flair and alchemy that I expect from a menu-ed drink nowadays.  Our appetizer was curried duck pastry puffs that had little to no flavor besides fried dough.  The curry and duck didn't seem to contribute to the flavor palette.  Finally, I wasted my steak points (I don't order steak that often, so when I do I need it to satisfy!) on a bland and mushy rather than tender sirloin.  Another bland course, though the smoked mushroom side had a delightful kick.  Still the best tasting part of the plate was the cucumber.  I'll stick to my atmosphereless holes in the wall in the 'Loin.
author: Ian S.

description:
I can't believe this place is just down the street from my house!

The food is delicious, and the service was great.    

I tried the house specialties:  the Basil Salad and the Basil Eggplant over rice.   I really liked how the eggplant was prepared and it was delicious.  the sauce was lighter and not as thick, so the taste of the eggplant really cam out.  The salad was not so big a deal.    The Julienne chicken with cashew nuts was also very tasty, and full of flavor!

The tiger shrimp and the Coconut soup were also fantastic!   

Th atmosphere is nice and the food is medium price.  our bill came to $56 ($70 with tip) for 5 dishes, but no drinks. 

I highly recommend this place and will be going back often no that I know how good it is, and the fact that It's just around the corner... but what isn't in this city?
author: Vlad C.

description:
I can't believe this place has been here for 13 years and I never set foot... what a shame!!  Our 1st visit was Sat, May 16, and boy, we are so satisfied with tasty food. We ordered eggplant with tofu and basil - excellent, marinated skirt steak in peanut sauce - very good, seafood curry - yummy, sticky rice with mango for dessert really good!

We were also surprise that they have good cocktails.

We are definitely going back.
author: Carrie F.

description: The vibe and the decor is good.  Cool lighting and atmosphere.  But then we had the food.  Sadness. The chicken was from Costco, which is a bad thing, and the Pad Thai was mostly ketchup and the curry was just OK.  Too bad I wanted to like this place but I give it two blahs.
author: Quinn D.

description: The Best Thai food I've ever had! beef peanut sauce mmmmm. Green Curry Indian breads are my fave.
author: sandy c.

description:
For as many times I've been here, I can't believe I haven't written a review before now!

Basil Thai is the de facto choice for dinner prior to going to the Kat Club for 80's dancing. There's probably other places in the neighborhood worth trying, but Basil Thai is so good, we haven't bothered.

I really love their crispy shrimp appetizers, the wine selection isn't half bad, and the prices are very reasonable, The ambiance is just about perfect for every occasion -- romantic, fun, casual, whatever.
author: Amanda S.

description:
SOMA has some great restaurants -  you just need to know where to look.  Had lunch at Basi.  Started with the hot and spicy soup...it was sooo good.  Large portion (only $4).  The consistency was perfect and the flavors blended well.  Lots of large mushrooms in there too.  

Fried Calamari:  It was one of the best I have had in a long time.  The batter was crisp with a touch of spice accompanied with a sweet and tangy sauce.  

Our lunch entree was the pork and pineapple and pad thai.  Both dishes were large enough to share.  The pork was tender...the pad thai was good but not great (I prefer more flavor).

Ambiance:  Natural lighting throughout.  Lots of space - they are not paying the high downtown rents.  Service was fast courteous.  I would go back and check out dinner sometime!
author: Laurie R.

description:
We hit Basil before a party on Folsom, and I wish I'd just stuck around to eat all night. The decor is chic, the staff was good, and the food was delicious. There were a lot of menu items that I don't often see at the standard thai restaurants I frequent, so it was nice to try some new things. Also, everything was very reasonable priced for the quality of the food.

+pork and shrimp dumplings were fried to a chewy crisp with a yummy dipping sauce
+cucumber salad was crisp and delicious
+grilled strak with coconut and peanut curry sauce was fanfreakingtastic
+sauteed chicked with bell peppers was also really tasty, but not as interesting as the steak
+perfect brown rice
-my manhattan was mediocre
-ladies bathroom door lock was broken
author: Jessica H.

description:
Thanks for a great birthday dinner!

The table was waiting when we got there, reserved and such. The waiter was attentive but not overwhelming. The appetizers were delicate and delicious. The drinks were sweet, and very girly. For eight girls ready for the town, they were great starters. I had the stuffed eggplant in green curry and loved every bite. The portions are enough for two! And we finished off with fried banana and ice cream. yummy! Everytime I drive by Thai Basil I'm so tempted to pull over.
author: Sara D.

description:
I'm generous with my stars.  If I find the whole dinner experience satisfying, what more could I ask for?

I ordered Chicken and Basil with Chili I think.  That and the Jasmine rice were a great combo.  I really liked how it tasted.  

The Skewered Calamari and Prawns were pretty good too.

The price is right at approximately $25 bucks per person and the atmosphere was cozy.

I'd recommend this place to everyone.
author: John M.

description:
Good menu choices, slimmed down and modern both in terms of the setting and the food.

But, been inconsistent, had several not so good meals, and numerous great meals.

So great place, if you hit a good day.
author: Ken p.

description:
Basil Thai knew what made Thai food soo good. Granted it wasn't amazing, but it hit all the familiar notes that I would expect in my thai dishes. The atmosphere was modern and hip and the service was decent but not the friendliest. If I'm in the SOMA this will be my Thai place, but I think there is potential for better out there...

PS: some of our dishes were tiny, like a shrinking ray gun was applied to it before serving...eeek!
author: Venatius P.

description:
Just what we were looking for!  We had a couple of friends in town and wanted to find a nicer Thai place with good food.  It wasn't as loud as I expected (which is a plus), but it was a later dinner on Sunday.  The appetizers were the best part of the meal.  Loved all five of them (calamari, curry puffs, the roti, lamb skewers, vegetable rolls)...love love love.  The yellow curry chicken was also a hit, but the noodle dishes were only mediocre.  Service was helpful and the decor was easy on the eyes.  Perfect place to have a nice sit-down dinner with friends!

Prices were within reason for the type of restaurant that it is.  We will definitely keep this place on our short list for good Thai places and I'm pretty sure our friends will want to come back if they are ever in town again.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Basil : THE BEST THAI IN SF

The Pad Ke Mao has the perfect blend of spicy and sweet, the curries use just the right amount of coconut infused sauce and the service is great, especially Ninja (called Ninja by the rest of the staff for his stealth-like water and busboy service)

Also being a veggie, it is important to note that most of the non-vegetarian cuisine can be made with tofu. 

The coconut, lemongrass soup is so amazing I can never say no, just as Chad can NEVER say no to the Pad Ke Mao. Also the basil Bloody Mary is not bad...not bad at all.
author: Alex M.

description:
Basil Thai WAS an instant favorite for my husband and I from the very first day we dined there. We loved their Chicken Pumpkin Curry, Thai Iced Tea, with great entree proportions at great prices. The service was friendly and quick. 

Unfortunately that experience was so 2010! From our most recent visit in March 2011, we were met with a new menu, higher prices and no Chicken Pumpkin Curry on the menu (which may have biased our review a bit). We tried a different dish (gai kra-prow) - which was tasteless and we left most of it behind. The Thai fried rice was completely flavorless and expensive ($7.95!) for a side. Basil Thai used to be a 4 star restaurant, but in 2011 its a 2 star - maybe a 2.5 star at best.

While the service was adequate the servers were not particularly friendly and the food was a big disappointment. So was the bill. 

After praising Basil Thai for the past year, we're done and don't plan on returning. With the new menu and higher prices - there are plenty better Thai restaurants in the city.
author: Erika K.

description: Terrible service! We had a party of 15 and they wouldn't break up checks and made us spend $15 per person and added tip! Ugg- I know it states these rules on their menu, but we did not appreciate being told how to order. Food was eh.
author: Julie H.

description:
My favorite Thai Restaraunt!
I eat here often, and have yet to be disappointed. The Pad See Ew and Param Rong Song (spelling?) are deeeelicious. The atmosphere is nice, servers are cool but if it's crowded don't expect a lot of attention. Food is inexpensive, light, and won't leave you too full to function. And unless it's a Friday or Saturday night, the wait isn't long.
author: Tiye W.

description:
Yelp! You have yet to let me down!

I went here last night (Thursday) and it was busy but there were still tables open. We were immediately seated by the incredibly gracious staff.

It was my guest's first time with Thai food so we kept it simple:
-Chicken and Lamb Satay
-Tom Yum Gai Soup
-Pad Thai w/ a side of peanut sauce
-Fried Banana w/ Coconut ice cream and Mango w/ sticky rice for dessert.

All of it was amazing. The only difference between Basil Thai and Thailand Thail was the price!

Great ambiance, helpful attentive staff, and fantastic food!"
author: D R.

description: We tried just because we walked by.  But it is surprisingly good!!  Especially the one dish with Japanese eggplant and shiitake mushroom with basil-chili sauce is my favorite.  I think the food here is WAY better than Koh Samui and Monkeys or Osha.
author: Sachiko M.

description:
Overall, a very good experience. My fiance was very surprised when we walked past. I don't think we've been to a thai joint that looks this nice. Awesome ambiance. He really thought it was some fancy schmancy diner, but I assured him it won't burn a hole in his wallet. Everything on the menu is very affordable. I would rather pay an extra dollar or two to enjoy my meal here than to sit at a hole in the wall staring at plastic floral decor. He ordered the pad ke mao and I ordered kao pad supparot. The pad ke mao was just right. Just enough seasoning and not at all greasy like most noodles. The fried rice, on the other hand, was lacking flavor. It seemed like the chef decided to nix the salt from this dish. I had about 3 spoonfuls of rice, then maneuvered over to my fiance's plate and finished most of his dish for him. I decided it would be a good idea to box the fried rice, take it home, add a bit of salt and have it for leftovers. 

The service was great. Everyone was very friendly and I did not feel rushed throughout my meal. This was at dinner time by the way, and a rush of customers were coming in right after we were seated. 

I will come back here to try the green curry that everyone is raving about :-)
author: Ashley B.

description: My duck was flavorful, juicy, and delicious, and the portions are well-sized for the price/
author: Paul K.

description: Showed up sans-reservation with a group of 5 and the staff were able to accomodate us despite being nearly full. We had a selection of appetizers and shared 5 entrees, plus several drinks and our bill was $128 + gratuity. The spicy tiger prawns were extra awesome.
author: Matt K.

description:
I dined here last night and I thought it was decent.  I'm thinking that maybe what we ordered may not have been the best items on the menu.

The shrimp crackers that they served us were a little stale.
We started off with the chicken satay - which was pretty good. I liked the peanut sauce and the pickled cucumbers.

We then had the pad thai, the duck curry and tum yum gai.  The tom yum was not that great - it was the clear broth type and the chicken was overcooked.  The duck curry was the best out of the three. I've had pad thai that was better in various thai restaurants.

The ambiance and service were great and they only charged $12 corkage.

Overall, I think this was a decent place, but nothing extraordinary.
author: Eleanor C.

description:
Had been meaning to check out this SOMA spot as it looks inviting from the street...After a quick check from Yelp, it looked positive.

Word to the wise, the yelpers are correct, if you prefer it even moderately spicy you'd be wise to ask for it to be spicy as they seem to go gringo on the spice level.

Seem open to accomodating large groups as there was a monster sized group (At least 16 people) when we ate there so something to file away as a place to go with large groups.

Menu is tough to navigate as there are a lot of tasty sounding choices which again makes it a sound choice to go in a group and try it family style.

Decor is sharp and clean...Service is adequate although they do seem to fall into the 'rushing' mode by taking away your plates before you might be done.

Tom Ka soup was terrific and that's one of my litmus tests for a good thai restaurant, how good are their soups.

Tried the Param Rungsong  (Skirtsteak in peanut sauce) to try something different...It was good but there were so many other choices we considered and wished we had...We'll be back.
