Portions seem very reasonable and pricing is fair...Disappointing to see yet another Thai restaurant with a built in 'tip table' on the check to 'help' you calculate tip.
author: Barca F.

description:
I used to live across from this restaurant and would go there once a week.  Very friendly staff, chill environment, and tasty Thai dishes - an all around winner. 

I've only had one take-out order mishap when they forgot to include my drinks...good thing I lived so close and was able to return to receive the forgotten ones on the house!
author: Maria L.

description: I like this place a lot.  The food is tasty and service is great.  Our company usually has company lunches here and I find myself ordering take out for lunch as well.  Only 2 1/2 blocks away from my office, perfect place for lunch.
author: James L.

description: At first I was a bit disappointed as they didn't offer my favorite Thai dish, green curry chicken.  Here the green curry is a vegetarian although the very helpful waiter said they would make it with chicken for me.  Bonus points already!  However, he did highly recommend the red curry with chicken and pumpkin and since it's that time of year, I ordered that.  What a winner!  Great service and delicious food.
author: Kara H.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant next to where I live, very nice decor (maybe to cater to the yuppy crowd)

Pretty decent, most everything I tried
- curry duck, amazing, kinda like Chinese roast duck (with skin) in thick curry
- som tam: papaya salad
- larb gai: minced chicken salad
- nuer namtok: grilled sliced steak tossed with parched rice + fresh herbs in lime lemongrass dressing
- basil's eggplant
- chicken curry: classic recipe with whole pieces (with bones), potatoes

Okay
- chicken satay, if you must
- sticky rice

So so
- panang short ribs: meat texture kinda gets tuck in your teeth
- chicken curry, white meat make em a bit dry

No go
- calamari, it has bamboo but even without em would suck


Thai ice tea of course caps of the meal right
author: xo x.

description:
Here's to the Ladies Who Lunch!

This is the place where I take every person I know for lunch.  Whether it is a get to know you meeting or a bunch of friends drinking Mohito's in the middle of the afternoon, Basil has excellent service, wonderful food and it makes you feel like you have a lot of money when you actually don't.

I'm so much of a regular, the moment I walk in they have the Mohito and fresh springs rolls with that peanut sauce ready to go.
author: Shaun L.

description:
This place is an affordably decent Thai restaurant. I am a fan of eggplant and they do a decent dish.

It's kind of small and could afford to do a better interior decorating job, but maybe I just complain too much.

I think it's a good place for a casual dinner and a drink or two, given that it's reasonably priced and pretty tasty. The only thing I'd say is that given the massive quantity of good thai restaurants in the city, there are a handful I'd pick over this one.
author: ting b.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed my keow wan nuer and was tempted to lick all the curry off the plate, but I stopped short because I realized ... I am an adult, eating in a public restaurant!

My dining companion's hoi ka-ta was very good and came with a healthy number of scallops.

My dessert, the Thai coffee granita, was underwhelming.  I should have ordered the fried bananas with ice cream.  Actually, I should have considered that it's swimsuit season (everywhere outside of SF) and skipped dessert altogether.
author: Marcus C.

description:
I have been to Basil about 10 times now.
I will keep going and going and going.
They have a diverse and eclectic menu, which I can't seem to get tired of yet.
My favorite dish so far is the seafood and okra in green curry.
The staff is always friendly, the food comes at you fast, and the prices are very, very reasonable.
Like, go now.
author: Walter G.

description:
*Yawn*, aaaanother Thai restaurant in SF.   We needed that like we need, uh, all those ugly-ass high-rises popping up all over SOMA like priapic steel-and-concrete stalactites.  

To its credit, this place does serve food which is not half-bad.  The "Beans + Roots" appetizer, with its crispy tofu and toro pieces was toothsome, if a bit bland.  The "Crunchy Bean Cakes" entree was the star performer of the night, with a pungent, spicy sauce and good consistency.  

However, It's tough for me to get excited about my 8402nd Thai dinner in SF unless the food's amazing or a bargain, especially since I cook insane Thai food regularly (and dirt-cheaply).  (see my food blog www.feedingfashionistas.com  for some good Thai cooking tips)

The problems with the place were thus:

- Every item was at least $2-3 more than it would be at another restaurant of similar quality.

- There were no condiments on the table, and the sauces delivered with some appetizers were extremely tame peanut + sweet chili sauce affairs*.  

- Portions were a bit out of whack- the appetizers were quite generous (good!), but the entrees were small to the point of being tough to share (bad).

Overall, the service was good, the atmosphere cheerful and clean- not much to hate, really- and when I asked for my veggie red curry "pretty damn spicy", they gave it to me that way, which is very rare!  

Why am I 3-starring a place with mostly-decent food and good service?  Mainly pricing and the ubiquity of equivalent restaurants.  Also, I have to ding the place for naming itself after a freaking ingredient.  If I see one more goddamn place called something like "Lemongrass", "Ponzu" or "Yak Snout", I am going to SCREAM!  

My future restaurant will probably be called something like "BLORNK" or "Hi-Colonik", in protest.

Feel free to visit Basil if you need servicable Thai food and are willing to pay a premium for an airy, tastefully appointed atmosphere.  Just don't expect any culinary miracles.

---

* If I owned a Thai restaurant, every table would have a condiment tray with fish sauce, rice vinegar, Sambal Oolek and a pepper grinder, at least.  Give the foodies in your audience a little control- c'mon.
author: George C.

description:
Great Thai! 
i ventured away from my usual white boy Pad Thai order and got a beef dish and it was awesome! 

also a good date place.
author: Nate C.

description:
A bit pricier than some of the excellent Thai restaurants in the Tenderloin. But that's the price of SOMA hipness.

The food is reliably excellent. Pad Thai, steamed fish, gai yang and tofu tod (not on the menu, but they prepared it for me last night, nonetheless) are some of my favorites.
author: Dan F.

description:
Seriously, one of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco. I used to live around the corner and I would call to order takeout at least once a week on my walk home from the Caltrain station.

I love taking my friends here because the inside is very classy and has a lounge feel that makes it seem a lot nicer than the average hole-in-the-wall Thai place, but food-wise, it has just as much flavor and tastiness as less-swankily-dressed Thai places.

Must try:

- The fresh spring rolls, served with a tangy peanut sauce
- The crispy spring rolls are also delicious
- The param rongsong, which is a wonderful marinated strip steak topped with cocount peanut sauce
- Excellent pad thai (and I'm really picky about pad thai!)
- The fire calamari -- a fresh calamari wok-sauteed with bamboo and lemongrass and chili sauce. Made me remember how tasty calamari can be even when it *isn't* deep-fried.
- The bar makes a mean mojito, which would cause me to sometimes avoid calling in advance so that I could enjoy one while waiting for my takeout

The people there are also ultra-nice. They remember who their frequent customers are and are always extra friendly. I haven't once had a bad experience, and the service is quick!

Oh, and on a side note, Lisa W, seriously -- don't pick on Basil Thai just because you didn't realize that having spicy food immediately followed by swing dancing is a horrible idea. Next time, enjoy one of Basil's very delicious milder dishes, like the yellow curry. :)
author: Steven P.

description:
I've eaten here MANY times over the last few years, and have it say it's a very decent place. The food is not AMAZING, but very good for the price.  

Their selection tries to be a "fancy thai", so things are a bit different if you are used to traditional thai food.  For example, yellow chicken curry comes with a whole piece of chicken, instead of slices in the curry.  Still very tasty.

Great place for lunch, private or business, probably nice as well for dinner.
author: Konstantin G.

description: I like this restaurant, not just for its delicious food. The whole environment is excellent and  very romantic in the night. The service is also very good. I have recommended many of my friends to go this place for party, and I am sure I will go there again. I like every food in the menu.
author: Yingjie S.

description: Had lunch there today, we ordered green chicken curry, pad thai and Chinese broccoli with crispy pork belly. Gotta say that the food was pretty good, tasted clean, and was not at all greasy or heavy. The pork belly in particular was excellent. I was worried the portions would be small, but it was just right for three people. I even liked the rattan chairs for the tables, they were comfortable and look great against the dark wood flooring.
author: Victoria M.

description: Alright where should I start? Well we came on a monday night and it was packed mostly by yelp elites form the bar next door. They took about 15 minutes to even take our order and I was starving. We got 2 flat noodle dishes, the fried turnip cake (This is not a noodle or a rice, why is it under that category?), roast duck curry, and garlic noodles. The turnip and roast duck was really good. Garlic noodles not enough garlic, and then the flat noodles, umm it was not flat noodles. We were in starvation mode and started eating after waiting another 30minutes for food to come out. Then I realized hey that's not flat noodles! We asked the waiter he said oh they ran out so you get that. Umm...if they ran out they should tell their customers and give them the option to change the order, correct?..Then to add insult to injury he said I can get you something else so we decided to get another turnip cake. Maybe we misheard but we heard him say sorry I'll take off the 2 flat noodles and charge for the turnip so he took the flat noodles away. We get the bill, they charged us for the 2 flat noodles!! Then he argues with us saying he can't remove it so we have to pay for it and he won't charge us for the turnip cake. Umm if that's the case why did you take away the food we will have to pay for? Makes NO sense! Then miracle he is able to remove the 2 incorrect orders and charged us for the turnip cake replacement order. I've never had such poor service in a long time! Why are you arguing with customers when you are wrong! Bad Bad. I will not be back even with pretty descent food, sad.
author: Karen T.

description: My cousin and friend decided to go drinking beforehand and were really hungry when we arrived at Basil. Seeing how it was a Saturday night, the place was really busy. We were lucky to get a table so quickly (without a reservation). The food we ordered was delicious and hit the right spot. It's not too expensive, and is definitely a place I would go again!
author: Vrinda S.

description: This is the best Thai I have had, even having visited Thailand at least 10 times.  The curries are wonderful.  I went back to eat there for lunch my last day in SF, despite being totally full from an earlier lunch.  I wish it was in Chicago!  I miss you Basil Thai.  I should say the service was not so impressive - kinda felt like there were slightly bothered, but who cares, as long as the food was great.
author: Rich C.

description: Cool place, love the ambiance. They also play pretty hip music! I like this place because service is good, it's not too crowded, and food taste great while being decently priced. My favorite dishes which I recommend if you come here, are the seafood green curry and the Pad ke mao. A word of warning, the Pad ke mao packs a kick. Thai spicy is pretty spicy. You could see all the chili seeds blended in this dish of wide noodles and beef. But if you can stand the heat, it's quite delish. The soups, tom yum gai and tom ka gai were good introductions to our meal. Some of the other dishes I tried were a bit salty such as the curry peppercorn duck and the pork belly. Need a little bubbly? Try their sparkling sake, it's like sipping on champagne!
author: Karen L.

description:
Joined a large (14) group of friends at Basil Thai last week for dinner. The food was fantastic, the server did a great job keeping up with all of us, including splitting the bill 3 ways; and the kitchen kept the food coming.

Thanks for such a pleasant evening.
author: Anthony B.

description:
So far, my favorite Thai place in SF and I really love it for those middle of the week, just grab a meal out, nights. 

Love the atmosphere. The food is great. Prices are about right. Portions are BIG (who doesn't love leftover Thai?).
author: S A.

description: The food was very tasty - the service was slow and being sick for three days after, then going to urgent care because of food poisoning not so good.
author: Richard S.

description:
More of a 4+ but not quite a 5.  Service is efficient.

Food is better than your average thai place with quite a few inventive entrees.  We would recommend the scallop and tempura green bean stir fry from the wok and the stuffed eggplant.  The pad thai is just ok - and the shrimp too chewy.  Their sticky rice is super hard so avoid it.
author: Stacy N.

description: I got the short rib panang curry and it was sensational! I've had the pad thai and papaya salad and it was okay. Somewhat great service.
author: Christina V.

description: Nice space, great food, delicious cocktails. One of the better Thai restaurants in the city, in other words, "An Asian Persuasion."
author: Alex H.

description:
There is actually parking you can find around here!!! Very rare in SF but we found parking right away and close by to the restaurant. The interior is very modern chic with large paper lantern bulbs over the bar area and soft blue lighting on the walls near the tables. Seating are booths or dark wooden tables and chairs. We were seated right away near the back of the restaurant near the bathrooms. Our waitress was very friendly! We decided to try an appetizer and ordered Porpia Sod which are rice paper spring rolls filled with vegetables, vermicelli, tofu and crushed peanuts on top. A chili and lime dipping sauce comes on the side. Very fresh and yummy! I loved them! For dinner I had the Kang Kari Gai which is yellow curry with chicken and potatos. Ok, I love curry so I have ordered it at so many places and never have I been served 2 breasts of chicken, uncut, on the plate surrounded by the curry sauce and 2 pieces of potato. I was alittle annoyed because I like my meat already cut for me. Call me a princess but I hate having to put the whole breast on my plate and start carving it off the bone. Thank gosh it was very tender so it was easy to come off the bone. But what also annoyed me was the lack of potatos. I love love love potatos. Why only give me two pieces!?!? That is a carb lover nightmare! Other than that, the meal did taste delicious and the chicken meat was vry tender. You have to order rice separate but you can choose white, sticky, jasmine, or fried rice.  I ordered a glass of wine with my meal and chose the Grans-Fassian Reisling because I love sweet wines. Highly recommend! I had two glasses because I couldn't get enough of it! Will I return again? Maybe but to try something else because I wasn't completely thrilled with the curry. 

On a side note, they need to work on getting soup containers for take out orders of curry or anything with a soupy texture. What they did with my leftovers was put it in one of those fold-up cardboard boxes. While driving home, the curry leaked right through the box and through the paper bag it was sitting in onto my lap. I was pissed because I had to sit in a car from SF to the East Bay reaking of spilt curry all over my lap. Please consider that for the future because there are alot of hills in SF for spilt curry to fall out of those boxes.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Solid food, nice atmosphere, great lunch specials.  The service is attentive without being overbearing and the place is very clean.

But I only go here when it's light out because SOMA frightens me.
author: Tony A.

description:
I went here at about 9pm, luckily before they had closed the kitchen.  The waiter was very nice.  They don't have air conditioning, and it was a warm day, so inside was piping hot.  I had a hot date, so I can't complain.

The food was delicious!  If this was on my street I would go here a lot.  Four stars because of the heat and comfort.  I'll have to go back and raise my starts someday.
author: Ben H.

description:
This is an excellent, low-key Thai food place.  It's the type of place that you take your parents to when they come into town from, say, the south or midwest, and are terrified of the idea of having "foreign" food.

It's got a nice, clean atmosphere, the food is good.
author: Jorm ..

description:
Great food! This is one of my favorite Thai places in the city! 
Parking can sometimes be a challenge.
author: Miyoko N.

description:
if you're looking for a decent and fine-dining Thai experience.  Here is the place you should go.  I've tried Lamb Satay, Shrimp Rice Paper Roll, Fried Wide Noodle with Egg, Curry Roasted Duck, all were above standard:
- the satay sauce is 5 stars
- the Shrimp rice paper is 5 stars
- the roasted duck itself is 5 stars
- the 3 stars goes to decor
- I deduct 1 star because the waitress was snobbish 

Overall, I had an fantastic experience from the food.
author: terrific h.

description:
Just had dinner there this evening after hearing so many good things abut this place.  I definitely left disappointed.

We ordered three dishes with each dish having varying flavor success.
1, Had the fried vegetable egg roll appetizer - very greasy D-

2. Stuffed eggplant - Interesting dish, not what I expected but was good.  The green curry accompanying the dish was quite falvorful.   B

3. Nuer Ta Cai (angus sirloin cubes stir-fried with lemongrass) - The sauce was very good but strangely the beef itself lacked flavor.  It seemed the meat was not marinated.  Very disappointed...could have been so much better C

I think I'll just go back to my favorite Thai restaurant - Manora's which is just down the street from Basil Thai restaurant.    I have never left Manora's disappointed.
author: Rene M.

description:
This is most likely the best Thai place in the city.  And why?  The food is excellent, AND the prices are reasonable.  I've been to plenty of Thai places, and I just don't see how some of them get away with charging $12 or more for yellow curry chicken!

Basil Thai serves a wide variety of flavors and dishes, even though they don't force you to read a novel to choose your meal.  While there are some dishes I like better than others (the stuffed eggplant is to die for), I've never been unhappy with anything I've ordered.  After trying nearly everything on the menu, I think that is a pretty neat accomplishment on their part.

The drink menu is quite excellent for a Thai restaurant.  They have wines, beers, specialty cocktails, and a full bar.  Gone are the days when you have the choice between only Thai iced tea and Singha.

And for the crowning achievement, you can order sticky rice with your meal.  And it doesn't have to be a dessert with mangoes.

By the way, I don't understand people complaining about egg rolls being greasy.  Have you never seen how an egg roll is prepared?
author: Jeremy T.

description:
There are no lack of Thai restaurants in San Francisco but this is one worth repeated visits.

I like this place for several reasons. Even before I enter the door, parking is typically a breeze in this part of town and I'm usually meeting other carloads of people here, so none of us have to spend 30 minutes looking for parking. I've always been able to easily get tables for 6 at this place AND WERE NOT CRAMPED like most other thai places. 

This place has killer curries and you will find yourself looking for more rice to soak up the last drops of curry sauce as the waiter trys to take the plates from the table - if you're not a Thai curry fan you will be when you walk out of this place.

For starters I like the fresh and crispy rolls as well as the green curry with eggplant and Indian bread (probably because I can soak up the curry with the bread).  Most all the skewers are good and the chicken usually goes fast. 

On main plates you can be safe and go with the Pad Thai or other noodle dishes that you're used to ordering at the run-of-the mill Thai restaurants. But at Basil Thai you should try out a curry dish.  The curry peppercorn duck is excellent and one of my favorites. And the fire calamari is one tasty dish!

Table service at Basil Thai is also darn good and the food usually comes out in a flash. The waitstaff is attentive but not in an annoying way like filling your water glass after every two sips.

My only ding is at the bar.....Basil Thai, if you're reading this, please get some red bull on order - I like to have a vodka/red bull before dinner.
author: Doug C.

description: One of two excellent Thai places in SOMA.  The food is a little more Americanized than its rival but good in its own right.  Beer here is a bit on the expensive side, but they serve Khao Soy (spelled Kao Soi on their menu) which is redeeming.  It also helps to speak a little Thai as they won't take you seriously about spicy unless you can communicate it to them in a way they'll know you're serious.
author: Scott S.

description: AHHHHh Basil Thai. Got the angus beef cubes in green curry. The curry was good, but the beef was pretty darn disgusting.  They were tough and really iron tasting.  The meat seemed either really old or boiled.  They should really call it "left over beef trimming" instead of "angus beef cubes".  The fish cakes were decent. But the beef was really below par.
author: Skye W.

description: Very good flavor.  It did not earn more stars because I don't think any Asian restaurant should charge for rice.  We were also automatically charged an 18% tip for a party of 8 that included 4 youths.
author: Michael C.

description: Came here on whim. Got there at about 6:30 PM on a Thursday Night. Restaurant is rather nice size and well decorated. It looked somewhat empty when we arrived. There were diners at the back, which was fairly filled up. Restaurant was full when we left. I guess they prefer to seat and start serving from the back to forward. Full bar which was nice. Menu is extensive with many plates to choose from.. We ended up ordering drinks and appetizers. Drinks were about average in price. Appetizers were delicious and filling. Price on the upper end. We had the Pan Fried Dumplings and the Chicken Satay Skewers. For the main course. Green Curry, Minced chicken stir-fried with eggplant, bell peppers, basil, and Thai bird's eye chili, Spicy wide rice noodles, skirt steak, onions, carrots, & egg stir-fried with basil, garlic & chili and sides of Brown and White Rice. All were excellent. **Caution** The Spicy Wide Noodle was SPICY for my taste but, my wife a daughter loved it. Overall, good experience. If I'm in the area, I might drop by again. The only thing holding me back, would be the price. "King of Thai" makes the same entree's, just as good and at a cheaper price. Your pretty much paying for ambiance and full bar.
author: J G.

description: Oh super tasty, but a bit on the sweet side.  The appetizers themselves can make a full meal.  Make sure to ask for a bowl of peanut sauce with your complementary shrimp chips, yum!
author: Mason G.

description: I have eaten a lot of Thai food...this was the best!
author: Shera K.

description: My boyfriend took me here for dinner for a few times.  A very cute Thai place, very nice ambience, not too pricey. Although not the most authentic Thai food around, the food is very tasty. Portions are not big, but the service is attentive.
author: Ling Ling Z.

description: I know the reviews here average to four stars, but unfortunately I wasn't that impressed. The location and decor are nice as well as the service. But my gai prik khing wasn't great. It had too much of a fishy sauce to the chicken and the chicken was sorta deep-fried! I also felt that there weren't enough string beans in the ratio. We also sat at the two seater table up front by the window and while it is great for the window, you sort of get neglected. My fiance said that when he went once during lunch, the food was a lot better. Either it was an off night, or we just ordered the wrong dishes.
author: Natalie S.

description: This place is amazing. I love the setup, I LOVE the food and I love the attentive waiter who filled my water glass at least 7 times.  We ordered some gyoza to start with, the dipping sauce was so delicious I wanted to drink it. Seriously that good.  I ordered the stuffed eggplant with green curry, it was one of those experiences where you cant believe how good the food is while your eating it. I was seriously in awe of the green curry here.  I cant remember what my boyfriend ordered but it too was amazing.  Nice place for a date too :)
author: Ciara D.

description: Sorry Pu.  Wait, I'm not sorry at all!  You were supposed to be a nice server and that's why we ask for you specifically!  The food is great, especially the duck curry, but man!  Who would hold to-go food ransom for their tip at the end?  We are an honest group and we totally included a CASH tip in the bill.  From now on, however, I don't think our group will EVER dine at Basils.  We're more embarrassed that our own favorite server accused us at the end of our experience for NOT giving a tip that we honestly did -- pretty well too as always.  Maybe next time, don't trust other bussers to take the bill.  5 stars for the food.
author: Michael B.

description:
Can I just say, "Thank GAWD for Basil Thai!"

...Okay, back on track here. We've been living in Oregon and Washington for a long time -- most recently in the Seattle area (Bainbridge Island, to be exact), so we'd gotten spoiled with the quality of Thai food. Then... Texas struck. Nearly two years in the Austin area numbed our tastebuds with fried everything and Tex Mex, and offered a very limited selection of Thai restaurants... and most were average at best.

So moving to the Bay Area gave us some hope that we'd once again find quality Thai food. I found Basil Thai through some friends, and made a reservation for my wife's birthday -- we were seeing a show at the Orpheum later that evening, so its location was really convenient. We showed up a few minutes early, and our table was ready for us. Not too busy, but by the time we left (around 7:30 or so), the place was hopping.

Our usual measuring stick for Thai restaurants is their Tom Ka Gai soup. Yes, the stuff that smells like an old sweatsock but tastes amazing, and Basil's was fantastic. Spicy, rich, and when ladled over a bowl of rice, easily enough to be a meal in itself. The porpia sod appetizers were fresh and tasty, and the entrees were quick to the table, incredibly good, and more than we could eat by this point.

We hope we can find a good Thai restaurant closer to San Jose for regular dining, but we know Basil Thai is on our list for every trip to the city.
author: Scott G.

description:
We walked in with 14 people on a Saturday, and they did their best to treat us right.  
The service was great, and the food was even better.  The chicken and eggplant dish is my favorite. Prices aren't too high, and the quality it outstanding.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Best Thai food I have had in a city that has way too many Pad Thai's to choose from!  

Really fresh tasting and several unique dishes.  I liked the skewers and the beef.  Interesting crispy basil.  

Probably twice as expensive as a "neighborhood" place once we had a cocktail and appetizer but worth it in my opinion.
author: John A.

description:
I just tried this place for lunch for the first time and it is fantastic!  fast and friendly service and reasonably priced entrees.  I had the Kang Kari Gai (sp?) (yellow curry with chicken and potatoes) and it was delicious!  They also included a tip guide on the bill which is very helpful to those who aren't math savvy tip figure outers like me.  :)

Would definitely go back to this place.  Yum!
author: Knitgirl P.

description:
I love Basil Thai!

The food is fresh and yummy and the service good.

The food here has never disappointed and you can almost always get a table.  The nice thing is once you 've eaten here you can venture out to other hip spots in SOMA.

Ambiance is basic Thai.  Service is good.  Parking can be OK, depends on time of day/night.  Decent bar scene.  The reliability and consistency of the quality of the food is why I go back.
author: DJ N.

description: It was 4 stars in my mind... Oh man, two group birthday party happened here when we visited. One of them was sitting right next to me, and another one was behind me. The one behind left pretty quick. But the another group stayed before we arrived and still there by the time we were leaving. They were hell loud! I assume those girls are Latino chicks. It also loud enough to make me drop off the dishes, couple times. Or maybe just me, being clumsy. lol Anyway, ordered crab fried rice whih is just ok, and some duck red curry which is one of the best I ever tried. So food is good here and serves are fast and friendly as well.
author: Flora F.

description:
After a year-long suburban sabbatical, I moved back to the city and ventured out in my new hood for a dish and a drink. I stumbled across Basil Thai and plopped down at the bar. The atmosphere was comfortably subdued and the din pleasant. I grabbed the last seat at the bar, but it soon thinned out with just a few of us loners left at the bar. The smells from the kitchen were mouthwatering to say the least. I ordered the curry puffs (lamb/sweet potatoes) for an appetizer and they were scrumptious. For dinner I had the Lamb Curry with brown rice and it was amazing! I was stuffed but had to order the mango and sticky rice for dessert, which is hard to screw up. Even though I showed up alone, I had a great time talking with the people sitting at the bar next to me; on the left, a local with an iPhone who was watching skate videos that kept me entertained. On the right, a doctor of infectious diseases with whom I had a lively discussion about the Swine Flu (as well as the latest hip-hop album from N.A.S.A.).

The food was so good here and the vibe even better; laid back and sophisticated without any pretense. I'm definitely going back!
author: Scot H.

description: best thai ever. scallops is currently my favorite dish.
author: Sahil L.

description: Fantastic food, nice atmosphere, not expensive, friendly service... what more do you need?  I went with a big group of people and we ordered a bunch of stuff, I dont even remember it all but every single thing we had was amazing.
author: Beatriz A.

description: Great vegetarian Pad thai! For 10 Bucks they give you enough noodles for two people! The staff is great, the kitchen is open relatively late and its speedy for take out. Yummy & fresh, its a lovely little thai restaurant, sure to please!
author: Chelsea H.

description: This was some of the best curry I have ever eaten. This is the first Thai restaurant that I have been to where mild meant mild, some may say that that is a bad thing but I hate fighting to burn in order to taste the good flavors. I plan on going to Basil Thai again.
author: Joe T.

description:
I broke a moratorium on eating out to go to this place, and I now deeply regret it.

We were the only under-30 couple in the restaurant, and the staff, aside from the hostess, made it very clear to us what they thought of that.
After being greeted in a very friendly manner and seated with lots of smiles, we sat and we waited. And waited. And waited. And waited.
The restaurant was fully-staffed, and _maybe_ two-thirds full, but ten minutes, fifteen minutes, twenty minutes passed . . . and not a single server would make eye contact with either of us, as we patiently waited and sipped our water. I could see that all of the tables around us were being attended to quite actively, and slowly came to the realization that we were basically being avoided.
Finally, a waitress came up to our table and, after not even saying hello, demanded to know whether we had decided. We politely placed our orders, and then the food started showing up right away, but I noticed that the attitude didn't change. The servers would drop things onto our table or take things away without any acknowledgment, and would turn their backs to us and walk away quickly, like we were lepers or something. Meanwhile, the waiter serving the table next to us was joking with his patrons. The same waiter scowled as he returned our check to us to be signed.
Go figure, no one ever checked with us to see if we liked our food or needed anything else until it was clear we were done eating and ready for our check. Did they offer dessert? Nope. We didn't even get the upsell.
And how _was_ the food? It was white-people-friendly Thai food. Osha is more authentic than this place. That's not to say that it wasn't edible, but I could easily get better food for a better price and with FAR less attitude than Basil.
In summation, to the owners of this restaurant: sounds like you have some servers to fire or some attitudes to set straight. To potential customers (especially for the under-30 set who actually are nice customers who like being treated respectfully), go someplace else, 'cause these guys are absolute jerks.
author: Erin P.

description: Okay food but with the price they charge, the food could be better.  Mediocre at best.
author: Moko R.

description: I wanted to check this place out due to loving Thai food, being close to my house and the high reviews, however, I was slightly disappointed. We ordered sticky rice and it was the strangest rice I have ever had, I think sticky equaled that it was more similar to a glued block of rice. I tried the chicken and it was decent, I did however really like my panang short ribs, they made a pretty good curry, and the service was good.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Wow I have rarely eaten so well for such an honest price.
Ok the serving can sometimes be better and little more friendliness is always welcome, but you want good Thai... this is the place to go!!!

Nice thing, they have no problem serving big groups...
author: Tom V.

description: There are not too many good Thai restaurants in San Francisco.  But I would have to say that Basil was a wonderful experience from all perspectives. The perfectly balanced flavors of their dishes made our evening.  I could not recommend it more, particularly the appetizers , curry's and desserts all had an elegance and balance at the right price.
author: Gizella D.

description: Found this place on a whim, thanks to Yelp! It was a wonderful find. We were seated right away at 9pm on Friday. The bar and restaurant are really nice. Service is great too. But cannot forget the food. Family style is always a plus and we still left with food to go.  We ordered something from each part of the menu and found all the meals to be complimentary and oh so filling. Parking in this area is great too!
author: Tamz O.

description:
Went to dinner here last night with a friend.  Loved the ambience and the servce.  To start off we had the kao pode tod (corn & bean cake fritter) and basil's panstickers.  The panstickers were OK, but the kao pode tod was divine.  I especially loved the tamarind cucumber salad that came with it.  Delish.

For the main course, we shared the gai ping (I think, it was the bbq half chicken).  That was forgettable.  I don't recommend it, it was a little dry.  we also had the crab fried rice, which was good as well.

The highlight of my meal was the $15 tiny little bottle of Hou Hou Shu (sparkling sake).  Tiny and expensive, yet so damn good.  It was a cross between champagne and sake, but it was sweet.  I could have guzzled down that bottle in like 2.5 seconds.  But at $15 for a small bottle, I don't see myself buying it again there.

I would come back, but I would definitely try something else like the curries or noodles.  The chicken and fried rice didn't do it for me.
author: Charlene R.

description:
We enjoyed dinner here tonight, on the early side, for our first time there, on a Saturday evening. We didn't have a reservation, but were seated right away at the corner table, which felt a bit stuck in the corner at first, right up against the wall, but then it didn't matter much after a few minutes. Most of the center and window tables for two had reservation signs on them, which suprised me to see. We ordered the fried egg rolls to share, which had a decent filling, but I wouldn't say they were anything special. My hubby ordered an eggplant curry which was rolled into fancy looking sculptures, surrounded by green curry. He ate it all up in minutes! I had the vegetable green curry, with a side of jasmine rice. This was delicious curry, maybe the best green style I've ever eaten anywhere. The portion was generous too, and I took the rest home for lunch. My hubby also had brown rice, which looked & tasted quite good as well. I had a Thai iced tea, which was sweet and perfectly mixed. The service was very efficient and friendly, but low key too. His water glass was constantly filled up, since my guy drinks like a camel. Haha. 
We liked the unassuming atmosphere and agreed that dinner was a good value for superior food. We didn't have liquor, and skipped dessert, but the menu looked enticing for that too. We will definately go back to Basil Thai again, and I will recommend it to my friends.
author: Debbie T.

description:
I live around the corner from Basil and have dined here with friends a number of times within the past few months.  The food is certainly acceptable; but the service is constantly  dreadful and  the room unbearably loud,  thus the one star rating.   On our last (be assured, it is our last) The appitizers arrived before the cocktail --we had to remind the server to bring the cocktails, the waiters started gathering up the plates before they were empty, the  shared main course plates arrived without rice (again remind the server0, we had to constantly ask the server to re-fill our water glasses,  The cocktal glasses were left on the table throughout the dinner, the tab was slapped down on the table without any thank you.  

The service, which is what one would expect in a fast-food joint, along with the high price, the noisy room, makes Basil a no go.
author: Thomas W.

description: This is a really nice place to take a date to. Fairly priced especially for a restaurant in the city. Portions could be a little bit bigger in my opinion.
author: Phil L.

description: Maybe its just me, but I didn't feel like this restaurant's thai food was any better than a variety of other cheap options I've had before. You are seemingly paying for the experience and finer dining atmosphere. Probably won't be coming back.
author: Michael P.

description: I love the ambiance of this place. It feels super fancy but it's very affordable. I also love the basket of shrimp chips they serve you as a starter. Entrees are very flavorful and I've not yet had a bad experience here yet.
author: Kathleen T.

description: Basil is a good sit down dinner restaurant, great for dates. The decor is modern with an Asian swag. And the food is well priced for the amount, the amount of food per plate is a bit small, but is not expensive.
author: Pauline B.

description: Service was stellar. Space is small. Atmosphere decent. Food was okay. Full bar a plus.
author: Jordan P.

description: I've been here a bunch of times, but my favorite visit was during Folsom Street Fair a couple of years ago. Despite the craziness on the street, the restaurant was open and seated my friends and me pretty quickly. The food and service was just as excellent as it was any other time. This place isn't the closest Thai place to my house, yet I still go there because I'm so fond of it.
author: Eric M.

description:
Flying 4000KM can really tire your arms out and works up a real appetite. I decided to satiate myself with copious quantities of quality Thai cuisine. After acquainting myself with the numerous options available I settled on one of the highest-ranked near-by Thai restaurants, Basil Thai. 

The food was extraordinary. It was beyond that, it was a religious experience. The chef is without a doubt a God among men. 

So why, you might ask, did I only give 4 stars. They forgot about 2 cucumber salads and an order of sticky rice. We just can't have that. 

Given that our hotel was a cheap cab ride away, it only made sense to journey over and experience the food.
author: Tyler R.

description: We had the Pad Ke Mao and Pad See Ew everything I tried-- I've had better. The ambiance is wonderful and service is very welcoming. The wine selection is great and pairs well with the spiciness of the Thai food.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
Neat glass wall in the restaurant, the overall layout was nice.
The food is great, I especially liked the yellow curry with half a chicken.
author: MysticZ T.

description:
I live around the corner from Basil Thai so this is my go-to spot for quick yummy food for dining in or taking home.  All my peeps that visit from out of town must go here first night here.  forget the latest spot...they all want basil thai.  I love it too.  

For me service is always fabulous, but I tend to not go at prime time.  plus i'm a regular so may that helps.  Love the decor.  Just the right mix or trendy, color, nature, casual.  good job!!

My standard favorites are always thai fried rice, tamrind prawns, param runsoong, the stuffed eggplant in green curry, basil eggplant, curry puffs, pad thai, what else...can't think.  not all at once of course.  usually skip dessert.  fried banana are OK. 

overall like comfort food to me.  amazingly consistent..  ah yeah, the sate is awesome.  nice that they have a full bar.  I usually stick to nigori or a beer or just water.
author: Celia S.

description: We stopped by for a quick dinner after an event at DNA Lounge. It was my first time dinning at this venue. Their food was very flavorful. We sat upstairs and nice overlook of the entire downstairs. Overall, it's a nice venue and would come back again :)
author: Ernie P.

description: after reading the reviews I tried Basil Thai restaurants & bar. food is amazing, they have a lemon grass tea which brings me the momories of my trip to Thailand. Their chicken pad thai is so good and healthy unlike other thai restaurants that I have tried. you won't regret trying it.
author: emily a.

description: Not great, not bad. My friend and I had their pad thai and the chicken cashew with bell peppers. Call my taste mediocre, but compared to King of Thai, their chicken cashew was sub par. It wasn't hot, and I'm a huge fan of super hot (temp) dishes, and this wasn't so. Their pad thai was also mediocre, nothing to brag about. I went w/ a group of girls a few months prior to this visit, and their affiliation w/ Asia SF's menu was a lot better because we got to try a little bit of everything. It was probably also better because we all had a few drinks before dinner. Overall, it was a nice place to go for the atmosphere, but I wouldn't recommend any of the dishes I had.
author: Camille T.

description: Fast service, tasty food. Convenient location for a night out in the SOMA region. The food is very well priced but the wine list better avoided - go straight for some sake. Big portions.
author: David R.

description:
A great go to Thai place where you can guarantee a good standard of food.

Its not top notch Royal Thai (hence the 4 stars) but the food is consistent (if sweetened for American tastes, I prefer my Thai a little sour) ad they will try and fit you in even without a reservation.

If you have a group of more than 8 or so they're not so crash hot in handling that however if you don't mind food coming out as its ready you should be ok.
author: D M.

description: I can't even tell you how many time I've been to this restaurant. The food is great, not necessarily authentic Thai but delicious and inventive nonetheless. My personal favourites include the Jungle Beef, the rack of lamb in red curry, the stuffed eggplant (really really good, but enough for two meals), and the pad kee mao (again, not the most authentic relative to what you can get in Thailand but herbaceous, spicy and delicious). The service is efficient given that this place gets pretty packed even during the week. I will definitely continue to be a regular here.
author: Sheena S.

description: Decor/ambience is nice. Wait staff is nice. But take a look at the customers and you'll realize that's what people come here for. The food is good but nothing special or amazing.
author: Leily P.

description: Last night found me and the beau in SOMA in need of quick food so I picked Basil. This place served us some overpriced, perfunctory Thai food that is too obviously assembled in the back instead of cooked individually as separate dishes.  The veggies that came in the curry were crunchy and tasted raw.  What do you expect when the menu is long, extensive and trying to touch every famous Thai-American dish?  I've had better Thai in the gourmet ghetto back in my college days of Berkeley.  I will give them two stars for the decent cocktails and serving gigantic cold junmai ginjo sakes.
author: Amber L.

description: Basil Thai has a great lunch mix and match option for $11.95 that allows Thai novices to taste more of the menu.  The restaurant has a modern hipster flair to it and can get very crowded for lunch.  They offer quite a few dishes that you won't find at most Thai restaurants, so try dishes that aren't Pad Thai or Rad Na!
author: Jason A.

description:
I like the vast menu that allows you to choose from standard noodle and rice staples ($8-$10) to fancier 'From the Wok' dishes ($10-$22) and curries.  Everything on the Wok section sounded awesome and we definitely want to go back to try more of them.  After much discussion, we settled on the chinese broccoli and house cured pork belly and the pad ke mao with a starter of duck and sweet potato curry puffs.  everything was fantastic.  The curry puffs are fried and we were served 4 pieces with a generous cucumber salad that complemented the puff very well.  They came out about 5 minutes after we ordered which we appreciated as we were starving.  The flavor of the pork belly dish was great and reminded me of my mom's home cooking.  The pork belly itself was crispy and delicious with good meat to fat ration (more meat than fat...for those who like it that way.) and the chinese broccoli was slender and TENDER...(yay rhyming!) unlike many of the kai lan dishes served at dim sum which are often fat and doused with oyster sayce and hard to manage with chopsticks.

a warning for those who fear the heat, both our main dishes were served medium spicy as the menu says.  while we enjoy the spicy very much, i could imagine others would be a little taken aback by their BOLDness.  The Pad Ke Mao was what we expected with generous beef slices and a more spicy than sweet flavor...

anyway, trying to keep my reviews short so wrapping up - the place is purdy: an aesthetically pleasing bar and nice rattan seats - very comfy - you can sink into them.  the recessed lighting gives it a romantic feel for an inexpensive restaurant.  I'd say this is a nice date restaurant... not as flashy /clubby as 2nd St Osha but the food is similarly exciting.  I'd like to go back for cocktails and more wok dishes. yum!
author: Mel L.

description: I used to  love this place; the food is amazing and the decor is industrial chic.  Lately, more and more, this is becoming a party place, and the owners don't seem interested in putting a cap on the noise level.  There are high ceilings, brick and wood, and at the best of times, it's noisy.  Now my husband and I won't come back until they tackle the screaming, shouting, noise level.  Too much!  Please give us back our restaurant.
author: NC B.

description: Some of my best meals were in Thailand a few years ago so I'm always looking for authentic Thai food here.  Basil is our go-to Thai place in SOMA. It's much more authentic than Osha and the ambiance is more laid-back. Anyone else hate the metal chairs and couch-seats at Osha?  Anywho, the service at Basil is great and the roti, tamarind prawns, and gai prik khing are especially fantatsic.
author: Aimee G.

description: Actually the food was pretty tasty.....however it was hard to enjoy as we had the RUDEST waitress I have ever had. She demanded to know if we were ready to order every minute and seemed very irritated when I ordered tea (lord knows why that was so irritating). By the end of the meal I considered asking her what we had done to deserve being treated so poorly. We left her a very very small tip.
author: Abigail D.

description: I had lunch with an old co-worker and let me tell you, I have found my perfect yellow curry!  Yellow curries are just my favorite Thai dish to eat.  I've eaten at a handful of Thai restaurants in the Bay Area and the curry is either too watery, there's no taste, or there's a bunch of oil floating on the service -Yuck!  We ordered the Gai Satay - chicken skewers.  The chicken was very tender and the peanut sauce was very creamy.  The Kang Kari Gai - yellow curry with chicken thigh and potatoes with cucumber salad was delicious.  The chicken was absolutely tender, moist, and juicy.  The curry was creamy, mild but with a lot of taste packed in.  I finished the entire plate which I don't usually do unless I really, absolutely, and truly love the dish!  Prices are affordable and the decor is clean and inviting.  Service was really attentive.  I minused one star just because I need to return and sample their drinks!
author: Jen S.

description: I've driven or walked by many times in the past but have never gotten around to eating at Basil Thai. Thanks to Amy C. and other friends who gave this place a thumbs up, I had a pre-show dinner here with T.W. and friend a couple of weeks ago. Really enjoyed the Fire Calimari and Pak Rad Kang (eggplant, zuchini, mushrooms, tomatoes and bell pepper in green curry ). We also ordered a wok tossed duck and snow pea dish that was good as well, although a little on the salty side. The service was attentive and efficient.  We were in and out in no time, without feeling rushed and made it right on time for our show which was within walking distance.
author: Trinh T.

description: This is one of my favorite Thai restaurants. Delicious food and regardless of what hour I've come - there's always been a table available - but not in a creepy way where the restaurant is always completely empty. Nice atmosphere - casual, but upscale enough for a date. Get the Kang Kari Gai - amazing yellow curry chicken. Yum!
author: Esther A.

description: Great fresh food selections, service, unique drinks and very clean yet comfortably warm atmosphere.  I'll revisit soon!
author: P H I L H.

description: Good food, great price. Will be eating here again when in San Francisco. Very happy customer
author: Jay L.

description: This place has served me the best Thai food I have ever had.  Service and food are top notch.  Prices are moderate, but this is a great place to go nuts and order extra.
author: Christian M.

description:
#2 of 9-17-07...

Can't beat my Osha's... but still, I was very pleased. The overall place reminded me of Pasadena's Saladang... Anyways, I have to say, WOW to service. They were sooo attentive and came at THEE most appropriate times, like do they have a video cam at every table or something? I prolly had 3 more sips of my h20, and bam, the waiter comes and pours you agua... We're almost finished with our meals, they come asking if we were finished, no, they weren't rushing us, it's because my friend, J and I were just chatting. 

Service: 5 stars.

Food: 3 stars. 

Bathroom: 4 stars.

Anyways, onto what we ordered...

-Tamarind prawns $11 (light battered prawns wok tossed in spicy tamarind with crisp shallots and garlic)... to the Koreans or any Korean food lovers out there, it kinda had a dukpoki kick to it... I give this 3 stars. The prawns come out all crispy with 4 huge cucumber slices and it was aight...

-Panang short ribs $14 (short ribs pretty much simmered with panang sauce w/veggies). Basically, tasted like satay beef without the long sticks, overflowed with peanut sauce but it was good, meat was cooked well. 3 stars.

A side of jasmine rice $1.50. 

And MAN, their dessert for $6... fried banana and ice cream, WOW, I usually don't LOVE this, but can tolerate it, but this place got me good, it was soooo good... 

Great thai joint~~* thanks J!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Came here for a friend's bachlorette party and dinner before watching Wicked. Like the food. Ordered a duck dish and it was yummy. Too bad there wasn't enough pieces of duck to share with friends.
author: Helen L.

description: Good Thai Fusion place if you happen to be in SOMA for some reason.  Nice atmosphere, but not too stuffy either.  I usually don't like Mojitos as my drink of choice, but if you were to ever order one at a restaurant in San Francisco...this is the place to do it.  Good, attentive service.
author: Christian H.

description: Pretty great thai food with a diverse menu and reasonable prices (ESPECIALLY for the quality).  Good service, efficient take-out, etc.  All around an enjoyable restaurant.
author: Max A.

description: Thai Basil is consistently good and the owner and staff are very friendly. We go there for lunch, so I can't speak for some of the bad reviews regarding dinner menu and service. The portion sizes relative to pricing are better than average. Brown rice, fresh foods, alterations with no problem.
author: Janet H.

description: The pad-thai was very mediocre. There are way better Thai places in the city ... like Koh Samui and the Monkey.
author: Antara B.

description: I don't know what it is really, perhaps I've had too much Thai food lately, who knows.  I just know that for some reason i want to be really "wowed" by thai food and I'm not.  The place is nice, it's clean.  The waiters were very attentive.  The food was good but didn't really stand out in any way.  And there's the reason for three stars instead of four or five.  It was okay.  It was good but not great.  I think I've been spoiled by my favorite Thai restaurant in Brooklyn, of all places.  It's called "Bangkok Thai" and once you've had authentic thai food I'm tellin' ya the Americanized version is just not enough.
author: Magdalena ..

description: This is the second time we went to this restaurant with my co-workers.  I forgot what I had the last time but we shared a lot of different appetizers and they all tasted yummy.  Last time we went there, we had two different appetizers and lunch made of Asian eggplant, tofu, mushroom with rice plate.  It was very good.  They also have draft singha beer.
author: Sunil P.

description: I came here for my friends wedding reception yesterday. What a class act. Delicious drinks,awesome wait staff, and the food...i must admit...was awesome. I say must admit because I am not a fan or enthusiast at all of thai food, and i was grubbing down .The duck is off the charts,OFF THE CHARTS
author: Lauren V.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant in the city. It's got a sassy atmosphere and incredible food
author: Nisha M.

description:
Best Thai food in the city....and I say that with one hundred and ten percent certainty. How, Jonny, can you be so sure? Have you eaten at every Thai joint in SF? Of course not.  I am, however, the self appointed authoritative voice on Thai cuisine, and love to make superlative statements backed by the only evidence that i need....my precious, precious pallet. 
     Basil is just great Thai food. Service is so fast, no frills, good value, delicious.  The decor is simple yet elegant. The menu is extensive and you can modify anything or combined two flavors and the chef will accomodate. May I reccomend the Nu'ur Krapow? (not on the menu, but wow). Pad Thai or Spicy Noodles are exactly how they are supposed to be.  Throw the Calamari, or a tiger prawn appetizer, a cucumber salad and Tsing Tsao or maybe some Saki and call that a done deal. Be sure to have your passport folks, because you will be crossing into Flavor Country. You want to talk spice, this place will Tony Jaa, Ong Bak Thai Warrior your lil' taste buds to submission, let them go and then do it again. 
     And as a non restaurant bonus, you can park in this part of SOMA all the time. It makes this place such an easy choice. Easy to get to from everywhere, (including out of town) bc it is right next to the highways.
    Thai is my favorite ethnicity of food. And Basil is my favorite place to manga in la Ciudad. Trust me, young padawans, this is top shelf.
author: Jonny C.

description: Celebrated my birthday here. They were extremely flexible and patient as I changed the reservation from 14 to 16 to 13 seats. Most importantly, everyone in our group loved the food. I highly recommend this place.
author: Shane E.

description: Best little thai place in SOMA and very strong drinks. Supa rich, great curry, YUM!
author: kristin l.

description: I love this place - the food is great, it's pretty and hip with friendly staff and good service.
author: Joe P.

description: I had the best pad Thai I've ever eaten. Pleasently suprised by the atmospher . Music was great. I even caught the basketball game in HD. Dudes take your girl here!
author: Bryon M.

description: Yummmmmm...... This restaurant has the best Thai food I have ever had! Everything on the menu has been prepared with TLC. The ambiance is romantic and could be a great place for a group! It is very worth your while to try this restaurant... I have been here to eat several times and I always leave happy and full, but not too full :)
author: Aimee M.

description: Went here with a guy on a date. The date sucked but the food was decent. Had these spicy corn fritters for appetizers. They were awesome! I ordered a pumpkin curry. The sauce was incredibly delicious, but it took some searching to actually find some pumpkin. I was kind of bummed.
author: Polina S.

description: went here with some girlfriends for  ladies night. and all i remember was everything freaking delicious and good size portions of meals. i recommend it everyone when they come to SF and all friends have loved it!
author: Mimi L.

description: Excellent Thai Food and Service! This place is small, yet cozy. Don't let the size of the place fool you. I had the green curry that I requested to have made non-spicy and it was the best! The service makes this place 5 stars. Ek, our server, originally from Thailand, was so nice. He was prompt and very helpful when ordering dishes. The bartender, Domingo, was also cool, not just because he was from San Jose as well, but he will make your drinks as strong as you would like, just let both of them know you read this review hehe. Enjoy!
author: Alina S.

description: I got the thai barbecued chicken it was pretty good. My sister got the pad see-ew but it was only okay; a little too much garlic. It was a little pricey but still good.
author: Natalie G.

description: We went here before a show in the city.  The place wasn't that big, but there were seats available.  The service was great.  We started with some drinks.  I'm not adventurous, so I had a mojito, but my mom had the Tuk Tuk, and they were both great.  The food was delicious, and decently priced.  Nothing crazy happened, and everyone was polite.  I can't say anything bad about the place.
author: Erica R.

description:
tons of thai shops in the city, but which one too eat?

starting to think all thai restaurants are the same, seriously.  or maybe my tastebuds are asleep from the dim, elegant decor.  so... based on price only...

basil thai is 4 stars.  its so comparably inexpensive compared to the other thai restaurants in the soma region.  and in this economy, that's a bonus.  8)
author: Ethan L.

description: Basil is a wonderful Thai restaurant with great food and aesthetic. (I'm biased because of the people, but hey, basil has the goods.) The restaurant is nicely decorated, yet simple and clean...very important. The food is what you should expect from a Thai restaurant, a little (or a lot) spicy and tasty. The food is cooked well, not just fast and the portions aren't crazy enormous. They have a decent bar and wine list, and they are very accommodating for groups.
author: Maureen B.

description: This place is good for bachelor parties! Yes, I'm serious. As Best Man for my friend back in 2002, I was charged with among other things picking a place to eat dinner so that we'd have enough energy for the rest of the night. The only other bachelor party dinner I'd ever attended previously was at Buca di Beppo. Gross. Anyways, for the same money you'd spend at Buca, the food here is so much better! There were 5 of us, and we were able to try a lot of their menu. The stylish and contemporary interior of midnight blue walls, bright yellow columns, chrome wall sconces and enormous flower arrangements combined with floor-to-ceiling glass bricks attract a yuppie Asian crowd. Starters are very sharable. I had my usual tom yum gai of course (no tom ka for me, I don't like coconut milk in my soups, I'm Viet that way!). It was a perfect meal for our bachelor party.
author: Hao L.

description:
Since I apparently haven't re-reviewed them since the move, yet have been there twice now, I'm fixing that little oversight.

Their new location is much swanker inside - a long, narrow space that feels like a trendy, nice restaurant, not a typical cheap Thai-spot.  They've also got a full bar.

Damn, this place is tasty.  Very comparable, food-wise, to the Valencia St Osha location - higher end Thai food, with comparably (but appropriate) higher prices.  Yes, a curry here is $11-13, but it's shockingly delicious.  The veggie green curry is fantastic - great selection of fresh grilled veggies of all sorts (multiple kinds of mushrooms, eggplant, peppers, etc) in a thick, rich, intensely flavorful curry sauce with the perfect amount of heat.  Curry puff appetizers are fantastic - curried duck (that has just the right amount of curry to enhance the duck, not overpower it) & (a bit of) sweet potato in a fried pocket.  Yum!  Would be flawless if they were just a bit less greasy, but that's a nitpick.
Thai iced tea (a personal favorite) is not the over-sugared beast you often run into; here it actually tastes like it's mostly tea, but with the expected added Thai spices.  And it's huge.

There are a ton of dishes you'll think sound amazing and want to try (many of which I still haven't gotten to), so do yourself a favor and go with a group so you can get them all.  It's worth returning to.
author: Don H.

description:
UDDATE: 6/10/07:
I'd mentioned to my friends N and J when we walked past this place once the last experience and they said NO! i know these people theyre always nice and its one of my favorites! So, yesterday, when my friend J and i were hungry, we went here. So i could see. Everyone was very nice and courteous. lots of water refills and plate changes. It was a saturday evening, we got seated right away.  We had some pretty good thai iced tea, and the calamari for starters. such a good calamari dipping sauce. mmm. j and i have similar tastes and always end up ordering the same thing half the time. ug. but yes we did this time too and got the stuffed eggplant. it was stuffed with ground chicken and had zucchini. i dont know what they put in that because it was SO FILLING. both of us are healthy eaters and we could barely finish. We didnt even finish the rice. it was GOOD though!  We also brought home a to go of duck for N, because he was sick. I didnt try it (germs) but it looked good. And very cheap too, with nice interior and clean bathroom.  i would come again. i dont know what was up with the girls and their bad service event.  i have a feeling one person in particular who can be difficult pissed them off. 

ORIGINAL: 2/2/1/07:i met some friends here saturday night before we went out to the cat club across the street.  they had made a reservation for 9 people for 9.  days earlier. i got there late, as i said i would, so i didnt see the drama, but apparently they wouldnt even seat them till after 930 and were extremely unhelpful. afterward, a said hey someone should write something about this somewhere online, so people know how unhelpful these people are. and i said hey i write yelp reviews, i'll do it. so there you go. reservations are not honored, and you have to get in a fight to get a seat.  besides that, the food was good. i didnt eat it, i had a yummy thai iced tea. they liked theirs esp the tofu/eggplant basil dish r had mmm i would have gotten that.  so i'll update my review if i do actually eat...
author: Merredith L.

description:
i must have been feeling really good that day i went into basil cuz i left feeling great and satisfied.  

even though their decor threw me a little off guard. there was a wierd balance of minimalism and clutter.  don't ask how that works but that's the best way to describe.

stick to the curries and noodles. none of the steamed fish and broccoli bs.
author: curi k.

description:
My wife and I went on our first date here, and it was a good experience.  The food is a bit on the rich side for Thai food, having a fair bit of fried foods, spicy dishes, etc.  In fact, I wouldn't be surprised if it is considered more asian fusion than authentic Thai, but I'm not a Thai food expert.  All I know is that the food is good, and given the upscale atmosphere and service, fairly priced.

We've been back a couple times since, most recently last week.  Each time we've gone, we've always gone away wondering why we don't come back more often.

They also have a full bar upfront, something of a rarity among Thai restaurants.  It was nice to wash the big meal down with a Fernet shot.

Good food, fairly priced (especially for SF), nice ambiance, and always a nice experience.  No wonder they've been around for years.  They also recently opened another location down the street.
author: Dave N.

description: Best and most consistent Thai food in the city... Their service and smiles are always a warm welcome to a weekly customer.
author: Paige W.

description: I think I've tried almost every Thai restaurant in the city and this place is definately my favorite. The menu options are different from most Thai restaurants and everything we tried was amazing. The atmosphere was great, not noisy at all, great lighting and very clean. The waitress was very good, super friendly and helpful.
author: Sarah K.

description: Just ate there for the first time on Friday night.  It was super packed but we were able to squeeze in at the bar and had drinks, appetizers and dinner.  The bar staff is nice and the vegetarian fried spring rolls were ok but the dipping sauce made them better.  The basil lamb dish was super and brown rice was nice and fluffy but the vegetable green curry was missing that extra something that makes you crave green curry.  The ambiance was great and created an enjoyable Friday night expereince for us. They take amex too!
author: K W.

description: Delicious dressed up Thai food at a less than outrageous price makes Basil Thai a great place to dine out in the city before you hit the clubs and bars nearby. Recently I came here with a pretty large party before going to bootiesf, and the food was great and service was prompt. My end of the table shared family style and we ended up getting more food than we could finish. We started off with tom yum soup, which was not too sour but enough so to give the soup a nice tang. The chicken was tender and the veggies mixed in were delicious. For the main courses we ordered panang curry pad see ew, moo yang (grilled pork filet with roasted pineapple in a sweet sauce), and basil's eggplant. My favorite was the eggplant; I absolutely loved the basil-chili sauce and the shitake mushrooms with the eggplant. The roasted pork cutlet was so tender and flavorful and the panang curry tasted like a pretty standard good panang curry (how can you go wrong with panang curry?). The only dish that disappointed me was the pad see ew (minus one star). The noodles tasted a bit overcooked and was something I would have paid much less for at a Cantonese restaurant on Castro St. in Mountain View. The rest of the dishes were great though. My drink was fantastic, although I don't quite remember the name. I think I got a Mango Cosmo - not very strong but very fruity. I wish I could have had a few more of them throughout the meal. Overall, had a great time here and I am drooling just thinking about the eggplant.
author: Joyce H.

description: They do a good job. Don't go here expecting to have the most "authentic" (whatever that means to you) Thai food in the world. It's good. The service is quick and attentive. The place is nice, and the food is tasty.
author: Reese W.

description: Went here for lunch one day.  Great ambiance, fast service, great food.  Relatively high priced for Thai food and the portions could be larger though.  I would have no problem recommending this to friends and family.  I would definitely consider going back.
author: Michael C.

description:
Not a 4-star restaurant for their dress attire or anything but this place deserves it for their overall value, service and food.

One negative recently is the overly emphatic and spirited bartender that seems to be trying to hard but he's really nice.

Can't beat the food though.
Shhh, don't tell Osha.
author: Faisal M.

description: My boyfriend and I had a perfect night at Basil last Sunday.  The waiter seated us at a table along a back wall that allowed for a little privacy amid the sea of other patrons.  The crunchy calamari tasted fiendishly good when dunked in the spicy sauce.  Then the entrees (I loved my ginger chicken!) came in just the right portions so that we were able to comfortably split a fried banana and coconut ice cream dessert.  This fried banana and ice cream dessert packed just the right combination of soft and crunchy, perfectly ripe and sweet, and warm and cold goodness that we still can't stop talking about it.  My boyfriend is only here in SF for a week, and he's dying to go back to Basil before he leaves.
author: Melanie T.

description: I've eaten here a few times, and everytime the food is amazing, I always try new things and I've never been diapointed. The servers are very friendly and knowledgable, they have a pretty good wine selection and the atmospere is quite friendly, I think this makes a great date place.
author: JIll H.

description: Been here twice already.  The lamb skewers were really tasty as well as the chicken skewers.  The roasted duck curry was amazing.  I like the ambiance too.  The lit orbs were cool.  I think I might get one for my home.  Everything was great but the staff was busy.  It took us 2 tries to order and two tries to get the check.  But overall it was a great experience.  My out of town guests really liked the ambiance.
author: LittleBird 8.

description: I came here for a lunch meeting.  It was pleasantly surprise.  The food was good, I enjoyed my Thai BBQ chicken and the other dishes that were served are all fair.  I would go back if I am in the area.  I also think the décor was very pleasant, definitely enhanced my lunch.
author: Walter C.

description: Decor was great - very trendy, albeit the small space made it a bit noisy at times. Food wasn't bad - the fire calamari is pretty spicy, make no mistake about that, and was fairly savory although the flavor could have stuck to the actual calamari pieces a bit more (I found myself splashing it in the sauce to get anything more than spice into my mouth). The roti in green curry is also pretty good, as was the house tea that I asked for.  Not bad on the list of Asian fusion, but there are probably other fusion places you could scope out in SF for a bit less cost.
author: Justin L.

description: All the dishes I ordered were at least above average. Panstickers, curry puffs, pumpkin curry, all delicious. A great place to go before a night out in the area (Slim's, Cat Club, etc.) or tasty enough to warrant a visit to the area on its own.
author: Elsa M.

description: Solid Thai restaurant, nice interior and very decent food.  The servers were attentive and pleasant.  If I need a Thai fix and am in the area, I will be back.
author: John K.

description: Came here with a big group of people, and with no reservations, they accommodated us very well. The thai iced tea was great, and my tamarind prawns were wonderful. Everyone enjoyed their meal. I do deduct a bit for a) messy water refills that resulted in water poured on my food, and b) asking for a knife but never receiving one.
author: Kellie P.

description: Oh yeah.  My favorite Thai food in San Francisco in walking distance from my apartment.  Great drinks, and even better food.  The green seafood curry, and the pad see ew are the best!   The atmosphere of the restaurant is simple, modern and comfortable.  I would go there even if it was across town.
author: Melissa G.

description:
What a wonderful oasis in what can be a bustling part of SOMA. The staff here were so nice, the food delicious and the service super efficient.  It's easy to park in this neighborhood and there is enough happening on the street with bars and cafes and such that you feel totally comfortable walking around.

Two enthusiastic thumbs up!
author: Tim G.

description: I know this place as a solid "nice" lunch option in the neighborhood. Group lunch? They've been able to handle 10-20+ of us many times quite smoothly and on short notice. It's pretty and the food is nothing exceptional but far from disappointing. I like the pak rad kang.
author: Tom L.

description: I must say that I've only been here for lunch, but I've tried a lot of different things on the menu and it all has been delicious!  It's a little pricier than your typical thai place, but the quality is better too.  I think my favorites are the panstickers, lamb satays, and the yellow curry chicken, but everything has been great.  They have live jazz on Thursdays that I've been meaning to check out, but haven't made it yet.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Going to Basil for me looks like it is going to deliver a stellar meal.  SF has so many Thai restaurants and I think there are only a few good ones.  Basil is not bad but I wasn't wowed.  My expectations were raised by the cover of this book but the pages didn't read to me as I had expected.  The fare is okay and the wine.... well I can't think of a single Thai restaurant with a decent  wine line.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: I've been here for lunch a few times:  Yelp's consensus is pretty fair: Great food, great atmosphere, a little pricey for the area, but overall very worth while.  My reason for giving the big thumbs up is that the chefs clearly understand the important but understated function that herbs and spices play in Tai cuisine.  No one else in the area comes as close to Basil Thai in properly melding the basic ingredients of the cuisine (chicken, fish, tofu etc) with the delicate flavors (basil, cardamon, etc)  that bring the food to life.  Very well done.
author: Mark V.

description: Though not very authentic, I like coming here.  The food is tasty and consistent.  highly reccomended!
author: Demanding T.

description: Nice atmosphere and the food is usually quite tasty, with good quality ingredients, although on my last visit the BBQ chicken was rather dry--maybe because it was the end of the day. Prices are also on the high side for some items ($14 for the chicken and no rice included!) and service was rather poor. They didn't even give us napkins until we were able to wave a server down ten minutes into eating our soup. And one of the waiters was texting on his iPhone as he came over to the table. Would be four stars if the service were more professional.
author: Geoffrey U.

description: Yummy thai food.. not the normal thai restaurant, Basil is a hip SOMA space. Their food is so flavourful...I'm in love with their beef short ribs, curried eggplant, and fried rice.. yes, it is a tad bit pricier but the quality is also much higher.
author: Nenette Y.

description: Some of the lightest, most creative Thai in San Francisco, a city flush to the gills with Thai. Recommend: beans+roots, fire calamari, any noodle dish, panang short ribs.
author: David Y.

description: Very friendly staff and delicious food.  I was pleasantly surprised at how cheap the meal was.  Overall a great experience and I recommend it.  I will definitely be coming back.
author: Ankur P.

description: this place has really good food! the pad thai had the most amazing flavor with a little bit of a spicy kick. the panstickers and the chicken satay with peanut sauce were great and I would buy the peanut sauce in a jar if they sold it!. my friend thought that the panstickers were the best she'd ever had. we had more than one Tuk Tuk, and i don't even like brandy! this place had a good vibe and decor was nice. a good way to start off a sat night!
author: Kara M.

description: Their vegetarian dishes are absolutely wonderful; incredibly flavorful, and filling. Fancy decor, with affordable prices. Drinks and desserts are fabulous, too.
author: Jade P.

description: Why Basil? The ambiance is very low key and I prefer to sit in the back of the restaurant. Start with the grilled calamari and you can't go wrong. I think the wait staff needs a little bit of work, but the food makes up for the service. I had the green curry with grilled eggplant stuff with chicken. Whatever is in that green sauce is delicious!!! As all the others have mentioned, just plain good!
author: Palak P.

description: Nice place to eat, decent food but not great.  Still very decent, satisfying in that tasty yet shallow sort of way, but well, decent, again.  The service and style is so pleasant, it's relaxing and i like it anyways.
author: Today Y.

description: Decent thai food and good ambiance. I love how much light comes into the place. It's good for lunch- a bit too much food (what a complaint) and I highly recommend the pad se ew.
author: B S.

description: This place consistantly ROCKS! The short ribs and the skirt steak with peanut sauce is the best. Service is always good---never too much but always there when you need them. And the price isn't too high for the atmosphere. What are you waiting for? GO!
author: Jeremy C.

description: So this review is two sided. The drinks get a 5 and the food gets a 2 1/2. We sat at the bar b/c the wait was 45 minutes for a table for two on a Sat nite at around 7:30.
